author: Rin
review: This game isn't for me. I can appreciate the time and effort that went into it, all the polish from the setting to the voice acting to the story writing, but for me, the game is just too damn sluggish.I spent about 8 hours playing, and I've heard from multiple people how this game can last you hundreds, but my question to them, is how many of that is mashing X on a horse, or idling in cinematic view while Arthur rides for you? Everything seems so incredibly tedious to do. I've tried a few Rockstar games in the past, and they've never latched on either though, so.Final Verdict: It doesn't have enough of today's Quality of Life mechanics to keep me interested. Any game that makes you walk away while the character rides A to B, is bad design imo.

author: Twist
review: I waited quite a while to make my thoughts on this game known, mostly because I was so busy playing it, that I forgot the real world existed.For those who haven't tried Red Dead Redemption 2 yet, you really should. Missing out on this game for all of the other games on Steam is like visiting the Louvre, but not seeing the Mona Lisa. It's like going to Rome and never setting eyes on the Colosseum. Don't do that to yourself. Don't miss out on this absolute masterpiece of a game. Even if you didn't play the original Red Dead Redemption (or Red Dead Revolver), this game is worth your time and money. Since it's a prequel, there are no obvious spoilers for the earlier games, as everything that occurs in this installment sets up the original Red Dead's storyline. And if you *have* played the original Red Dead but not this installment, you really should! The best aspect of Red Dead Redemption 2, aside from the *phenomenal* storytelling, is the pace of gameplay. As the player, you can choose to speed through each story mission and still get a satisfactory ending. Or, you can spend hundreds of hours in the earliest chapters, hunting and fishing your way around the Old West frontier, growing a Grizzly Adams beard and collecting cigarette cards with pretty pictures on them. Want to drop a few hundred dollars in blackjack or poker, then get up and shoot your opponents in the head if you lose? This is the game for you.Red Dead Online has its fun moments as well, though if I'm being 100 percent honest, after a few hundred hours it can get a little repetitive and Rockstar hasn't added much to the online portion of the game in quite some time. However, the story mode alone is worth far more than the box price, so if you're looking for a great game, get this one.

author: Feuersturm
review: Steam wants to know if I would recommend this game to other players. Yes or no. I'll tell you what. I would recommend this interactive movie to others.RDR2 is on the surface so triple A, it's practically quadruple A. The first clue of this is when you look at the keyboard control layout and go "AAAA!". There's literally 50 binds you are supposed to assign, that will serve absolutely no purpose at any point. The game will keep you pressing different keys to do the same actions from start to finish, seemingly for no reason. In the very beginning you pick up items with one key, but pick up a hat with another. There is no rhyme or reason to it. Sometimes to simply perform an action you're supposed to press Enter, when a moment before it was another key or a mouse button. Is this a cunning plot to nudge players into using a gamepad instead, I don't know, but I wanted to use the trusty mouse+keyboard combo even if it meant having to deal with a convoluted to hell control scheme. Of course no one will ever need all the assigned keys and just having those fundamental things at hand works fine, and the mouse can be used to bypass things like having separate keys for turning pages left and right when browsing some weapon catalog... sheesh.But I have to admit - RDR2 is the most beautiful open world I've seen on the PC, possibly in any game for that matter. Even totally vanilla with no mods, the scenery is sometimes so gorgeous you will just have to admire the impeccable eye Rockstar has for crafting visuals. Once you reach Saint Denis for instance, the attention to detail, be it how every passerby is an individual or how the lighting and shadows are so true to reality, really captures your attention over and over again. The snowy visages are the best looking renditions of wintry landscapes I've ever seen as well and the way the snow glistens or how a lantern's glow bleeds over it is a sight to behold. Reminded me of Finland's winter nights for certain.Having this living, breathing wilderness around you is a thing of beauty, but Rockstar has chosen a very narrow path with their mission design. It works not unlike an interactive movie, where you play the action scenes. This was probably the biggest fault of the game. As soon as that marker is reached, the massive open world narrows to a footpath and the player is lead through the quest in a tight leash. The developers want you to experience the story the way they intended and the missions will allow practically no innovation or personal freedoms. Attempt to flank the enemy from the right? Mission failed, you abandoned the gang. Shoot a bad guy in the leg to stop him? Mission failed, target was killed. Grab a horse other than your own? Mission failed, you became wanted. Odd, considering you're a wanted man anyway. The scripted chase sequences have not changed. Often times Rockstar will even limit movement by disabling running and climbing during certain parts. Weapons will be disabled as well so that you don't dare do something stupid. It's an epic western on the outside, but you will find yourself reduced to a passive bystander all the time, holding down one key or tapping another to make the interactive cutscene keep playing forward. AAA title mission design, everybody. Most things that would work better under player control have been turned into essentially quicktime events, meaning you will play their fiddle and watch the events unfold. Having the option to switch weapons during firefights is the most of your own material you get to write in the story. Stray 50 feet from the designated path and Rockstar says no, screw you, you didn't play by our rules, back to previous checkpoint. Difficulty is no issue because the actual parts you need to play are beginner level shooting ranges and knowing how to move from point A to point B. Do I further need to explain why this game feels like a movie? I quit playing for 2-3 months because I didn't feel like it was worth watching, but came back with lesser expectations, knowing it was going to be a linear run with heavy emphasis on telling a story. And you know, as such, it works better.I think Rockstar has sacrificed a lot on the gameplay side to favor the hottest trend - a "cinematic experience". Some of the mechanics have suffered in the process. For example, why not allow the player to climb freely? Because it might look inappropriate? Why can't you run in the camp? That's not justified hero behavior? Why is the melee system an insensible few animation minigame when it could have been a fun way to showcase the abilities of the physics engine? Remember fights in GTA IV? That stuff was fun. In RDR2 you don't really want to beat anyone up because you end up watching the same motion captured stuntwork and then a falling ragdoll in the end. Why can't I lasso the bad guy during a chase when I'm right behind him? Why do bullets leave trails of smoke??It took some introspection but the game won me over ultimately. I think what matters most here is the visual presentation and insane amount of production value. The rest, well, maybe it's just meant to be experienced.

author: θανεσεστερεοφων
review: Like any good prequel, there's an incredible amount of tension in knowing what happens without knowing exactly how. If you played Red Dead Redemption, you know who survives and as a result who probably won't make it to the end of the game. Even during the slower parts, you're waiting for betrayals and injuries and other events you've only vaguely heard mention of before. You're waiting for characters to reveal their true selves, and watching as everything unravels is riveting and heartbreaking if you know what's to come.You can still enjoy the story in its own right without that background knowledge, though. Some of Red Dead Redemption 2's best moments have almost no relation to its predecessor. One mission takes you to a women's suffrage rally, and a painful side mission has you facing a woman whose husband you killed and life you ruined. The new characters are among the best, too; Sadie Adler is a personal favorite for reasons I won't spoil.Generally, Red Dead 2 tackles pertinent issues of the era with care. Rather than defining any of its characters by the bigotry they may experience, it allows them the room to be well-rounded individuals while still not ignoring that things like racism and sexism exist. One arc focuses squarely on a very serious issue, and here, the lack of real choice in the story's direction--and your resulting involvement in what transpires--will likely make you uncomfortable in a powerful way.While Red Dead Redemption was mostly focused on John Marston's story, Red Dead 2 is about the entire Van der Linde gang--as a community, as an idea, and as the death rattle of the Wild West. It is about Arthur, too, but as the lens through which you view the gang, his very personal, very messy story supports a larger tale. Some frustrating systems and a predictable mission structure end up serving that story well, though it does take patience to get through them and understand why. Red Dead Redemption 2 is an excellent prequel, but it's also an emotional, thought-provoking story in its own right, AND IT'S A WORLD THATIS HARD TO LEAVE WHEN IT'S DONE.

author: stinkypincky
review: If you plan on playing Multiplayer/RDO then DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. Buy it for console if you are playing RDO. If you are only going to play single player and never touch Multiplayer then it's a fantastic game. The graphics are amazing and the game runs great and Ididn't run into any problems as far as glitches or bugs in Singleplayer and I had some of the most fun playing a game I've had in a long time while following the story of Arthur Morgan and the gang. Multiplayer on the other hand is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ show and a complete waste of money, time and hardrive space, not because Multiplayer has bad content or nothing to do but because you will not even be able to play the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. Apparently modders and script kiddies have free reign over the RDO servers and will continually grief you until you either uninstall the game or throw your monitor out the window. In my first hour of RDO alone I ran into at least 1-3 modders per session that I joined, in the midst of the constant dynamite arrows randomly spawning on you from across the map and continually murdering me I was also teleported across the map to some location in the middle of the snow over and over again with one of these teleports occurring in the middle of a timed starter mission, well I failed the mission and it seemed to break the game because my camp was no longer anywhere to be found and unable to be moved. Once i finally loaded into a session where i could get to my camp I was greeted by another modder who proceeded to somehow lower the safety flag of my camp allowing him to keep griefing me in my own camp. In roughly the hour all of this happened I realized that somehow all of my $1000 in-game starter cash had randomly disappeared and i was left with nothing. Tried playing multiplayer for days after but continually ran into modders in every session with no end. With more research i found out that these "hackers" are breaching your game files through RDO to access private & personal info on your PC as well as modders and script kiddies easily deleting any cash you've earned in a game session. Your p2w gold will be safe but cash is free game.  Oh and Steam wont refund you for "Multiplayer not working" or any other reason if you have over two hours in the STORY mode regardless of all these known issues making the game completely unplayable as far as online at most times and basically taking half of the game away because its such a mess of problem trying to get anything done in RDO when you're being griefed and harrassed literally every 1-2 minutes.If you want to play multiplayer do yourself a favor and save money and time and just buy it for xbox or playstation because at least Rockstar somewhat gives a ♥♥♥♥ about their servers for those platforms, been playing on XBL and haven't ran into a single previously noted issue in any of my game sessions.

author: Engellus
review: 14 Dec 19 (Will update as time goes on)Radeon R9 270x runs this game, BARELY.Red Dead Online:Never call your horse when you're running toward where you want to go, always turn back and THEN whistle for them. Your horse always spawns behind you and never catches up, so you'll just waste time running or waiting, unless you do the quick U-turn to call em.The roam quick missions are overrun with Chinese hackers. On the bright side, if the mission isn't about killing everyone, they won't understand what to do and you'll be able to win. If it is about killing, you're just going to waste 15 minutes getting snap-on headshotted over and over by the Chinese hackers. (Possibly Korean, i shut off public voice chat after all the Chinese ear raping that i received every time i was near them)All the real fun stuff is stuck behind a soft pay-wall. I.e. you need the premium currency "gold bars" to purchase roles for more money and missions. Most missions give somewhere between 0.08 to 0.2, and you'll need 15-25 per role unlock and etc. Or you can drop some real $ to get the gold bars, on a game that already costs 80CAD. Yeah, not happening.Levelling is silly slow, same with earning money to get anything done. Best way is the drop in missions, treasure maps, or stranger missions. Do those in-between your long excursions of searching the swamp for feathers and gator skins. Hopefully you get $50+ for one hunting run, but you'll need several to purchase guns. Ammo is dirt cheap.Lots of bugs and random crashes as well.I'll probably shelf this game in the near future and come back to it later like i did with GTA5. Once the hacker issue is resolved, the game has a lot of potential to be quite interesting. Especially if you've got friends to play with that aren't murderhobos.7 Jan 2020Asian hackers still a problem. Spawn gators, grizzlies, pumas, cougars. Can blow you up or teleport to you and shoot you. Literally only place you're safe is in an instanced game OR while talking to a shopkeeper. Spawning animals kills you even if you're in your camp with white flag raised. They are a true plague on what could be a fun game. They need to be region locked out because this is just pathetic. The exact same hacks as in GTA5 are happening here and they all use the local voice chat to spam chinese/korean (so far that's all i've heard clearly) with horribly broken english trying to troll you and provoke you.That all taken with the fact that changing sessions is buggy as hell... You're screwed. 7 Attempts to join my friend's instance recently, all failed. Game crashes maybe 1/2 the time i try to load into a new session from another. Hardware issue, maybe? My friends on better rigs report similar issues and therefore I doubt it is hardware.DO NOT BUY UNTIL HACKER ISSUE RESOLVED (was it ever resolved in GTA5, or did they just get bored?)25 May 2020I have shelfed the game. No point in doing virtually the same missions 50 times just to get up a level and do them again. I'll come back if China gets region locked or anti-cheat software that actually works gets added. I might come back if they add more content, though it's unclear because why bother if you'll just have to deal with the feeble-minded people that hack?

After which the hacker spawned a chest in front of me and pointed their gun at it over and over. author: IL PALLINO
review: 9/10: Almost everything the player expects from a AAA game made by Rockstar. It's just a shame that a few bugs, flawed honor system, flawed crime reporting, and shorter story than the first game prevent  from being perfect in spite of improvements in other areas.Does a AAA game that's a few years old really need a review? Ol' Il Pallino has his gripes and the founder of  needs more reviews, so may as well! The people who need a description of  are the same people who will never read this review. Set in 1899 (roughly twelve years before the first ) the story of the Van der Linde Gang starts with main character Arthur Morgan as the only lieutenant to Dutch Van der Linde who takes his gang through a misadventure through multiple (and mostly new) states in hopes of being able to pull off that one perfect heist so everyone in the gang can retire from their life of crime. Of course with the contents of the first , it's pretty obvious that the Van der Linde Gang never comes close to this accomplishment. About the only real unexpected surprises are the stranger missions and new features.Normally this category wouldn't apply to a AAA game, but it is unforgivable for a game with such a high budget to have floating rocks encountered (albeit infrequently) along with the occasional floating character.However,  does have a really cool graphical effect that sometimes occurs in shootouts, and usually whenever headshots are scored.The sounds, however, were faultless, and the game's soundtrack was perfect for the late 19'th. century with a score of original music. (One song was even performed by Willie Nelson.)The biggest positive to  is that the game is a dramatic improvement over the first game on account of the improvement to horses. Horses have four levels of bonding (five if level zero is included) and increases in levels unlocks horse skills and increases health (hit points) and stamina. Horses can have their looks customized, and new saddles can not only be purchased, but new saddles can also be crafted by trappers located on various parts of the map. (More on that in a minute.)  On the downside, horses can now be spooked by predators, and there's a chance that a horse (especially at a lower bonding level) will buck the player off and leave them to deal with a predator whom the player will hopefully have enough time to activate deadeye and put a bullet in it's head.Unlike the outfit ensembles in , the player has the ability to truly customize the outfits of the main character in the event they see something they'd like to mix and match with clothes that can be bought from tailors and general stores, along with clothes that can be unlocked at a trapper's shop by selling snakeskins, hides, pelts, and feathers to a trapper. The best saddles in the game can also be purchased at a trapper's shop.Deadeye has also been improved with one new level of deadeye allowing the player to shoot and remain in deadeye without painting any targets, which is particularly useful in the event the player is using a sniper rifle.The concept of animals needing to be taken down with a specific type of weapon makes hunting more interesting than the first game, and makes all the difference between good and perfect condition. (With enough overkill, an animal or snake carcass can drop from perfect to poor condition.) The game also introduces a bow and arrows, and specialty arrows can be crafted and used to kill game in one shot (if aimed perfectly) and keep it's condition perfect.Also on the issue of hunting, players do not have to skin what they killed for the most part. If the player wants to have more food (at the expense of sacrificing it's outer layer or feathers) for either themselves or their camp, an intact animal carcass can be stowed on a horse. (Animal carcasses can also be sold to butchers and trappers.) In fact, several decorations can be crafted at the camp require an entire carcass.Fishing has also been added to the game, and is a nice activity to engage in to help add variety to whenever the player doesn't wanna do story missions, go hunting, complete challenges, or whatever. Apart from being a food source, fish meat that's classified as  can be used with berries to make  that can either be used to attract perfect quality predators or sold for money. While it is advised to catch fish with the fishing rod that unlocks fairly early into the story, ol' Il Pallino caught his first fish by shooting at it. (Fish can also be "caught" by throwing dynamite into a body of water.)Weapons can now be customized in a plethora of ways. Some ways are useful in that they make weapons function better and degrade slower, but most are purely aesthetic.The biggest negative is that the honor system is flawed and does not recognize acts of self-defense. While honor can be built easily enough by greeting everyone in the game's biggest city (along with catching and returning fishes) it is annoying to have people shooting at you and lose honor because you killed them in retaliation. Plenty of members of the rival O'Driscoll Gang can be encountered in the town of Valentine, and a few times ol' Il Pallino managed to get a bounty for getting into a non-lethal fight with some of those jackwagons. Unlike other criminal organizations, people strangely care if they see the player looting an O'Driscoll and can expect a bounty just for making an encounter worth their while if said encounter is in the Valentine area.While not affecting honor directly, ol' Il Pallino saw some game to shoot at in the outskirts of Emerald Ranch, and a freakin' dog attacked him. Again, self-defense wasn't recognized when the dog instigated a kill or be killed situation.While complaining about aesthetics, it may be unfair to complain that Arthur Morgan's (plain) default hat always takes up an inventory slot on the horse, and cannot be changed. Hat accessories to Arthur's hat also count as an entirely different hat, but this is problematic since ol' Il Pallino's favorite hat is not Arthur's default hat!Rockstar Games has been making games featuring Blackjack since 2004, and *STILL* do not treat a ten to be any different from a face card in regards to hitting a blackjack. (This works out if it's the player who hit an ace and a ten, but the dealer can also get blackjack with a ten instead of a face card.)There are bugs that are game-breaking. Ol' Il Pallino has a friend who's experience was ruined by bugs, but the only game-breaking bug that was encountered personally was once getting accidentally stuck on a stagecoach and needed to quit just to get unstuck. (An inexcusable bug for so much as a tiny indie game.)Fun fact: If the player steals a wagon transporting oil, they can sell it for $50 instead of the usual $40.This review provided independently by .No compensation was provided.Email contact@dnbmedia.co for requests & promotions.

author: Umph
review: Yeah, so always on DRM, let me tell you:I am in a country that is suffering civil war, and in my free time I thought, since I lost my job, maybe it would be fun to finally play this since I have time now, and escape a bit from the massive problems in the world.Anyway Social Club let me play this and GTA5 for about 7 hours until social club starting having authentication errors that kicked/locked me out of both games.  These errors loop infinitely with longer and longer capchas each loop.  I tried VPNs, reinstalling, calling support, editing the registry, I made a post on reddit, where others from where I am came forward & said the same.  Steam would not refund the games.Now, the only way I can play this is by stealing.  Thanks for that rockstar.  So I need to download another 67 gigs to play, in a place where data is precious.  I don't want to play multiplayer by the way, I just wanted to finally enjoy these two rockstar games after all of the years of waiting while I still can.  Always on DRM only hurts your actual customers, especially those of us in disadvantaged parts of the world.  The cracked versions don't have the DRM, so why put it on the version I PAID for?  Anyway, I will never buy another rockstar game, they did nothing to help me, ditto steam.  I am an edge case, so I don't matter, and that is what always on DRM is all about, that people in bad situations don't effect sales enough to matter.  Especially if they arbitrarily flag players in a region and disable their accounts, but sell us the game anyway while not mentioning anything in the EULA.  As a bonus DLC, steam won't let me set my region to where I actually live, my requests were denied twice by a noreply@  account.  A robot I cannot reply to disagrees that I live where I live and I suppose that's reasonable.  I've been on steam since gabe was in diapers, idk what happened around here.That said, the few hours I was allowed to see was neat 2/10

author: guddentehpwner
review: A day or so ago the Rockstar Launcher updated. Game crashed on load and gave exited unexpectedly error every time. The fix for this was to sign OUT of BOTH Steam AND the Rockstar Launcher. After I signed back into both the game runs fine again. Hope this helps somebody.UPDATE - Game started crashing again. Go into graphics settings, make sure the Graphics API is set to DirectX 12. The game is having problems using the Vulkan API....After running the game in DirectX12 awhile, saving and quitting. Then restarting the game with Vulkan seems to work.

author: Gattsu
review: You're alright BOAH if you follow the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ PLAN!- A true emotional masterpiece with the greatest game protagonist ever and with the greatest voice acting ever by Roger Clark. - This is a prequel story to Red Dead Redemption, which released 10 years ago for the PS3. - Story telling and character progression is unmatched and perfectly made. - Music is epic and reminds me about Ennio Morricone's legendary music sometimes. - The open world is beautiful.- There are a lot of actually interesting side quests to do. - Makes you care a lot about the characters, also more about a horse than in any other game.- It has Photo Mode.- Lots of options to change graphics settings. For me it runs very smoothly with RTX 2060 Super and at High-Ultra settings, while some I kept at lower.I highly recommend this to anyone who wants an unforgettable gaming experience and especially to those who like western genre. I think this might be the best game I have ever played. On PS4 my first playthrough took between 80-90 hours. Now on PC finishing the story took me about 220 hours by doing a lot more stuff and I'm not even done with it all.Now be a good cowpoke and buy this game.

author: Khaine
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is a modern masterpiece that is designed to be a grand experience from start to finish. It should be taught as lesson on how an open world game should be made, from the massive natural landscape to the towns full of life and to the way the random encounters/side activities plays out, which are presented in such an organic way that it creates a strong immersive atmosphere in which you can easily lose yourself. It offers a great freedom of exploration that often makes you take a sudden turn to a distant landmark while riding to your objective, just to see the view from there, and it does not disappoint because needless to say this game is stunning to look at. As for the narrative of the game, there is really little else to say except that it's truly beautiful, exciting and heartbreaking in so many ways. Each character you meet is believable and behaves like a real person with their unique personalities, ambitions and flaws throughout the story. It is easily one of the best games of our generation.

author: .#𝚌𝚊𝚞𝚜𝚝𝚒𝚌
review: There are 6 games that always have a place in my heart. Not because they are perfect, but because each of them has something special that touched you and/or keeps you coming back. Next to Far Cry3, Ark: Survival Evolved, Dying Light, The Witcher 3 and Cyberpunk it's this game and probably even at the top.I'm built close to the water. Guilty. When I see something that touches me (positively or negatively) the floodgates open, but I've never had to cry at a game before. RRD2 has changed that. And for those who did NOT cry in this game, sorry, you are psychopaths and I want nothing to do with you.The story is so compelling. Even as a woman, I can completely identify with Arthur and the hatred for other people unites us. The world is breathtakingly beautiful and you don't even look at the fast travel points because you just want to ride.For the story alone, the game is worth every penny, but the multiplayer is also very well implemented. Unlike GTA Online, you hardly ever have griefers and modders in the lobby. In fact, people tend to help you out. The missions are varied, even if they are, of course, worn out at some point. Nevertheless, this game will never be deleted from my hard drive, and I always take a quick look to immerse myself in the world.

author: rracz

And you go back in forth in a conversation with them the more times you do it. 2) There are supposedly 1/2 million lines of dialogue and 300,000 different animations in the game3) If you hurt an NPC and see them again 2 days later, they'll be bruised or have bandages on them corresponding to HOW you hurt them4) You will be hunting some animals and you will see a cougar kill a deer or something5) The horse's sack shrinks when it's cold6) The snow looks absolutely incredibleBuy this game

author: LordGandhii
review: While all critically acclaimed games are well-regarded for a reason, I never really understood why  was praised as much as it was. To me, it looked like your run-of-the-mill open world game. Once I realized I was stuck inside, I knew that I had to finally give this a game a shot. And I'm glad I did, because I was really missing out.I don't think it's a stretch to say that  is the best looking game on the market right now. While open world games, especially ones as densely packed as this one, are prone to having messy textures, everything in this game looks insanely crisp. It's a remarkable technical achievement, and I'd say it's one of the few games over the years that has left me genuinely awestruck in how beautiful it is. On top of this, RDR2's other big visual strength lies in its presentation. The story is compelling, but there's definitely some moments where the game doesn't have much going on, and while these parts should be boring, they're saved by the presentation. You really feel like you're in a western film, and the cinematic camera helps add to this feeling. A lot of games that lean on being realistic end up sacrificing style as a result, however Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of the very rare examples of a game that still establishes its own style and identity while placing an emphasis on realism, and in that regard, makes the graphics arguably the game's biggest strength. But, thankfully, it isn't the only strength.While this game has a lot of things going for it, unfortunately what holds this game back is definitely the gameplay. The first big criticism, of course, are the controls. They're messy, confusing, and outright unresponsive at certain points. While I did somewhat adjust to the controls as I played more of the game, there were points where the controls were so unbelievably janky that killed my immersion. However, this jank doesn't really affect the gunplay, which is a good thing because there are way too many massive shootouts in this game. I found the game was at its best when you had the smaller, mundane tasks with the occasional combat segment and full-town shootouts on rare occasions. However, as the story progressed, every mission began to follow the same structure of having you mow down hordes on top of hordes of enemies. The epilogue helped dial the game back a little bit, but even then it was still prone to having these massive shootouts a tad bit too frequently for my liking. But worst of all, these issues as well as the game being open-world create the game's biggest flaw in my eyes: the massive dissonance between story and gameplay. Just from exploring the world a little bit, I had around $4000 by the time the story ended, and that was after getting all of the camp upgrades and spending tons of money on new outfits, horse items, and customizing every single one of my weapons. Therefore, the constant stream of "WE NEED MONEY" and the desperation the story tries to create gets undermined when the answer to all of the gang's problems lies in my pocket. It got annoying and eventually I lost interest in exploring the open world, which sucks because the world is full of so many cool things to see and do that I'm considering starting a second playthrough just to find more of them. But the game wants to be linear, and so the game's incredible open world and compelling story collide into each other head-on, and both get tarnished as a result. Is the gameplay outright bad? No, because it's still quite fun to play and has plenty going for it. However, it still conflicts with the rest of the game, and ultimately does a lot of harm to the overall package.But that's enough negativity. Like I've already said a few times now, the game's story is amazing. Arthur Morgan is one of gaming's best protagonists of all time, and how they handled him in this game was absolutely perfect. He has an incredible amount of depth and leaves plenty open to interpretation, and he grows right alongside the player. While John is also a great character in his own right, Arthur single-handedly bumps up the game a few notches for me. But he's not the only standout here, as characters like Dutch, Micah, and Charles all excel at their roles in the story as well. I do wish some of the characters like Javier, Mary-Beth, and Karen got more screentime, though, as they were enjoyable characters in their own right. Some people argue the main plot is too predictable, but I think the game actually used this in its favor. Especially when it came to a major reveal close to the game's end, I think the idea was to give you some extra motivation for the final mission, and fleshed out some of the characters in the process. I wasn't fond of one major segment of the game as it exemplified a lot of the game's main issues, but it ended quicker than I thought it would so it didn't bother me too much. Otherwise, it's a slow burn that hooks you more and more as it progresses, and the game's amazing presentation and world help keep you occupied during the moments that aren't as engaging. There's a lot more I could talk about here, but that's a discussion for another day. What's relevant here is that the story is amazing outside of some smaller issues, and is another high point for the game.I was surprised by how much I enjoyed the music. Outside of some of the major vocal tracks (which are excellent), I wouldn't say most of them were particularly noteworthy, but they blended in with the game's world and tone perfectly. The sound design is also excellent here, as everything sounds incredibly crisp and satisfying. However, the real star of the show here is the voice acting. Roger Clark absolutely nails Arthur, and helps provide a subtle layer to the character that couldn't be conveyed through text. Another standout is Benjamin Byron Davis as Dutch, whose charisma really helped me understand how Dutch could be as revered of a figure as he was, and he manages to keep you hooked on every word that comes out of his mouth. The voice acting is some of the best in a very long time, if ever, and really helps sell the western feel of the game. And with the music and sound design blending together perfectly, the audio continues to prove the game's remarkably high quality.Gameplay/story disconnect aside, the open world is absolutely phenomenal. There's a ton of different side activities, like fishing, hunting, and playing poker to keep things interesting in ways that aren't just shootouts. There's also lots of cool little interactions in the world, and while you don't get rewarded much in terms of loot, the experience of seeing them is worth it alone. On top of a densely-packed single-player, there's also an online mode. I have no intentions of playing it, but it's like eating a pizza with too many toppings on it. Even if you ignore eating some of the toppings, the pizza's still delicious. You'll get a ton of value just from the game's world alone, and the engaging story and additional online mode merely serve as supplements for the incredible world. To conclude,  is a remarkable achievement in almost every way. The gameplay does hold it back, but it's the only blemish on an otherwise incredible game. If you have the time and money, then I have to insist that you give it a shot. - 10/10 - 5.5/10 - 10/10 - 9.5/10 - 10/10+ Amazing protagonist+ Beautiful graphics+ Engaging story+ Strong presentation+ Outstanding voice acting+ Detailed open world- Gameplay/story dissonance- Messy controls- Repetitive missions

author: Brek
review: I wouldn't recommend this game based on it's Online content.The singleplayer campaing is as close to perfect as you could possibly wish. Breathtaking story, living open world with lots of things to explore, mysteries to unravel, activities to participate. If you're looking for an open-world shooter action with guns and cowboys, this game's singleplayer will leave you more than satisfied.The reason for my disappointment in this game is Rockstar's greedy attitude towards their online projects. I have somewhat about 500 hours in GTA V, most of wich comes from the GTA Online and after many years passed from PC release of the title, Rockstar haven't or didn't want to learn from their mistakes.Red Dead Online faces same issues as GTA Online did. Bugs and glitches aren't getting fixed, if they don't help you to get money. Rockstar selectively fixes bugs that allow for easier in-game income, while ignoring any gamebreaking glithes that may occure during the missions or open-world exploration.All they care about is making players buy in-game currency for real money. This would've been understandable if they tried to make more profit while fixing issues existing in the game, but they're not.Just wait for them to add horses with homing missiles and jet-engines up their arses. GTA Online: Wild West.edit: since they've made RDO stand-alone game, I change my review to positive. Keep in mind tho that RDR2 still contains RDO and anything said about Online in this review is what I believe to this day.

author: Kreuzer
review: When people ask what is the best game of all time, there is usually a fair number of subjective answers. However, for red dead redemption 2, I struggle to find any reason why it's NOT objectively the best single-player game of all time.Its story may not be an intricate plot but it's full of small, nuanced displays of emotions and life-like dialogue that pulls you into the world and sometimes forget that these are virtual characters. It's by far better than most Hollywood films, tv-series and dare I say should be up there with some of the great tv shows if it could be classified as one.The gameplay is equally amazing with npcs feeling life like amazing random events, amazing side quests, and a robust selection of guns, outfits, animals etc.I really struggle to find any negative to this game other than the slow start to the game. To me, it's necessary to have that slow start as good pacing but I can see how the slow start might put off people from the game entirely. Anybody that says red dead 2 is a bad game either never completed it or is just trying to be different and go against the wind.  Red dead 2 is a masterpiece. Even after 2 years since I finished it, I still remember its story vividly and without hesitation say its the best game I've played if someone asks me that question.

author: Hodd Toward
review: Single player is fine, but the multiplayer is a total ♥♥♥♥ show, you jump in thinking it's like gta and ready to do outlaw stuff like robbing trains and banks but instead you have to gather plants and sedate animals. Every role is locked behind a paywall, the only viable gold farm gets nerfed to the ground just like the $ farm got last patch, they lock gameplay advantages behind the season pass and everything is overpriced so squeeze every last bit of money from you.The players were asking for robberies for a long rime but rockstar robbed the players insteadEdit: Today, 06 jan 2021 the game just refuses to launch after it worked fine for more than a year.

author: HAN 絆
review: Yesterday I bought RDR 2 on Steam because I really enjoyed playing it on the PS4 and was looking forward to play it with better graphics and higher frame rate. It turned out to be one of the worst PC gaming experiences in my life. When I launched the game the first time it installed Rockstar Social Club launcher and I had an accout already so I logged on and then the launcher said I had to switch to a very old account I completely forgot I had. The problem is that the old account is linked to an email I don't have anymore (it's a very old account) so I can't access it and the launcher won't let me start the game with the newer account which is atleast a few years old.Good job Rockstar! How can you mess up a launcher to the extent where it won't let you start the game you want to play and why do I have to use your stupid launcher when I buy it on Steam. I tried searching for a solution to this problem but couldn't find an answer anywhere. Until Rockstar either fix their stupid launcher or even better remove it completely and just let me play using Steam I guess I'll never buy a Rockstar game on PC again.Steam refunded me for the game so I want to give a big thumbs up to Steam. Thank you Steam!(I usually never write reviews but this experience was so bad I want to warn other people.)

author: Jartan
review: Please excuse my small amount of playtime hours I have in this game. This isn't one of those one-sentence reviews.I regret to say that I cannot recommend anyone to buy Red Dead Redemption 2 on PC in it's current state. This comes from a variety of reasons, which have led me to request a refund of the game.To start with, upon installing the game I encountered immediate crashing (before even getting to the main menu) every time I launched the game. After trying many forum fixed to no avail, I decided to contact Rockstar support. I spent a few days trying to get a hold of Rockstar support on their website (a confusing badly-made mess of a system), and eventually managed to get in-contact with someone.I spent around 7 hours talking to Rockstar support in a live chat attempting to fix the crashing, and all they did was (unnecessarily) walking me through steps in an attempt to fix the crashes. They had me update drivers, change launch options, run things as administrator, UNINSTALL MY ANTIVIRUS (I refused to do this), and numerous more pointless tasks.After getting to the point where I was about to give up and simply refund the game, I ended up managing to fix my issue by actually reading the files they were having me change. It took me less than 5 minutes to read, comprehend, and fix my issue. I find it ironic how I fixed the issue so quickly (once knowing what to look at) while the support were seemingly messing around with me. Not only did I spend an extended period of time with support talking to them in the live chat, I also had to actively wait well over a total of 4 hours on my computer to even be assigned to a support agent.The live chat system that Rockstar presents is one that demands the user stay at their computer awaiting assignment to a support member. If you don't reply to the support staffs message soon after they send it, the chat is closed and you are forced to wait another hour or more to open it again. For the first chat I opened, I had to wait a hour and a half before reaching a person.At this point I managed to actually get into the game, which at the time seemed like a blessing. I spent about a hour actively changing the graphics settings in the game to attempt to get a reasonable FPS in the game. No matter how low I set my graphics settings, my FPS struggled to get over 40; I was getting frustrated. Some may automatically assume that my hardware is not good enough for this game, but this is easily dis-proven by taking a quick look at the other games I actively play in my Steam library, most of which I have on near-maximum graphics settings.Overall, it's extremely hard for me to put a negative review on this game, and especially to request a refund for it. The original Red Dead Redemption remains one of my favorite games of all time, and I still go back to play through it once in a while. I really wish I could play this game, but the state that it's in and Rockstar support have made it un-playable for me. If after reading this you do still decide to purchase Red Dead Redemption 2, I sincerely hope you have a better experience with it than me.

author: Body
review: Revised review:The game itself is great.  Aside the fact it took me a year to get the game working on my PC after a complete rebuild, and Rock Star's crappy REQUIRED third-party system, I did manage to get it to work.But I am continuing to give this a negative review.I pumped about 50 hours into the game.  I log back in one night (tonight) to play some games and about 30+ hours of gaemplay vanished.  Just all of it is gone, and I don't have it in me to continue playing this game or trying anymore.This is just a terrible PC port and I don't recommend it on PC.Old review:Bought this game maybe 6 months ago but had issues with Social Club, so I refunded it.Tried again last night, same thing.I keep having problems with Steam connecting to Rockstar's Social Club. >Buy game>Download game>Launch>Sorry, you need to download Social Club>k, I download it>You need to make an account with Social Club>k, I make an account>Sorry, but that email address is linked to a different Steam account>huh?  k, lemme check brb>nope, it's the same email>Re launch>Sorry, but that email address is linked to a different Steam account>*randomly gets emails from Rockstar in all Russian*I am in the middle of my second refund.  I have never played this game and I really want to, but it literally will not let me.  That said, I have no choice but to down vote this as a Steam game.  You can likely just buy it direvtly through Social Club - that said, just buy it and play directly through Rockstar's system.

Meaning I have to log in to windows as a separate user every time I want to play. Apparently that was a satisfactory outcome for Rockstar. The sheer number of hoops I've had to jump through trying to reset profiles, doing system scans, editing registry permissions and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, coupled with a complete lack of error code details on Rockstar's behalf. It just boggles the mind.I cannot in good conscience recommend this, simply because of the terrible, broken and frankly (for single player) unnecessary launcher and Rockstar's cavalier and negligent attitude towards improving or fixing it.

author: sup
review: When I first bought the game, my game was being bombarded by red dead online invites from someone with a twitch name (terrible advertisement). The game was trying to connect to that online lobby automatically (why?) every 10 seconds, causing game to be unplayable. Because i didn't do the online tutorial it was just showing an error. This issue persisted against all my efforts until I blocked the game in windows firewall. After that I played the game in peace. Rockstar is not showing the required attention to the problem of cheating in both rdr2 and gta5. Both games are time and time again rendered unplayable by its toxic and childish community of wannabe hackers. At this point Rockstar should put a disclaimer at the start of their games stating that ruining the fun for other players wouldn't make a person "hacker". So children get the right idea.As a result i will not even head to the Red Dead Online. And also I added Rockstar to "pirate don't buy" list next to Ubisoft.Apart from that 11/10 game of the year, must play :)

author: xMakezx
review: Honestly, past the hype train, I feel like I got robbed. Glad other users on here have seen this, since pro journos can't be trusted.Gameplay:First person really doesn't work well. Difficulty is laughable, even playing in first person with all aim assist turned on. Enemies take multiple hits, and you are a tank. There's lots of standing in the open and shooting at each other from 10 feet away, out of cover, shaving off health with multiple shots. Basically gives everything a very low energy, low pressure feeling even with all assists turned off, so that you feel no excitement. The whole experience just feels like a chore. Free aim is terribly clunky, and hit detection is something they still haven't got the hang of without lock on turned on. I'm a very mediocre gamer, and this was one of the easiest game I've played, and not in a good way. Enemies are identical in behavior and armament, and don't behave organically enough to justify the sameness on the grounds of "realism". Last but not least, a lot of boring riding through the same forested landscape. Its wants to be the Witcher but lacks the beauty, variety, and depth of the countryside. It also can't get off its own shaft, and constantly make you ride the same area and pause so the developers can jerk themselves and make you look at their masterpiece. Never though, did I have organic moment like in other games where I stopped to admire.Story:Bad. But I have a much higher bar for stories than most people, while my gameplay bar is about average. Still if you like HBO stuff more than say FOX or NBC, the story will disappoint. It's the same tragic tale as last time, with very inconsistently written characters. The dialogue is great in some cases, but the overall story is very lacking. The biggest issue is the attempt to paint Arthur as the good guy, vs just a likeable bad guy.When you murder 700 law abiding government officials, its hard to portray the guy as a classic hero, but try they do. To make it doable, the employ the laziest method ever, which is to make everyone else racist, and Arthur and his gang of barely literate horse thieves and prostitute feminists and equality centric. Why is it okay that Arthur is killing trains full of 18 year US Army personal just doing a job? Oh, because they are, every one of them racists, so now Arthur the murdering thieve is a nice guy do-gooder. Dumb + lazy writing. Makes me wish for Niko again. Didn't pretend to be a good guy any more than Scarface, so when he thinned out the ranks of the NYPD, it still made sense.Value for money:Low. They claim like 200 hours in bonus activity, but this isn't the case. You end the game with tons of money, with nothing in the game world to spend it on. Even if you did have something worth buying, you wouldn't be able to make it. All side activities pay very poorly. Robbing a store (banks are not robbable???) pays 30$, meanwhile the bounty you'll rack up escaping will be a minimum of 400$ bounty if you want to have any fun, and you can lose thousands if you die. Bounties pay nothing, like 80$ on average, and hunting fishing is boring (somehow the only viable option is with a bow, and you there are so many animals you can just ride up to them and dead eye, making it pointless to go looking) and pays very little. Stick ups pay 50 cents, and always go the same way. Poker games are limited to 5$, also making them pointless. I think the reason the post game feels so dead is to force people into online.

author: B
review: For starters, if you like open world games, beautiful scenery to take in, character customization (not the best, but it suffices), and have a soft spot for historic games, this might be the game for you. The attention to detail is fairly impressive, to give some examples, you get bloodied and dirtied on specific parts depending on what you did, such as on the hands after skinning an animal, on the shoulders if you carry a skinned beast, mud on the side you fell from your horse and so on, not only that, people on the street comment and have different treatment towards you about it, the singleplayer character's hair and beard grow over time, shop owners' comments change depending how recently you visited them and more, so, among other things, praise on this aspect is well deserved. The combat is ok, featuring decent gunplay, wall/object cover, gruesome melee that makes you feel the impact of hitting your enemies, different animations depending which weapon you have on your hand when grabbing someone, having to click again when using repeating guns, a lasso and other tools that are very fun to use on animals and people, all make it overall enjoyable, the only con, besides the ones in the following section, though i'm probably biased thanks to playing some shooters where every shot is lethal, is that some enemies take too many shots to die if you don't aim for the head/neck, granted it's not as bad as some other stuff out there. The sounds of the game are overall pretty good, it's nice to just stop and hear the scenery around you whether you're in a farm, a city or the wilds, the animals, gun sounds are alright too. The soundtrack puts a nice touch, it heightens every moment well, whether it's a relaxing or intense one, though it's not something i plan on stopping to listen to when not playing. Overall the ambience is nice and the game provides good decent immersion.Now that i'm done talking about the things i think are nice, i'm gonna talk about its shortcomings related mainly to multiplayer, which i play more than singleplayer, and is the main reason i'm on this game for.The bugs/glitches are the ultimate reason that led me to giving this game a negative review, and quite honestly, given the relatively extense list of positives, even if you expect it as a standard of an AAA title, they have to really be bad to outweigh the positives, and it turns out to me that they are. For the price this game has, the ammount of issues on this aspect is subpar to what it should have been, actually, just saying that feels like an understatement, i normally don't write game reviews, but i reached a level of frustration that made me want to use the time i normally would be in-game and write this. Now onto examples:- The absolutely most aggravating issue, is the fact that sometimes you get stuck on infinite loading screens. This can happen on the most unfortunate times - just before i was writing this review i had finished doing a mission that took around 20 minutes, the cutscene ends, and a load starts, i cross my fingers per usual, because every loading screen feels like a russian roulette where  out of 6 rounds are loaded, after it took too long, leading me to wait over 5 minutes, i realized, "yep it's bugged again" and had to press Alt + F4, effectivelly nullifying all my effort and time i spent doing that job in the game. Thanks to other bugs i'll mention below, you're forced to go through loading screens more which only adds up to the problem.- Randomly losing connection to the game servers, it doesn't matter how good your internet is, you will still get disconnected at some point from the game, it may be now, it may be in 2 hours or more, it can also happen so much you give up on playing that day, it'll happen, and just like the previously mentioned bug, it may happen on unfortunate times where you're in the middle of something, which can upset you. Now imagine you're in the middle of a mission, the game disconnects you, taking back to the menu. You try to join a new session, then you have to load...and load, and you get the infinite loading glitch, thus making you waste even more time and have to alt f4 again. It happened to me, my friends and a bunch of other people i'm sure.- Sometimes your horse, which you spend more time on than on foot, and is the main transportation method on the game, straight up gets stuck, you hop on it and it doesn't move, sometimes you can try things and it'll work to restore it, specially getting a friend on the horse, sometimes it doesn't and you're left there on foot, sometimes you have to restart the session... and have to  the game again, do you see where i'm going? Maybe have to reboot the game again if you get the infinite load bug.- In the game there is a role called trader, which is a job that utilizes a table on your camp to start its missions and retrieve animals that are used as resources for it, so here i went to hunt good quality animals to bring to my camp, i set my path back to camp after being done, reach its location, and the camp is not there, even if the icon on the map tells me it is. This makes me unable to deliver the resources bogging me down. I open the camp menu and try to relocate the camp, it doesn't work, so this made all the hunting i did be pointless, because the only way to fix it, is swapping session again. Not in the mood to do it, i gave away the animals to another player hunting near me and decided to do missions from another job. I get there, interact with a door to get in (most places don't need loading screens to get in btw, but this one does) and...- Sometimes interacting with things straight up doesn't work, continuing from above i couldn't get in the estabilishment to conduct a completely different activity from what i was doing because it was bugged. Long story short, i had to reset the game post infinite load bug after trying new session because i couldn't do both of the options i felt like at the time.So yeah, those are the main bugs i remember on top of my head because they're the most aggravating ones, the game seems to be worse on peak hours also, which is the only time some people have to play. Some days are better than others. I've experienced other bugs and if this doesn't convince you this will be a frustrating experience, i don't know what will. My other complaint is that the online economy is pretty grindy, so if you don't have a lot of time to play, expect the rewards and wealthy part of the game to come in slow, granted it's worse in the beginning than when you have more hours put in and have more resources.Saw some people complain about poor optimization but it runs mostly smoothly FPS wise for me.Sometimes the game crashes, but it's rare on my end.I still play the game despite everything, call me crazy, but the good part of the game is still there but it's mostly because there's no other game i feel like playing right now. My advice is for you to  don't buy the game just yet, me and i'm sure a lot of the player base are looking forward for this stuff being fixed, in some time it'll be cheaper and hopefully with less bugs. If the bugs never get dealt with i'll probably ditch this game.Hopefully this review helped you, cheers :)

author: Tocxic
review: Simply put a true masterpiece. Absolutely amazing work and effort put in by Rockstar Games.The game's graphics are absolutely spectacular, especially when you finish the first chapter of the game. The lighting and fog effects are unbelievably good. The god ray effects in forests are realistic. Nighttime lighting is realistic as the moonlight spreads over the whole area instead of being a light in the sky. Character clothes have great attention to detail, along with the fur on animals, and mud effects in towns.The gameplay can be a bit of a slow burn at the start, but once the first chapter is done, the gameplay becomes less restricting, and continues to do so as you progress forward. The gameplay is also very realistic as you have to maintain your guns to keep them working effectively (they can jam if you don't) and you also have to bathe regularly to keep yourself clean, eat regularly to keep your weight in check and also yo You also have to feed your horse regularly so they don't starve. All this may be confusing at first, and may be tedious to some, but you'll figure it out once you start playing the game.The story is possibly one of the best ones in videogames. rest assured, if you pay attention to the story, you will enjoy the game to its fullest. Coming to the other thing, side missions are often humorous and enjoyable, and are usually as good as the main story. Make sure to do side quests around the same pace as the main missionsI could go on and on but I'll just let you experience the rest. It is a 10/10 game made by the legendary company Rockstar Games, so rest assured, it's worth every single penny.

author: Minato
review: Masterpiece !!. You can actually bond with the characters as you play through the story. Challenges are one of the most boring things that I have ever done in this game to achieve that bastard 100%.I don't why Rockstar is not producing DLC's for this great world, really sad.

author: GGGxBeast
review: Waited for this game to release on Steam for over a year now. After getting to play it for only 3 hours, it crashed and was never able to open again. I tried to do a clean install of the game, left controller unplugged prior to starting the game, updated graphics drivers, and even tried reinstalling the Rockstar Launcher. Nothing worked. Rockstar should NOT have released this game in this state.EDIT: The game seems to now be somewhat playable, but this is only after reinstalling both the Rockstar Launcher and Steam entirely. I would only recommend getting this game if you're willing to do a bit of troubleshooting to prevent the game from crashing. When the game works, however, it looks phenomenal. All in all, it may be best to wait for a patch from Rockstar until the game is working properly.

author: rarankin2018
review: Use a controller not mouse and keyboard. This is a great game. I have over 1,800 hours on it. I played four play throughs of story mode and I'm at level 296 online. If you ever plan to play online, a controller is necessary to compete if you plan on engaging in pvp. Auto aim only comes with a controller. Mouse and keyboard users don't have this option. Movement also favors a controller users with the analog stick. People may have a different opinion, but I seriously think that the best M&K player will only be just ok against the best controller player. I really wish Rockstar  would've made this bit of information known at the beginning.

author: Trigg
review: I have waited to get the 100% completion achievement to make this review.This game is filled with limitless content, An amazing Story, One of, if not the best open world game that does not get boring for even a second, tons of sidequests, a great online multiplayer mode and so much more.This game is perfect (in my opinion)This game is one of my favourite games of all time!I highly recommend this game to everyone, even if you are just buying the online mode (though the story is a huge part of the game).This is not a great review but thanks for reading :)

author: Chief
review: Ok so I usually dont review games , my other reviews are good as **** , but this game has really forced me into reviewing it.First of all its story is just outstanding , yeah some might argue that its story is way to slow , but if u progress through the story you will realise that slow pace was well worth it , I dont want to put spoilers in this review so........Moving onto the open world part , well its open world is totally beautiful and the realism it has is just out of this world , in my opinion its the best open world out there , there are no games that can compete with its open world , I mean even its side quests are enjoyable , unlike other games , in fact its the first game in which I did side quests.You can do several things in its open world like hunting , robbing ofc and a lot more stuffs.Its npcs are also really very well made , if u follow them u will realise that they are not here just for the sake of being here but they have a life , they gotta earn to stay on their feet , believe me you will think twice before killing them.The characters are also really well made , you will either hate them or love them but you will never be able to hate Arthur , you will for sure bond with this character , he is just too good and a very well developed character , unlike Micah ofc, haha.Gameplay wise the game has done a pretty good  job , never got bored , its totally up to you how you want to handle a situation , unless game makes you do something specific.I have not even tried its online part yet , so I cant put everything in this review , and I am pretty sure I have not put everything in this review that this game has to offer   , its just very vast.I am positive that I have not explored it to its fullest , so I am gonna still gonna dive into this game whenever I get the chance. (I am yet to play as john)In the end all I want to say is that this game is a masterpiece ,  if you dont have it in ur library , what are you waiting for ? Go and get it boy (In Arthur's voice).

author: OmniWiXXXard TigerBlood
review: Do not get me wrong. This game IS worth playing for it's immersive gameplay experience and rich storytelling. You'll find plenty of things to do in the Wild West setting of Red Dead Redemption 2. I'm just over 90 hours in as of writing this and I'm not even 50% of the way done with the main story. I play in bursts and love what the game is.I don't recommend the game however because of what the profoundly incompetent nimrods at Rockstar have done with it. The online content is not only now dead but was always atrocious and plagued by cheaters, not something new to Rockstar online games but really seems to be bad in this one. It also will not be receiving any further content updates so Rockstar can focus on GTA6 (which if we're honest is the only franchise they actually care about anymore). The final nail in the coffin for me was the announcement of no planned DLC. The BEST thing about the original game for me was Undead Nightmare. Period. All hopes for a similar mode for RDR2 are dead and gone. Screw you Rockstar.

author: sum_stupid_punk
review: Bought the Deluxe Edition, was excited to play it on my PC since its so much more powerful than my console. Ran into Waaaaay to many issues that Rockstar claims are because of my graphics card driver. Went through every single official step to fix it and its still not working properly and crashes. I see that the community came up with a few things, but screw it.Now I love this game, On Console. Its a great game and Arthur is a Fantastic Character. Generally speaking I dislike Most Rockstar games. But this game is fantastic. It just doesn't work right now unless you do their work for them.Honestly, if Rockstar can't be bothered to make sure this game will work on its release. Or even a couple months after its release, then I can't be bothered to pay for it on another platform. Refund has been requested. Hopefully Rockstar gets off their ass and fixes the ERR_GFX _etc issues.

author: a passerby
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is hands down the best open-world adventure game I've ever played. The phenomenal story, well written characters, and incredibly talented voice actors makes me wonder if this might be the greatest game ever made. Other fantastic open-world games like AC Origins and TW3 felt incredibly vibrant, and RDR2 easily stands tall amongst those giants with its incredible sights and sounds. But what really sets RDR2 apart from those 2 is the level of effort put into developing the NPCs in this game. You just don't see random NPCs with unique conversations amongst themselves in other games, and with such diverse appearances, emotes, personalities, and mood states at that. Hiring over 1000 voice actors to voice NPCs that aren't even a part of side-missions? Truly incredible.I challenge anyone to ever feel bored playing RDR2. And yes, there're some game breaking bugs every now and then, but everything else is so phenomenal, that you just don't even care.RDR2 is truly a landmark in video games as an art form.

author: Meatbug
review: In Red Dead Redemption 2 you're playing Arthur Morgen, a member of a posse of outlaws, lead by Dutch van der Linde, who are on the run from federal agents due to a heist that went awry.While on the run and relocating their camp regularly, you're trying to make money by doing jobs that aren't necessarily legal all the time, everytime with a promise that the next big job will be the last.Over the course of the game, Arthur is also faced with his own mortality, making him question the things he does and their consequences and together with things going wrong and questioning the motives and integrity of Dutch, tensions rise and a conflict seems inevitable.The game is played in third-person, in a huge open world that you can traverse by foot or horseback (there are also carriages you can pay).Visually the game is gorgeous, from the snowy mountains to the prairie lands and dark and swampy regions, it's a feast to look at.But not just the visual presentation is great, there are some tracks from the soundtrack that are absolutely fantastic and their implementation in the scenes of the game sent shivers down my spine.Besides looking and sounding good, the gameplay is fine as well in my opinion. There's nothing groundbreaking new here though. You aim, you shoot, take cover and reload. Sometimes movement might feel a little wonky and sluggish, but there's nothing really standing in the way of enjoying things.The open world offers a lot of quests and activities you can do, animals to hunt, collectibles to find so you shouldn't get bored too easily.Now, while mentioned "boredom", the pacing of the game is quite deliberate, if not slow at times. Especially in the beginning. Personally, i think it fits the game and helps getting to know the characters, the situation everyone is in and personally, i love stories in games. So be aware, that you might not be able to explore and roam free as much as you want right away.I did played the multiplayer part a bit, though it feels more limited, empty and more repetitive than the singleplayer.Though if you have friends to play with, i guess it should offer some fun as well.I haven't encountered a lot of toxic players in my playtime, i really just got into a fight 2 or 3 times and that never really lasted too long and was more or less a minor inconvenience, though i'm not sure if this might have changed over time.Overall i think the game is a very good singleplayer, wild west game, with an online part that might hook you as well, depending how much you can bear repetitive tasks and if you have friends to play with as well, which probably increases the experience a lot.

author: Iron|Cu!
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 tests the boundaries of interactive immersion. Few games look this good, play this well, and have this much to offer. It begs you to slow down, turn every page of its dramatic tale, and savor every last breathtaking detail. It challenges you to be prepared for anything, and make the right decisions when your choices matter most. In my humble opinion, and in my 20+ years of gaming career, without a doubt in my mind, this is the best game I have ever played to this date.
