author: Fishly
review: Single Player:Absolutely amazing in every way. Could never recommend against it.Online:-Script Kiddies (Hackers) galore. I don't think in my many, many hours online I have ever had a session without seeing one.-Rockstar pretty much abandoned Red Dead Online and puts all their focus into GTA online. Which is sad, because this game is incredible, and has a very dedicated fan base.-'Pay to win'... it is definitely a big feature. If you don't have enough gold in game, just spend some real life cash and get yourself anything you want that's available in the game. or... you could pay to cheat just like so many other people have with their 'hacking'... But really.. don't do that.-THE GRIND IS REAL. I have never experienced any other game where it has taken so long to get anywhere. But, on the plus side, if you have a friend who has a high level, lots of cash, and all the roles, they can carry you and get you to those high levels in no timeDespite all these negative things, I keep coming back. Been playing online since it came out and don't plan on stopping anytime soon. It can get a bit boring if you play constantly for a while and you are a really high level with everything you want / and or need. But get a group of friends together, posse up, and go crazy. There are always ways to make your own fun in this game.Definitely recommend this incredible game

author: Ƥyrefeather
review: Take-Two, which is Rockstar’s parent company, is a stain on the art form known as Video Games. You know, a lot of AAA companies get called out for greed and unethical anti-consumer tactics, but Take-Two has somehow managed to avoid scrutiny for the despicable things they have done.Before that, let’s get into this game. It doesn’t work. At least for me. The dumb Rockstar Launcher DRM is broken so I can’t even play single player. It is an utter joke. But maybe it is for the best since everyone is saying this is an awful port. Bugs, FPS Drops, server problems, game crashes, and so on. Not to mention over 100gb and a 2 day download period. And that is with good internet. This port is a joke and not worth your money.But onto Take-Two. Did you know that Take-Two hires thugs they refer to as “Private Investigators” to harass their community? Take-Two has this fun little thing they do where they will hire online thugs to find where you live and go to your house to threaten you. They have done this multiple times, mostly to people who mod their games.But the worst of all was the case of SupMatto where Take-Two ruined a Youtuber’s career over him covering leaks for Borderlands 3 he found on Reddit. They went ahead and hired their thugs to go to his house and threaten him on his property, get his Discord shut down, and illegally file over 120 false DMCA claims on his Youtube channel getting it shut down also, destroying his monetization and channel.Most recently at the time of making this review they filed a lawsuit on a modder making the Red Dead Redemption Enhancement mod. This is a modder who they were harassing about 4 months before the lawsuit and through private investigators found his real name, phone numbers of his family, and email addresses. They then proceeded to harass the modder anywhere they could, and even called his elderly mother and threaten her with a lawsuit.Take-Two is a blight on the video game industry that insults customers who do not buy micro-transactions in their games by calling them “Freeloaders”. Out of all the anti-consumer things other companies may do, they at least don’t act like they are part of a Mafia.

author: Zogg
review: Almost unplayable with mouse and keyboard.This isn't a PC game - it's a console game, with console controls clumsily remapped to mouse and keyboard. Even a simple task like getting a gun from a horse becomes a tedious chore: You think it would be as simple as standing near the horse, pressing a hotkey and clicking on the rifle? Noooooo, that would be too easy! You have to focus the horse with the RMB, pressing Tab down, then - while still holding RMB and Tab - aiming the cursor at the correct segment and cycling through weapons in the segment with Q and E. Also, the game seems to change constantly which hotkey to use for contextual actions. It's a bit of a mess.During the first mission, I observed an allied NPC talking with another NPC. The game showed me a help text "Press [° ] to aim", with a mouse symbol with highlighted left mouse button. So I pressed that button - and triggered a gunfight. Ooops. Took me a while to understand that the game was talking about the other button... Don't they even have an UX guy at Rockstar?The second gunfight - a fight between two gangs - was even worse. I struggled with the confusing hotkeys and clumsy interface to shoot out of cover, until a teammate was shot (apparently he forgot to take cover) and the mission was lost. No possibility to retry the mission afterwards. I found myself in a cabin with lots of snow but no mission objective whatsoever, only the gang boss talking about sending someone to go to the site of the first gunfight (the one I had triggered with the wrong mouse button) to bury a corpse. So I took my horse and my bow (my rifle was nowhere to be found), convinced the interface to display a map (no, there is no hotkey) and tried to ride to that site... I said 'tried" because about halfway, my horse died under my but "because of the harsh weather". I tried several times, always the same. Apparently, the game doesn't want me to go where it told me to go, or to do anything else for that matter - just walk around in the snow around the cabin and have one-line conversations with depressed people. Maybe whe I do this for an hour, something will happen, I dunno, but it's not what I would call entertaining.Only then I discovered that there is a save-load screen, well hidden in the menus behind an obscure menu item like "Story". Of course there was only one autosave, and it was already in the cabin with no missions whatsoever. Bummer. I might restart the game one day to play it with a controller, but not anytime soon.

author: Dr. Faülkner, MD.
review: I enjoy the crap out of the game. Wouldn't have spent over 100 hrs playing just the online mode if I didn't.That said, the amount of hackers (server population getting mass teleport dropped or having grizzly bears literally rain from the sky) is absurd. I expect more from a triple A company. Until Rockstar does something about the security of their product, I can't recommend purchasing it for the online content.Update since my last review (6/20/20)Spent 20 minutes in the online. Not even a minute in and my character is getting blown up repeatedly. At least I get a lovely view of the fireworks (other plays off in the distance experiencing the same pain). Deciding to not let that a single instance kill the fun, change servers where someone is cycling the clocks by a few hours every few minutes. Could be worse. But then of course I encounter a bug that makes all missions stop working and the game crashes.What this all feels like is an online game that has been abandoned.

author: Ghostface
review: Don’t expect to play this game without any crashes and without tweaking the settings (unless you got a beast PC) since it’s not optimized like Grand Theft Auto V was.The story has the never ending drama and action you get without overdoing it and really selling it. I'm having a blast playing the story (just hit chapter 4) and meeting all theses different characters and story lines Rockstar has given us. As someone who found the story in Grand Theft Auto V bad and pretty childish, it’s nice to play a Rockstar game take the story more serious and make us feel emotions at times. Story mode has a lot to give and you could easily clock in 100 plus hours trying to do all the missions and if you want to 100% , 500 plus.I played for about an hour or two of online and it was great from what I saw, I can’t really say much since I didn’t even hit level 10 on a character yet but I hope they support online more with some future updates like “Undead Nightmare” since I feel like Story mode is pretty much set and a lot more people bought this for online vs story mode.I Really hope people pick this up and enjoy the story like I am and not just go online because you’re truly missing out on a great story.

author: Fed?
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Kiwi
review: You know a game is good when it has a skip cutscene option and you don't want to use it.You know a game is good when you are sad that they skip the boring part of traveling to a mission objective.You know a game is good when the story makes you almost stop playing because what's the point.It's hard to write in a review what makes this game so special as you need to experience it. What I can write is why I think it's a masterpiece while not spoiling it.If you want an open world experience where the world feels alive, NPC live their lives and where stories unfold with or without your active involvement this is the game for you. Just riding around between missions you will get so many random events, some of them even forming little stories that even after 100 hours I was still finding new things. Save a man from his own bear trap? Meet the same fellow in a nearby town few days later and he gives you a reward. Pickup a stranded girl and bring her home, get some information that helps you later. This type of event's make it feel like individuals have their own life and good or bad luck. Activities that you can do are plentiful and integrate very well into the game. Even collectable mission are something you do for extra cash and you can do them in increments. This makes it so natural during gameplay and it's not something you go out to do just to achieve 100%. Finding cards and bones just happens while exploring, hunting or fishing. Not to mention that there are so many interiors, shacks, houses, whole farms that you can explore, steal and murder your way through them. All of this makes the world of RDR2 one of the best open worlds out there. Ubisoft should take a note here. This is how you make a open world work. Every mechanic stands alone but also is seemingly integrated with the general feel of the game.Story is I would say Rockstar going to their original quality. Memorable main and side characters. Through story, side mission and activities you get to know them and they become part of the experience. This leads to questioning any available decision that the game throws at you whit great caution. I feel that they took a different path than in GTA 5 where side characters kinda felt like a mean to an end while here they are your friends and you actually care for them. Your character Arthur has a very unique progression. Without spoiling anything he is a man that tries to live in the ever changing world  going through industrialization. He is learning to cope that the old days are gone and trying to find a purpose in this new era. Even if you don't do any side activities just playing through the story is a worthwhile experience.The downsides are very few. There is some jittering of animations in towns that happens at random. I also experiences a bug when toggle to aim was on so I had to play with hold to aim option and one quest was bugged from progressing due to a known bug.Besides bugs I would love to see the eating and drinking mechanics serve a more survival purpose. I loved going up to the mountain rationing and hunting for food.All in all this game pulled me in and didn't let me go until I finished it. It's a unique experience that I would recommend to everyone. Only regret is that I didn't start playing it sooner!

author: Leon F. Kennedy
review: The greatest Western tale you will probably ever experience (in game, movie or any other form). With that out of the way here are some things that stand out the most; The story and (especially) the gameplay is very very slow for the first 20 hours or so - it's a slow burn and it's not for everyone, but the thing is when things heat up - you will miss those opening hours very much.  Juts stick with it and try to relax and enjoy the ride, don't rush it (and don't even start the game if you don't have enough time to properly enjoy it).The game looks and sounds incredible. It feels like a proper generational upgrade over GTA V, especially the character models (but also pretty much everything else) and it's optimised pretty good although it's pretty demanding.The characters in the game are written beautifully and even though there are a lot of them all of them have different personalities. You will care for a lot of them and you will hate some of them (not because they are badly written, mind you).The story is set before the events of RDR1 and it ties pretty much spot on to it. If you haven't played the first one I would even recommend doing so after you play RDR2 because it will hit even harder then (storywise). There are countless random encounters, side missions and activities to partake in. You can also customise a lot of things like your hair/beard, guns, equipment, horse, camp, etc.I didn't play RDR2 online so I can't really comment on that, but I could ramble on for a long, long time about the SP story. If you like open world games, a great story and memorable characters or maybe just want to experience the old West in the best form possible just go for it. It's not a perfect game and it's not for absolutely everyone but nothing is. As it stands RDR2 is a masterpiece and it gets a 10/10 from me.

author: twitch.tv/xChrispay
review: is a sprawling Western tale of loyalty, conviction, and the price of infamy, chronicling the inevitable collapse of a motley crew of Wild West holdouts kicking against the slow march of civilisation and industrialisation. Set in Rockstar’s most authentic and lived-in open world ever, there are so many things to do, so many people to meet, and so many places to explore it’s giddily overwhelming. Red Dead Redemption 2 isn’t just Rockstar’s greatest achievement to date; it’s a game so lacking in compromise it’s tough to know where best to start discussing it.So let’s start at the beginning: It’s 1899 and American outlaws are an endangered species. Dutch van der Linde and his gang are on the run after a botched heist in the growing town of Blackwater and they’ve retreated high into the mountains where an atrocious blizzard is covering their escape. We slip into the spurs of Arthur Morgan, an exceedingly cool and capable outlaw who was found by Dutch as a boy and raised on the wrong side of the law, and settle in for a roughly 60-hour story.And what a world it is; broader, more beautiful, and more varied than the one we explored in 2010’s Red Dead Redemption by a massive margin (though parts of that game’s map are also included). There are snowy peaks and dank, alligator-infested swamps. Thick forests and open plateaus. Quaint homesteads and grand plantations. Narrow streams and great lakes. Dusty gulches and dim caves. There’s the muddy livestock town of Valentine, with its wooden buildings and rustic charm, and then there’s the imposing city of Saint Denis, a grimy and growing metropolis full of modern extravagances like electric trams, paved roads, and Chinese restaurants. The vast assortment of ecosystems and environments seamlessly stitched together here is nothing short of remarkable.The ability of this game to keep itself fresh after so many hours is extraordinary, and not entirely due to just the size and diversity of the world; it’s how alive all of those places feel. While the largely rural world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is far less dense than the likes of Grand Theft Auto V, it’s absolutely brimming with wildlife to discover, people to interact with (and potentially help), and places to scrutinise. The best kind of open worlds are those that seem almost indifferent to your presence in them; like life goes on whether you stick your nose into proceedings or not. I’ve sat and watched lumberjacks felling trees at a bustling logging camp and curiously tailed a perturbed Englishman wandering around town looking for his mate “Gav.” None of this is crucial to the progression of Arthur’s story; it just helps build a world around him that made me feel like a visitor rather than the centre of the universe. Red Dead Redemption 2 nails this in a way that few – if any – games have before.The slower pace of Red Dead Redemption 2 compared to something like the slightly more breakneck GTA V is also a big part of how it encouraged me to drink in all the world has to offer. Bodies have to be manually looted, and Arthur needs to physically manhandle a body to do so. Single-action pistols need to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ before firing. Guns Arthur isn’t currently carrying need to retrieved from his saddle. Coffee needs to be brewed before drinking it.The main story missions themselves are a cocktail of high-stakes heists, deadly shootouts, desperate rescues, and thrilling chases, mixed with a lengthy list of other activities. Many of those function as organic ways to teach us about new side hustles and activities that can be undertaken, from selling stolen horses to playing poker or fishing.It all feels great to play, similar in a lot of ways to its immediate predecessor but injected with a pile of new animations and multiple layers of interactivity. It asks a lot of the finite amount of buttons on a controller, but once I became accustomed to which commands require a tap and which require a press-and-hold I had few hassles. Shootouts are supremely cinematic thanks to plenty of gun smoke and the same style of on-the-fly, ever-changing death animations that have characterised Rockstar games since GTA IV. You can even shoot off people’s hats and pick them up later for yourself.I think there’s a common presumption that Red Dead Redemption is just GTA on a horse, but that’s a bit reductive. Certainly the GTA DNA is here, but with far more primitive firearms at your fingertips gun battles are more intimate and anarchic. I love the close range clashes, hunkered down behind bits of cover exchanging lead with enemies often just yards away, or slugging it out in bareknuckle scraps. It’s exciting and fun. Combat from horseback is equally well-handled and it’s always a grisly highlight to watch unfortunate saps go limp and tumble from the saddle in a seemingly endless number of ways. I think Arthur feels a fraction heavier than any of the GTA V trio, but I would not say that I found his movement cumbersome. I really like how connected Arthur feels to the world. I’m not a particular fan of that old-school, skating third-person feel – like the player character has no inertia – and that’s certainly not present here.Dead Eye returns, naturally, as it’s been part of the series since Red Dead Revolver. It’s had some upgrades this time, the most useful of which highlights critical hit areas on a target (very useful for clean kills while hunting). It’s still a very effective way to make you feel like an unstoppable gunslinger and the gruesome ballet of slow-motion death-dealing remains disturbingly satisfying.Red Dead Redemption 2 is an undeniably pretty game across the board. The lighting is fantastic, particularly in dark, misty situations where shafts of moonlight stab through the trees, and I love the way it handles Arthur leaving weakly-lit interiors into the temporarily blinding sun outside. The sunsets are especially spectacular and seem to vary depending on the weather system. Some are harsh and beaming while others are warm and soft. The facial animation is a noticeable step up from GTA V, and the level of granular detail is almost absurd, from the way blood smears on Arthur’s shoulder after carrying a kill to the way individual strands of his majestic mutton chops quiver in the breeze. The way wagon wheels become caked in mud. The way rust builds up on a poorly-maintained firearm. It’s another long, long list that speaks to a high level of attention to detail.No matter where you look, everything feels meticulously handcrafted. Every consumable is labelled and can be picked up and inspected. Every catalogue in stores is full of custom text and illustrations pointing to products available for sale or old timey advertisements. Hallways are decorated with framed pictures I’ve never noticed repeated throughout the world. Remember: this is the game where horse testicles shrink when the weather is cold. More than once I found myself temporarily hypnotised by the musculature and skin creases on my horse’s butt. That’s a weird sentence, but you’re going to be spending a lot of time looking at a horse’s butt. It might as well impress you.Red Dead Redemption 2 stands shoulder-to-shoulder with Grand Theft Auto V as one of the greatest games of the modern age. It’s a gorgeous depiction of an ugly period that’s patient, polished, and a huge amount of fun to play, and it’s combined with Rockstar’s best storytelling to date. Even after finishing the lengthy story I can’t wait to go back and play more. This is a game of rare quality; a meticulously polished open world ode to the outlaw era. Looking for one of this generation’s very best single-player action experiences? Here’s your huckleberry.

author: Rocket
review: I'm afraid I have to insist, this game is a masterpiece!Sorry folks, but you can't complain on the fact this game has animations for every action, it ain't some dumbed down gameplay for ya, it's immersion at it's peak. For real, this is a late-wild west simulation, and the best at that. Enjoy the story, that is great in its own right, but when you go free roaming, robbing banks and random people, stumbling upon some weird couple murdering lone travellers, or just play some law-enforcing bounty hunter, you feel free, and totally immersed in this world. I hope we see more games with that kind of mindset, that level of work in the animations and in the world. I'm afraid I have to insist Dutch, but the animations of opening chests, random furnitures and picking up loot, made me feel like I interact with the world more than any other game I've ever played. They took the tech from LA Noire (the item manipulation stuff) and expanded it greatly. Even though it's slower than just mashing triangle to loot every plant and three in the zone, it feels totally normal and once you understand you have to take your time on Red Dead Redemption 2, you'll feel less strongly about those. Again, without those great animations, the game would just not feel as good or immersive. Other than that missions are still too linear and Rockstar did not give enough love to the online mode, but who cares? I prefer to talk to the random folks I cross paths with, listening to the dozens of Greet/Greet/Antagonize jokes and NPCs reactions, and more. Have fun guys, this is a safe pick.

author: King Link
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 feels like Rockstar has turned a corner, but it might not be the corner fans were hoping they would turn.Rockstar’s previous titles, both Red Dead Redemption, and Grand Theft Auto series had a lot of variety.  Grand Theft Auto 3 through San Andreas focused on a satirical open world where the player could create his own brand of havoc.  Grand Theft Auto IV created a more simulation-style game though fans had mixed reactions, though generally negative.Then Red Dead Redemption moved back to allow the player to create their own fun, and Grand Theft Auto V returned to the satirical style Rockstar was known for.I bring all of this up because Red Dead Redemption 2 is another attempt like Grand Theft Auto IV where the goal is to create a more realistic game.  Part of the reason is while crime and urban gang life can be satirized very easily, westerns are no longer as common in pop culture, and while there have been amazing comedies in the genre, like Blazing Saddles, Rockstar made the assumption most fans would prefer a serious take on the western formula. Perhaps they were wrong. While Red Dead Redemption 2 maintains a serious tone, it goes so far as to almost become a wild west simulation rather than a normal open-world game.   The player still has the normal ability as a personified superman, where they can take too much damage, become a crack shot, and is the only person who seems to matter in the world.  However, the game removes much of the niceties players expect.   There’s no way to quickly travel around the world, skin animals, or even purchase items.  There’s even a bounty system where if players are seen having too much fun (Stealing, harming NPCs, murdering, and more) they can get a bounty unless they deal with the witnesses. Quite often players are given a menial task and expected to execute the entire thing.  This has created some issues for some players where shoveling ♥♥♥♥ in a pig trough upsets them or creates situations where players want to get to the action quicker. But Red Dead Redemption 2 seems more focused on these smaller actions, and the experience over the gameplay.  The story and graphics always seem to be at the forefront, but just the simple act of riding a horse towards a town while the player sees wildlife he can chase after, smoke from a camp he can investigate, or other people on the trail shows the amount of detail that Rockstar invested in creating a realistic experience.If you want to really experience the wild west, Red Dead Redemption 2 is going to be the standard for many years to come. With an amazing world, the next question would be what can players do, and while the open world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is absolutely packed with content, there is also a story that Rockstar attempts to tell. The opening cutscenes catch the player up to the current situation of “Dutch’s gang”, a group of outlaws on the run from the law, which the main character is a part of.  This is a band of outlaws that have become tight knit.  Rather than a couple of robbers getting together for a single heist, they are a group that follows their leaders even as they are being pursued. Dutch and his cofounder of the gang, Hosea, clearly have inspired loyalty in the gang and you can actually feel the bonds between these characters.  This is absolutely what people talk about when they discuss “Show, don’t tell” It’s easy for the game to tell you that Dutch is the leader, but the characters you meet and spend time with here are amazing.  There are multiple members of this gang that feel like real people with actual problems. While the characters are well designed, the story is weaker.  The main thrust of the opening is to get away from the law, get settled, and make money.  This however is the mentality of Dutch for the entire game until the end.  It’s always about one more score and while that mentality is understandable, especially when one learns about Dutch, the issue becomes the story doesn’t really change for the first two acts of the game.  The entire gang takes Dutch’s desire for one last big score as a necessity. The third act does change the formula, and finally, some characters start to wake up but for forty to sixty hours before that point, the story was focused on the same topic and it’s not a great experience.  Taking some time at the beginning of the game and showing a little more of why this gang is so tight-knit, or even showing the gang before the fall of the gang in the first mission would have been better because it would inform the rest of the game.  Shortening the first and second acts of the game from a monstrous forty hours to just twenty or thirty hours could have made that section feel less like repeating the same patterns and more visceral leading to the final act of the game.  It also could have freed up time to show more of the gang’s history.Without talking about those final chapters of the game, I can say that the story does resolve itself well.  It’s one of the reasons that so many people praise Red Dead Redemption 2 and it’s storytelling.  When it has a story it wants to deliver and a purpose, the scenes are well done, and the final ten to twenty hours are exceptional as are the first five.The problem is those bookend such a large and dull section where much of Red Dead Redemption 2 seems to be repeating the same story beats, and truthfully that really harms the experience because it feels like the game is filled with the content just to elongate the experience rather than because it is evolving the story and narrative. A similar problem happens with the gameplay.  While Red Dead Redemption 2 has some amazing moments, much of the story missions feel the same.  Most missions involve long rides where characters talk.  This often comes moments after the player is watching a five-minute cutscene at the start of the mission. But with a five-minute cutscene preceding it, another five minutes spent riding to a location while discussing topics with the other people on the mission feels excessive.  Some of these conversations are excellent, and there are quite a few moments where the player feels like he’s riding in a posse, but having every mission have these travel sections gets old.  There’s a handful of missions with cutscenes for traveling but these are the exceptions.At the same time missions feel like they all run into the same pattern.  After the cutscene and travel sections, the player often ends up in gunfights, and while this is typical for a Rockstar title, it feels worse here.  I actually analyzed all the missions and found 72 percent of the missions had some form of gunfighting, usually a large shootout. That means almost three-fourths of missions have you shooting it out with enemies and while there’s a couple of them that are small contained shootouts, many shootouts have double digits numbers of enemies, even when it makes little sense.  There isn’t a lack of originality in what the missions ask the player to do.  There are all the classic staples of the Wild West story, though they get overused here.  Bank robberies are a staple of the time period’s myths.  And the player ends up robbing a couple of banks.  There are also town shootouts and robbing of trains that are done a few times, and by the end of the game, it feels a bit excessive.  At some point early in this game, the whole gang would be public enemy number 1 and have people chasing them no matter what.Due to Steam Character limits, you can see the review at There is also a video I made on this game that is available here

author: heisenberg
review: Pretty good, as long as you understand that it is a MOVIE game, like most other open world Rockstar games.Pros:-Great living, breathing open world, full of stuff to do and interesting NPC's to meet-Best graphics I've ever seen in a video game, and it runs really well, despite of that-Well written characters that you really end up caring about. Arthur Morgan and Dutch van der Line turned out to be some of my favorite video game characters that remind me of characters from shows such as Breaking Bad-Very good soundtrackCons:-The "gameplay" is boring and braindead easy. The Dead eye ability is overpowered as hell. Even if you avoid using it like I did, it's impossible to die at any point in the game if you've ever played a shooter before.-The missions are very linear, with annoying fail conditions, because they want to railroad you into the story.-The game pushes some agendas in very obvious ways. Robbing and murdering hundreds of innocent people is fine, but racism and misogyny is where we draw the line?Despite its flaws, this is actually the only Rockstar game that I like, so I have to give it a positive review.

author: clint
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of the few games which took the gaming industry a step forward. If you are interested in games telling a gripping narrative, then you should have played it. About  60-80 hour of gameplay can be expected, depending on how much time you spend on exploring the breathtaking, palpable wildnerness. The open world is fantasic, dragging you into an life of hardship in the slowly vvanishing frontier. What really stands out, is the audio oif the game. The audio alone comprises 25 GB of the disk space needed, offering a cinematic musical score, countless dialogues around the open world.It's incredible how much time has been spend on making the world believable by recording a myriad of different conversations for the NPCs around the world.It's one of the few games one can recommend without a doubt. Unless you are completely indifferent to anything regarding the western genre or narrative driven games, you should try out this game.

author: Zingaringo
review: Game has a lot of bugs that Rockstar never seems to get around to fixing.  In addition, new bugs show up that previously didn't exist.  For example, the metal detector used to work, and now it doesn't.  Also, they need to make it MUCH easier to contact customer support.  I don't want to be lost in an endless loop of web pages with suggested solutions that don't address the problem.  If they'd fix the problems, the game would be fine.

author: Lav
review: What to say about this game that hasn't been said already. Let's start.First things first, Rockstar Games surpassed itself. It's understanding why this game has been in developing for a long time, and now it's even more understanding why are we waiting for GTA VI this long. To make game better then this masterpiece, it's even hard to imagine what can we expect in GTA VI.Concerning RDR2, game is perfect. It's like some RP server where everything is already planned and developed, you have feeling that you are playing with Real Life players instead of NPC's. They are programmed, they have daily routines. You go there and sit in restaurant, you see NPC entering, sitting, ordering, eating and then leaving same restaurant in few minutes. This detail said, there is no need for anything else. About more details, horses balls are getting smaller when is on snow, cats are catching mouses, dogs are playing with each other, 500k+ lines of NPC's + Story modes, simulation already without any additional mods or anything needed, and many more details that are incredible and unimaginable, but Rockstar did it and Rockstar added it. Story: What to say about story? After Last of US and God of War, this is probably my favourite story game ever made. To experience life as a cowboy, in wild west that we all grown up, learned about it at schools, watched some of movies, and then got a chance to see it in game, to experience life as outlaw, helping those Indians, getting betrayed after so much adventures and etc. It's just remarkable what gaming industry is available to offer, only if people such as Rockstar Games team know how to use that potential. I can't express my feelings about this game, I dare say it's like first time experiencing s 3 x, only that game lasts 40+ hours, and other thing 40sec :D. Just magnificent thing, music, environment, company, characters, side missions, random events, graphics, nature, horse interaction and relationship, options. I believe that I can't say everything I wanted to say in this 1 recommendation section, but this game is 10/10 with not doubt and one of saddest but also best I've ever played. True, it has some minor bugs, you might even experience lag on some parts in game, but after playing it and experiencing it, you forget and forgive all about it.At the end, I just hope 2 things from this company. I hope that they will make GTA VI experience even more better then experiencing GTA V and this masterpiece RDR2. I don't care if it takes 5+ years, but once it's done, you can enjoy a few years playing it. Just like RDR2 there is so much that people are still discovering after having 300-500-800-1000 hours on game. 2nd thing I wish to see from this company, is Red Dead Redemption 1 remake/remasterd or whatever. I read that it's complicated to do it cause codes or something, but I believe that Rockstar can manage it!Once again, total recommendation about this game, buy it, experience it, you will not regret it. Words and reviews cannot describe it until you get feeling by playing this game!

author: Sfogliatella Riccia
review: All in all, I enjoyed my time in RDR2, but going back I wouldn't buy it and play it again. It's beautiful world to explore and immerse yourself, squandered by the worst of R* game design.So, each time you boot up the game on pc you must log into the R* social club because reasons. But whatever, that's barely mildly annoying. Then the game reverts your graphic settings at every launch, so you have to re-edit back everything you altered, every time. But okay, I can live with that.Now, let’s list how RDR2 allows you to partake in its “open world”:1.	I tried to turn off radar and directions for a more immersive experience in this beautiful game, and got a game over twice in the first mission because it's not enough to just move towards your destination, you have to guess and follow the ONE specific route you're supposed to take.2.	My first duel went with a tutorial on the bottom centre, a prompt on the bottom right and another tutorial on the top left, all at the same time. I got killed five times trying to process all the info. This one is on me I guess, but that's really a counterintuitive way to explain stuff.3.	There were two separate missions where I tried to sneak close to a target and capture them without problems, but I couldn't do that because I *had* to follow the prompts and learn the tutorials for catching them while they were running away, which basically means riding a horse, the first thing the game teaches you.4.	In fact, in multiple instances I tried to solve a boring mission using a bullet or, again, sneaking, but every time I tried the game then just went "X cannot be done now, come back later", so I can't even choose to fail.5.	One of the first missions gives you the option to "borrow" a horse but then do the right thing and bring it back to the owner once you don't need it anymore. I did so, and the owner promptly walked under his own horse, scaring himself and running away. Okay, that's fine, I can reload and try again. The guy wasn't there anymore. I still had the horse I stole, but there wasn't anyone to give it back to.6.	Once I got my horse stuck into the woods and kept whistling for a good minute because I refused to accept this nonsense was possible. While whistling a lawman saw me and, for some reason, I was now wanted. Very immersive indeed.7.	Speaking of immersion, in R* endless bulls--t quest for achieving realism, there are perfectly climbable slopes in the world that, despite being visibly walkable if you were a human being, just makes you slip no matter how you approach them, slow, fast, jumping, crouching, you cannot traverse otherwise *realistically* traversable paths.8.	Bulls--t realism aside let's talk about the mission structure. It's terrible.The storyline wouldn't work if Arthur wasn't the world's greatest doormat and if the gameplay allowed for choices (not choices about the narrative but regarding what tools to utilize for each situation), but that's apparently R* whole template. The best mission I've played up to chapter 3 was the one where Arthur had to get drunk with Lenny, not because it was necessarily a good mission, although it was funny, but because it stuck out into the endless bog of sameness that prevents any mission from being unique. One mission starts with Molly trying to open up about her personal life, and immediately she's cut off for a robbery with horse chases and shootouts, she’s not heard from for another 15 hours. That's the entirity of RDR2, which would be fine if the game was more upfront about it. Instead, there are missions with a legitimate interesting premise (a jail break, a fishing trip with friends, sheep hustling, train robberies, stealth infiltrations) but screw it, at some point it turns, unavoidably, in horse chases and shootouts, with dozens of bodies piling up, bloody hell. 9.	Once, a man literally asked me to pick up pig manure and the only way I could play that mission was by doing that, the main character plainly stating "all right, but I ain't gonna like it", EVEN THE BLOODY PROTAGONIST WISHES THERE WERE OPTIONS IN THE GAME. I get punished for trying a different approach in a sandbox game (some sites even say RPG lol), and the punishment is doing the task deemed, by the narrative itself, too stupid to do. Actually, at one point I did find the roleplaying feature: during a stealth mission the gang was, bloody of course, discovered and chase and shootout ensued. I was so done by that point that I just let the mission fail and discovered that, if you fail enough times, the game offers you to skip the checkpoint and proceed to the next part of the game. Which I did and, from a narrative perspective, it seemed like I had successfully completed the mission and left without problems.So, R* actually did put the option to choose your own adventure, by letting you choose to skip it.This is such a weird, bizarre, welcomed and utterly awful feature. If the devs were so uninterested in having the player play the game like they planned, then why not give them the possibility to choose how to approach a mission? The rails of each mission are fixed but, if I don't like them, I can just move on anyway instead of having an actual choice in the gameplay. And the only explanation I can find is that they were so confident in the narrative and so aware of the gameplay shortcomings that this seemed like the better choice? What the hell.At that point I was actively avoiding story missions for as long as I can, I just travelled around trying to engage npcs on the road and in the cities, walking around the camp looking for odd jobs, doing menial tasks, trying to balance hunting and wildlife preservation, apparently pointless stuff but, again, I'm just trying to have fun by immersing myself into this world, anything but having to do only those obnoxious horse chases and shootouts.I won’t get too deep into the story, only a couple of things on theming and presentation: pacing issue aside, I like the decadent western setting where there are no heroes, only criminals masquerading their atrocities as a search for freedom and a government that vexes its people with corruption, idiocy and militarism. Both are a most accurate representation of the United States, indeed.Problem is, the way the story is told is so padded, the important bits relegated to sparse cutscenes or long debates on horse-back riding, which are funny but so overlong yet so overconfident in their delivery.And all in all, it's just doesn't never hit emotional high, because the stakes are always so undercut by (supposedly) adrenaline pumping action. In the camp (the hub being actually one of the best features in the game) Arthur complains about feeling angry all the time and, by extent, killing a lot of people needlessly, when my playthrough instead was with almost no civilian death, so is he talking about the dozens of cannon fodder I have to slay with no choice in the matter? Bloody hell, at least Deus Ex or Mass Effect let me get to the ending before telling me, in the face, that every choice I made was equally useless, RDR2 doesn't even wait for the middle act. Also, because by that point the game has forced you to kill so many people that you’ve gone numb to it as one of many menial tasks you need to do to progress into the game, but now apparently it matters, even though the game sure as hell won’t stop having you mow down hundreds of mobs from that point onward.All of this to say, no new ground in the western canon is being explored here (this genre has been used to tell how terrible America is since, afaik, the 1950s, and it only progressively became more explicit with titles like High Noon, The Searchers, The Wild Bunch, Butch Cassidy Heaven's Gate, Unforgiven, Once upon a time in the West, The Good The Bad and The Ugly, etc etc you get the idea) and everything that the game's story actually explores would be good if it wasn’t unceasingly undercut by the worst ludonarrative dissonance.

author: Beggar Soldier
review: , not for the Online mode, because the online is not really great experience as RDO gets little to no updates..- The Story is very good and very enjoyable, and this game takes place before the first Red Dead Redemption game.- Memorable characters- Cutscenes are well animated- Western setting which is well portrayed.- Beard Growth system- Soundtrack is awesome.- Controls are good (I played with a controller)- The visuals of this game are stunning (even on lower settings like medium)- Photo Mode- You can have your own horse and you can customize it or buy accessories. (Custom saddles, Preferred horse tail etc.)- The map is huge- You can spend 70-80 hours with just the Story mode!- Side missions are fun.- Attention to detail (An example: If your hat falls off, you have to pick it up for yourself and put it back on your head)- Weapon customization and keeping them clean.- Side activities (fishing, playing cards etc.)- Some parts of the map feels kinda empty- The cover system isn't that great- Gunplay feels weird at first.- Looting feels monoton after many hours into the game.- Sometimes you get into situations when you get down from your horse you run into battle and then notice you don't have your guns with you, only your handguns and then you have to run back.- You can have your own character (Obviously)- Some characters from the Story mode appears here too.- Completely new story just for the Online mode- Side missions across the map- You can choose from several roles to play as. (Bounty hunter, Trader, Collector, Moonshiner)- There are custom made cutscenes for criminals when you do "Legendary Bounty"- Characters in RDO's story aren't really memorable.- Servers are often laggy making every PVP matches unfair and frustrating.- No text chat, you can only use emotes or voice chat as a way of communicating. (..Why Rockstar?)- Side missions get repetitive after completing them once.- Rockstar doesn't really update Red Dead Online.- There isn't really much to do after you've done the missions. Not much replayability.- Some things in the game are way too expensive and grindy. (Like the Moonshine shack which I've never got, because I got so bored of grinding)- Having deadeye in online mode is kinda unfair.I can recommend this game for its Story Mode 100%, but not for it's online mode, not in its current state, but if Rockstar updates RDO with many more new interesting content, then maybe.

author: Shubham
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is by far one of the greatest games I’ve ever played! This is the best Rockstar Game till date.This game is a masterpiece and a must play, the story is so compelling and emotional. It features what is probably the most impressive open-world ever created, staggeringly massive, breathtakingly beautiful and mind boggling amount of details more than any other game which transport the player into its brutal yet breathtaking world and constantly finds ways to take your breath away and it's a world that is constantly joy to explore for many reasons such as while riding on a horse you will come across any number of dynamically occurring events.Overall the game offers a spectacular experience and amazing and immersive environment. It is a hell of an experience,everyone should play this game once in their life. This is by far the most realistically beautiful game ever. RDR2 Obliterates pretty much any of the today's open world games. It is the true next gen game. Looking forward to see how far they take things in GTA 6.

author: BlkBird
review: This game has a God tier level of immersion and it offers an insanely great deal of realism and detail that not even a game that sets in retro futuristic timeline can past its degree of competence. The NPCs in this game have a real-life kind of intelligence and common sense that you would think twice before messing around with the people and the law enforcement. I highly recommend playing this game at least once before you die.

author: Thund3r
review: The storyline is an emotional rollercoaster, perfect voice acting, motion capture, you could feel and see the emotion of the characters, as well as the character development of John Marston, a man who doesn't care for his family at first to a man who would do everything for his family. And Arthur Morgan, an outlaw to a man trying to find a good exit or his redemption in life. The game is a Arthur is arguably one of the best protagonist I've played in recent years. He's up there with Geralt.The graphics and the landscape just looks gorgeous and very detailed!As for optimization, well, it's not perfect but a little tweak here and there can make the game smooth and playable. I'd suggest watching Hardware Unboxed's video on optimizing the game. I managed to run it on a 1070 + R5 1600 smooth 60 fps on 1080p.

author: Tasty
review: From somebody who was underwhelmed by the GTA5 main story, I was pleasantly surprised to find what Rockstar had created in this game. I can confidently say that this is one of, if not the, greatest story ever told in gaming. Arthur Morgan has one of the most compelling and emotional anti-hero arcs I have ever witnessed. But it isn't just him - there are a dozen other characters that get plenty of time and attention alongside him. They all get their own complex character arcs, which are deeply explored and developed. How Rockstar managed to achieve this is a testament. Halfway through I was invested in so many of the characters and the whole thing was an emotional roller coaster. You'll surely feel every emotion you can imagine by the end. Take your time and appreciate this game as there are few out there like it.

author: Dennis
review: I love the original RDR. It is my favorite game of all time. But this game does not live up to that. It is a technical mess. I was plagued by the game crashing on launch. I followed a fix on Rockstar's support site that did fix it.....temporarily. One day, for whatever reason, the crashes started again. I reapplied the fix, and the problem went away......temporarily. This time, I had to submit a ticket to Rockstar support. They told me to switch from Vulkan to DX12 and to disable the Steam overlay. This has ended the crashes on launch, but why on Earth does this game feature an API that it can't run on? And why does the Steam overlay impact? Every other game I have runs just fine with the Steam overlay.And then there is the in-game crashes. This game must crash at least once per session. My most recent crash just happened during a very long story mission. The previous checkpoint was ages ago, and now I have to replay a large portion of it all over again. I tried but closed the game out of frustration and came to leave this review instead.There are also other smaller technical things. I have lost complete control of the horse on several occasions for no discernible reason. The physics get wonky on a regular basis. There is also some graphical artifacting from time to time. The game play is also repetitive and boring. I would list some of the positives, but I am too disgusted with the constant technical hiccups to write them out. It has been several months since launch on PC, and the game is still beset with issues. I am fed up. If I could get my money back, I would. If you want to play this game, wait until it is one deep discount some time from now. Do not pay full price for this. This, with its issues, is not a $60 game.

author: jsalx
review: A murdering psychopath steps in the shoes of his helpless victims when he faces an enemy he can't put a bullet in. A well crafted story with gorgeous graphics and great gameplay. The attention to detail with varied dialogue and consequences is the best I've seen since TES: V or the Mass Effect Series. Best game I've played in a loooong time!

author: Murosama
review: A perfect game? No. No such thing exists. Just like there can be no perfect movies, music, or TV shows. Art, perhaps by its definition, must be flawed. Which is to say that this is not a list that aims to prove that Red Dead Redemption 2 is perfect, but simply to prove that it is as damn close as we've ever seen in gaming as a medium. It's The Godfather of video games, The Black Album of video games, and the magnum opus of Rockstar so far.It's the rarest of rare diamonds in the industry: a jack of all trades and a master of each.

author: Luuttaja
review: Amazing game in every aspect. Great storyline, amazing graphics and action segments. Anywhere you go and anything you do, you will not be bored. I can guarantee that anywhere you go (most of the time), you will have a random encounter or an ambush happen to you. You can flee, ignore or interact however you want. I've even spent multiple hours just playing poker. Hands down the best game I've ever played so far, and it is a 110% worth the money. I haven't played online much, but it's a possibility if you want. Don't buy it just for the online though, the story is what is worth the money.

author: Chris
review: The tutorial section of the game bored me to death, I quit playing two times because of it. The animations are painfully realistic, it is as if the game is taking place in slow motion at times. I would have never thought I would be complaining about a game being too realistic, worst of all the controls. With v-sync off the input delay in this game is borderline unbearable, by far the worst I have ever experienced, the only way I was able to get past it was by using a controller, even that took time to adjust to. The open world was amazing at first however It does get old fast riding across the map time after time, the random encounters are repetitive and the side missions aren't too interesting either. There are a few exceptions however if you want to 100% this game be prepared for mindless fetch quests.Despite the shortcomings this game has an excellent story, the voice acting is top-notch, and the facial animations are fantastic. Once I focused on the story and getting side tracked for the occasional side mission, the game really started to shine. This type of story would be better played in a semi open world with more linear game play. Weapon variety is strong as well as weapon and outfit customization. If you are expecting a massive open world game with tons of varying side content like an elder scrolls or fallout title you will be disappointed. The story writing and voice actors do such an outstanding job they redeem all the negative aspects of the game. There are countless hours of high quality cut scenes it is almost like a movie-like at times.I give Red Dead Redemption 2 an 8.5/10.Update: 11/23/2022The control related issues appear to have been resolved, DLSS and Nvidia Reflex have since been added to the game. Input delay is much lower than on the initial release of the game, DLSS not only improves framerate but serves as the best anti aliasing option and removes the horrible smudge effect that happens from TAANew score is a 9/10

author: Torllay
review: Let’s just be honest here. I strongly doubt you’ll be disappointed. But~  and maybe you want know a bit more of what you’d be getting, so, bear with me, I’ll go into more details. You play as , and you’ll be surrounded by his gang which is more of a family than anything else. The game is set in the year 1899, right as America was getting more civilized and there was no space for cowboys and gunslingers in the new world anymore. You start this journey as the group is running away from the law after what was probably their biggest score. Though it went wrong and, being forced to leave all the money and gold behind, for now, they are on the run trying to survive. I won’t go any more into details, I can, though, say, this game’s story is absolutely one of the best I’ve ever played. It’s amazingly written and I could not consider it anything less than amazing. As per usual, from Rockstar. Talking of Rockstar, the game is extremely detailed, as expected. The currency is perfectly in line with the year, which makes winning 76 cents at poker far from sad, but incredible, since today that would be 23$!The world feels ALIVE, from the cities to the forests with animals that have behaviorism to keep in mind when hunting or fishing, it feels like it has its own well-crafted ecosystem. This world is nothing short of great and full of love, and it shows in every step you take going from A to B around America on your horse as you bond and take care of it.It’s very simulative and there’s so much detail and so much attention into everything you could literally open the game just to hunt, play poker, or pet and brush your horse and it would be fine.Even side quests are not-so-side after all, a bit like in The Witcher 3, they are entire questlines and stories of people you meet more than once in your journey.   The gunplay and gameplay are extremely fun, every weapon feels unique and it's a bit customizable. You also have a dead eye ability, that evolves as you go through the game, where you can slow time down to aim and shoot someone. A little bit like Micheal in GTA V. The game has also some survival mechanics. You increase your stats by using them, but if you go lower than your stats you'll start to drain the core of your health/stamina/dead eye. You can recover the core by eating food or sleeping, making you micro-manage especially stamina cause you don't wanna run out of that since it's gonna start draining your health after you run out of it. The same thing to the horse, you gotta take a lot of care of it, and caring will make your bond with it stronger.Now that I praised the game, I want to address what I said earlier: the game is not perfect.See, being a Rockstar Game, means you've got to cope already with the fact that inputs are extremely slow. It might be good on controller, but on mouse and keyboard, it feels really unresponsive. Very simulative, but slow.The game is VERY unresponsive, making sometimes simple things like getting on a cart to use a Gatling gun the hardest thing in the world when you try and get in position to interact with it and it just doesn't.The Anti-Aliasing techniques they choose for this game are a nightmare. There is FXAA which does less than nothing, MSAA which is way too performance-heavy, and TAA which leaves a lot of ghosting and it's very blurry. There is also an option to have TAA Sharpening, but that makes the ghosting even more obvious at times and creates a lot of weird artifacts. Simple TAA with a 15% Sharpening is the best option, although still not ideal. I hope that when DLSS 3.0 drops it's true that it'll work with any game with TAA, which would definitely save this game's AA. Other than that the game is very well optimized and it is very scalable, but, one little complaint is that even if the game weighs so much, the textures are only good at ultra, making it even high hard to look at, so I really hope that in the future they'll release a better texture pack to increase the life of the game.I praised the story and side quests, but...that's mostly all there is to the game. Sure, the world is nothing but amazing and extremely detailed, but compared to other similar big titles it feels more like a painting than anything else. There's very little interaction with it.And yeah, the game does have some collectibles and side objectives. One of them is hunting the legendary animals that allow you to craft unique clothing, but the clothing is just aesthetic, and hunting animals, even if legendary, is sadly more of a: go around the area, find clue, follow clue, kill. You usually you'll just follow the fur, marks, and dung of an animal in the general area of it to find it.Also, these legendary animals are less than 20, which is a lot, but it's also not since after that there's no reason to go hunt beside some specific pelts to increase Arthur's bag, which is almost useless since the normal bag by itself is just so big that you don't really need this upgrade. Also, killing the legendary animals gives you a way to craft trinkets that gives you a passive buff, which to me is such a wasted chance cause if said buffs were instead on the clothing it would make sense to use the whole outfit or part of it cause hey, , instead of all being passive effects you get regardless.The game has a great melee fighting system, and as I said earlier you can play Poker, Blackjack, Domino, etc. But that's it, all the things I just listed in the game besides some moments, are just there in case you need or want to do them. Leaving the game almost empty after you finish it and you have so much money that honestly going and playing poker for 10$, besides the fun of it, makes no sense. I'm not saying the game should have done much more, but even just some tournaments in fighting and poker would have made these activities more than just an option and something else to do after you finish it or even as you play it, besides the side quests which as I said, don't feel like side content at all. And don't get me wrong, I played other Rockstar titles, and I know, usually, in these games, after you finish it there's always very little left to do if not replay the game and get all gold medals in missions.BUT, compared to GTAV which came out in 2013, this feels more like an open-world TW3 style and I was hoping for at least some things to do in the open world besides hunting, fishing, and going through it. It feels bad after all these hours you put into the game, realizing that you can only go hunt some animals and go around looking for some cards and stuff.Anyway, let me wrap this up in a single sentence:Great world-building, an amazing story, and an extremely beautiful mapVery slow inputs and a world that has very little to do with it besides the story. I loved it, but this is still a videogame with a big open world, and, from RDR2 and its budget I guess I was expecting a bit more than just a nice story. I was hoping for a bit more interaction with the world, Which is why my vote is .The game is great, I strongly suggest it, but I see so much potential unused. PS: R.I.P Online

author: LiviD
review: Originally I had played it on PS4 since launch day and eventually beat the game. But as soon as it came out for PC I had to get it as it would solve the only issue I had with the game... the capability of the PS4... it's hard to focus on being an outlaw in the late 1800s when you constantly hear a plane taking off from your TV stand lol… But I knew I wanted to play it again, mainly just for the story & experiences.A big reason I loved this game so much is because the world feels alive. Animals to hunt, plants to gather, places to explore, notes & secrets to be uncovered. I've been trying to complete the game for a 3rd time, but I just always find myself just getting lost in the world looking at the beautiful scenery, caves, abandoned buildings and other secrets this world harbors within.  Another thing I noticed about this game is that every character seems fleshed out like they're a genuine person living in this world that's beaten them down. Regular NPCs go about their daily lives, jobs, getting drunk at the saloon or just going back home for the night.  Plus back at the camp some of the gang members will tell stories at night by the fire, get into arguments with each other, drink together or just try to pull you in for a short conversation.In my opinion this is probably one of the best games I've played alongside others like fallout New Vegas, GTA San Andreas and GTA 5

author: Str3ltsov
review: 9.5/10. As a fan of the RDR game franchise and the whole wild west theme I was thrilled and excited when Rockstar announced that RDR2 is coming out on PC, so couldn't wait to get my hands on it as soon as possible. When it did came out on steam I quickly bought it and the experience I had wasn't disappointing.Breathtaking graphics makes the game feel realistic. The story telling and the voice acting is truly remarkable, makes you really feel attached to the characters and their traits, especially the protagonist. A lot of side quests, missions and challenges to do. Really gets you addicted to playing, usually ended up playing from dawn till dusk every single day of the week without even realizing it. The only downfall is that the game isn't well optimized on PC, demanding lots of graphics card usage.Overall, the game is worth every single cent.

The graphics are incredible and there are many possibilities to have fun in this game.Overall I think this is an amazing game and a must play for everyone

For some people it would seem slow paced, but for me it was perfect and it might be going to be one of  my favourite games of all time.

review: The game is not at all optimized. Native display 3840X2160, 23-32 fps range at ultra settings; 23-32 fps at lowest settings. Something is very wrong with the pc port. The game itself seems amazing if it would work.Update. Optimization still not addressed. Finished the game at lower resolution. Game is amazing.

author: liscombc
review: As of 1/22/2020 I can not recommend purchasing this game for the full price. Even when I picked it up when it was 20% off, I feel the price does not reflect the polish I would expect from Rockstar. I have been waiting to review this game after several bug fixing patches, but every day when I check there are still no updates.In short, there are numerous bugs and stability issues. The game frequently crashes and I have to replay missions. One of the most annoying bugs effects story cut scenes where I miss out on the dialogue. For example, when hunting the big bear and saving that one guy, I have no idea what happened because the cut scene skipped. Another really annoying bug happens frequently in missions where I need to chase someone on my horse, and all of a sudden my horse will just run in circles. It does not matter what I press or what direction I try to move, my horse will just go in circles and I fail the mission.This game will be awesome one day. I would encourage Rockstar to focus their development on fixing the current game before trying to add new content. Optimize the game, fix bugs, and increase stability. Until then, I would recommend waiting to buy this game.

author: Drastic
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 pits you into a beautifully crafted, awe-inspiring sandbox of a world where you assume the role of Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van Der Linde Gang. (I'd love to go on about this but spoilers!!!)For those of you looking for a wild west shootout game, look elsewhere, however, if you're looking for extremely well thought out character development, an albeit linear yet intriguing story, and an overall emotional roller coaster of an experience within the wild west universe, Red Dead Redemption 2 is the game for you. As for the game itself and how it plays, while I believe Rockstar could have done a better job with the PC port (as my friends and I have gotten quite a few issues with tabbing out, random crashes and what not), the world is immersive, be it in terms of visual fidelity, sound or the environment it offers. While there is no doubt that the RDR2 is impressive looking, what stands out for me is the sound engineering and its use in encapsulating the experience of the environment.In short, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a must-play. P.S Quite a lot of people have trouble getting into the Red Dead Online world as it is a bit different than that of the game. I'd advise it best to finish the story and then head over to Online as it'll be easier to get into. In addition, when getting into online, research on how the RDR Online world works and figure the do's and don'ts out so as to have an enjoyable experience.

author: ChipT
review: Great single player, ruined by broken online and greedy microtransactions, avoid online like the plague

author: Nomad
review: Game is great - when you can get past the launcher screen After about 40hrs it says my product is not activated. This is BS.

author: Trigger
review: "Okay, boy"RDR2 is a technically impressive game where actual gameplay takes a back seat and the narrative devolves to an unsatisfactory mess.As we have come to expect from Rockstar, the game boasts an impressive open world which is, however, disappointingly static and at times laborious to traverse (and you will be doing that traversing quite a bit). Likewise, as we have come to expect, the voice acting is once again stellar and the game has an interesting cast of characters (some of which are more cartoony than others, and some of which don't really get anything meaningful to say or do, if truth be told).The game's considerable technical merits are let down by the following issues in particular:Too bad the open vistas and gorgeous game world are not equally matched by inspired gameplay. As it stands playing RDR2 feels quite repetitive with severely limited player agency and choice (you don't really make any meaningful choices, aside from the length of your beard).Rockstar needs to update their formula which has remained pretty much unchanged since GTA3. Despite the numerous criticisms listed above the game is still good...but it left me feeling that it could have been so, so much better. Which is probably why the tone of my review seems to be quite negative despite many of the positive aspects of RDR2.EDIT: formatting

author: decizion
review: I first played this game on ps4 but haven't played it much because i don't really like playing at 30fps like a console peasant.So i waited for the  which was delayed by a month (thanks to the epic games store ♥♥♥♥♥).Well let's say that i'm happy the game is finally on pc but i'm also a bit disappointed by the quality of this port...It took Rockstar more than a year to bring this game on pc but still the optimisation is not great.Even on high end pc the performances are not that good, or maybe i expected too much from Rockstar...Sure it's 100% better to play it on pc rather than on the sub par garbage consoles versions but it could and should have been better.With almost all settings set to ultra at 1080p, average framerate is 70fps with dips below 50 at times.With settings set to a mix of medium, low and high also at 1080p i can average 110+ fps.So yeah not really stellar performances as stated above, at least there is a lot of graphical options to tweak and configure the game...And maybe Rockstar will keep patching and updating the game and finally get it right one day.Alright let's get to the pros and cons.+The atmosphere and universe are absolutely amazing.+The graphics are stunning.+The open world is mind blowing (probably the best ever made).+Gunplay is really satisfying.+Choice to play in first or third person perspective.+Story is fascinating and engaging.+Characters are charismatic and interesting.+Voice acting is awesome.+Musics and sound effects are fantastic.+There's so much attention to details it's unbelievable.+Hundred hours of content.-Optimisation is not great.-Too many confusing controls for the keyboard and remapping everything is a pain.-Some people are still experiencing issues with the game not launching or crashing, and that's unacceptable (personally i haven't had any problems so far).-Steam players have to pay full price compared to other platforms.-Online seems to favorise controller plebs with aim assist just like halo reach, a joke if you ask me.-Mandatory installation of the rockstar game launcher.
