author: Nosh Scrumble
review: 82 Hours to beat as much as was reasonable and not too tedious. Excellent game from start to finish with a gripping storyline, excellent mechanics, and wasn't cookie-cutter progression. Specifically, just because you were further along didn't mean you'd make more money on your jobs. It was all about the context. Most money I made at one time was on my first bank job early in the game. My biggest cons are:- Still very early, so there's a lot of really unpredictable crashes. Luckily, autosave protects most if not all of your progress depending on timing.- Game was slow to start and kept only a slightly faster pace as time went on. - Never found Gavin.- Didn't feel like there was much choice in the decisions. Regardless, the above were outweighed by a well-crafted true masterpiece, through visuals, storytelling, gameplay, and the whole shebang. Worth every penny.

author: jSM2704
review: Hands down, one of the best games ever made. Everything in this masterpiece of a game is done to almost perfection. Be it sound design, combat, characters, acting, the story, or the music. This world will suck you in and present you a gaming experience unlike any other, if you let yourself believe in it. It's a typical Rockstar Games title, with a lot of cinematic flavor, excellent writing and a lot of action packed gameplay - that for my liking, especially during the fifth chapter, was a bit too much, personally - but if you know and love Rockstar's games, then you will get exactly what you want and more!

author: OhhPop
review: Played through it at least 4 times, 3 times on ps4 and once on pc and yet I still find new stuff within the game. I highly recommend the game as the story is great and gameplay is fun. The graphics are great as well if you don't mind your pc blowing up.

author: Deadeye
review: The story, atmosphere, missions and random events are really awesome. Game has this strange, scary, gloomy like mood, and i love it. Only Fallout games made me feel similar to this before. Controls are sometimes majorly annoying for such straightforward basic stuff. It takes a long time to get used to it. You gotta be really careful for not pulling your gun, or anger some folk. because even for little things they may go on an all out death match against you. Some people just turn hostile just because you are near them, and they immediately shoot you and never back down, unless you kill em, or run far away.Another thing is, how your camp works. its simply ridiculous, annoying and not worth most of the time. I mean, whats good about "upgrading" your tent with some animal skulls. You walk like a slowpoke in your camp, you can mistakenly initiate missions while thinking you are just chatting with NPCs. All of your guns stored in your horse unless you pick them up before getting of your horse, and when you get back on your horse, they automatically go back on your horse... Also, some of your items are in your horse. I see they were trying to look more realistic, but come on, this is GAME! Just give me a backpack and its good to go. Everything is fairly expensive and usual stuff that you can grind to earn money goes by pennies. And you have to go to a special store to sell most things, a place like a pawn shop which are kinda far apart. You advance a bit in the story and then everything turns 180 and drown in money. I have about 10K and nothing else to buy, and yet Dutch needs money for this and that, and work we do brings 500-1K, Dutch says we are so close, it was a good work lolLast thing is inventory clutter. BOY there re so many useless crap in the game. I mean do we really need 10s of different drinks and food and other consumables ? and you can only carry limited amount of real good ones, 3 or 5 etc. Rest is just a clutter, tiny benefits etc.After advancing in the story, and finishing it, I can say this game pretty dope, even with a very little discount, I dont regret buying it!RDR2 Online review:After a year playing Single player, I gave RDO a go, things were pretty slow at first but then, It gets better, especially with the roles, and friends. Coming from Fallout 76, I'd say its a lot harder to make new friends, people are either afraid or griefy. I love going to a rival and help them in their mission. So I play with friends I have. I got The Collector first, and made a ton of money and traveled across the map. Random griefings are not uncommon, stay in defensive mod, work on your ability cards to fight them or just parley and move on, or go to another server. Another tip is, rockstar places you in a map location with the highest player density, so when you join a server, start from a location FAR away from your intended play area, and then fast  travel there. It will most likely have less players/griefers.

author: Chief Greef
review: literally won't launch or read my hardware. no other games i own have an even similar problem.Rockstar is blaming this on customers not having their gpu drivers up to date. my drivers are fully up to date, and the game still will not launch. tried many bug fixes, and none work yet. maybe i'll change my review to positive once I actually get the chance to play it, but for now i can't recommend anyone buy it due to the number of problems people are having with getting it working.failing to understand how a game can be out in the live market for months and still have such major ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bugs.***edit***was able to get the game working thanks to a nvidia hotfix i was able to dig up. after hours of wrestling with it, i finally got the game running.up to the settings menu, where i then found out that Rockstar has, for whatever reason, chosen to regulate how you are allowed to use your own hardware for this game. my gpu is fairly old, but it's still capable of running most games on ultra or high settings at 60fps. rdr2 claims in the settings menu that my gpu can't handle the game at 1920x1080 on even low settings, and so tries to force me to play in the lowest resolution possible, which looks absolutely terrible stretched across my monitor.normally this wouldn't be a problem because normally, like with literally any other game out there, you'd be able to say "actually no, i know my hardware better than your preset options do, Rockstar."except you can't. Rockstar has removed the "ignore VRAM limitations" option that was present in GTA V for this title, meaning that you are literally blocked from controlling the graphical settings in a game that you bought and own.worst and buggiest port of any game i've ever seen. never had as many bugs compound with ♥♥♥♥ design choices as regards settings. cannot recommend this game unless you've got a better GPU than i do, and only then after at least another six months of Rockstar bugfixing. assuming they can be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to do so.

author: SNValadez
review: Guess I should finally say something about this.Two words: Worth it.There is nothing I wanted more last summer (and this summer) than an interactive diversion with an excellent story and game-play that pleases both casual and hardcore players alike. I enjoyed taking my time and searching the land. Some days I would just play so I could fish for an hour or two. I love how relaxing it is (you know, before ♥♥♥♥ really hits the fan), and the last couple of chapters always makes me sad.I’ve even created a 'bubble of security' by staying in the first and second chapters. I explore and fish and hunt and throw my pocket change into the camp funds, and everything seems right. Who knew role-playing as a cowboy was so much fun?!Too bad the online mode sucks, so don’t buy this game for that.Buy it for the single-player experience, and the many hours you can wander and interact and progress. It’s actually pretty cool being in Arthur Morgan’s head.

author: Gasnryo
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is split up into two different games, RDR2 and Red Dead Online. I say they are two different games because of how wildly they differ from each other, both in available content, and gameplay. RDR2 (Which I will refer to as story from now on) is one of the greatest games I have ever played. Theres so many things to explore in the wilderness, so many missions, random encounters with strangers, hunting, and more! There's many hours of replayability here and never ceases to be fun. The story takes you through the adventures of a man named Arthur Morgan, who is part of a notorious gang of outlaws. I can't say much more without spoiling some early game things, but I would highly recommend buying the game for just the story mode.Online on the other hand, is an absolute ♥♥♥♥ show. The wilderness that felt so colorful and full in story feels empty and dull, with less random encounters, a lackluster storyline to follow, and bugged animal spawns. Also, money in online is very hard to get, with most stranger missions paying a maximum of $15, which even for 1899 currency is barely anything. The only solid ways of making money is completing the storyline missions (which give about $200 for your first time completing it, they give very small amounts of money if you choose to replay the mission.) and using roles. Roles are "jobs" that you can buy with the premium currency, gold. Completing missions awards very small amounts of gold, so the only way to get it reliably is grinding daily challenges (which give amounts of gold) and getting a streak of multiple weeks to increase the yield of gold they give you. If you aren't able to get on for a day, your streak resets and the challenges go back to giving you the small amount of 0.2 gold. Once you spend a few days/weeks (depending on how much you play) grinding up the gold to get a role, you can start making some okayish money. To get all 4 of the roles, you will need to play for multiple weeks or months, which shouldnt be necessary for a game that gets boring and repetitive quickly.Theres also the issue with bugs. The game uses a P2P connection method, which leads to cheaters, poor connection, long load times, and more. Many times I have completed a high-paying mission or delivery, only to be faced with the disconnect screen instead of being payed. The result? The mission I spent a long time setting up was worthless. This shouldn't be acceptable for a massive company like Rockstar. Sometimes I will try to enter a certain building, just to have it brick me into not being able to use weapons or move freely. Sometimes objectives are uncompletable. I've invested some time into RDO so I have all the roles, and decent ways of making money, so I still play the game occasionally, but at its current state, I would not recommend buying this game for the sole purpose of playing the online mode.One thing I always tell friends who are looking to get it:When you buy Red Dead, you're purchasing the story mode. The online mode is just included as a bonus.(Another note: Once you buy the game, theres no way to upgrade to higher versions without paying the full price again, which is another really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ move by Rockstar.)TL:DR: Story mode is great, online mode is ♥♥♥♥♥♥

author: Sammy the Wizard
review: Seeing as I was never a fan of Grand Theft Auto or slower paced games, which I had heard this is, I wasn’t sure if I would like Red Dead Redemption 2. After 65 Hours, I have now beaten it and can easily say that this game is amazing. For the most part, it is not any slower than other story heavy games that I have played. It would have been nice if you could run inside your camp, but other than that minor annoyance, the game never felt dull. There is always something happening. The game does have a decent bit of walking, or in this case horse riding, from one spot to another, but so does every other open world game. This game kept those journeys interesting by almost always having conversations happening during the entire journey.Even before seeing the almost 40-minute-long credits, it was clear that a lot of work went into this game. The world is beautiful, while still running pretty well. Everything is fully voice acted as you would except from a AAA game these days. The story and characters are interesting and well written. I really like that this game was not afraid to . This really made the game feel a lot more real. Something that makes the game stand out is the little things. For example, picking up a skinned animal will get your clothes bloody, which you can wash of by taking a dip in a river and when you go for a swim or hang out in the rain, materials, such as your clothes, get visibly wet. The music in this game is also amazing. Its often very subtle but fits perfectly.Of course, this game is not without issue. The most frustrating issue I had was with movement. Sometimes while simply holding ‘W’ to go straight, my horse would decide to just start running in circles until I completely stopped it and started moving again. Other than that, it was mostly just small things like clipping, floating objects, or a horse parked funnily.

author: moxsi
review: Review is being made purely on the online portion of the game. If you're interested in it's story mode it's actually pretty alright.Rockstar's attempts to incentivize players into participating in PvP gameplay is a borderline joke when considering how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the player on player interactions become. Players relying on endgame equipment and OP ability cards to irritate low level players helps build complete apathy and ignorance to such a feature, a feature I was looking forward to.Also hackers galore, teleporting players, blowing them up, spawning 30 panthers around them, they've even managed to drain players hard earned cash over time. With all this in mind Rockstar prefers to patch money exploits and quick xp glitches rather than enacting justice on these power-tripping neanderthals that plague this game in droves.You'd think Rockstar would've learned from GTA:Online.

author: Dao Jones
review: TL;DR: This is a really great game marred by absolutely horrible PC controls.I want to like this game. I really, really do. Great graphics, good story, interesting NPCs, and a dynamic world you can interact with that changes over time. It's got everything it needs to be absolutely amazing.Except a decent control scheme.Like most PC ports of a console game, the controls are a bit fiddly. Functions that innately require button press sensitivity (like gun duels/fast draw) simply don't work as well due to the fact that PC keyboards don't function that way. Steering with keys in a system that expects stick movement ends up feeling really sluggish, and sometimes you just lose control and crash into things while doing something important like riding for dear life away from a bandit camp that you unwisely picked a fight with.But that's not the worst part. It's the buttons. Dear god, *everything* you do in this game requires too many discrete buttons to accomplish.Picking up loot has two separate buttons. Gun duels require several buttons. Using Deadeye? Three. Hell - even trying to exit the @#$%ing game requires literally FIVE different actions to accomplish (Esc > select Exit > Action Key to confirm > Quit Game on main menu > Action Key to confirm).It's clumsy, and it's janky, and it's basically killing the game for me. Sure, I could use a controller, but if I wanted to use a controller I'd have just bought the game on console. (Plus, I can't bullseye headshots for crap with my thumbs. Mouse Aim Crew 4 Lyfe.)Some people can get past all that (or aren't bothered by it), and I salute those people. This game is well-loved for a reason. But for those of us that don't want to play Twister every time we want to loot a battlefield, this game is a regrettable pass.

author: Hornet
review: 8/10In typical Rockstar fashion, RDR2 is a mix of high production values, fun gameplay and engaging narrative and characters, but also poor design choices that disrespect the player's time, and sloppy porting from consoles that frustrates the overall experience. Still, it's compelling on multiple levels if you can endure the consoleitis that plagues the UI and controls (and a few bugs besides).It's not a mile-a-minute in terms of action sequences and more often than not the joy is found in immersing yourself in the beautiful game world and moseying on about to stumble across random encounters or engage with the plentiful busywork (collect-a-thon and minigame completionists will be moderately satisfied).Overall, there's a lot of outlaw role-playing and shooting fun to be had here if you can work past the game's shortcomings. I have not engaged in the online mode yet as by most accounts it's full of griefers akin to GTA Online. Sort your life out Rockstar.

author: Sib3riX
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is Rockstar's best game, and it's gripping from start to finish. It sets a new bar for open world interaction, providing an absurd level of detail across the board. It's an immaculately polished release that pulls no punches in its delivery, pushing both brutally mature themes and perfectly placed satire. While its clumsy controls and convoluted button layouts can ruin the fun on occasion, it's easy enough to look past these flaws when everything else is of such a high quality. Red Dead Redemption 2 is a modern masterpiece.[✔]- Beautiful graphics- Open world- Soundtrack (add soundtrack dlc)- Astonishing - Realistic gameplay- Modern masterpiece- Storyline- Character interaction with open world[✘]- Optimization is not the best- Glitches- Online is meh9.5/10 highly recommended game for people who are looking to get best singleplayer experience.Thanks for reading!

author: Sedrethi
review: I am one of the posse members mentioned in Mauin/Azaren94's (currently negative) review and I must say that it sums up my experiences with the Online portion of the game as well, so far. As much as I want to really love and recommend this audiovisually stunning game, especially to more of my friends so that we can have fun together on it, I'm sad to say that my very first review on Steam is to point out that this game's glaring flaws stifle its success as proven by the generally mixed reviews from its playerbase.I thought, as an add-on, I would include more to points brought up in my friend's review mentioned above:• Vanishing NPCs: The beautiful wilderness is often scarce of wildlife, making hunting — one of my favorite aspects of the game — less exciting and more of a chore for certain challenges or building up materials for the Trader role.• Stability: I originally played the game using DX12 as the renderer, but as a result of their latest patch, this has caused my game to completely lock up my computer. I was forced to switch back to Vulcan, which unfortunately causes the aforementioned disruptive and reoccurring "ERR_GFX_STATE", necessitating the routine deletion of the sga files to resolve. Infinite loading screens upon entering or changing sessions/lobbies definitely adds to this frustration.• Posse: In regards to the "content starting" bug, it also prevents inviting or joining a posse as well, which is equally frustrating.• Griefers: While I encounter them somewhat uncommonly, they are generally nuisances. If you're a Rival Trader or Moonshiner, or something, fine. But running up and executing me for no reason other than to just ruin my time to relax and enjoy something because you're miserable in real life, you're just being obnoxious. Unfortunately, many griefers tend to be...• Hackers: The single most infuriating part of the game. If you're going to grief me, at least do it fairly and not be untargetable, undamageable, and ragdolling me into the sky with explosions, while spawning predators everywhere, and circumventing my reports for your disruptive and cheating behavior. These two points about griefers and hackers are especially prevalent during my evenings, particularly when players from "the Far East" start appearing online.• Customer Support: Painfully slow, although seemingly accommodating upon response when provided with enough details of your issue.The following is a >>player-made<< patch note list from another website that hits the nail on the head on how many players feel:• fixed an issue where an infinite black loading screen would appear when completing/starting missions or switching lobbies• fixed an issue where moonshine making progress would randomly reset, even if the player were doing nothing other than standing inside their shack• fixed an issue where the price of mash would randomly reset to $50• fixed animal spawns• fixed bounty hunter license awarded from Twitch Prime benefits• fixed an issue where players could not start/leave a Posse because the "in mission" status was stuck, even after completing the activity• fixed an issue where player camps could not be placed• fixed an issue where player camps would be invisible• fixed an issue where player camps would randomly change locations when logging in• fixed an issue where piece of **** cheaters could attack all players from any location• fixed an issue where piece of **** cheaters could teleport other players across the mapYou get the point.Rockstar's blatant negligence and disregard to the playerbase overall is disappointing for a AAA studio. It appears they put very little effort into the health of the game given its patch history and large severity of bugs, glitches, and exploits that go unresolved. Given its niche of being Old Western-themed, you think Rockstar would want to really make it stand out and polish their product to appeal to players who have been looking for a setting as such to play with their friends in, rather than allow it to appear as it does, a cash-grab that they simply don't care about enough to improve.TL;DR — If you're looking to play this game, buy it for the single-player portion. You'll be fairly disappointed with the Online portion for the time being and foreseeable future.

review: This game is a major pain in the ass to even get running.  The Rockstar game launcher is a slow pile of garbage, and you have to set up a Rockstar account.  By default, the game launched at a low resolution that was stretched across my monitor in such a way that I could only see the top left corner of the UI.  I had to launch the game in safe mode to do basic things like change resolution.  By the time I got this far I had lost patience.This is after a 108 GB download, too.  How much of my time is this game trying to waste?Rockstar, this isn't the 90's.  I don't want to have to fight with a game before I can start playing.  Games are things people play for fun, not things I want to spend my time on Google troubleshooting.  Completely unprofessional and shoddy.

author: Sploofy
review: I haven't played the multiplayer really, so can't comment on that. The singleplayer though... ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ had me in tears at some times. The whole thing is amazing, truly worthy of the tag "masterpiece" in my mind.The soundtrack is beautiful, the characters, the storyline, the world is just amazing. The storytelling is captivating, like you're watching a movie or series, always thinking "Just one more episode..." to yourself. This has been a journey from the beginning to the end, and I've thoroughly enjoyed every last bit of it (even the side missions!). Even playing on a rig that is a few years old, it runs well and I've never crashed or anything of the sorts. All in all I would recommend to play it, and get a friend to join ya, so you can discuss and talk about it. There are plenty of questions for you to engage about both during and after you're all done with the SP game.

Funny thing is when the runs , i will obviously tagged this game as "recommended", otherwise "not recommended" xDD Btw if the game runs, buy it. U will not regret for a penny spent for this game

author: slurmfactory
review: I have spent a lot of time in Red Dead Redemption, and its sequel Red Dead 2. You will find many of the same gameplay elements of the first game expanded upon, and if you are a new player luckily this game will take you through all you need to know. The story and soundtrack are well developed (as they should be, the game was in development for 5+ years) and no doubt rock* achieved what they were looking for.Besides all of that, this game does for me what many others fail to do. It brings me peace to simply play within the environment. You can travel, camp, hunt, relax, and take in the nature that could fool you for the real thing. Many of us struggle with blood pressure, depression, and dissatisfaction, however RD2 at least lets me forget about and attempt to mend that for the time I play it. That is something I cant put a price on, and therefore I recommend this game. No memes, no caveats, if you want to feel peace but cant physically spend a week out in the state parks camping, then play this game. Take care everyone <3Edit: Rockstar is making Red Dead Online a stand alone optional purchase beginning December 1st. For $5 you will have access to the multiplayer only version of the game, while rdr2 rarely goes on sale and if so does not drop further than $40, this will get you to explore the wilderness at a much lower point of entry. The physics and textures are toned down online as compared to the singleplayer version, however if that does not turn you away: welcome

author: Hymen BTFOer
review: One of the best games ever made.  The writing, the atmosphere, the world design, the gameplay, graphically and technically; it's superb on all fronts.  I cannot recommend this game enough.

author: senzei
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is an open world, story based game. It is fairly slow paced which might not appeal to everyone. This is not a game you want to play in short sessions. From the moment you launch RDR2 it is so immersive you might as well forget you have real life for a while. Incredible attention to detail and beauty of this massive world is a step above everything else you have played before, even if the gameplay itself is nothing too special.Game world looks stunning, actually some of the best visuals I have ever seen in a video game. Amazing story with great, memorable characters and even better voice acting. World feels alive, there is always something happening around you. To me RDR2 felt more like a good movie you get to take a part in rather than a video game and I enjoyed every moment of it. The main story alone is lengthy but there is so much to do besides the main story you will no doubt get sidetracked for hours at a time before you realize you have important business to attend to.Having said all that RDR2 is not without its flaws. Controls on PC feel really awkward and clunky, sometimes to the point of frustration. Some weird sound glitches every now and then. Online is average at best. And then there is the mandatory Rockstar’s social club launcher. F*ck you social club.All in all it has been an incredible journey, definitely worth a buy.

author: Caliosaaa
review: I absolutely love this game! The full game is worth every penny full price or on sale. The story mode is packed with stuff to do and on average you will have 50 hours of content in the story alone. The world is beautiful and the main characters truly feel alive. Throughout my play through I really felt I was apart of a family and could come home from my stressful life and be completely immersed with the characters.The online mode is a different thing. It is the same beautiful world, but in your own created character perspective same as GTA Online. The online mode has so much potential that it just doesn't live up to, but I still managed to have fun and have amassed 300 hours unlocking and doing mostly everything you can do in the online mode. Just really hope Rockstar realizes the potential here and invests a bit more time.

author: Tecnocrat
review: NEXT LEVEL - THE GOOD, THE BAD AND THE BEAUTIFULI know I'm late. I buy my games and I wait for the right price. I've played the 'Rockstar Collection', the good, the bad and the ugly. I'm a super fan of GTA 4. I liked a lot Vice City and San Andreas. I've been a fan of the Max Payne saga, so I played the weird Max Payne 3.RDR2 is on another level. What they've done here is changing gaming. It's the best animation I've ever seen on a game, the graphics are also top-notch, but the storytelling is ALSO looking amazing. I've just started, so I'll review it more later. Just saying is as good as everyone say (for once the public is right) and a little more. Nevertheless I suspect this kind of game attracs a more 'refined' mob. I don't see a hyperactive teenager used to fornite pace (and quality) to step into the slow growing boots of this super realistic cowboy adventure. Some will do I hope, the good ones, altough is good too for the bad ones and for the ugly ones. As good as it gets - 10/10

author: MasterDex
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is a great game. It's a beautiful game. It's an exciting game. It's a game you could lose not just hours to, but days, weeks, and even months.Red Dead Redemption 2 is a great game. When you get to play it. Instead, what I'm faced with is a convoluted launch regime that only half works, until it doesn't.It goes a little something like this:"Hmm, I think I'll play Red Dead Redemption 2."> Click Play on its Steam Library Page.> Watch the Rockstar Launcher start up (Rockstar heard we liked launchers so they put a launcher in your launcher, yo!)> Watch as the game crashes inexplicably to desktop.> But wait! We've been here before! Every. Damn. Time. We've launched the game. We know what to do!> Unplug any attached controllers. Can't be launching a game with no darn controllers on a PC! Why would anyone want to use a controller in a game like RDR2?> Try to start the game again.> Once again, watch the Rockstar launcher start up.> Success! The game is booting up!> But wait! There's more! You bought the game but Rockstar's shoddy activation process is gonna fail! You're not entitled to this game you paid €59.99 for. Oh no!> Go online to > Find a help article about offline mode.> Scratch your head in confusion as to how you could be offline when, clearly (being able to browse websites while you chat to a mate on steam), you're online.> Scratch head some more.> Browse the depths of the steam forums, reddit, and elsewhere for an answer.> Find only more confused and lost souls.> Try again.> And again> And again.> An hour passes. You're just about to give up but you say "One last try! By all the gods of gaming, let this be the one!" so you try again.> Success! You can now play Red Dead Redemption 2. Until it crashes, presumably because Rockstar can't get their * together and the game has tried to "periodically check for activation" mid-game and crapped its pants.> But hey! You can play the game now, right? I mean, it only took an hour to get it launched. After a year of waiting so Rockstar could intentionally double-dip.

author: shan
review: so far the best game i have played in my entire life. --> Good graphics--> Insane physics--> Outstanding story--> Best soundtracks i have so far heard in a video game--> Great online gameplay--> Good servers--> Worth for the price ( 45$ without discount ) Reason i love this game so much :--> Arthur Morgan : So far the most iconic gaming characters i have ever seen in a video game has to be ''Arthur Morgan''. Apart from John Marston from Red Dead Redemption 1 Arthur has became the most fan favourite character not because of personality but also for every action he makes in the video game-->Smooth Freeroam : The free roam in this game is unlike any other game. Red Dead Redemption 2 has  relaxing free roam with a natural environment and great visuals and physics-->Online multiplayer : The online multiplayer experience at the moment is decent actually, not a lot of contents and also the moonshine businesses and few objectives are cool but lengthy, if you got friends to play with its fun but i really didn't enjoy that much playing alone as the online is still lacking content--> Story : The story is outstanding and it will give u goosebumps and specially talking about real goosebumps here if u played rdr 1 before. The game really gives you a cowbow kind of feeling which is absolutely amazing besides good soundtracks. I loved how they actually make the game in a way that your choices actually matter and also the ending depends on your choices. Every single characters in the game were outstanding but my personal favourite were Arthur Morgan, Sean and Hosea besides John from red dead redemption 1. The game takes place before the time period of red dead redemption 1 so it's really intense. I won't spoil much anymore play it yourself and taste the masterpiece yourselfReplayability : Undoubtedly yes Game lackings : 1) Red Dead Online contents are very less, they should add more content to make the multiplayer more enjoyable.2) Some of the missions in the game feels a bit repetitive and boring3) have poor optimization for PC players ( they recently fixed it, it's a bit better now )4) Red Dead Online grind is too lengthy and buying a new horse or owning any business is really hard with less effort Note : besides these there were no other flaws found in the game according to my opinion and and the game was an absolute masterpiece for me so far thanks for reading

author: DeltaFiveNine
review: Game still has notable, game breaking bugs so I would not recommend buying the PC version, even though the gameplay is great. After playing fine for the first 2 hours, I alt tabbed and left my PC for a few minutes to come back to an ERR_GFX_STATE crash. Afterwards, game crashes every time I try to load back in to story. Google search says Rockstar says to do a launch option, doesn't work. Forums say delete some settings files, doesn't work. All the while, when the game crashes if I don't hit safe mode or retry on the crash prompt, I can't restart the game as Rockstar launcher says it's "still running" (even though there's no process running in the task manager). After spending quite a while trying to figure out how the hell to fix it, I switch to DirectX 12 as some forum posts say and it finally starts fine. I switch back to Vulkan, since performance is far worse in DX12 and... works fine. Unacceptable to have to troubleshoot stuff like this in a AAA title months after release. Could at least be bothered to save crash logs and have better crash prompts than giving ERR_GFX_STATE for what seems to be a dozen different actual bugs.

author: TyranWolf
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is a stunningly beautiful and immersive open-world game that offers a vast and varied landscape to explore. The attention to detail in the game is unparalleled, with breathtakingly realistic graphics and lifelike character animations. The story is captivating and emotionally powerful, and the voice acting is top-notch.One of the standout features of Red Dead Redemption 2 is its expansive and living world. The game takes place in a vast, open-world environment that is filled with a wide range of activities and points of interest to discover. From hunting and fishing to playing poker and robbing trains, there is always something to do in the game.It features a cast of well-developed and realistic characters that are integral to the story and gameplay experience. The main character, Arthur Morgan, is a complex and multifaceted protagonist whose actions and decisions throughout the game have a tangible impact on the story. The supporting cast are equally well-written, fleshed out, and memorable; with each character having their own distinct personality and motivations.One of the standout elements of the characterization in Red Dead Redemption 2 is the level of depth and nuance that is given to each character. Many of the characters in the game have complex and conflicted personalities, and their actions and dialogue reflect this. This makes the characters feel like real people rather than just caricatures or stereotypes, and it adds an extra layer of immersion to the game.In addition to the well-written characters, the voice acting in Red Dead Redemption 2 is top-notch. Each character is voiced by a talented actor who brings their role to life with a level of authenticity and emotion that is rare in video games.The gameplay in Red Dead Redemption 2 is smooth and intuitive, with a wide range of weapons and equipment available to use. The combat system is well-balanced and offers a satisfying level of challenge, while the stealth mechanics are well-implemented and provide an engaging alternative to going all out with guns blazing.Overall, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a good game that offers a vast and immersive open-world experience. It is a must-play for fans of the genre, and it is sure to captivate and engage players for hours on end. An absolute no-brainer if it goes on sale for $20-$30.

author: Jacktorious_REX
review: A game the literally sets the standards for what a AAA game should deliver, the only game that i have ever played which is able to lift me out of a depressive or anxious episode due to its beauty, attention to detail and realism, its possible to become overwhelmed with all of the things to do but for me personally i find that to just load it up and set no intention on what you will do is the best way to enjoy. I have spent countless hours just hunting and travelling around enjoying the sounds and scenery. I owned it on PS4 and was lucky enough to be gifted it by a friend for PC, what a hero he is as ive enjoyed it even more on PC.

author: BickyMonster
review: An absolute masterpiece, tarnished by an unnecessary and temperamental launcher.Having finished it for the first time, I’ve got to say that Red Dead Redemption 2 isn’t just a game; it’s an experience. I’m a huge fan of open-world games and this is easily the best open-world I’ve experienced. It may not be the largest or have the most activities, but it’s a joy to spend time in. It’s probably the most visually impressive game I’ve ever played, from the general beauty and atmosphere to fine details like footprints in mud and bullet holes in hats.Those impressive visuals need a powerful PC to experience though. With an i5 12600k and 3080 I ended up using graphics analysis videos on Youtube to configure everything to get a mostly-stable 120Hz at 1440p. I have screenshots of the settings I used in my collection that may be of help.I’m posting this after a single playthrough of the story mode. I didn’t rush through the game but I also deliberately didn’t see everything, to save plenty of side content for another time.The story hooked me in the first hour and never let go. The general pace is excellent, the characters are interesting with fantastic voice acting and the missions were varied and interesting from beginning to end. The soundtrack and general ambience are stunning. I repeatedly found myself strolling through populated areas, finding somewhere to sit and watching the world go by, listening to conversations between people that could easily have been missed. I haven’t done that since my first playthrough of Skyrim. The world really feels alive.Red Dead Redemption 2 is easily one of the best games I’ve ever played, and in my humble opinion it’s one of the greatest games ever made. I could say a lot more about the game, but I don’t want to spoil any aspect of it for anyone. I went in blind and I’m very glad I did.It certainly isn’t perfect though. The compulsory Rockstar launcher sometimes decides I don’t own the game, requiring a restart of just the launcher or the whole PC. I’ve also experienced a few crashes when trying to load the game from the main menu, though I didn’t experience a single crash once I was actually in. I experienced a few graphical glitches, like shadows not appearing or shadows not disappearing when they should, a bit of light flickering, some artifacts when very close to particle clouds and parts of the main characters face not loading, but nothing major. Most were solved be reloading the last save.I did find the controls a little awkward at times. I started the game using mouse & keyboard, where I found armed combat very easy but melee combat and general movement was clumsy. After a few hours I tried a controller and found everything except armed combat much better. The free-aim was too slow with controller, but enabling aim assist helped without doing all the work for me so I’d personally recommend playing with a controller.I was hesitant to get this at first, as I’ve never really been a fan of stories in this setting, I never played the first game and I found GTAV disappointing overall, but from the opening cutscene to the end credits, Red Dead Redemption 2 is enthralling, spectacular and magnificent. I very highly recommend it to anyone interested in story-based games. It’s an experience I certainly won’t forget.

author: Slazenger ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
review: Well worth the wait.  The game has a meticulous, plodding pace that is genuinely fantastic and allows complete immersion.  It's what I'd consider a period piece; the game is best played if you assume the role of Arthur and do the things you believe Arthur would do.  It's not a game for you to go max speed everywhere, shoot everything in sight.  The game will allow it, but you won't be getting the most out of it.PC port is fine so far - have had one bug that required a restart due to losing the ability to interact with my horse at one point, but other than that I've had no performance issues.  Game is running great at 4k even on my aging setup (i7 6700k/1080).  Gorgeous game, enticing storyline, and a world that feels incredibly alive - I'm a massive fan.

I doubted if it could reach that.It not only reached it. It not only surpassed it. It took my expectations on a fancy dinner date, and proceeded to f**k. I love the game so far and would recommend it to anyone.----EDIT: Don't play it for the online. It sucks in its current state.

author: Lothemar
review: One of the most impactful video game stories that sticks forever with you. Full of both thrill and emotion. Profound gamelay and beautifully breathtaking graphics. The story sticks with you forever after you're done with the game. Red Dead Redemption 2 is a game about consequences where you have only the illusion of choice. Yes, there are some decisions to be made, and those decisions will shape your character and the world around you. But some of the most disastrous choices were made for you before the game even begins, leaving you to deal with the fallout.Red Dead Redemption 2's version of America is vast and wide open, stretching from snowy mountains and the Great Plains down to the original game's New Austin in the southwest. Further to the east is the Louisiana-inspired Deep South, which is still feeling the effects of the Civil War after nearly 40 years. There's a distinct shift when traveling from region to region; as grassy hillsides become alligator-filled swamps, Union veterans give way to angry Confederate holdouts, and good intentions and casual racism turn into desperation and outright bigotry. The variety makes the world feel rich, and it both reacts to you and changes independently of your involvement; new buildings will go up as time goes on, and some of the people you talk to will remember you long after you first interacted with them (for better or worse).The story has incredible weight as a prequel with the anticipation that comes from knowing how it all ends. A varied and reactive world filled with chance encounters and surprises to discover compels you to explore. Mission structure and morality mechanics create tension that increases the story's impact.Simpy one of the best games out there, definitely well worth your money.

author: Commander Llama
review: Not reviewed: Online mode. I am only playing the Story mode right now.First, the Bad:- Demanding game. I wouldn't recommend this game without also recommending watching the DigitalFoundry and HardwareUnboxed Optimization videos from YouTube. Even so, on a top spec PC I can manage 1440p at 60-100fps, the range varies a lot by time of day and environment. I could run 4K at 45-60fps. This is after following the optimized setting guides, which boosted performance by around 40% at almost no discernible visual cost.- Stability may vary. Mine has been good, but some people I know have reported consistent isses. I crashed to desktop once in 37 hours while playing at 4K. No other crashes.- Performance tanks with Steam Overlay events is a consistent issue of mine. Whether you have the In-Game Overlay enabled or not. If someone sends me a message on Steam, the game starts micro-stuttering quite a bit, even though fps counters don't register it.- Dual layer DRM. Rather expectedly, the game runs the Rockstar service behind the Steam service. I also have the Nvidia overlay, so there's quite a number of layers on this bad boy. No big surprise the above bug exists...The Good:- Pretty much everything else. This is one of the best games I've ever played, and I think I will give it the #1 spot for most immersive. Most of the bad points are technical in nature, but once we assume you're running the game fine and so on, I have almost nothing but good things to say about it. - Huge, but not over-sized game world with a number of different biomes. You're never more than a hundred meters away from some kind of action, so there's always something to do theoretically. Exploring and hunting  in this space is so much fun. Plenty of secrets to find, people to rob/save, animals to study/hunt, and scripted encounters to come across.- The gunplay really comes home on PC, where you can finally aim with a damn mouse. I played about 30 hours on Xbox and while the game is still great, I disliked the mandatory reliance on auto-aim. With a mouse I can aim so much better, but I still need practice and skill to be the best gunslinger in the land.- The gang and camp gameplay adds a richness to resource acquisition and management that makes it feel like more than just numbers going up or bank account getting bigger. The gang characters are varied and boost the immersion. The story isn't mindblowing so far (in Chapter 3), but you can just about ignore it after the introductory Chapter 1.- I just really can't get over the attention to detail in the game, and the game design. Everything seems well thought out, from time it takes to skin animals or loot things, being able to choose honor vs. dishonor, supporting the gang vs. not. This may backfire with some players however, since the game "takes its time" and all these animations have a pretty massive input latency. Dark Souls slick RDR2 is not.The Nitpicks:- The introduction (Chapter 1 and part of Chapter 2) is rather slow, which I think will lose some players. The game also really takes its time introducing concepts. You're almost at Chapter 3 when the game explains a gunsmith, for instance, which is so elementary and can be visited right away.- Not aware of being able to set a consistent weapon loadout for Arthur when he mounts and then dismounts his horse. I pretty much rock the same weapons every damn time, but the game constantly unequips my weapons and I have to set them up every time. This does get old after a while.- I keep chugging Hair Tonic but I can't seem to get my beard longer than 7 on 10!- The "Core Drain" bug might still exist. I've been playing the game at roughly 75fps (compared to the console ~30) and Arthur is becoming consistently underweight even though I eat game meat regularly and stop for meals at saloons. It's not severe, but good PC performance might still correlate with skinny Arthur.- Far be it from me to suggest nerfs, but the Legend of the East satchel is a little OP. Carrying capacity is 3 or 5 for most items. Upgraded satchels can double that for one item type, and then Legend of the East does Full Blown Video Game and boosts most capacity to 99 for all items. Kind of an insane jump. Why not all item types to 10?- As far as I can tell, all of the Pearson camp upgrades don't matter besides the satchel? It would be cool if they did.

author: Divalti
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is an epic taking place across a long span of time and several locations, telling the tale of Arthur Morgan, the rough-around-the-edges yet lovable lieutenant of the Van der Linde outlaw gang.Aesthetically, the game does a great job. The Van der Linde gang's journey will take them to all manners of locations, from frosted mountaintops to vast plains to soggy swamps. You'll find yourself at new, beautiful locations at a reasonable pace and, if you're anything like me, you'll always find something to investigate. The visuals are intertwined alongside great sound quality as well. I was enamored by the voices of the characters you interact with, the sounds of the animals and the somberness of the sung music.After a botched heist forces the Van Der Linde gang on the run, they search for that "one last heist" that will finally let them go into hiding comfortably forever. Arthur will have to duel rival gangs and Pinkerton lawmen to keep his posse safe along the way. The story for the game is quite enjoyable, but it is not the star.  What draws you in more are instead the characters. Protagonist Arthur Morgan is a man of but's - serious but comical, shaken but determined, brash but endearing. The other characters you'll meet aren't quite as lovable as Arthur, but you'll love the ones you're intended to love and hate the ones you're intended to hate, and it's hard to ask for more.The gameplay mixes combat with exploration.  Outside of story missions, I wandered the western prairies,  hunting animals, investigating stranger encounters, and squandered my time just simply exploring in a relaxed fashion. The story missions can do with a little more variance - most of them involve going to a location, getting shot at, and shooting back. Still, the missions were enjoyable. A gripe I do have however is how unrewarding it is to be a criminal -  you'll quickly accrue a bounty if you're not a skillful outlaw.I didn't get too far into Online - I encountered a few bugs and lost connection to the Online server and decided that I had enough of Red Dead 2 for my money's worth.TLDR: If you're going to play Red Dead Redemption 2 for its base campaign, you'll almost definitely enjoy it due to its charming characters, diverse locations, and simple but engaging gameplay. I can't speak for the quality of the Online because that mode seemed to be pretty buggy, as opposed to the story mode.

review: Game started once after installing.Infinity loading screen bug-> PC restart -> Game opens the Rockstar launcher. ->Rockstar launcher says I own GTAV but have to buy RDR2I really hope they will fix this fast otherwise i need to refund the game...Update: Fix for me: Activate your steam overlay -> Run the game through steam -> The game should now be recocnized in your rockstar library -> Close steam and the rockstar games launcher -> Run the rockstar launcher before you start steam (steam should be closed) -> Disable any connected controller -> Start red dead redemption 2 in your rockstar launcher and click on play with steam -> Login in to your steam account -> Have funEdit: Good game after you can finally PLAY it.

author: Joe
review: While I love RDR2 and have played it on PS4, this game would simply not launch on my computer. Everything was poorly optimised; the game would crash due to memory errors, even though I had double the minimum requirement; general audio errors and more. On top of all of that, the external rockstar launcher would sometimes refuse to run the game. While I loved RDR2 on PS4, I simply cannot recommend it to anyone.

author: Thetoker47
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of the best story that Rockstar Games has ever developed. Details are very amazing, characters are easy to get along with, and easily one of the best games of this generation along side with Witcher 3 and God of War.A lot of people are claiming this game is very bland and boring because you ride with your horse and destination can take a long time. However, once you push through the story you won't stop playing the game. In Red Dead Redemption 2 there are features that makes things easier like the saving feature which you don't have to go back to camp to ensure your game is saved, fast travel system in game, and other side quest which is not repetitive and can be very interesting.You play as Arthur Morgan and you are apart of the Dutch's Van Der Linde Gang. A bunch of outlaws fighting for freedom after the incident that happen at Blackwater. Each chapter demonstrates what the Van Der Linde gang goes through to survive. As you progress in the story, you will see how each characters build up with emotions and connections.Do not go in this game and expect to be or have the same gameplay as Grand Theft Auto or any other Rockstar title. Yes gameplay can be similar but the story and some game mechanics are different.

Anyway I was super disappointed with my experience, not even 3 missions in and this game has crashed countless times with this ridiculous GFX crash. I've done everything seen online to no avail. I had to play some of the game on safe mode (windowed at 1280x720, at low settings). Ridiculous having to spend so much of money for so many problems. 9 months later and still no patch or update to make this disappear. Very disappointedUPDATEManaged to make the GFX error lest frequent and getting to play the game makes me realize how amazing it it: in gameplay, story, graphics. There is so much to do in this game it will be a long time until i get to finish it. I would still give it 4/5 stars cause any game you pay more than 80 CAD for, you shouldn't be getting errors often especially from a big company like Rockstar.

author: Ozzmoddious
review: The amount of time money and effort that went into making this game goes to show that Rock Star did not give any effort into making a decent port for PC. Single Player  runs terribly, Multiple black screens, infinite loading screens, buggy path finding, broken audio and a downright abysmal frame rate on SLI systems makes this a huge disappointment for me. And that's just on the Single Player mode.     To say Online is in a good place is a lie. The community has had major problems since GTAO and those same problems carry over to RDO. Hackers are abundant with overpowered weapons, speed hacks, aim bots and exploits. Forced online play is a joke and the idea that they removed private instances reeks of them selling it back to you like Bethesda did. On top of the random kicks that are clearly on Rock Stars end. A lot of the bugs from single player come to online as well. Broken animal spawns, audio bugs, broken screen tearing and bad hit boxes make playing with friends a chore. The “DLC” patches that you have to pay way too much for reeks of greed, and once start you run the risk of crashing out or having trolls one shot you even in defensive mode.  This game is a joke and needs to be seriously looked at if they want the cash-cow that GTAO is.

The online seems pretty cool so far as well but I haven't done too much in that yet.If your willing to test and see if it will work for you, go for it. Its worth it if it does.Otherwise maybe wait for some news on a patch or a fix for the crashing.I'm having fun with it so far though.10/10

author: andyf247
review: With over 160,000 reviews I feel it's not worth my time to give the usual level of depth that I give to gaming reviews as the chances of this being read are tiny. Instead I'll summarise that I believe RDR2 to be a true masterpiece, a gaming experience unlike anything I've ever had before and probably never will again and that Arthur Morgan is one of the greatest fictional characters of any genre ever conceived. Between the main story, the online mode and the hundreds of hours of optional content, this is one of the rare games that is truly worth every penny you spend for what it will give you in return. If you haven't played RDR1 then I strongly recommend watching a summary video of the story as it will greatly enhance your experience of RDR2

author: Danika
review: Well, here we are. I can honestly say that this has been one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. It took me well over 300 hours to 100% the game, though admittedly I took my time taking in all that the game has to offer. RDR2 is, by far, the most content-rich open world game that I have played, and I wish I could experience it all over again. Apart from the rare immersion-breaking bug, this is the most realistic game that I've seen to date and implemented some features that I've been longing for in games since forever, for example snow physics and a great looking, stable LOD.If The Witcher 3 amazed me with its world building and landscapes, RDR2 brought up the same feeling in me, but elevated it to a whole other level. Not only was the world beautifully designed, it really felt alive. Not just were the cities bustling with NPCs following everyday schedules, but the wilds were brimming with wildlife. And holy ♥♥♥♥ I commend Rockstar, there was so much effort put into the wildlife, with so many lifelike animals to observe and discover. The map itself is huge and full of places to explore, from ancient burial grounds to strange landmarks to abandoned shacks. There's so many little easter eggs and oddities scattered around the world, some of which haven't even been found out yet. There are also tons of challenges and sets of collectables to complete and the process of filling up my journal was very entertaining and satisfying. If you're a perfectionist/collector/achievement hunter like me, I can't think of a more perfect game for you, because there is a TON to do.As usual with Rockstar games, the characters and voice acting did not disappoint. There are so many well-made charismatic, lovable characters and a healthy dose of humour sprinkled throughout your interactions with them. Every single character that matters in this game feels human with their own flaws and problems. Arthur himself is an outstanding protagonist, a complicated (anti-)hero that undergoes some incredible character development as the game progresses. Going through this journey with Arthur is the most I could empathise with a story in any media in a long time. I'll even go so far as to say that Arthur Morgan is probably one of the best video game characters of all time.In my opinion, the story was fantastic. Without spoiling the details, it's about an outlaw gang in the late 19th century America trying to survive as the glory days of the Wild West are coming to an end. The tale was moving, and I have to admit, also pretty emotional. There were moments of elan after a momentous occasion, moments of exasperation and absolute tearjerkers. I enjoyed it very much, even if it did make me depressed as is usually the case after you finish a good story.Of course there were some gripes I had with RDR2. The game felt quite badly optimized for PC and the performance could definitely have been better. Graphical errors and crashes were quite abundant, so were connection issues on the Red Dead Online servers, which in the end I couldn't even be bothered with. As for the actual quests, in both story mode and online, they were nothing innovative or special and carried out in the usual Rockstar fashion. Similarly to GTA, most quests followed the formula of: go here, commence shootout with the baddies, collect the payment, escape, and repeat. So even in this late 19th century setting, Rockstar managed to make "steal a car" quests, only that the "cars" are horses and carriages.Overall however, my experience with RDR2 was one of a kind and I'll never forget the fun I had with this game. I was very pleased with RDR2's story mode and I do believe it's a masterpiece of a game. Hats off to the artists, the writers, the animators, voice actors and everyone who contributed to make this into the great game that it is."It's been quite a journey."

author: Big Bird
review: I had to make the choice between getting Doom:Eternal and this, and in the end I'm quite glad I chose RDR2. While RDR2, compared to GTA V, may be lacking in it's Online mode, it compensates through the well-crafted story and gameplay. You find yourself in the shoes of Arthur Morgan, an enforcer in the Van der Linde gang, a rogue's gallery of outcasts that desperately cling on to old-world ideals in a society that is quickly modernising. As the story progresses, the feeling of hopelessness, melancholia, and disillusionment begin resonating deeply as Arthur begins to question himself, and the values of his mentor. Without spoiling much, it all culminates in a cathartic finale that gives a satisfying and bona-fide end to the prequel chapter of Red Dead Redemption. As someone who was completely uninterested in GTA V's plot, RDR2 was a complete surprise; I found myself being immensely invested in the characters, the overarching storyline, and the  themes of change. Overall, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an exceptional title that doesn't just introduce an abundant amount of action, but also a heartfelt tale of the final days of the Wild West. You don't have to play the first Red Dead to get into this masterpiece, but if you have, it only makes the whole experience more bittersweet. Greatly recommend.

author: Aisakey [Baka-Mitai]
review: ABSOLUTELY UNACCEPTABLE. Rockstar is making the same mistakes again and again.So I have played GTA V, and I'm well aware of how it is plagued with cheaters ("modders" ? Whatever you call them, kids) who are free to ruin any session by using ridiculously obvious hacks that would have been unimaginable in any other game (changing weather, turning your player into objects, slaying you, etc.). Now I have bought RDR2, and I was hoping that somehow, Rockstar would have learned from their mistakes and made it more difficult to hack the game to the core in multiplayer. Well, I was completely wrong.I have only played about 4 hours, half of which I actually spent online. And I already had to leave a session because someone was able to set me on fire wherever I spawned, instantly killing me. And because they really couldn't care less about this problem, you have : 1) No easy way to report a player for cheating and 2) No way to LEAVE THE GAME or change server before you respawn. I actually had to Alt+F4 to be able to escape this situation.Seriously, what's the point of tolerating mods in RDR online ? Can't they use some kind of anti-cheat ? (Even games with the most basic hack protections could easily spot someone messing with the code in such obvious ways) This is especially sad considering this was released YEARS after a game which already had these issues from the start.I paid more than 40€ for this, and I am greatly disappointed. My advice : If you want to buy this thing, wait until it gets veeeeery cheap. Not worth a cent right now.

author: Bowie
review: What I consider doomed RDO was that they never added the Rockstar Editor like GTAO. If you’re not adding content for the players, just give the tools to the community and you’ll be surprised at how creative can people get. If they had let us create our own pvp matches, races, maybe a way to create gang hideouts or bounty missions, and maybe missions for the different roles... I’m sure the players would have come with stuff to keep the game feeling fresh between the sorely missed updates. I loved RDO, even if I considered it broken after missing so many of the features of the original RDR1 multiplayer. It was one of the most immersive worlds to get lost into. RIP.

author: Matt
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Changing my initial negative review because this game looks stunning. When a game is this big (150 GBs) let's understand there will be bugs in putting everything together. However, the game is certainly not overclock friendly and if you are struggling with error_gfx error you can try these steps that worked for me:If your game is crashing right on the start, delete the RDR2 folder FROM rockstar games. Enable cloud saves so that if it happens again, you have your saves.1) Make sure that you have latest windows updates.2) If you are running on an overclocked CPU, make sure that it is stable. 3) Install MSI afterburner-kombuster and test your GPU stability. If you have overclocked it already it could be causing the crash, try bumping down the core clock by 20 and memory by 100 each time. Hopefully this should fix your gfx error.4) If you get some frame stuttering, optimize it further by bumping down your core/memory clock.

author: caconym
review: It's the best-looking game I've ever played. I have a 1080, i7 6700K and 16 GB of memory and I get ~30-60 FPS, which is not great, but it's quality over quantity. I haven't seen any bugs or weird performance issues or anything like that.The graphics are somewhere between painterly and photorealistic. In a way it reminds me of BOTW (Zelda), though obviously a far greater amount of processing power is being thrown at it. Just beautiful, in a handcrafted way that transcends polygon count and texture resolution etcetera. Lots of handcrafted shaders here.What I've seen of the story is decent too. The characters are drawn fairly well, good voice acting, good cinematic presentation. Some of the missions feel like they aren't much more than delivery vehicles for dialogue.That brings me to the bad part: the gameplay. It's tedious. The dude walks *so* slow, and his "run" speed is constantly changing in arbitrary ways depending on where you are and what you're doing. All the animations are slow, and the dude controls like he's wading through molasses. I am not new to third-person cover shooters but I constantly find myself doing stupid stuff like getting behind the wrong cover or walking when I should be running, and it's mostly because there's no immediacy to the controls. Looting buildings is excruciating.There are too many systems. I feel like they really wanted to create an immersive experience, and it works sometimes, but just as often I find myself feeling like the game wants me to keep track of so many things and juggle so many menus and button presses (e.g. every time you get off your horse you have to go up to it and press some buttons or you'll find yourself without weapons when you need them) that it's just exhausting in a way that's destructive to immersion. I spent a bunch of money on a cool horse and a bunch of time feeding it apples and whatnot to build its trust and then some bandits spawned in front of me and headshotted me instantly and only later did I notice that when I died my horse had been replaced by one that looked similar but was actually new and worse... I think? I don't even *know* what happened to my horse. It did not feel good to have the game take that away in such an arbitrary and frustrating way without even explaining what happenedAnd *that* brings me to the combat: it sucks. It's bad mostly because of the aforementioned slow-as-molasses movement controls. I feel like I'm trying to control the dude with puppet strings. Sometimes enemies will just headshot you and you will die instantly, sometimes they are completely ineffective. I'm not expecting something arcadey like Gears, but look at e.g The Last of Us for movement and combat that's tense and fraught and messy without using comically slow movement and convoluted controls as a crutch to achieve "realism".I get that some people might really enjoy this sim-style gameplay, but it's not for me. Right now I'm pissed off at the game because it sucks me in with its beauty and then does something opaquely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and frustrating that makes me feel like a chump for trusting it. I don't know how much more of it I'll play.

author: Dat Feef
review: What can I say except that this is the biggest disappointment of 2019. Lets be clear; I think RDR2 the game is the best gaming experience of 2019. But the PC version just took a dump on everyone who bought it.The game itself is great. I had crashes but it wasn't because of the game (I'll get to that later). The game is gorgeous; simply breathtaking, no doubt, when I played hooked up to my 60" 4K TV. My beefy rig was able to run it maxed out at 4K at a solid 45 fps average. But by using the very good benchmark included with the game, I was able to fiddle around to get the game looking almost as good as maxed out but with an extra 10+ fps average.The only problem I had playing the game itself, when I was able to actually play it, was with the mushy mouse controls. No amount of fiddling with the ingame mouse sensitivity settings or my mouse's dpi settings was able to get it to feel right. I think I would have gotten use to it in a couple of hours; but I was not able to play for that much...And the reason is simple: greed. I know having your own launcher platform is the new craze in the industry; but come on! The Rockstar Launcher is a piece of garbage, and that's being generous. Shoehorning a launcher that's neither needed or wanted on the PC port of the best game of the year is just simply ridiculous. I mean; the launcher isn't even able to recognize the game's installation FFS!Preloading the game, installing it, installing the Rockstar Launcher, synching my Steam account with my existing Rockstar Social Club account, and booting up the game for the first time all went without a hitch. I was able to use the game's benchmark to get my optimal graphics settings and actually create a character for online and play for about 30 mins. Then the game crashed; and I wasn't able to get the game to start up again for almost 24 hours... all because of the Rockstar Launcher. Rockstar support has been less than useless and suggested that the solution for my problem is to redownload a 100+GB game... not gonna happen. Finally got in to the game again and then found out the character I spent 20 mins creating and through most of the beginning tutorial was deleted because the game crashed before I actually completed the tutorial. That was the last straw.Sorry for the wordy review; but I hope this helps to shed some light on what you're going to face if you buy this game. I would say wait a few months to see how things pan out then decide.

author: Not Pup
review: Ive played hundreds of games in my life, and the story single player isnt too bad, but the online is without doubt the worst made, glitchiest, hacker cesspool of a game i have ever seen in my life. Im not talking about the "hackers" where they pull off some one in a million shot and the victim being a poor sport yells HACKER! Im talking i got into a pvp match and a guy was flying around in godmode firing dynamite like a machine gun and blowing everything up within a 50 meter radius. Or when youre in the middle of a trader mission and you get teleported to the center of the map with every other player in the session, turns into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of gunfire and you inevitibly lose your cargo, your money, and your mission. Like how hard is it to set up SOME kind of anticheat? Then theres the glitches; got a mission to bring supplies to camp? Thats awesome; watch your camp disappear in front of you then you cant reset it up because it glitched itself into oblivion. Missions get glitched horses get glitched. Like ive played prealpha early release games on day one with less glitches. The economy is hot garbage. They pretty much force you to pay real money to buy gold in order to progress in ANY of hte roles. Unless you have 7 months of time to farm up the gold needed to even START a role. OR you can be one of the AFK asshats joining pvp missions for the microscopic gold output from doing pvp. They effectively prevent pvp missions from progressing because not enough people complete the task; being afk and all. And what gives in online mode; there is literally no role for a criminal? But they made a collector role? Who the hell wants to roam around collecting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ OVER being a bank robber? Like what? Huge miss. Bad all around. If you want to play online; dont get this. If you want to play the story and ONLY the story; you can get this but its not worth 60 bucksOh i almost forgot; the roles have ruined possis forever. You see only the possi leader can have a role active. You want to be a trader and they want to be a bounty hunter? Too bad. You cant do both. Whats worse; trader role is a passively wait for goods to build up afte ryou load cripps up. But you STILL HAVE TO BE POSSI leader to have them increase. So everyone just stays away from possis until theyre ready to go on a trade run; then they all join up get money and leave again. This game is outright awful if you wish to play with friends. Possi leader gets money; the rest of you do the work for him. Amazing gameplay; just like a real life ♥♥♥♥♥♥ job

author: STABBY
review: This is the greatest game I have ever played.Everyone has already gone on about how it has the most immersive open-world, godlike graphics/art direction, the most lifelike physics engine ever made, exquisite music and attention to detail, and that is all true, but I want to draw the attention to what really makes this game special: its connection to Red Dead Redemption 1.Most game sequels of this calibre completely neglect their previously established characters and story because they don’t have the confidence to try and build on them in case they flop and just make everyone hate their previous work as well, but Red Dead Redemption 2 is different. It actually HAS that confidence. And it delivers. This is the greatest video game narrative ever written. The choice to make it a prequel and tie it back to John Marston’s old days in the Dutch Van Der Linde Gang is hands down the BEST aspect of this game. It harkens back to characters you love, so you instantly have that connection and uses that context to establish new characters you’ll know and love as well. Arthur Morgan’s struggle with morality and the inevitable outcome of his actions is one of the most engaging gaming stories ever told and is a great successor to John Marston’s story which was also brilliant.

author: gnrlbudman
review: Single player works great.  Now the multiplayer sucks.  I can freeroam with no issues.  The instant I start doing a online story mission or any mission in online that involves multiple players to play it.  I get through the cut scene and into the game play and then disconnect.  I've port forwarded, I've shut off firewall and antivirus, I've changed my DNS and I've done lots of other crap.  I've played through the rockstar launcher and now through steam and it hasn't changed a thing.  This game has been out for years and it's the ONLY game in my library that does this.  It get a disconnect error of Ox21002001, saying that my internet speed is not consistant.  Yet my internet speed is 400+mb/s and my ping is 30 at average.  My friends have no issues with gaming online yet for some reason rockstar won't check to see if the issue is on their end for me.  Sorry but if this is the only game in my library that can't stay connected to a fast connection and I've done everything but a clean boot of my pc to make sure their game works.  Then the problem is on there end.  I don't recommend RDR2 Online and I'm kinda getting sick and tired of the way they treat their customers as cash cows.  If anyone has any ideas let me know.
