author: Aether
review: The single player experience is one of the best that I've seen in a game, and that's why I have to give a negative review.Picture two different objects: One, an elegantly crafted scepter with incredible structure, depth in its engraving, and created specifically for its user in mind, fits in your hands perfectly. It makes you feel good, strong, the world makes sense. The second, a giant, petrified turd roughly buffed into the shape of a diamond and set into your scepter in a way that you can't get rid of it.The single player game is so well crafted, so detailed, and so much thought was put into it. It was an incredible experience that I couldn't help but play until the end without stopping, and I really empathized with the characters, which is something very difficult for me to do in a game. It's in my top ten. It's a love letter to westerns and a pinnacle triple A title.The multiplayer, though, is a predatory mess that roughly uses the same systems to make a chore simulator that encourages you to spend real money to break up the tedium with even more tedium. It baits you with the single player and then draws you in to the same daily tasks week after week that amount to folding your laundry or making breakfast. There *are* some story missions here, and some interesting gameplay in the form of legendary missions, but otherwise its designed, like any other online rockstar game, to make you grind and encourage you to spend more money on TOP of the $60 you already spent for the game. It's only good if you have someone to play with you, and even then most of your tasks are going to be broken up by monotonous travel that lets you hold down a button for a second or shoot some people at the end. You better really like your friend.I can't condone pairing such scummy game practices with the masterpiece that is a single player, and that's why I'm recommending that for those of you who really want to experience it, borrow a copy. If you have a friend and want to play the multiplayer with them despite those warnings, play the single player in its entirety first, otherwise your experience is very likely going to be spoiled.

author: pfhorce82
review: The quality of the content is moot when you are unable to launch the game. Due to issues with Rockstar online services, the Rockstar launcher has been down for almost 24 hours now and it refuses to launch the game. This is a prime example of the dangers of publishers tying single-player games to online services. I did not experience any online elements during my first hours of gameplay, so there is absolutely no excuse for Rockstar not to support a proper offline mode. Thus, this game gets a thumbs down just for the Rockstar launcher.

author: [KEX]
review: Red Dead Redemption 2, developed by Rockstar Games, is an outstanding game that sets a new benchmark for open-world action games. From the game's immersive world design to its rich story, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece that will leave players captivated and immersed for hours on end.The game's world is a sprawling and detailed representation of the American West in the late 1800s. Every detail has been meticulously crafted, from the stunning landscapes to the bustling towns and cities. The game's attention to detail is truly breathtaking, and it is clear that the developers have poured their hearts and souls into creating this immersive world.One of the game's strongest aspects is its story. The narrative follows the character of Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van der Linde gang, as he navigates the changing times of the Old West. The story is masterfully crafted, with complex characters and a deep sense of emotional depth that is rarely seen in video games. The game's themes of loyalty and morality are expertly woven into the story, making for a truly unforgettable experience.The game features a vast cast of complex, characters that are expertly crafted and brought to life by outstanding voice acting and character design. These characters are not merely archetypes, but rather fully-realized individuals with unique personalities, motivations, and backstories that make them relatable and interesting to anyone.The game's gameplay mechanics are also exceptional. The shooting and combat mechanics are well-designed and satisfying, with a range of different weapons and strategies available to the player. The game also features a range of different activities and side missions, from hunting and fishing to robbing banks and trains. The variety of gameplay options ensures that players will never get bored, and there is always something new and exciting to discover.The game's graphics are also outstanding, with stunning visuals that bring the game's world to life in breathtaking detail. From the rustling leaves of the forests to the gritty dirt roads of the towns, the game's environments are truly stunning and a testament to the power of modern gaming technology.Overall, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a true masterpiece and truly one of the greatest games of all time. Its immersive world, rich story, and exceptional gameplay mechanics make it a must-play for any fan of action games or Westerns. It is a testament to the power of video games as a storytelling medium, and a true work of art that will be remembered for decades to come.

author: Nasty
review: You cant in good faith write a review of such a tittle in just a few hours of gameplay.This game has its own pace. Respect that. Great environment and so far a interesting story. That says a lot of the game you have in front of you.Havent tried online yet, cause Im still trying to hunt a perfect rabbit hide! Sadly not as optimized as GTA V.Too price.Some bugs and glitches. None of them are game breaking.* Whats up with the controls?*If I didnt knew better I would say this game was ported from a console or something like that. This controls dont make sense from a PC point of view.I recommend this!

author: Kovic
review: How to Make Vanilla Cupcakes:These cupcakes are easy to master and you will be making bakery-quality cupcakes in no time.In a medium bowl, whisk together dry ingredients: flour, baking powder, and salt.In a second bowl (or bowl of your stand mixer), beat together softened butter and sugar on medium-high speed 5 minutes until thick and fluffy.Beat in eggs 1 at a time, mixing to incorporate with each egg then blend in vanilla and scrape down the bowl.Reduce mixer to medium speed and add the flour in thirds, alternating with adding the 1/2 cup buttermilk and beating well between additions.Pour batter into 12 lined muffin tins, filling 2/3 full. Bake in the center of the oven at 350˚F for 20-23 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Let cool 5 minutes in the pan then remove cupcakes to a wire rack to cool completely.

author: CameronW02
review: One of the best story games ever made.  Easily in my top 3 games of all time. Never felt so enamoured with a story. Each character is unique and beholds an interesting backstory. The mechanics are very well presented and bring a unequivocal sense of fun and exploration. It follows a great deal of depth, encapsulating many emotions. Prosperity, hope, greed, disillusion, leadership; yet the list continues. Combat lacks in a sense but that is to be expected with Rockstar, whilst it is de-emphasised, it is enjoyable thanks to the Dead-Eye feature, allowing for cinematic kills. The online is very poor and a generally lacklustre experience. The heavy emphasis on micro-transactions ruins the experience. With a severe lack of content and excitement to be had, it is worth a miss in my opinion. The story alone in RDR2 makes it worth purchasing, and the online section of the game should not even be held in the same regard. It is easily one of the best games ever produced.

author: Majkel
review: I just don't know what to say. This game is just... perfect. It has everything. Insane and mind blowing details, very good graphic level that is hard to find in other games with that good performance. Heart breaking story, and many activities to do after end game. Thats what i'm saying. As always next words will be a bigger review with no spoilers and at the end is summary.Set in Rockstar’s most authentic and lived-in open world ever, there are so many things to do, so many people to meet, and so many places to explore it’s giddily overwhelming. Red Dead Redemption 2 isn’t just Rockstar’s greatest achievement to date; it’s a game so lacking in compromise it’s tough to know where best to start discussing it.It’s 1899 and American outlaws are an endangered species. Dutch van der Linde and his gang are on the run after a botched heist in the growing town of Blackwater and they’ve retreated high into the mountains where an atrocious blizzard is covering their escape. We slip into the spurs of Arthur Morgan, an exceedingly cool and capable outlaw who was found by Dutch as a boy and raised on the wrong side of the law, and settle in for a roughly 60-hour story.The ability of this game to keep itself fresh after so many hours is extraordinary, and not entirely due to just the size and diversity of the world; it’s how alive all of those places feel. While the largely rural world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is far less dense than the likes of Grand Theft Auto V, it’s absolutely brimming with wildlife to discover, people to interact with (and potentially help), and places to scrutinise. The best kind of open worlds are those that seem almost indifferent to your presence in them; like life goes on whether you stick your nose into proceedings or not.The slower pace of Red Dead Redemption 2 compared to something like the slightly more breakneck GTA V is also a big part of how it encouraged me to drink in all the world has to offer. Bodies have to be manually looted, and Arthur needs to physically manhandle a body to do so. Single-action pistols need to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ before firing. Guns Arthur isn’t currently carrying need to retrieved from his saddle. Coffee needs to be brewed before drinking it.At any rate, it’s seriously worth settling into the pace Rockstar is trying to set here because there’s just so much to see and hear. You’ll hear unique, one-time conversations that occur in camp after certain missions, as well as other bespoke bits of dialogue that reference recent events. Strolling through camp, I’ve been privy to everything from a heated bust-up between John Marston and his partner, Abigail, to the good-natured con man Hosea Matthews regaling the young Jack Marston with stories of his latest fishing adventure. This is all happening around Arthur whether you pause to eavesdrop or not. It makes the camp feel like a concentrated version of the world at large, a place with people going about their business and interacting with one another completely independently of you. I can’t understate the genuine feeling of life this injects into the overall experience for me.IT'S JUST A MASTERPIECE! JUST BUY IT AND DON'T THINK.🎨 GRAPHIC 🖌✅ BEAUTIFULL | 2 points☐ GOOD | 1 point☐ MEH | 0.5 points☐ TERRIBLE | 0 points🧯 GAMEPLAY 🏹✅ BETTER THAN LIFE | 2 points☐ AMAZING | 1 point☐ AT ALL IT'S OK | 0.5 points☐ SO BAD | 0 points🎵 MUSIC\SFX 🎼✅ FIND IT ON SPOTIFY | 2 points☐ WANNA DANCE | 1 point☐ NOT INTERESTING | 0.5 points☐ MAKES GAME WORSE | 0  pointsBUGS☐ TOO MUCH | -2 points☐ MANY | -1 point☐ CAN LIVE | -0.5 points✅ NONE | +1 point🛴 MECHANICS 👾✅ FORGET REAL LIFE | 2 points☐ SOMETHING NEW | 1 point☐ CLASSIC | 0.5 points☐ NOTHING WAS INVENTED | 0 points📤 UPDATES  👨‍🎤☐ MANY | 1 point☐ SOMETIMES | 0.5 points✅ NEVER | 0 points+ (PROS) ➕ FOR EVERY "+" IS 0.5 points (CAN'T GO HIGHER THAN 10)+ MIND BLOWING STORY+ SATISFYING TO PLAY THE GAME (KILL, ROB, JUST RIDE A HORSE)+ MANY THINGS TO DO BUT NOT LIKE IN UBI-GAMES+ UNIQUE QUESTS AND MISSIONS- (CONS) ⚡ FOR EVERY "-" IS -0.5 points (CAN'T GO LOWER THAN 1)- FORGOTTEN MULTIPLAYERSUMMING UP, Red Dead Redemption 2 DESERVES ASSESSMENT: 10/10POINTS:2+2+2+1+2+0+2-0,5=10,5 CAN'T GO HIGHER THAN 10, IT'S JUST MASTERPIECEIf you still here you have to know that you wont regret buying it

author: AG操完灰梦泪
review: Red Dead Redemption 2, an absolute beautiful game made by Rockstar. The amount of details that was part of the game makes it worth the 540 million that Rockstar has put in. The map is massive which features cities, small towns, deserts and snowy mountains. The graphics of the game is insane and sometimes you can't see the different between it and real life. Red Dead 2 feels more like a movie than a game due it is brilliant story line, sad but often realistic.Spoilers: When Hosea died, it was when everything was going bad, like how Arthur said he missed his Wisdom. Dutch started to get fooled by Micah. When I heard Arthur had tuberculosis and it wasn't possible to take a rest and get to places warm I was depressed that both the game is coming towards an end and Arthur is dying. When I found out it was Micah who told I was really angry and pissed just wanted to kill him. I thought Dutch would always be on Arthur's side, but i realised things has changed now Dutch is no much the old Dutch, he doesn't care about his gang anymore he is like Micah. I was despaired when I saw Dutch walking toward Micah. I cried at when Arthur said you are my brother to John and also when he died, his true Redemption. Arthur might be an outlaw and might not be the smartest but he is always kind to others."Face me towards to the west so I watch the setting sun and remember all the fine times when had"

author: Heretiko
review: Had my fair bit of game experience by now. Long from finished yet, but here what i think so far.I've escaped pursuit from rival bandit gang through the snow; I've hunted legendary animals; i've been arrested for starting a brawl after being p1ss drunk at the saloon; i've stolen carriages and sold them; i've murdered people who owned money to my boss; i've saved my ex's young brother from an ugly destiny; i've camped in the middle of nowhere under the stars; i've rode anywhere with my horse and escaped death multiple times;I think this game is not merely a cowboy simulator: instead it's an experience. I've never played a game where the characters seemed so alive to me and Arthur makes me crack up everytime he speaks. It's more like an interactive movie and it's so deep and rich and complex.Please play it.

author: MNi
review: Phenomenal, absolutely phenomenal. Immersion and attention to detail unparalleled by any other game so far. If you're interested at all in the Wild West genre then this is the game that trumps em all. I highly recommend to use ReShade and find a decent preset on Nexus Mods. It changes the game into something photorealistic. (Haven't used it on Online so I can't say if that'll ban you but I would turn ReShade off if you were playing Online)Only complaints are that this game requires an internet access to start, which doesn't make sense as I only touch the amazing story, and a bug that seems to have appeared from the latest Online mode patch that makes it so that everyone at camp will keep telling you to wear warmer clothing despite wearing the warmest of artisan coats. Also originating from the previous patch, when starting up the game the audio for the game is at the lowest point which is annoying but fixable by going into the volume mixer.EDIT: Seems the cold bug and audio issues were fixed with the recent RDO update.Other than that it's an excellent experience and it is not often that video game characters can teach you something.10/10 Story mode.P.S Check Hardware Unboxed's optimization guide for the best experience.

author: TheLordBailish
review: I started playing this game sometime last June or July and got about 18 hours in and then gave up on it. Even though I was really enjoying the story; it was moving too slow for me, and the gameplay grated on my nerves.About two months ago, I decided to pick it back up again. I downloaded it and launched my save, but when I started playing, I had no idea what was going on or even how to play anymore. So I decided to start over.I still struggled with the slower pace of the game. The cutscenes were long, and even though I enjoyed the character interactions, the gameplay—specifically when dealing with looting and such—was irritating because of the slower animations, and the fact that the game actively punishes you for being a prick. (I was playing as a bloodthirsty monster who killed everyone I came across)So at some point, right around the time you finish things around Valentine, I decided to just slow down. Just relax and enjoy the scenery and story.And that’s when this game clicked for me.I’m so used to playing games where you constantly have stuff trying to grab your attention, and there’s constantly things going on. So in this game, when things aren’t happening constantly, it gets kind of boring.But when I slowed down and tried change my mindset, this game really showed it’s strengths. The point of the game isn’t to run around doing whatever you want, killing innocent people and robbing everyone you see (though you can). The point is to immerse yourself in the characters and their story.I decided to really put myself in Arthur’s shoes and experience the world as he did. I started doing everything at a slower pace. I started actively trying to be the “good guy”, and helped people I came across instead of killing them immediately. It became obsessive to the point that I was more concerned about being a good person than helping the gang.When I did this, I started to appreciate the all the things that annoyed me before. I really felt like I was the one going through this story; like I was Arthur. Where most games it feels like you’re just an observer.And I gotta say, this game blew my mind. The story had me sucked in all the way through. It was surprisingly emotional to me.One scene that comes to mind specifically is one of the missions with Mary.  This mission in particular stands out to me for a couple reasons. It really showed the emotional stakes to the story. was much more emotional than I expected.The other thing it showed was the amount of effort the development team put into every facet of the game. The theater had actual acts that you could sit and watch that legitimately entertained me. Most other games I’ve played would have just had a cutscene of them walking in and then back out; but Rockstar actually voiced and animated it all.The other thing that I loved about this story was the gradual shift in dynamic between The whole final act with After Anyway, this whole game is just a work of art and I was blown away by how much I enjoyed it. I haven’t played the first one, but I’m on PC and don’t want to buy a whole console to play it. Pretty please, Rockstar, will you do a remaster or at least port it to PC?

author: Bled
review: The year is 2012,  millions of players around the world have been eagerly anticipating the last installment of the Mass Effect Trilogy.  Within hours of release, the first signs of bitterness begin to surface on the internet regarding a short, unsatisfactory ending to BioWare's otherwise beautifully crafted series.  I was upset too.  How could a beloved company create a trilogy so immersive and entertaining, and then misjudge the last fifteen minutes so poorly?  Rightfully, thousands of fans were calling for an update, asking BioWare to give their story a proper send off.  I remember responses from several developers; "BioWare shouldn't cave in to this pressure, video games are art, they need to be respected as the artist's original vision."I had a very agitated response.  It was laughable to me.  Video games are not art.  Video games are meant to be played and enjoyed based on several merits including graphics, gameplay, animations, story, and several more based on the genre.  It's ridiculous, as with any product, your goal is to make the consumer happy, and if you didn't do that, you failed.  McDonald's can't put out a horrible new burger and hide behind claims that it's art and satisfy the public -- it's the same for games.The year is 2018.  Red Dead Redemption 2 is art.

author: Springbee
review: This game is absolutely fantastic. The story starts off slow but amps up once you get past the basic tutorial sections you will be left laughing, crying, crying some more, and feel like justice has been done. I binged this game all 47 hours of mine (so far) in about a couple of weeks because I wanted to see how it ended. Highly recommend it. It is similar to GTA in a way but with a much better story and an honor system which I really liked. In GTA games you can pretty much kill or steal whomever and nothing happens but in this game doing anything like that will lower your honor and will change the way the story goes and how it ends. The characters are probably the highest point as everyone has fully fleshed out personalities and you do start to really care for them and what happens to them.I do want to address all the comments about the game not running on their PC due to the game not being optimized. I ran everything on high settings, had a constant 60 fps and never any stutter or frame drops ever. I will say that I do have very good specs on my PC (Intel Core i7-6700K 4 GHz, 16 GB of RAM, GTX 1070) so that definitely helped so I can't compare my experience to others. Looking at the other comments with it not running if your PC doesn't have great specs I would skip this. You could always try it and find out and return it on Steam if it doesnt work for you. Hopefully R* will fix the optimization on this game.

author: Shroomhead
review: The game is amazing, but Rockstar's greed made a lot of PC users sad, mad & etc.Here's the story:Trying to grab maximum amount of cash, they released PC version of the game during one of the best sales periods. Look's like they've got to made a quite good amount of work here, but decided to release it earlier to keep cash flowing, get some free QA reports from users, that actually paid for complete game (not for the pre-release beta) and then fix the bugs later, during sales. I've waited for a steam version for some time, than kept waiting few more weeks and decided to buy it, hoping they fixed a lot of troubles people reported at start. I've installed the game and first 3 launches caused crashes even before game's starting screen loaded. Then I've reseted game's configuration using rockstar's safe mode and get into it. After ~16 hours of game experience I've got ~15 crashes refered to my graphic adapter (RX590) due to error screen info. I've lost 2 saves, when game crashed at the end of different missions when it used to save, look's ike save files were corrupted and loading game using them caused infinite loading screens, so I've decided to restart my story mode again - this story teached me to make some saves by myself from time to time. I've also spotted that one of side missions was causing repetative crashes when I was tring to explode dynamite at the pile of ♥♥♥♥ near Granger's house - the same moment of crash, exactly at the moment of detonation. Then I used to read forums and I've spotted that most of my crashes were caused by Aorus Engine and usage of Vulcan settings for graphics - game doesn't work properly with overclocking tools, as well as with Vulcan, especially when they're combined. Using DX12 I've been able to pass Granger's mission succesfully, avoidiong most of other crashes during 2 hours of playing. I would test it further, but for now:I'm not recommend buying this game at it's current state - I think developers got to fix most of the major/critical issues, as well as few I've described earlier. It's sick releasing such a great game with such a great price and such a great bugs. Just wait for a fixes and enjoy it as it should be. Let them do their job they've got to do earlier before game's release on PC.UPD1. I've seen an amazing thing - settings I've done last time for graphic adapter were randomly changed after reboot. Now the game is uplayable and starting with 7-8 fps no matter what I try. Wonderful!UPD2. Most of the issues fixed and the game is waiting for you.

author: supernaut
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is a culturally significant work of art that should be preserved and archived. It should be backwards compatible with every equivalent device and OS that will be released in the future, so that it doesn't collect dust in said archive or be available only to a select audience as the original Red Dead Redemption. It's time that we bring the same level of care and respect to video game preservation as we do with motion pictures. I would name other titles that should get the same treatment, but comparison is the death of joy. This is bigger than Take-Two and Rockstar Games, it's not just an IP that has sold over 50 million units, it's not shareholder-porn or a toy for children, it's art. From Pong to RDR2, there's a bit of a leap there, so in a way it's the result of over 45 years of trailblazing. If a banana taped to a wall is considered art, then this is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ art. Red Dead Redemption 2 takes an honest and self-reflective look on a young nation through a personal journey of a gang of outlaws. The outlaw way of life very much lives on today, but these people saw themselves as a dying breed in the face of lawful civilization and the industrial revolution. Romanticizing gangsters or outlaws is not everyone's cup of tea, which is understandable, but I believe most people are not beyond redemption. If Vince Gilligan made it possible relate to Walter White, then you should be able to relate to Arthur Morgan. While bestowing it all of this praise, I'm not suggesting this is a perfect game. The game's inventory needs refining, there are too many collectible strands and I need reasons to own and spend the tens of thousands of dollars I accumulate, to give you a more personal list. Open world games are a difficult balancing act and Red Dead Redemption 2 is probably the closest to a perfectly balanced open world experience. Be it an indie game made by one or two people or a game made by 3,023 people, to get the necessary funding, the talent and ideas together in time and produce a landmark, generation-defining title is the result of an obscene amount of luck and there are no winning formulas to keep a genre from stagnating. Every developer should ask of themselves: "What are we saying with this game?"It's hard to write about the characters and the story without going into spoiler territory, so I'll do it in more broad strokes as best I can. Continue at your own peril. This is a prequel to a game with a different protagonist, John Marston, who's also introduced in RDR2 in a big way. Arthur Morgan is an iconic character that rivals its big-screen equivalents played by Eastwood. Arthur's facial animation clearly gets the most attention here; Roger Clark's performance is pivotal in bringing this highly detailed world and its great story together. Arthur is the counterbalance to Dutch, the gang's leader, Arthur's father figure, a narcissist intent on digging his own grave and willing to bring down everyone with him. But he's not alone in that, his mind is further twisted by the snakes around him. Arthur is loyal within reason, ultimately kind in his unlawful ways, if that's the path you take. He's uneducated but has wisdom, he takes time to think, but is helpless in trying to keep a dysfunctional family on the right path. He's not alone in his attempts, he gets help and guidance from Hosea, Charles, John and Lenny, while Sadie Adler could easily have her own spin-off game. Dutch has the allure of a seasoned preacher and the looks of Colonel Sanders in negative. He's the man with the plan and he tells everyone to have faith in his plan. No one is held prisoner, in a 'sinking ship' sort of way.If you're going to invest 50-200 hours in an open world game, at least one of them ought to be this one. It doesn't overstay its welcome or careen into monotony and soulless completionist exploration. It's immersive as Skyrim and Witcher 3 and in many ways more so. As Witcher 3 it looks better than most games released today, which is not bad for a 4+ year-old game. It'll still look amazing another 5 years from now, so as you upgrade you can push it further. I got genuinely emotional playing this to the end, alongside hours spent on fishing and hunting, simply because Arthur Morgan is so beautifully realized as a character and without Roger Clark, who was robbed of many a award, this entire Western adventure would start to crumble. I don't mean to undersell Dutch van der Linde, played by Benjamin Byron Davis, cos one doesn't exist without the other, but they really lucked out with Roger Clark. One person simply can't make something on this scale and detail, so for now it takes a village of 3,023.

author: Ciggy Rat
review: I sincerely believe Red Dead Redemption 2 is the most impressive game ever made, or at least that I've ever played. It is not my favorite game, and I do partially understand why a lot of people have some problems with it but I honestly can barely process how good of an experience it was, even on my low spec PC.The game presents peak storytelling matched with a very appropiate and solid soundtrack, an unparalleled graphic aspect, incredibly inmersive world full of details and complex NPC interactions like we've never seen before (and have not seen again since, to the day I'm writing this), powerful intense action and equally strong slow paced touching moments, full of well written dialogue, flawless voice acting, and beautiful scenery.RDR2 is not perfect, and it will at times restrain your options whilst trying to make you believe that you are free to make any decision. It may hold your hand a lot through it all, yes. But if you let the game guide you through the astonishing world it features, a world that seems to never stop showing you new things when you thought you had seen them all. If you take your time to hear what is being said. If you take a minute to behold the world around you. In summary, if you play along...You will get a great journey, one of the best I've ever played through

A cowboy game that really lets you horse around, pun intended. Unless it's the story missions. TL;DR: It's really good, but the gameplay is at odds with the story, which could have probably been shorter. If you like wild west media in general or open world games, it's definitely worth a try even if you are just going to mess around and not finish a story(only 20.3% of people did on Steam actually). Visually, it's (mostly) beautiful, especially considering how huge the open world is, with some worse textures here and there. A lot of care went into animations, the cutscene animations are especially worth mentioning, and many little details that make the world seem more lived in. Apparently horse balls shrink in the cold, but as I am not weird, I haven't actually checked.  Though admittedly, being an 2018 game, it's showing some age. It's also worth mentioning that game uses checkerboard-rendering, which causes visible artifacts in hair and fur. The only solutions are to either use TAA(which makes everything blurry and makes it look worse) or much higher rendering resolution. The DLSS isn't that amazing in this game and makes the hair artifacts worse.Sound-wise, I have nothing wrong to say about this, everything is essentially perfectly spot on.The gameplay by itself is good, though dated with some more immersive elements like looting animations or skinning or animal as well as some survival mechanics such as eating. The survival mechanics are pretty shallow and really more for some immersion like I said or minor roleplaying.What also helps roleplaying is really wide array of customization options - hair, beard(both growing in real time) or clothes. And boy, there is a huge variety of clothes to choose from as well, so you can play the cowboy dress-up game too if you want to.The world is beautiful, with a lot to hunt and explore. It has quite a few side story missions that are usually pretty funny and nice diversion from the main plot. The story is about a gang of more noble outlaws during the ending years of the Wild West, as the country was becoming more and more civilised. The fact that you can't fight the progress and change is a large thematic part of the game, whether it's the the law trying to end the outlaw life, or the gang itself being against old values such as slavery.It's well written for the most of it, but sometimes characters killing 40-50 people during as story missions feels really off for the kind of story it's trying to tell. Other times there are some AWFUL story conveniences that are just straight up irritating with villains escaping in awkward manner. Though that did sound more negative than positive, the story is definitely worth experiencing, though could probably be bit shorter to be paced better.I haven't played the multiplayer component, as I heard it's pretty grindy and I already have an actual job, so yeah.If you can buy it on sale, which is lately usually 50% off, it's a really good deal. I don't think I'd want to pay 60 for it.

author: ThaCrypte
review: This game... It's easely the best game I've ever played.It took me a while to consider buying the game as there were a lot of launch issues on the pc, and I've heard the game was "too realistic" in the sense that some stuff is just... grindy and repetative (e.g. cooking, crafting). Man was I wrong.I bought the game, and started getting along. In the beginning it's some getting used to but the game sure shows it's graphical beauty. I started fiddling with graphical settings to make the game look really good yet not /as/ demanding given that my poor RX480 only gave me 21 fps when I maxed out the game. I managed to still get a REALLY good looking game running at 40 fps. The story.... It made me laugh, cry, angry, and so much more. I won't go into detail but the story is straight up 10/10. Some characters are forgettable as in they're not oftenly encountered or spoken with, however all characters are unique. Most characters though will stick in your mind and you'll actually feel some bond with them. I experienced maybe 2-3 crashes of which 1 was annoying because I had to re-play a mission but other than that it ran pretty stable. P.S.: I didn't look up anything before playing the game and just jumped in, and I reccomend everyone to do the same. You'll get to experience an emotional rollercoaster that get's you 60h of high quality content (story) and possibly even more.

author: davesaint88
review: I initially enjoyed this game. Tons of stuff to do and collect. Tons of stuff to see. Good story, god voice acting. The problem is that rockstar has made the single player portion of this game unplayable if you can't connect to their servers. I personally don't care about multiplayer. I perfer single player games, and it is an atrocity that I can't play it when their servers are offline. I'm really sick of this idea in gaming that everything has to have an embedded multiplayer setup. It makes people like me, who prefer to play the single player campaign, a bit upset that I spend hard earned money on this awesome game, that also has the misfortune to be infected with the disease of multiplayer garbage.

author: inkyblackfire
review: I'd love to say I recommend this game. I've been saving for it for a while and waited the moment I can play it with anticipation. It's still objectively very pretty, nicely voice acted, interesting story-wise. BUT I do not recommend a game that doesn't launch on win7 even if minimum requirements say it should be able toI do not recommend a game where support team cannot help me fix the launching issue no matter what they tryI do not recommend a game which I bought mainly for the online mode which keeps randomly disconnecting making me lose rewards in this already overly grindy modeI do not recommend a game which I bought for a lot of gold mainly for a poorly working online mode and now the same mode is being released separately for a lot less gold. There's far too many bugs for a far too high price. There's a faint risk you won't be able to play it at all if you don't have another machine you can run it on, all due to mysterious activation error. So go ahead and buy it if you like to gamble.

author: akroessler
review: EDIT; Now that some time has passed, updates have made actually playing the game possible again. The game is now enjoyable as was originally planned, Looks great on 4k. It seems some optimization has occurred as well, I run an I7-4930K, 6 core 12 thread (OC 4.4ghz) with an EVGA 1080ti on full custom water, and I get averaged just over 50 fps in 4k while playing single player. Have spent 2 hours trying to get the game to launch without crashing. You must have the rockstar launcher in order for it to work, which defeats the purpose of Steam entirely, so I'm glad i waited the extra month for no reason. When the game opens, it crashes because it cant connect to the Social Club, even though everything is connected outside of game. I was hoping this would be fixed for the month of "FIXES" Rockstar has been claiming they've been doing, and an optimization probably would be beneficial since people with 1080ti/2080ti and 9900k's cant get more than 40 FPS. Just absolute garbage.

author: Fiireside
review: **SPOILER FREE**The actual gameplay elements (combat, looting, crafting etc) are all sub par/mid, and usually this would be a deal breaker for me. However, there are 2 elements in this game that make it one of the best I've ever played.Firstly, the story. It's honestly like playing out a movie. Masterfully written with a consistent tone and a damn gripping plot. The characters are all rich in intrigue and personality, your band of outlaws FEELS like a family. The cast of VAs are exceptional, the dialogue makes every interaction feel exciting and refreshing.Secondly, the world itself. I'd never played a video game where the environment didn't feel like a game at all, and instead it felt almost real. Until I played this game. The landscape is gorgeous, and changes perfectly as you're driven from region to region. There's wildlife everywhere, fellow travellers on the road, towns, mountains, valleys, lakes, and one random dude who somehow always manages to get bitten by a snake (gotta suck the venom out for him every damn time). 9.5/10(It's really THAT good)

author: Stampe
review: Just played through the campaign. I can say that this is one of the very few single player games that I've played for several hours and never got the blockdown of saying to myself; 'why the ♥♥♥♥ am I just wasting my time on doing this ♥♥♥♥, this isn't worth it.' After that I usually just alt+f4 and then go wash my hands and sit and be sad. But I just played several hours in a row and I was just into it and both enjoying the visuals and the story. The graphics are lovely but there are a decent amount of physics issues in the game even though I played it on ultra which kinda breaks immersion at times, but not too often in my experience. The story is lovely and the side quests are absolutely lovely and I found myself doing all the sidecontent I could find. I can even recommend buying it at full price which I haven't done since Fallout New Vegas. Go ahead and have fun, qts <3

author: A2
review: TL;DR : If you are looking for a game which can offer you an massive open world, full of adventures journey with random events, massive set of quests and treasure hunts with western outlaw style, this is the game for you.Also, I have few non-spoiler game-play tips at the end, so if you are interested, take a look.================ Detailed Review================NOTE :This review is done only from the single player/story mode prospective. All the points mentioned are strictly my opinion only and my take of this game. It may or may not give you the same experience as mentioned here.============== My Experience==============On 26th December 2019, Along with this game I bought and installed few other games too, but since then this is the only game I ended up spending 17+ hours and still counting.========= Pointers=========To put it in 3 words, "A Rare Masterpiece"The game has 2 different modes,1.	Story Mode/Single player2.	Multiplayer/OnlineIn Story mode, the game revolves around main protagonist, named Arthur. You play as Arthur who is an important part of an outlaw gang.What this game has to offer?Game has huge offerings, in terms of player engagement.1.	Main Story Driven Gameplay : For Story driven fans2.	Quests : To help player boost/unlock some attributes3.	Side Missions : To make available few items/skills earlierBesides the vanilla/default game mechanics?what makes a PC game more fun? "Mods". Though Rockstar doesn't officially support mods, they also do respect the creativity approached by their fans to the game, as far as it stays in offline/story mode only.Source - ============ Pros & Cons============Pros.1. Open-world Massive and Beautifully crafted Open-world(From Icy mountains to muddy swamps)2. Story - Amazing & well paced story line3. Player Attributes - Well balanced player characteristics and attributes and practical at the same time. E.g. If player is in snow surrounded area and doesn't have winter clothes on it will affect it's health and cores.4. Interactable Objects - Tons of Guns and Ammunition, Horses(your primary medium of transportation), Tonics and edibles, Loots etc.5. Gameplay - Smooth and versatile. Game doesn't forces you a character oriented story, but rather lets you decide, who you want to be.5. Apart from Main Story line - Tons of things to do apart from missions(Hunting & skinning, Fishing, Horse Riding, Crafting, Cooking and much more)6. Optimization - Very well optimized for PC7. Music - None other than "Woody Jackson"(aka composer for Red Dead Redemption, GTA V, Max Payne 3, L.A. Noire). Great situation and world adaptive music. I would say, its one of those games, where the BGM/and other sound effects takes the gameplay to the whole new level, Try it with Headphones8. Random stuff in the game - Very well done in this regards, Imagine, you are on your way to start a new mission, and you have a stranger asking for help in the midway, Do you really want to help? It could be a trap, or are they genuine?9. Realistic Touches - Be that your beard growth, be that your hair growth, be that a hunt you have skinned leaving a bloody spots on your right/left shoulder. One just can amaze to see how much work does Rockstar have put into. One of the most realistic games I've played. And loved it.10. Apart from default game-play - Still looking for more? Single Player / Offline Mods? Does that answer the point? There are limitless possibilities with this section, as community has so much to offer and people are awaiting for a lot to grasp to.Cons.1. Key binding - If you are playing it on PC, I would very highly recommend to play it with keyboard and mouse. As game-play can be really frustrating at times if you are playing with controller.2. Hard Mechanism - "Easy to learn, Hard to Master." The game is a whole eco-system in itself and grasping everything at once can be really tough. There are Ledgers, Documents, Skill trees, Diary, Inventory System and much more.================ Final Take-away================Well, if it's not clear so far, let me repeat, the game itself is amazing and really one of a kind. There are few restrictions and the game is very hardware demanding, but again, it has to be that way. The game has so much to offer to.The has massive open-world, There are literally individual systems made for each aspect, Player characteristics, Skill tree, Camp and it's requirements, NPCs, Livestock(Including your horses, which has bonding mechanics, just like real-life),============================ Do You Recommend This Game?============================Yes, I absolutely recommend this game. I only recommend if your hardware meets minimum specifications. This is more kind of a game, which one needs to enjoy it while exploring and playing.================= Non-Spoiler Tips=================Here are few of the tips I found very helpful myself, and thus sharing it here. It may/may not help you in your game-play.1. DO NOT RUSH INTO THE FINISHING THE GAME - Sorry about the caps, but I've seen many players who are just in a rush to complete the story mode and to reach to an end. I would very very highly recommend do not do that. There are many side missions which are associates to the main story mission. What I mean by that, once you complete story missions(Marked with Yellow area) the side missions(marked with White area) might not be available later on in the game.2. Try to Explore the world  by Horse-riding - I would suggest to explore the area and complete your journey using your horse/s, and not by using fast-travel or any other types. Due to 2 specific reasons.    i. While exploring the area using horse/on foot, there are many random events you run into, some of them are really very important at the early game stages    ii. The beautiful scenery is one to fall in love with.3. The game becomes tedious? - Well, the game takes practical approach so it has to be tedious. You being the part of the group, you have few responsibilities. In order to make your group survive, you have duties to feed the camp(By Hunting), to provide the medical resources, to provide the money, to provide the guns and AmmunitionAnd the game exactly becomes tedious here, as most of the player end focusing just one approach. They either will try to finish the game and all the missions and later will end-up only hunting or fishing.Instead, I would suggest to mix and have the perfect blend of approach, here, how I play, i. I usually start from my camp in the morning by completing few of the chores at camp(Emptying Bucket full of water etc.) ii. Then I go up to campfire to have a bowl of stew, This helps restoring the cores and attributes iii. Then up-to horses, I start by cleaning them(by using brush or by riding it threw a water source) and then by feeding them. iv. I usually take 2 horses(one I ride and the other one follows me) iv. After that, I pick side-missions(if there are any), or mission v. Ride to that mission(by completing random events if there are any) vi. performing and completing the mission(this usually end-up consuming 1/4th of the day, so around evening in game-time) vii. Ride back to the camp site(again, by completing random events if there are any on the way back) viii. Interesting part, either hunt on the way back to camp, or hunt somewhere near the camp, This is why I take 2 horses out. Each horse can carry 1 big/medium scale animal(Deer, lambs), 2 small kills(rabbits, chickens), and then I carry 1. So basically on my way back, I usually have 7 kills and then end-up donating all to the camp. It fulfills all the camp food needs 1 go If you are reading this long, then thank you so much for taking the time out read it and I hope you find this review helpful.

author: Marjoka
review: This game changed the way I see things.This was a blind pick. Back in 2018, when this game came out, I picked up Assassins Creed Origins for my PS4, I was extremely hyped because I'm a pretty big AC fan, and saw this game on the shelf - full price - all i knew about it was that Rockstar delayed GTA6 to finish this game (which I'm not entirely sure if this is true) and I was like: ,,Wtf is this cowboy garbage?,,- And i picked it up...full price with the idea that i will hate itBoy I was wrong.This aint a simple game, this is a whole experience. I played it more than i played AC Origins, more than i played GTA V, more than i played Overwatch and Team Fortress 2.It has a unique way of getting you into that 1899 vibe, it doesnt feel like the world was made for Arthur and the gang, it feels like they're part of it- which is kinda rare these days in games.I got attached to this game in chapter 4, and i was slowly falling for it. I finally understood what was all about, and what they were standing for, when i was the most into the game....it ended. The end gave me the feels.I didnt really like to play as John, since i didnt play the fist Red Dead Redemption, but i really wanna play it. But it made me feel like i really lost someone, it wasnt like it died a game character- it was like a friend died.I played it like 3 times, enjoying every single mission and side mission, every stranger encounter and random little details, because Rockstar really knows how to tell a story and immerse you into it.On the technical side: this game feels better on console, i enjoy it on PC as well- but the true experience was on my PS4. Maybe its subjective but i feel like this is a console game. Even for a console it has great graphics, imo, and the atmosphere is incredible and very well executed. The light, fog, shadows are really nicely done.Online is kind of a let down. I really enjoyed it for a couple of months, but it gets too grindy, and it lacks content. It sure has potential, but they are not going for it for some unkown reason.All in all this game has a special place in my heart and, to me, it was way more than just a game, it was an experience.

author: PassionateCannedPeaches
review: Fun game. Enjoyable main story and characters, and there are lots of side missions and tasks to do. Something I'm enjoying the most is hunting for perfect pelts and legendary animals. The landscapes are too pretty to miss so I'd recommend foregoing fast travel for the most part.My biggest criticism is about the game is Chapter 1. It's a glorified tutorial where you're stuck following your fellow gang members around. The real fun of the game is the open world so I hated the idea of being locked into what are essentially escort missions. I highly recommend making use of the cinematic camera to speed up them up.The performance is fine and I haven't experienced crashes. I have a fairly good computer (i5-9600k, 1660Ti OC'd, 16GB RAM) and I only drop to 50 frames when I head to a city like Saint Denis and there are lots of weather/lighting effects. I normally get 60-70FPS @ 1440p, w/ Ultra textures/16x anisotropic filtering and other settings med-high. I've noticed stuttering unrelated to framerate, but it isn't terrible.For those interested, my GPU clock goes up to 2070MHz and memory clock 13080MHz. Never seen temps reach 60*C

author: Ruski!
review: Single player mode felt nice, however, as soon as I switched to online, hell broke loose. Everytime i am in a mission, the game would disconnect from the server and I'll lose all progress. Then, it would sometimes try connecting to the server in an infinite loop.I am not facing this issue in any other game.I even tried refunding this game but steam is not allowing it saying that I have played more than 2 hours.Of course I ran this game for more than 2 hours because it took me more that 1 hour to finish prologue itself. How can you expect someone to have played this game for less than 2 hours and then jumped to online right away to find all the issues that it has.This is ridiculous and I am very disappointed with steam!

author: are u mad?
review: I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to get this game and see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.Thank you <3

author: ZuriVolante
review: AUGUST 2022 UPDATE:I'm now using a new custom build desktop and everything worked perfectly fine with none of the steps in the original review. Launched just like any other game. For the original review, I was using an Alienware m15 R2 which used the Nvidia GeForce GTX 1650. Of course, I did all the standard driver updates, which I didn't mention in the review. When I was researching the problem back then, I found plenty of other people reporting the same issue, which is how I found the iGPU workaround. Everyone seemed to agree it was a video card issue.My new build uses the Nvidia GeForce RTX 3050. So perhaps Rockstar fixed the issue, but more likely, it was an issue with the video card the laptop was using, or maybe some other nonsense I didn't discover. And I could't swap out the card without voiding my warranty. Yet, I also noticed much less launcher ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ this time around. The 10 hours of gameplay between the original review date and now was entirely troubleshooting and testing to fix the damn issue. Nothing worked. Moral of the story: don't buy a gaming laptop, build your own machine. It'll be cheaper anyway.Changing this to a positive review. Original review:This game uses the Rockstar Social Club Launcher and that causes nothing but problems. In order to even get that launcher to work, I have to launch it by itself and have Steam closed. Once I figured that out, I thought the game would work. Nope. It won't launch from the Rockstar launcher. It seems to try but nothing happens.I found that you can fix this by disabling the iGPU. I did this for a while and that's how I have any playtime. However, re-enabling the iGPU glitched once and I had to re-install Windows and set everything back up. I tried to get a refund for the game and received the standard "you played too long" response. So, now I have a somewhat pricey game that I can't even play unless I roll the dice with disabling my iGPU. I'll keep updating the game and the Rockstar launcher, but I'm not hopeful that this issue will be fixed. If the issue is fixed, I'll change my review. It's a fun game, but Rockstar using their own launcher is absurd.

author: Jazz the Goose
review: Game runs fine enough except for the fact Steam Overlay is broken and can neither be interacted with nor closed so you got no choice but to quit the game.The real middle finger however is how Rockstar has been treating Steam customers. The game was already sold 1 month prior to Steam's release and also discounted by quite a bit, yet we neither received discounts nor pre-order bonuses.It does render me a hypocrite to a degree, but I could not wait anymore to play this game. But bare this in mind if you consider supporting this company.Also remember that the online mode is built around heavy grinding or microtransactions.

author: Woodeh
review: Let me start by saying that I passed this game several times, when it first came out on xbox. I can't believe it was 5 years ago...Red Dead Redemption 2 is an unforgettable masterpiece that has left a profound impact on me. From the moment I started playing, I was completely immersed in the world of the game, and the emotional journey of the main character, Arthur Morgan, had me hooked from start to finish.Throughout the game, I found myself deeply invested in Arthur's story and his relationships with the other members of the Van der Linde gang. As the story unfolded, I felt a genuine sense of empathy and compassion for Arthur, and I found myself rooting for him even when things seemed bleak.The game's attention to detail and its immersive world-building created an experience that was both beautiful and heart-wrenching. The game's depiction of the American frontier in the late 19th century was breathtaking, and the characters and their stories felt incredibly real.But what truly sets Red Dead Redemption 2 apart from other games is its emotional impact. The game tackles difficult themes like loyalty, betrayal, and mortality, and it doesn't shy away from showing the consequences of the characters' actions. The game's final act left me feeling devastated, and I found myself thinking about it for months after I had finished playing.Overall, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a truly unforgettable gaming experience. It's a game that will stay with you long after you've put down the controller, and it's a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming. It's a game that will break your heart, but it's also a game that will leave you in awe of its sheer brilliance.

author: TrueKnight
review: Almost like a mix of GTA and Skyrim in the Wild West but with a bit more cinematic flair. Only in Chapter 2 but a great game so far.Edit - 6/30/2020 after having the game for about 5 months.This may well be the best game I have ever played. The story and voice acting had me more invested and engaged than I have probably ever been with a game. I finished the single player campaign almost two months ago (you can keep playing after finishing the story).Came back a couple of weeks ago, just intending to mess around in single player, and decided to try Red Dead Online. I'm hooked yet again and so many new things to try and explore as well as random players (good and bad).I often look at prices of games much like I would a movie for time/enjoyment factor. This is a great example of a game that you are getting your moneys worth and then some. My hour counts are always a bit skewed because I will leave a game running, sometimes for hours, while I'm away, but I have still sunk a ton of time into RDR2.Try to avoid spoilers to the single player story. I cannot recommend this game enough.Edit - 11/25/2020I'm still playing online fairly regularly. They have continued to release new content (some of it's not great but you can't win em all). Great game!

author: Loba ❤
review: Where do I start? I got the game for Christmas. So I've been playing for two weeks now. The game itself is not the problem. The problem is ROCKSTAR. There isn't one day that I played that I didn't encountered at least one hacker. And all you can do is jump to another server. Your hunts? forget about it. Once they start, you can't even access stores to sell stuff. Either you are being summoned somewhere miles away from where you were, and everytime the salesman is dead or disappeared. It's frustrating, it's really frustrating. It's even more frustrating because you know that rockstar is giving SH*T on what is going on. The ''write a report'' itself is a joke, since you can barely have words to explain what the f*ck happened that you had to stop everything to report the player. You know how I know they don't care? I'm pretty sure a lot of people that came to play RDR2 played GTA V, so you'll know what I'm talking about. Well...seems like the same bunch of hackers that kept playing unpunished came to RDR2 online. GTA was launched years ago, and I never saw rockstar do something to discover how they could even do such things and at least try to stop them, and after years they were still there doing everything they pleased. And they are here in RDR2 too. Alright let's go to some examples. I was in defensive mode, in tumbleweed (desert, south of the map), and suddenly was summoned inside a store or a house in Valentine (green mountains and stuff, north of the map). I was traped there aloong with other 'victims' of this hacker. We couldn't even control our characters, they wouldn't respond. Whoever were on horses? horses were there too. And then we all started to catch on fire, horses dying. Mine died. I was so pissed, at least I could know who was doing it, because the name appeared when I was killed by burning. But while I was writing the report I could, my character started flying and catch on fire, out of nothing. I tried to get out of the server but It was like I was trapped there, couldn't even get out. Took about 15min so I could leave. Another example: I was in Blackwater, in defensive mode once again, guy summoned A BEAR inside the store. And then more several bears around the city, and sometimes they spammed beside you. I look in the map, I could know who was messing around because the guy was totally red, and he was teleporting in the map. One time he was right down the T of ''THE heartlands'', second later he was right above Rhodes. And then he started to jump around the map. I reported? of course. But once again...you can't tell much in that JOKE that is the ''write a report'' field. Last but not least: I was hunting a bounty with my boyfriend. I was carrying the bounty on my horse, almost inside Rhodes, ready to deliver the bounty. Suddenly I was summoned west of Glacier (farthest north part of the map), and the place I was summoned were the outer part of a mountain, so I was almost out of the map and there was nothing I could do to get out of there, since everytime i tried to walk, I slipped more and more far out of the map. Guy that summoned me was there, and I couldn't confuse him with another victim because he killed me EVEN THOUGH I WAS IN DEFENSIVE MODE. At least this way I could, once again, "write a report".And yes, I checked out, I was defensive mode all the times. I'm not the kind of player that likes to mess with others, I always prefer to play defensive and stay chill. If you are a gamer, please...don't buy this game yet. The game is soo good that is addicting? YES. But the complete lack punishment for those who are cheating is even more FRUSTRATING than how good is the game.  I wish developers saw this review and started to rethink their priorities. Stop developing new ''limited content'' and ''season pass'' for some time, you guys need to focus on annihilate  what is spoiling your masterpiece...this is driving away players and future players.

author: Dyldo Baggins
review: Its red dead 2 which is a fantastic game, but the problems are just a bit too much for me to recommend it even now.  Even with all of the updates the game still crashes roughly once an hour after a ton of tweaking to get it running for that long.  If they eventually fix all of the stuff wrong with the game itll be a must have for anyone wanted to see what PC gaming can really be but for now its just a bit too broken.Update:After a lot of messing around and watching a few videos on Youtube i seem to have gotten the game running pretty stable at around 90 FPS. Haven't really had any crashes either after doing that but I still cannot recommend this game due to the sheer amount of tweaking it takes to get it running at a stable frame rate without constant crashing.  Specs:2060 SuperI7 9700k16 GB DDR4Game stored on a Samsung 970 Evo M2 Drive

author: Bat_NooB
review: The attention to detail put in this game is really something to admire and fall in love with. The design decisions taken to make it more of a thematic experience than just another RPG with convenient vehicle spanning or modern day gaming logic payed off its dividends sometimes because I lose myself in the world and the theme, abiding by the Lawless Law and  the Honor among thieves code, although i can see how it would become an annoyance later. The story, characters and gameplay all tie in to make it an amazing single player experience definitely worth the price, can only imagine how much fun multiplayer would be considering Rockstar made this and GTA 5 online is still poppin.

author: Kasiornis
review: So, RDR2 consists of two modes, Story and Online. - is simply incredible. Not only it features a solid and really dramatic plotline, the amount of details in this game is beyond any comparison. From your first hours in this game you will literally FEEL much love and dedication devs have put in it. Lots of stuff to do, explore and complete. It's interesting, it's enjoyable, its fun. Overall - really deep and really entertaining, very much recommending it, worth it's full price without any doubt. - well, now it becames problematic. It's simply too shallow comparing to singleplayer. In general your gameplay in RDO consists of two things - missions and competitive sessions like deathmatch or races. Even so caled "roles" are basically sets of different missions, some of them are nice and interesting, most of them are your typical fetch-kill quests. RDO also has story missions, they are kinda okay, but nothing special either. What's really bad about RDO - its people, who are playing it, since in 90% of player interactions you will be one-shot instantly from a sniper rifle long before you actually see who did this. Which in turn forces even the peaceful players to behave the same and kill first to avoid being killed. Game is full of griefers and cheaters, Rockstar doesn't give a single about them, as they never did in GTA:O. Thus the same "pull the plug" countermeasures which worked in GTA:O are working (and recommended) here too. It's also filled with minor, but extremely annoying bugs, the game is really unstable at times. In general - it's playable, sometimes enjoyable but lacks any memorable moments apart from really toxic ones which you won't be really happy to remember at all.Thus, as friendly advice - don't buy standalone RDO, just buy this full version for it's Story mode in mind and you'll be good.

author: KAGE
review: The game is good single player wise online can be good as well but there are many issues mainly with disconnects  a couple of crashes here and there, bugs and hackers{this being the worst thing i have encountered so far} people with god mode that can control everything and kill you instantly send you flying make u explode teleport you aimbot etc they seriously need to up their security.... I will be giving this game a thumbs down mainly on the fact that some content is unavailable for some countries for example poker if i had known I would be marginalised for being in a certain country and content would not be available to me that is available to others i would have not bought the game just out of principle but nowhere do they mention this for the consumer and if they are going to do this ♥♥♥♥ it should be required for them to inform the consumer beforehand if content will be unavailable in their country.EditI would like to add to my list of gripes of this game is the absolutely horrendous  slugish controls this game has I have had to beg my character to do things i want him to do while resisting the massive urge to slam my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ keyboard to pieces the controls are ♥♥♥♥.

author: [OMGk] Joel
review: Massive massive game. So much content. But you'll need to want to take your time with this game and just luxuriate in the beautiful world that Rockstar have built. Get this game if the idea of spending 200+ hours in a detailed wild-west open world sounds like your idea of fun. And that's just the Single Player experience!

author: Woolly Goat
review: Beautiful game. Epic narration. Stunning score. Sweeping visuals. Fun game play.  RDR2 is a phenomenal game but its PC release is atrocious.  The first day I loaded the game and I was able to play without any issues for hours but when I tried to start playing again the crash to desktop fiasco kept happening.  There is an unresolved ERR_GTX_STATE bug which has not been fixed by Rockstar since its PC release without any present solution which will happen whenever you are playing -- typically at the worst time.  Not being able to play the game for 30 minutes straight without a fatal crash is pretty atrocious for a AAA release.As for Online -- the game play is boring and unrewarding.  The game feels hollow and empty.  It is setup to be an absolute Pay-to-Win microtransaction grinder.  It is completely polluted with toxic Chinese hackers who jabber on voice chat and then use every sort of mod exploit to teleport invincibly, blow you up with dynamite on the other side of the map, aimbot, etc. -- pretty much everything awful that happens in GTA Online.Not worth the $100 price tag.  I would save your money and buy Disco Elysium instead.

author: emmustee
review: I own this on the PS4, this is the same but with frustrating Social Club. I got it working on one of my PCs but am having trouble on my second. These are well above system requirements, issues were authentication-related. My friend had to change security settings in Windows and I was asked to click on pictures of school buses and crosswalks in a captcha IN THE LOGIN SCREEN, typed the correct username/password, hit login, and nothing. The launcher keeps giving me captchas!Rockstar, no one is going to DDOS your launcher: remove the captchas, allow us to play your game, and fix this nonsense! You're not getting more of my money unless you can design well-rounded working products like you used to.I played on other platforms, the actual game is great (the first game is one of my favorites, and the story here was great), but I strongly believe technical issues such as the ones mentioned above are important. You cannot have a good game if you can't even start it.

author: 𝕯𝖚𝖙𝖈𝖍
review: People often praise this game for the masterpiece that it is, whilst others bag on it like it’s the most overrated piece of trash ever released. In reality, those people are just mad that their favourite game was topped in popularity, scale, ambition, and so much more that contributes to the hate. In this re-review I’ll cover the basics, Story, Gameplay, Graphics, Bugs, Sound design, and more.By far one of the greatest stories ever told, and it’s in video game form, how lucky are we to deserve this? Possibly the greatest bunch of characters ever put to gaming, alongside THE greatest performances, period. Every single person who acted in this game, put a level of love, care, and attention to their characters like never seen before. You play as Arthur Morganon an epic journey through the ends of the Wild West at the turn of the century. The moment you click play, you're sucked into the most gripping title cards ever put to gaming.   In these title cards we can already tell the type of story this game will tell, and it’s a gripping one. With no doubt the best writing ever done for a game, and possibly the entirety of media. The story will take you around 50 to 70 hours to complete on average, depending on how much you like the free-roam, which is one of the greatest worlds and free-roam experiences ever made. The story consists of multiple chapters each of which are brimming with life, originality, and a plethora of new characters introduced. Throughout the campaign you’ll experience excitement, adrenaline, hardship, anxiety, anger, grief, and so much more. I have never been so moved by a video game in my life. It’s by far the most emotional, attaching, and gripping story ever made in gaming and possibly in media.If you've played a Rockstar game in the past couple decades, you know the basics. Love it or hate it, this game uses the Rockstar playbook. The way all the actions and animations blend seamlessly together whether on foot, horseback, or interacting with objects makes for an awesome immersive experience.On top of the basics, there is a mind-blowing number of systems and simulations going on in the game. Everything from bustling cities to the animals in the wilderness make the world feel very alive. Both the weather and climate of your location have an effect on your stats. There are some basic survival elements like food and stamina to consider. Your equipmentcan be maintained for a stats boost.All of this stuff combined allows you to ignore the story for a while and go full on wild-west simulator if you want. However, the survival/maintenance is balanced forgivingly so you can just focus on the story if you want.Weapons consist of the typical gunslinger revolvers, however there is a huge variety of weapons you can purchase at gunsmiths, or find around the world. Each has stats you’ll need to maintain or upgrade for more accurate weaponry.The screenshots do not lie. The game really does look that good if you have the hardware for it. Every inch of this game has high resolution textures, well crafted models, realistic animations, and beautiful lighting. My Dad even mistook it for a movie a couple times, but after playing the game for hundreds of hours he now knows it’s a game.The design of the world also has countless beautiful environments. There are snowy mountains, thick forests, swamps, lakes, rivers, deserts, plains, bustling cities, and every one of the biomes looks gorgeous. I constantly found myself just standing on one spot watching the world go by and taking it in.All these contribute to making the most beautiful game ever made, all extremely well optimised which might I add.Like GTA V, this game will probably be a benchmark for future hardware for years to come.There isn’t really much to cover. The game is one of the most polished I’ve ever seen. Sure you may come across the odd glitch or two, but it’s nothing game changing like in a Ubisoft game. So that concludes this section of the review.The soundtrack is mostly instrumental with a few songs during specific story moments. It nails the introspectivewestern vibe. The whole score blew my mind, and it sets the mood all while remaining in the background. No doubt the greatest score in the history of gaming.The sound effects are amazing which makes for extremely satisfying gameplay. Bullets ricocheting off rocks is extremely satisfying. Shootouts are epic and tense all thanks to the sound effects. The sound design is nothing but spectacular, end of story.Here's where we get a bit negative. The ultimate edition is a 50/50, half feels like a cash grab, whilst half actually adds some cool stuff that seems “worth it”. All new side-missions, clothes, horses, customizations, etc, can all be applied to both Story Mode and Online. Overall, purchasing the Ultimate Edition is really up to you, but if you’re a madman like myself then by all means go ahead, it will not disappoint.No matter what your current opinions are of the company, Rockstar Games clearly know how to make a polished product and are fully dedicated to the craft. They clearly don’t hold back in terms of budget, RDR2 was and still is the most expensive video game ever made, coming in at a whopping 540 Million dollars. You can only imagine what GTAVI is going to be like. I for one am extremely excited.

author: shez
review: My previous review for this game was based off of how it ran close to launch. Unfortunately I was one of the many who struggled to run the game without being faced with frequent crashing.While I'm yet to complete the game, here's what I can say about what has changed since then.Firstly, I haven't experienced a single crash in the 10 hours I have played since coming back to the game. Clearly R* has updated the game to a point where it is running much smoother.Additionally, the game would appear to be running better on mid-range hardware. While I am running this on a 6600 XT, I almost never drop below 60fps using my settings (based off of Hardware Unboxed's suggested settings). I have made additional changes as recommended by others particularly to make hair in particular look better, such as using TAA high instead of HWU's suggested medium, and additionally running the game at 1.25x render scale. Adjusting the TAA sharpening to a level which I find to not be overly sharp, hair looks much better than it did before and environments look incredible. Performance would appear to be better than it was at launch. You may find yourself having to adjust settings to achieve better performance, however using HW Unboxed's settings guide as a guide, you will be able to find settings that make the game look both as good as it can for the best possible performance.TLDR: the game no longer has crashing that plagued the launch and appears to run better on all hardware. Game looks incredible, environments so full and lush, character models incredible, much better performance than I can remember at launch. Of what I have played so far, story is great and it's well worth a revisit in 2021 and beyond if you can run it and especially if you were plagued with the above issues closer to launch.

author: MISFORTUNE
review: I first played this game on Xbox 4-5 months ago, and I can honestly say that this is the best game I've ever played, and always will be. I never thought that I'd love a game this much, it's absolutely amazing! I'm not just talking about the story here, the graphics, the music, the details, the world itself...but man, the story "CHEFFS KISS". You can tell that this game was made with love, and passion by overworked RockStar employees (no sarcasm intended). I never thought a game like this could exsist. You might think that I'm exaggerating, but damn it, I'm not! I cried for 2 hours when I finished this game (not the epilogue part, tho that made me cry too). Then I tried explaining why I cried so much to my friends, and I teared up again. I was more depressed, and felt very, and I mean VERY empty for 2 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ weeks, this game wrecked me! Ok, so basically this game made soft, but ♥♥♥♥ man, it's worth it. The side characters, every part of the side missions, every main mission, all fo the songs, every little detail, John Marston, and esspecially the one and only ARTHUR "the GOAT"  MORGAN were absolutely amazing! I never got attached to a character like this. He became one of my all time favorite fictional characters. I know that the price is a little bit high, but it's worth every penny of it. Definitely buy this game, and not watch story walkthroughs, because it's a whole other experience when you play it yourself. I can talk about this game for hours and hours, but I'm not gonna. So just buy the fricking game, and enjoy it.

author: Zorasht
review: I already played in PS4 when it came out there, completed the Story there, which is awesome. Go and play the Story, seriously, it is amazing.The environment is out of this world, the animations are insane and the way that you and your horse interact with the environment is unmatched. If you haven’t played Assassin Creed Origin and Odyssey yet, do it before you play RDR2, otherwise RDR2 will ruin those otherwise great games for you because the level of interaction that you will expect from AAA games after RDR2. (I played Origins before and Odyssey after and I know what I am talking about, I finished Origins but I couldn’t finish Odyssey)The amount of customization, weapons and items is very realistic and plentiful. The fauna and the way they interact with you and with themselves is breath-taking.But when RDR2 Online went live in PS4 it was glitchy and without many things to do, and even thou we were a few of us playing online in PS4, it wasn’t that great and we abandoned it after a few sessions.Now in PC, and after a year of Online content, with four professions and many more things to do, the Online is fun. Out of the 86 hours, easy 80 are online only. I had a lot of fun playing with friends, as Trader (hunter), Collector, Bounty-hunter and Moonshiner, plus the Online Story missions and the many random encounters that happen online, added the causal interaction with other players and how it may affect the outcome of the missions. I don’t know if the online will have the longevity that GTAV had, but it has delivered so far.Still, I can always beat the Story again when I got tired of the Online.One of the best games of the decade.
