author: NotMcrib
review: ONLINE IS BROKEN!This game is great if your main focus is the single player campaign, just a bit of tweaking in graphic setting and you are good to go, no problem.The problem is with the Online mode. It is a bug filled mess, with constant infinite loading screen bug, frequent  disconnects for no reason, almost no animal spawns and that is just few of the bugs. That is just half of the main problem with online. The other half is that its super boring and there is nothing to do in online. You finish the online campaign missions in couple of hours and that is it there is nothing else left to do. There is no robbing trains, nothing. The most you will do is some repetitive missions for few hours till you get bored of it and maybe try to hunt some of the few spawning animals. No wonder people turn to hacks, thats the only way to have fun online.Now you might be thinking that they will add some stuff in the future, well you are wrong, its been over a year and the only thing they do is fix any goldbar/money exploit found by players and give out some weapons/ammo/etc which most high lvl players already have. It is boring and not fun, DO NOT BUY FOR ONLINE

author: duck.jpg
review: If you are having issues with game crashing after the Rockstar game launcher, giving the error message: "Red Dead Redemption 2 exited unexpectedly", then try right clicking the audio icon in the task bar in the lower right corner of Windows and turn off spacial sound setting. Worked for me after trying everyting between run as administrator settings, anti-virus settings and windows updates. GTX1060 6GB, i5 6060k, 16GB RAM.

author: Dr. Sonovavitch
review: Might be fun if Rockstar ever puts a kibosh on some of the insane hacking in this game.  Every time I play some one starts burning everyone in the server with nuclear fire. If I knew that I would be dealing with hackers every time I played I would never have spent $40 on this gem. Save your money for a game without cheaters maybe sometime rockstar will fix the problem but I wouldn't hold me breath

author: MeanMachine
review: This game is a masterpiece, it currently sitting at Mixed reviews is a travesty. I am an FPS junkie, I looked up a guide on how to optimize and am getting approximately 70 FPS (GTX1070, 32GB RAM, Intel i7 4770K 3.50GHZ), really wasn't that difficult. As for people complaining about their Rockstar Social Club account, sorry you can't remember you used an old email. Crashing, haven't had any crashes.Usually I am very strict on convenience that a developer needs to provide. I would love if the game gets some optimization down the line, but as long as the framerate continues to stay steady, I am fine, it's the jarring framerate fluctuation in games that usually causes issues, and I haven't seen any of that here. Story draws you in, and is a nice slow burn so far to teach you the ropes. Can't wait to see how online is. I will update this review as I progress, but I am already getting a fantastic first impression that this could be in my top 10 games of all time. Felt the need to weigh in because the game should not be sitting at Mixed because of people either not being able to troubleshoot or having outdated rigs that can't run the game on High settings. Sorry but sometimes PC gaming requires some tinkering (again I read a guide here on steam on optimization, took 15 minutes), if you want to set it and forget you can play on console where everything runs on 30 FPS. If you have a decent rig you will probably get somewhere between 50-60 frames just running the game on high settings.Update 1:Still great, have had 1 crash in almost a week of playing, and a couple hiccups connecting to a friends session online. Have spent most of my time online now. I personally have enjoyed not knowing what to focus on and what things do. I have basically just gone out hunting, stumbled upon random events, and have been trying to save money to buy new clothes. Been a blast to play with a couple friends online. Thunderstorms are mind blowing, I don't know how they pulled off the draw distance on the effects. Seems like there is a ton to keep me busy online. Hopefully the missions provide plenty of action, currently they are plenty of steady fun but I would like to see a horde mode similar to some of the co-op missions you could do in GTA Online, where waves of enemies just come at you. Just in case there are some nights where we want to jump in and just start blasting. One of the rare games where I am tempted to get home and immediately ditch any responsibilities I have, that hasn't happened in a while.

author: Netrunner <3
review: RDR2 is a heavily mixed bag for me. It has a fantastic story, world, and an impressive amount of detail. If I were reviewing it on that alone, the game would be a 10/10 easily. But we cannot forget about the GAME part of a GAME. That is where RDR2 struggles. It's stuck in a weird place in between favouring realism, and gameplay. There are some aspects which are quite nice, including the cover system, horse riding, and firearm maintenance. Pretty much everything else feels tedious because of this weird in between state the game is in. The animation for picking things up is far too long and drawn out, really taking me out of the game, the walking speed is far too slow many times, resulting in long treks of boredom, and the shooting has this stupid sway that makes me want to avoid gunfights entirely. So overall, I would recommend you play RDR2, but I do not think it is the masterwork some people label it as.

author: Protecting
review: The single player is probably the best game I've seen in a long time.  However if you are into multiplayer it's constantly hounded by modders.  The game will patch, they'll stop modding for one day.  Then it's back to the usual not being able to accomplish anything, finish any missions, constantly being trolled by modding.  The dislike is only because there's no way to private server join with friends... Unlike GTA5 there's no way to experience a troublefree environment with your friends.  The only way is to go into the mod infested servers.

author: Cooliodude223
review: The absolute pinnacle of first-person, open world story-based gaming. RDR2 is easily one of the best games ever created, full-stop. The story is the greatest told in the medium. The gameplay is some of the best Rockstar has ever created. The world design and graphical fidelity is that which can only be created by large AAA studios. RDR2 is the golden-standard by which other games are compared. You cannot go wrong playing this timeless classic, this absolute titan of gaming.

author: Hollow Man
review: This software is perfect if you enjoy griefers and modders glitching your horse out, teleporting you in front of a train, or worse. If you plan on actually attempting to play the game... good luck.Update. After a further 36 hours of playing the game, it's become drastically worse. It's to the point where it's SO buggy, and there are SO many glitchers and griefers, the game is completely unplayable. I'd love a refund, but we all know those companies who sell products they care less about once it's released. The community is purely toxic, the glitches and bugs are OFF THE CHARTS. The game is simply unplayable. I don't think I'll be purchasing any further games not only with the Rockstar tag on them, but I think these developers are pure trash and I'll be keeping an eye out for their names on other games so as not to purchase those as well. No point in wasting any further money. This game is AIDS.

author: Shrek
review: Let me start with some of the good things about this game, first of all this is probably the best game I have ever played. It's probably also the game with the best story I have ever played. If you have think about playing the whole story (first Rdr2 and then Rdr) I'll recommend it, there will be a quiet different between the graphics, but you also have to think about Rdr is 10 years old. Rdr2's world/map is very very big, it's bigger then GTAV's map, so if you have a low end pc, you should be prepared to run it with low fps, I have a Rtx2070 and a i7-8700, and I run Rdr2 with 65-85 fps with very hign/ultra settings. This game is also about exploring, and you can fast end op using 20 hours or more by just exploring, so if you're the type of guy who dosent link exploring and search a lot of houses, this game is probably not for you. Now let's go to one of the bad things about this game. Rockstar have made Rdr2 very realistic, there is just some few problems/annoyiong things about that, let's say that you have bought a horse for $1250 (which is a lot in Rdr2) and you fall off a cliff, and you and your horse die, then you will not spawn with your horse again, you will have to buy it again!But all in all this a masterpiece from Rockstargames, I'll highly recommended this game to people who have a high end pc and love exploring and stroy games

author: BurritoBaron
review: EDIT: Finally got back into this game and I'm glad that they have fixed the issues I had. Still as beautiful as before and I haven't crashed yet. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------In it's current state I cannot recommend this game anymore. Before the Dec. 13th update I only got a few crashes here and there. Maybe 1 or 2 in a 3-4 hour period of playing. Ever since this update I've been getting the ERR_GFX_STATE error. I've followed what they said on their support page, and even tried a few other things I found elsewhere to no avail. From what I have played, the single player is great. There is always something going on for you to come across. None of these side quests, random happenings, etc., feel forced either. For example I don't feel like I have to save the caged woman who's being transported by local lawmen. I can continue on my merry way to go ruin someone else's day.Until these bugs get worked out, I'm leaving this review and recommendation as is.

author: GRIM
review: Its been a pleasure to have a great adventure with Arthur Morgan ♥ :')What a masterpiece this became!! I did not expect the game to turn out the way that it did, the suspense and emotion of the characters keeps you so drawn into the game that you can’t stop playing! Literally pulls your heartstrings you didn’t realize were there! It was such an incredible honor to play as Arthur and to Be able to witness his story. Rockstar did a bad ass job! Though, honestly I wish they would have given Arthur a chance to live having the Indians give a miracle cure to him so that he didn’t die. It would have been so much more beautiful to have him move off and start his own life somewhere else, then leave it at that, then go play as John Marston. Sadly that’s not how it turned out, but it is still a fantastic and wonderfully put together game! I just thought the last of us two was tearjerking, this one’s up at the top and I highly recommend!! 10/10

author: Moon Illusion
review: There are two parts to the gameplay in my opinion, there is the cowboy sandbox experience where you explore the Open World and rob people, hunt in the wilderness etc. And the second part is just the massive shootouts throughout the story. Now I love the Open World sandbox, and everything you can do in it. The shootouts are ok, and in some moments can even be great. I do think that the cover system is pretty dated feeling, and aiming your gun is sometimes un-intuitive especially since your gun aims itself by locking onto enemies. Even with that said though, I like it. I find it makes it easier to portray Arthur Morgan as a super cool gunslinger cause he is. This is what elevates the game past just something that you enjoy for 50+ hours you spend playing it. I have thought about this game's story so much in the past few years since I first played it. It is hard to put into words without spoiling the story how much I love it. My best attempt to speak it's praises is that Rockstar managed to have nearly 30+ characters, nearly 20 of them being apart of your camp, have them all be unique with their own personalities and motivations. Every character grows and changes throughout the story, their motivations might change, an aspect of their personality changes as well. Your character affects them in the story, and Arthur changes throughout the story. The story itself is one about friendship, family, insanity, revenge, love, betrayal and of course redemption. All of these aspects are done perfectly, and really resonate and makes you think long after you play through it. And the ending is absolutely perfect, which making a good ending seems to be a rare aspect of story nowadays, making it all the more impressive here.The sounds is amazing. Some of the best I have every heard in a game. There are so many examples to give that I have trouble even pointing to one sound I enjoyed in particular. The soundtrack is superb as well, the combat music keeps the rhythm and intensity up, and in some serious moments in the story songs with lyrics creep in the background making moments that would have just been Arthur riding on a horse have so much weight and impact.I don't even know how this game is possible graphically. It is too good to be 4 years old now and as big as it is. This in my opinion should be the industry standard in terms of graphical fidelity for realistic styled AAA games. The lighting and environments are also the best I have seen in modern games as well, the only games that come close at all are games like Elden Ring, and games made by Naughty Dog. If you have not played this game, please buy it and take a couple of weeks just to experience everything this game has to offer. I recommend this game even when not at sale, it is one of the few games that are actually worth the 60 dollar asking price. 10/10

author: Gay Fungus
review: So since this game game came out, I've been very excited to play. For a while now I've had a lowkey interest in western stuff like cowboys, deserts, etc, and have even been (very slowly) attempting to write a book with that theme. I couldn't afford the game, both because PS4's are expensive and the game itself is expensive. So, I waited until it got on PC, and lord was I hyped when it did. I had to wait a while still tho so flash forward to about 2 months ago when my brother bought it for me as a surprise gift. I'm gonna get a little sentimental here because frankly I can't be more grateful sometimes that he gifted me the game.This game is everything I wanted for over a year, and more. I avoided spoilers and all content on it like the absolute plague, and really my only knowledge was "cowboys, the main protagonist is Arthur I think?" and that was it. And I'm really glad I did that cause experiencing the game completely blind was worth it.I like to state cons/flaws first though, so I'm going to do that, but I'll say the pros definitely outweigh the cons. A game this big is bound to have cons, and I'm not going to ignore that, especially with the one I'll list first.CONS- The hillbilly in the swamp encounter. Y'all know who I'm talking about. If you don't, look up Sonny from RDR2. This really is something that either should've been expanded on as an immensely traumatic experience for Arthur or just cut from the game completely if it was just gonna be... like this? It just seems like a joke at this point with how it's played up, and quite frankly it's disgusting. I don't want a damn rape joke. It would've been interesting if it was explored on a deeper level rather than just ignored like it never happened, but that's what they did.THANKFULLY though this encounter is optional, so at least there's that?- Linear missions.This game is linear, and that's not a bad thing, but... Well. NakeyJakey's video titled "Rockstar's Game Design is Outdated" does a better job explaining this than me, so I'll leave that there.Those are the biggest cons I'd say. If I have anymore, I'll add them later. I could say Micah, but then again he's a very well-written and well-executed character. Still hate him though. :3And now, the pros.PROS- Fantastic story. The story is about a gang trying to survive and avoid being captured and/or killed by Pinkertons after a ferry heist gone wrong. After that, I'll try not to spoil, but as vaguely as I can manage it: there are some "good, bad, and the in between" themes with the protagonist throughout the story. You choose if he is (or stays? idk) a bad man if you go Low Honor, or becomes the best he can be if you go the High Honor route. The way they do this, too, is something that I very much so appreciate and enjoy with how complex it is, how the character is, no matter what, not black or white.Also the story is the equivalent of riding in a shopping cart down a hill that slowly gets steeper and steeper, so have fun with that.- CharactersThe gang has a LOT of well-written characters that I love. Usually in stories there will be a character or two I'll latch onto, and I won't like the rest too much? But I /love/ these characters. Arthur is the protag, and probably the best protagonist I've seen. I love Hosea (and had a dream where I was Arthur and he gave me the most comforting fatherly hug possible but that's besides the point). I love Charles, he's my favorite after Arthur and Hosea. I love how incredibly complex Dutch is as a character. I love Sean, Tilly. Reverend Swanson is a guilty pleasure of mine. I love Kieran. And there's more but there's so damn many gang members, and it's honestly really cool how they wrote so many, all who act as a family (maybe with some exceptions, but they're getting there).- Pace & ImmersionSome people get pretty impatient with the slow pace of things but honestly I really enjoy it. If it's a world you can get immersed into, then a slower pace only helps that. Then again, I do have a lot of free time on my hands, so I can understand why this can be frustrating sometimes for other people? For me though I love it. I love the attention to detail, with an animation dedicated to skinning (and as someone who has done it before, and this is not a complaint, the animations are VERY quick lol but they're realistic enough and I honestly appreciate that), looting, eating, pretty much everything. Again this really helps the immersion, and on that note -- RealismGoes hand in hand with the pro I listed above. Probably one of the most realistic video games to date, at least so I've seen. I've even seen screenshots of the game before where I had to take a moment to evaluate if it was a screenshot or real. A lot of the environments look very real and gorgeous. Even the desert that you unlock in the Epilogue.The people look real. The environment looks real. Even the animals look quite real. Hell, your horse looks real. God I love Buell.Anyway I can say "love" 100 times more and keep repeating myself but those are my main points and probably everyone else's main points. I appreciate this game, it holds a special place in my heart, it came at a time in my life where I needed some of the lessons it taught, and also it's very fun :) I very much so recommend itOh, and also, you can punch bears. That's my favorite activity.

review: RX Vega 56 Overclocked getting 60 frames per second 1080p maxed out. Amazing gameplay, great storytelling. Even the most trivial activities such as fishing or hunting are extremely fun and rewarding. The game keeps on giving. Im 40 hours into the game and still mechanics are being introduced to me. author: MoeFugger
review: This is a beautiful game. The environment and level of detail they put into it is fantastic. But the controls are so clunky it get's really frustrating to play. It's hard to interact with items and at times you're fighting your horse just to get it to move around a damn tree. Or you'll be taking on enemies trying to aim down your gun sights, but if you're standing too close to your horse your character will just focus on the horse while you get shot up trying to aim your weapon. The online game occasionally has server issues but looks like they've taken care of them for the most part. But when they do occur you can log back in to find all the resources you just spent time collecting are gone.Because they've at least fixed the online server issues, I'll go ahead and recommend this game. BUT ... expect to have some frustrating times dealing with the controls. If you can get past that, it's a pretty nice game.

author: TheBerkayss
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 could be the best story-rich fluent game ever. Due to my experiences I would like to have seen more content in RDR2 instead of update to GTA V however some part of people can get bored at the beginning to find out this marvelous game because beginning of the game process really slowly. Even after I had finished game but I had felt like characters were my relatives for a long time. Naturally besides all praises I got some complatins for RDR2Story and all kind of stuffs are work fine but since the game released, controls have delay problem well this is could be hard to get used to with it at the beginning. For me at least unfortunately I had chance to play with low-med settings at acceptable fps furthermore it made me to have more delay problem but its okay as time goes by playing it. Another thing that I criticize is story ending. I mean with should this bad-good cowboy bar affect ending of the story? I have discussed this thread for many times with my friends but I couldn't find anything that makes sense for me. It's well-designed system for world events but it shouldn't have been affect ending. Another thing is our gang camp upgrades and etc. Gang camp should have been more highlighted to the game, I hadn't even stop by to camp unless I was heading for quest. But sometimes after quests ending lines you to camp to have celebration, it gives real mood to us however personally I couldn't catch the camp atmosphere much. Besides the bad sides I should explain good ones. I mean whole game cannot be explained with 3-4 sentences. It is totally package that includes simulation, action games. If you're looking for hunt, fishing game? just go for rdr2. If you want to find peace by gun-shooting? you could find the most relaxing shooting game ever in this game.And the last thing. This terrible content shortage in Red Dead Online makes people angry. I still don't understand with all of this fantastic atmosphere, graphics, mechanics etc. why would you let it go to stay game itself. No markable content update or ♥♥♥♥. Instead they spammed more content to GTA V Online. After Rockstar saw the big chunk money were flowing out from GTA V, they must have changed company policits for sure. Especially last three remaster ♥♥♥♥ of nostalgia gta games show us something went  and could be going wrong on rockstar side. After all RDR2 is great game.I hope micah's mom went to hell for giving birth him.9/10-1 for lack of content in online ffs

author: Znoz
review: First game that I completed without using fast travel.Game looks awesome - rocks slide from hills when you walk over them, sun shines trough trees and fog. They managed to capture atmosphere of different zones - from cold north, to hot south. It looks so good, that you want visit USA after playing this game.Attention to details is insane: animals and people react to character, camping, best horse mechanics and riding I've seen so far, world full of Easter eggs and events (some can be repetitive - one guy was 3 times bitten by snake). Modern physics - objects can be destroyed, fire from molotov can burn whole house, stones slide down from hills if you step on them, good ragdolls and collisions.World feels alive, especially in camp - reminds me of Gothic 2.Fishing and hunting can be addictive - spent 2 hours hunting legendary fox.Game can be chill\calm (one of the reasons why I didn't used fast travel) and full of crazy action with train robberies and chases.Crafting is good, but can be improved.I think shooting compared to other aspects of the game looks weak. It didn't go far from GTA - point, click and enemy dead. You don't "feel" weapons (apart from Double barreled), duels could be much more detailed, dead eye is boring - you press button, time slows and select targets for your character to shoot at.On the bright side - good animations, visuals and wound marks. Hats can be shot off from heads, horses drag dead bodies etc.One of the best stories in gaming. It makes you think not only about the game itself, but about real life and people that surround you.Cool characters - all made very well and interesting (different point of views, stories etc.). Atmosphere in camp changes based on events in game. Some are guarding camp, other are cooking and work on different chores in camp, leader is planning, and drunk Uncle sleeps under a tree.

author: Lothos88
review: A friend bought me the game to play with them and some other friends online. I have not played any single player, only online, so that's what my review reflects: My specsThis game is buggy as hell. It constantly disconnects you, your camp randomly just disappears and then can't be reset anywhere until you restart the game several times. Doing the various role missions, other than trader, seems to crash the game about 75% of the time upon completion and you get no rewards. Randomly will get stuck in infinite loading screens. I'm playing with 3 other people and we all get some or all of these issues. For me, the random disconnects seem to be the main issue.Looking through posts online it seems I'm not the only one. I've tried all the various "fixes" people have posted (forwarding the dozen or so ports the game uses, disabling various windows network management features) none of them work. Which makes me believe the problem is solely rockstar's junk servers. There are also rampant cheaters in the game, people flying around through the air, invulnerable, one person had some kind of hack where if you aimed your weapon at them it made you immediately holster you weapon. Even without all the above, the online play is also extremely grindy. You want to get different clothes? Most of them require you to be lvl 50+. They don't offer any real benefit, just fluff, but you still can't buy them. You want to learn how to craft your own ammunition? lvl 70+. Better saddle? Pay real money. Buy better ammo? Lvl 50+.I've played over 40 hours dealing with all the crashes/bugs and am about lvl 24. When the game actually works, it's not bad. The bounty missions are fun, especially the legendary bounties. Just wandering around exploring is fun, general hunting/fishing and stuff is also fun. But the game is just so unstable that it makes trying to progress really frustrating.

author: stmpunk
review: (this is not a "online" review, for I refuse to even open it, I've read so much about how bad it is that I prefer to stay clear of it)UPDATE: Tried Online out, it's cancer. You either inject the equivalent of 3 full game releases in real money or grind for a month playing daily just to get started. It's garbage.Okay, I've endured a little further into it, it's a constant grind, at times whenever in any PvP mode, it feels like you are playing with 1500ms ping, some players make plays that seem like blatant cheating (but it could be the in-game broken mechanics, like allowing auto-aim for controllers), and to top it all off, there's this random and very common "Error: 0x20010006" which disconnects you mid match, depriving you from rewards, basically killing your efforts and forcing you to waste more time.Error: 0x20010006 can be fixed by using VPN as reported by multiple players, but any decent VPN that doesn't lag costs you more money.So, conclusevely, the Red Dead Online really is cash-grab garbage, modelled after greedy models like Korean and Chinese MMOs with "almost-p2w" and everything in the game focused solely into cashing-in extra bucks, with zero support or actual service being delivered to the players...Update: It's been a week since I've started experiencing the MP aspect of the game, and it's much worse than I've thought. The grind is insurmountable, the time it takes to do anything is ridiculous, and everything that's quick, is unrewarding, kinda buggy, and unbalanced. It is in fact, very very very hard to have fun in this mode, given that it's too strict, lacks even basic things from SP, and on top of it all R* insistently tries everything they can to push people into Microtransactions. It's possible, but unhealthy, to get things for free.Seriously, horses die due to glitches, so if you have a fancy rare horse, you're ♥♥♥♥. Opportunity heists are not opportunous due to this plus a massive amount of amounting factors.The game is cool for it's ambience, it's atmosphere, and overall it's art (including sound fx and it's Music, not just the looks).That being said, the game mechanics are all half-a**ed, most stuff feels incomplete or simply the result of incompetence pertaining the people in charge. In-game story-walls that basically create a loophole where you can't complete the game as the protagonist. Locked content before you advance but punishment for advancing isn't a really smart thing to do.What people in R* do not get (since GTA 4) is that their games are not movies. To this date their single master-piece was GTA SA, everything before that, and after that, is just dull. GTA 1 and 2, which were pristine, were not made by them. I've heard that RDR1 was pristine too (much like GTA SA) from some friends, but I wouldn't know because them a*holes never made a PC version (and I simply can't stand consoles). Still, I've paid a small fortune on this game, and it feels like a indy game going through some rough Early Access, all while the graphics, price and it's publisher and developer are AAA. It's just schizophrenic.I don't mind playing it a lot though, because I'm quarantined (in Italy), but I'd likely get a refund after feeling their clumsy controls given I'd be super busy to waste time in a game that feels bad (UI and UX wise), yet I've endured that only to find out that the game core design itself, surprisingly, is just as clumsy as the controls. Even Skyrim (2011 made by Bugthesda) has a better "bounty" system/performance with a couple of mods. I'd figure a game that came much later from a big dev like R* would've made at least something alongside that, but no, it's just the same clumsy system from GTA 3 to this date, with a few slapped-in scripts to make things seem different, but in the end it's all the same.Another thing that bothers me a lot is their saving system, the autosaves are out to sabotage us, sure, they're needed, and I mean NEEDED, because the game crashes sometimes, other times because you need to reload before a mission due to one or two things, but whenever you're onto side-content, the autosave will deliberately sabotage you by saving whenever a permanent in-game dmg happened, like your horse dying due to some ridiculous AI combined with glitched hitboxes. Worse than that is the fact that you can't tell the horse to stop following unless you are looking at it and focusing it at the same time, I mean, that's just lazy development. Even in Skyrim amateur modders have managed to implement more complex tasks to mounts in a game that isn't even focused on mounts. Bah...Adding salt to the wound, there are tons of unrealistic behaviors coming from the AI, because the point in this game is to make the AI cheat while you grind your a** like a fool for hours just to stay alive. Meanwhile a small town manages to summon an entire platoon of lawmen under 10 seconds, you wipe them out, and here comes another platton 10 seconds later, all of them having x-ray vision and as accurate with their rifles as Vasily Zaytsev. I've honestly killed more lawmen than there are people in this game. I really can't feel a smooth progress here, crafting sachels was a pain, a real pain, but I've did it because the inventory space is unnaturally small. I mean, they've piled up things to annoy the players as much as they could. Challenges locked to the Epilogue, killing the protagonist needlessly, etc. I'd rather play as the guy from RDR1 the entire game than being forced to switch characters. (and I didn't even got there yet, I've learned about this killing because I was trying to complete side content first so I wouldn't get bothered by countless icons on the map screen) Then I've learned that I have ahead of me: locked challenges, locked trinckets, locked outfits, all for the Epilogue, the question is, what is the point? Once I've finished the game, why would I keep grinding? I know I will until this lockdown ends (the whole Coronavirus thing), but other than that, what is the point? If you're not locked up at home, why would you waste so much time on a game you've already finished? Even GTA SA I would start anew, play stuff with a different weapon and vehicle choice, make a playthrough as a fat guy, another as a digital version of 50 cent, another as a skinny crackhead... In rdr2 nothing really matters since the character dies anyway, and you lose your mounts, so you have 2 choices, you either "lock-up" the game incompleted and do all side-stuff without ever progressing the main story, OR, you progress with the main story without doing ♥♥♥♥ of side content so you don't lose stuff (and time) with a dead-man-walking.Anyway, enough rambling, I'll keep playing, but had to get this out of my chest. R* is a really mediocre developer, even though they've made the most expensive games when we talk about development cost. It's impressive.PS: I'd even dare to say that this game is a prime example of wasted potential. I wouldn't bother playing rdr3 after seeing this poor port. Overall I think this game deserves a 4/5/6 in a critic score, for many reasons, varying on the overall reviewer quality priorities. If we take game design, it's a 4 (which's my cup of tea), if we take overall experience, it's a 5, and if we take more superfulous features as a priority it's a 6 (at most).Given that fact, and knowing how complex tastes for games can be, I'd say this game isn't for some people, but IS for others. So I do not recommend it, nor do I think you should avoid it. Just think before purchasing.What I don't recommend without conditions is buying any of the editions, just get the standard game, the "editions" are just a greedy move that gives you nothing in return, much like the in-game "Get Rich Book", the editions are a over-priced scam.

author: OgieStacek
review: It is with great disappointment that I am unable to recommend this game. The game itself is a great concept and could have been one of the best of its kind, but unfortunately, in my opinion, was poorly implemented.If I could sum up my Red Dead 2 experience with one word, it would be: Hackers. So far, of my +230 hours in game, there has not been even one single day I've logged in without hackers affecting the gameplay in some way or another. Some examples are:* Teleporting everyone from the entire session to the same spot, at the same time, then blowing everyone up* Randomly getting blown up while zero players / NPCs were around* 10+ bears / cougars / <insert aggressive animal here> spawned by a player on top of my character * Players being invincible, with unlimited ammo / items, flying around in the air killing other players* Players teleporting themselves all over the map, even up into the air* Players using the above methods to kill other players then forcing the game to blame the kill on another innocent player* Even changing online "sessions" doesn't get you away from the hackers most of the timeI will admit, this review is primarily based on my experience with "online mode", but that is the aspect of the game which appeals most to me. Furthermore, "online mode" is arguably one the biggest, if not biggest, aspects of the game. I happen to enjoy the open world PvP this game offers. In online gaming, there is little that is more exciting than a PvP skirmish when you least expect one. The hackers just turn PvP into an impossible to win against scenario when there is zero way to fight back. Far too often, it also seems that little is done to stop the hackers. However, in "Story mode", none of the stuff mentioned above would be encountered. So, if "online mode" isn't your cup of tea, then by all means, "story mode" is a fairly enjoyable and relatively bug-free experience. However, a review should be based on 100% of a game, and unfortunately, hackers ruin +50% of this game. If they would be dealt with, I could fully recommend this game.If you can't play by the game's set rules, then why even play?Anyway, I digress./soapbox off

author: Crazyfaith
review: Ah, Red Dead Redemption 2. The game that made me feel like a rootin' tootin' cowboy, except without the horse or the hat. Or the accent. Or the gunslinging skills.But despite my lack of cowboy credentials, I have to say, this game is pretty darn impressive. It's like a Wild West simulator, complete with horseback riding, shootouts, and even some good old-fashioned cattle rustling (or as I like to call it, "moo-napping").The attention to detail in this game is mind-blowing. I mean, have you ever seen a virtual horse poop before? Because I have, and let me tell you, it's a sight to behold. And don't even get me started on the facial hair options. I've never had so much fun styling my virtual mustache.But let's be real, the real star of this game is the horse. I mean, I don't want to brag or anything, but I think I've formed a pretty strong virtual bond with my trusty steed. We've been through shootouts, horse races, and even some cliff diving (sorry, Mr. Ed). So if you're looking for a game that will make you feel like a true cowboy (or cowgirl), Red Dead Redemption 2 is the game for you. Just don't blame me if you start accidentally using cowboy lingo in everyday conversation. Yeehaw!

author: A Son of a Shepard
review: I've played a lot of games, but RDR2 is really something different.  When I first started  playing RDR2 I killed people randomly and indiscriminately. As I went through the game I really felt that the story was calling to me to tell of how pointless violence is.  I really grew to like Arthur and I recall that near the end of the game once I learned of his fate I tried very hard to gain as much honor as I could so that Arthur was able to pass in peace. I felt by the time I reached the epilogue a really heavy sense of sadness.  The sadness has never gone away anytime I attempt to play the game.Something about this game feels so real and weighs really hard on you.  If I could point it out I would say the story is written well enough to display the cruelty and unfairness of life and how we all will be forgotten and left in the wind someday. Most importantly, the game and the first RDR sell the message you can't outrun your past and you will have to pay for it.

author: Finn
review: The Rockstar Launcher is absolutely the most disgusting, dreadful thing ever. I've never thought anything could top Uplay but it did. That said, the game's single player campaign is phenomenal, top notch writing and acting that makes for a very engaging and immersive story, combined with the smooth Rockstar gameplay. author: Yamaii
review: We are not criminals, we are outlaws! There's a difference?Sad thing is good people do bad things.We are more ghosts than people.Nothing means more to me than this gang, this bond we share!We're thieves, in a world that don't want us no more.You people venerate savagery and you will die... savagely!Come on, take your best shot!I just hope dutch was right, when he said that we had to do it to survive.We represent everything that they fear Killing in cold blood, revenge. Look at us, risking our necks and for what exactly. I'm dying, what am I gonna do now?Perhaps, you could help somebody.You saved my life!Don't thank me...Thank you, Brother.Thank you, Arthur.Thank you, Mister Morgan.I said don't thank me!I ain't looking for forgiveness, it ain't about that.forgiveness?There's some folks who don't deserve it.This whole thing is pretty much done... And all you can do now is decide the man you wanna be fore the time you have left.You're a good man!I'm not a good man, not usually.There's a good man within' you, Arthur.You'll do what's right!This is over!Everything is coming together exactly as i planned!That's clear, I gave you all I had, I did...Be Loyal to what matters, and don't look back!I don't talk about him much, but I think about him!

author: Tom_Husky45
review: Wow... What a storyline, and what a game. I played the original RDR on Xbox - the biggest flaw is that the earlier story is in RDR2.. I feel that is a redundancy. But what a beautiful game, that takes us back to the start and helps us relive those moments we were always wondering about. What I now wonder is, weather we'll play Arthur when Dutch and Hosea first met him? Maybe even go forward to Jack again and see what he ends up doing in his adulthood. Can't wait to see what more beauty and story we end up seeing from Rockstar. The game, yes. The game is beautiful, you can admire so much detail, and such enjoyable hunting environments. It has a crafting system in currently, but it's not like you can build your own campsites out of logging or something fun like that (I'd like to see that in a distant game).Rockstar could have quite a franchise here by maybe going into a full on ranching game, instead of cops & robbers for every game they make. There looks to be a lot of experimenting in this game with that, more so than RDRevolver and RDRedemption One. I am keen to see what else Rockstar release.

author: Cheesus Krust
review: It is a shame. Visually stunning, some interesting mechanics, but overall just frustrating and not really enjoyable. The second you think you get to do something awesome, the game just screws it up. The game will take all the long range weapons off of you each time it reloads. So you are out and about and need your guns? Too bad, you have to get them from your horse. Sometimes you have to press E, sometimes it's R, sometimes it's F, even had U or H. There is no clear pattern to follow or get used to. Riding after a target? Be careful not leaving the track, your horse might turn or spin around riding off into the completely wrong direction and it completely ignores your input. Also you need to right-click to interact with someone. When you rightclick it centers your focus in that direction, so you will literally run or ride into someone that you just wanted to interact with. Or maybe you still had your guns out, so rightclicking will make you aim at them, instead of interacting with them, which will antagonize them or scare them off, so you can no longer interact with them. It is just so damn frustrating having some piece of gameplay that looks fun and interesting be ripped out of your hands as soon as you attempt it. BTW: Most of what i complain about here are actual design decisions. The result of it is a clunky experience where you don't get to play the game how you want, but how the developers envisioned you to suffer. Brilliant. Waste of money and time.

The issue was fixed but the game is a terrible port. when it works it is fantastic and when it doesnt it is one of the most frustrating experiences of my life.

author: Scrumpy
review: The best game I have ever played, it has its flaws but nevertheless is a complete masterpiece. The game world is beautiful, characters interesting, story line both engaging and emotional, music atmospheric. Arthur Morgan is a great character. When I was a child I wanted to grow up to be a cowboy and Red Dead lets me fulfil that fantasy in a way no other game has ever come close too. There is not enough cowboy games out there  and nothing anywhere near as engaging or as detailed as this game. Play the single player and lose yourself in a story of regret, remorse and ultimately redemption. Then create your own character online, ride alone or with friends and make the world your own. As mentioned before, it isn't perfect. Controls can be clunky, there are glitches, and the online world has cheats and griefers like most online PC games do. It would benefit enormously by introducing dedicated servers, private lobbies, and more activities for players to engage in but its not as bad as many say and the community is generally friendly. There are always going to be a few bad apples in the barrel but you can always block them and change lobbies. The reporting system could also be improved and Rockstar investing more time and effort into improving the game and fixing some of the bugs wouldn't go amiss. They don't seem to care about it much and focus on a corporate model by pushing sales of gold and making tasks grindy with little reward. But none of these flaws detract from the overall experience. I love this game, recommend it whole heartily and play every day. I live here now.

author: Professor Aggressor
review: This game is poorly optimized. The benchmark was not very representative of the quality I actually get in game. One of the most infuriating issues I've encountered is that both the Vulkan and DX12 graphics APIs seem to be broken in different ways, so I have to chose which problem I want to deal with. Vulkan doesn't allow me to see my mouse cursor, so navigating menus is a nightmare, while DX12 does seem to have a cursor, but treetops flicker in and out of existence to the point of it being nauseating when riding by on horseback. In my first few hours of play the game crashed infrequently and ran acceptably, at this point in the game I am experiencing consistent crashes that have made the game effectively unplayable. I have 2 story critical missions available, and they both reliably crash at the same part every time I have attempted them.  While this game may work fine for some, in my experience it has revealed itself to be a broken mess that at the best of times I would describe as "somewhat functional". Most of the time though the frustration with the litany of issues this game has outweighed any redeeming characteristics in my opinion.

author: LoneSurvivor
review: what can i say, been waiting RDR on pc for 7years. I'ts good, like REALLY good, love it, not much to say.Edit: Just got back into this game (in 2021). Forgot this game for a year or so, but now i regret that i haven't played this before. Feels like i'm gonna put too many hours in this game (and to poker). author: Amen

author: jacob
review: I've barely touched the multiplayer, but played through the singleplayer on PS4.This is, without a doubt, one of the best video games I've ever played. It really is that good. Everything about it. I don't know if there's really anything I'd change about it. No game in recent memory has engrossed me as much as this one.[edit] This review deserves to be fleshed out more, so here goes.On a technical level, the game is a masterpiece. A beautifully realized and realistic world that truly feels alive, probably more so than any other game I've ever played. I don't know if I ever used fast travel because I wanted to see what I'd encounter as I rode between the towns. It truly does feel like a living, breathing world and is absolutely outstanding on this level.The story is also quite good. A gang of outlaws, of which you are part of, following a strained leader through a series of hard times. You meet many interesting characters, partake in tons of missions, and get drawn in to the well-woven story about Arthur and his struggles.Even completely ignoring the online functions, there's such a huge breadth of content here that you'll get more than your money's worth in gaming hours.I really can't recommend this enough.

author: MCpl Green
review: If I could rate the single and multi player portions of the game separately, I would. Single is a stable, wonderful experience.RDR2 Online is a bag of dog manure. On average I launch the game three times to get it to work. If it doesn't crash when it loads, it just doesn't load at all. I've left it on a loading screen, ate a meal, and come back an hour later to find it still on the same loading screen. And once you get it working and into a session, it's not much better. Griefing is fairly common, cheating isn't nearly as rare as it ought to be, and you're left with absolutely zero power to control your exposure to this. At best, you can report with some hope, try to load into a different session, and have it go through it's crashing bull all over again.The gameplay itself isn't terrible. Grindy, but not horrendously so. But the amount of ♥♥♥♥ you have to wade through to get to it is unpleasant.Given some love and attention, it could be as good an experience on both game modes, but I have my doubts that it'll see that.

author: JohnM_83
review: I have purchased that game first for a PS4 Pro, afterwards for XBOX One X and now I may finally play it as I like – with mouse and keyboard.It was a long wait for a PC port, but finally it is here and it looks beautiful. As for the game itself, I do believe that by this point, everyone knows exactly what RDR2 is.I have seen some minor problems like strange white frame and black one here and there during the cinematics, same goes for a one case of strange background pop-in – a whole mountain loaded during a cut scene. I am aware of many technical issues with PC version, but fortunately for me, with my hardware / software config, it runs flawlessly.In short, if you want the absolute best RDR2 experience, and have a reasonably well equipped PC, go for it!

author: Grampus
review: The game has been out for over a year now so I can't really say anything new about it that hasn't already been said. I have played it on console, since launch, and will say that it looks phenomenally better on PC and the controls with keyboard and mouse are also greatly better. Despite people claiming you need a really beefy system to get good frames, I seem to be able to get a really smooth and consistent game-play with a Ryzen 1600x and Nvidia 1070. The requirement of Rockstar's Social Club launcher, even though it doesn't seem to have any beneficial functionality, is ridiculous.BUT...I cannot recommend this game, and absolutely do not recommend the online-only version.  First and foremost, Red Dead Online is also a huge technical mess: disconnects like crazy, hackers, broken features, and more.  Rockstar clearly does not give a ♥♥♥♥ about fixing it.  It is clear they view it only as a cash-cow to milk players for money via gold bar sales.If they stripped away microtransaction, allowed friends only lobbies or, since it is a mostly P2P game already, just let us run out own servers, made it as reactive and lively as singleplayer, and stopped introducing more bugs as they go, it might be a pretty decent multiplayer experience.  Alas, it is not.

review: Good Graphics , Good Story , World feels alive.Haven't faced any issue in running the game...maybe some people are having issues like crashes or something like that but i have not experienced anything like that.I am getting 40-60 fps with the mix of ultra and high settings on GTX 1070, i7 6700K with 16 GB RAM.SHOULD BE GAME OF THE DECADE

author: Traiin
review: This is a long, well crafted story. I'm not much for westerns, so I never really was interested in this series. I have not played the first game, and to my understanding this is a prequel that only piqued my interest for the first one. Being candid: the story kinda guns for your 'feels' and hits it pretty hard. Arthur Morgan, and his story - well, play it and see what you think. If you're like me, and reading this years after it's been released trying to decide...I can tell you it was worth the play through if you like story rich games. My only cons were the demanded slow downs the game would force upon you - at times it felt like the game was slowed for the single purpose of intentionally slowing you, and what you wanted to do. Easily overlook-able and forgivable in the grand scheme of the totality of the story and adventure.

author: Sashik
review: I have updated my previous negative review, which addressed the game crashes. After a two-year break, I returned to the game and experienced no crashes on startup or during gameplay. However, one issue still persists: playing in fullscreen on an ultra-wide monitor results in a stretched and unplayable map bug. To solve this problem, I recommend playing in borderless fullscreen, although the UI may be pushed too far to the left and right of the monitor. In fullscreen, the UI is placed in the middle, which is much more comfortable.Aside from this issue, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an incredibly beautiful game with a well-developed storyline. Every detail, voice line, and mechanic in the game is thoughtfully developed, just as if an enormous amount of work has been put into it. Story mode is great, don't make your decision on first start the game, it gets more and more interesting with changes.Iit is definitely worth time spent.

That fixed the game for me.

author: Hammer Of Evil
review: recommended, not for full price. -has no anti cheat for online play, -has drm always online required, -has crappy controls that will get you killed just from how slowly they react, -the police are telepathic in the 1800's, -developer forces you to play a single way for almost everything you do, while forcing you to watch unskippable cutscenes.Conclusion:a lot of people are praising this from the floor to the sky, but its pretty easy for me to see they haven't played games with really good crafting systems, or games where you're given a lot of tools to solve many problems in different ways.i'm enjoying this because of the 20 dollar price tag, i don't think there's anything rdr2 offers that isn't already out there, and performed better and faster. just not with the 1800's setting.i figured rockstar was hiding something legendary with all the fanboy hype and the huge price tag, but i'd say this is a 5 or 6/10, not a 10/10.a lot of guys aren't going to look past the pretty graphics and the atmosphere, which is fine by me. but i don't think a game 'looking pretty' should enable it to get an automatic 10/10 =p

author: Colonel Sanders
review: One of, if not THE single greatest story experiences in my life. Red Dead Redemption 2 could stand toe to toe with any of the greats. Between the vastly expansive and seemingly alive map, to the incredible attention to detail that Rockstar has become notorious for. But above all, the graphics are absolutely breathtaking. Every face has emotion, the shadows are so well done that at times this game can seem almost like a movie. If you have been thinking about playing this game, disregard any experience you've had with a Rockstar title and just jump in, I promise you you'll absolutely love it. Oh yeah, I almost forgot to mention that the incredibly detailed and addictive story to this game is roughly ~70hrs, that is if you don't get caught up with the endless side missions, activities, and hell just sight seeing. 120 hours in on my first playthrough and I can already promise I'll be playing through this title time and time again for years to come.

author: Kartonpiyer
review: Not much to talk about its single player: a game with perfect (and linear as hell) story, beautiful atmosphere and well written characters. There are some issues like crashes, but nothing game breaking.For the online part: there are tons of content, pvp events, roles, daily challenges etc. But without scripted events of single player mode, online version of the world itself (free roam) feels a bit empty. There is also no such thing as p2w as people complain.. You just jump in everyday, do your dailies and you get everything you need in no time. PvP is mostly skill based: if you are good with your aim, then rank or any consumables doesn't really matter. All it takes is a single head shot. There are cheaters here and there, you just avoid them and you are good. Connection issues are also there, sometimes it ruins your missions, but since no mission lasts more than 5-10 minutes it is negligible.To sum up: RDR2 is clearly one of the best game ever released.

author: Pricey
review: After reading the initial launch day reviews about the appalling state of the game I thought I'd give it a few weeks to let Rockstar sort out the issues.  Perhaps I should have given it a few months (or years) instead.I can launch the game, so that's a good start considering so many people had issues with the launcher.  I read a number of articles about how best to configure the game for stability, looks and frame rate.  Once configured, I ran the benchmark on my i9-9900k with an RTX 2080.  It ran well with a resulting 84 fps average.That's where the good news stopped.  Trying to play the game results in constant crashes.  I can't play more than 5 minutes without it crashing.With over 2 dozen AAA titles installed I don't have an issue with any of them crashing.  Ever.This title is still broken.  I recommend leaving it for another few months, and seeing what reviewers have to say about its stability then.

author: RenegadeNic
review: Pros:-Beautiful open world-Some of the best side quests and hilarious encounters-Immersive rootin' tootin' cowboy experience-You can pet dogs-You can "yee haw" onto your horse from a tavern balconyCons:-No checkpoints before tertiary encounters. Entire sidequests can be rendered pointless with no reward for making the wrong decision, or a mistake, with no way to undo besides reloading an older save. Some interesting encounters can be lost and difficult/impossible to find again if you die during the encounter.-Some parts are "too realistic" Example: Cougars are stealthy and instantly kill you. This can happen while you're out trying to track a legendary animal or doing something else important.-Very long horse rides that require constantly tapping the same key in a rhythm to reduce travel time. Game could've used more fast travel points-Not much weapon variety. You can fully customize your initial revolvers and not much will ever be better than those.For the above reasons, I definitely recommend playing through the main story and hitting up any side quests you come across, but I can only recommend doing legendary hunting and tertiary objectives(bounty hunting is the best if you want to do any of them) for completion if you absolutely hate yourself.

author: TKY665
review: Storywise, this is one of the most wonderful games out there, Period. However, this PC port of Red Dead Redemption 2 has many technical flaws, and they need serious attention from Rockstar. What is point of writing such a great story if you can't properly deliver it to your PC players? For that reason alone, I cannot up-vote this game. I have spent my hard-earned money on this unfinished PC port, and I don't want others to make the same mistake. So, my advice to others is DON't BUY THIS GAME ON PC, AS IT IS RIDDLED WITH TECHNICAL PROBLEMS AND GRAPHICAL BUGS.

author: Manic Toaster
review: 200ish hours in... Core mechanics of the game are fun, it's a bit of a grind, but overall enjoyable. Crashes often and without warning causing you to lose everything you have on the back of your horse. CHINESE HACKERS IN EVERY SERVER and Rockstar can't or don't want to implement decent anti-cheat. Absolutely kills the game and why I've stopped playing.

author: Krex
review: Unacceptable status for  a full price AAA-game!Online mode is great but gamebraking bugs and endless loading srceens about every ~3 hours are normal...*My complete Bounty Hunter business don't work because its broken and the suppurt can't help me.

author: Mars
review: The Game itself is fantastic. I doubt i need to describe it much, the graphics are stunning and the gameplay and story are fantastic.The only issue is that the game periodically crashes for no apparent reason. This wasn't a major issue. It was annoying but as long as I saved often it didn't bother me too much.But now. 44 hours in, the game has suddenly decided to stop working altogether. I can reach the main menu, but whenever I try to load in it crashes. I've asked around and tried everything to get it working again but absolutely nothing has worked. And because I have to be in game to access the save/load menu, I can't even check if I have a corrupted save.This is a major game breaking issue and until you get absolute confirmation that it has been absolutely 100% fixed, then I'd recommend that you don't waste your money.

author: Honigpanda
review: Possibly the most immersive open world game I've ever seen - even three years after it was released. Every interaction with the environment feels natural and convincing. Atmosphere and staging - breathtaking. The (voice) actors - fantastic. A wild west in which one would like to lose oneself.At the same time the worst part, the most user-unfriendly UI, key assignment without any external or internal consistency. Do you want to save quickly? Click your way through five menus and then three more back. Immersion breaking. Pick up object? Five different buttons, depending on the situation. Accept money from a stranger with the same key as last time? Jokes on you, this time the button lets you strangle him. You are wanted now. Duh.Any attempt to enjoy the game goes down in frustration with the incompetent implementation. Maybe it's better to play with a controller. Unfortunately not to be recommended with mouse and keyboard.

author: HerpesAteMyDog
review: Red Dead Online has been a huge disappointment. It is yet another RockStar Grindy game where you spend hours grinding for nothing. There is barely any missions online, and numerous hack loop holes that people exploit. I see people nuking an entire server and killing everyone in one shot. One thing that was very disappointing is that you cannot sell horses or tame horses. You spend $50 dollars on a game then you are expected to spend more money on gold to be able to do anything like bounty hunting. I feel like this game is yet another example of the rich always being able to afford whatever they want, while people that have less money have to grind. I strongly discourage you to buy this game unless you plan on playing the story mode only. Don't waste your time or money.

author: Rexy.Leonard
review: RED DEAD REDEMPTION 2[Story was reviewed on the Xbox One X]Reviewed by Rexy.Leonard42 Hours on recordDate: 13/09/2021[CAMPAIGN]Before I start the review, I would like to say I have only played chapter 1 of the story, so my review of the story is small. Red Dead Redemption 2 is a really engaging story and game. Like Rockstar Games hit Grand Theft Auto V the game uses its surroundings and story missions to make cool action events. The large map lets you see side events and other side quests making the world feel more alive. Red Dead Redemption 2 has an amazing story and great gameplay and I strongly recommend playing this game.[MULTIPLAYER]Red Dead Online is not as good as its story but still has up's. The game is best when going through the story with your friends working out how to finish the mission. unlike grand theft auto online the game lets you complete the story without any paywalls. I could finish the game without having to spend a single dollar on the game while getting new guns and outfits.If you would like to support my reviews please give them a thumbs up or award them.Reviewers HardwareI7 9th generationNVIDIA GeForce RTX 207016GB RAMNVMe M.2 Solid State Drive 2TB

author: Oblong360
review: I SHOULD HAVE READ THE REVIEWS!!I will start with this: This game is incredible. The story mode is SUPER fun, great acting, cool side stories, enough to keep me satisfied. It's an outstanding game, considering you have the hardware to support it. However, Rockstar is still running this game on PC like an Xbox game with zero **** given about getting up to par with PC gamers. Online mode crashes all the time. The software is not friendly with my machine, which is a top notch gaming computer, and I wonder if other people have this issue? I'm getting up to 94 C and that is likely because the software sucks and hasn't been made to be compatible with PC. No other game do I have a problem with this. Also, the people who play online are racist to black characters,  and the whole thing is just a huge cash grab from Rockstar, who could really give a **** if this software runs smoothly or not. But for 60 bucks (more if you get upgrades) it had better be stellar. Shame on Rockstar, taking a big dump on their PC gamers. Buy at your own risk.

author: Kimchi Cat
review: Game is great, It offers hours of fun , a lot of places to explore, secrets to uncover.I love the offline map system where you can keep track of animal locations and herb locations byvisiting the areas. Really sells the idea that Arthur is learning more about the world around him as he explores it. Online is great too if you are willing to ignore having a few modders that change the time of day, change the weather, kick you off your horse, teleport, or just straight up spam you with explosions. But other than that, joining another session is always an option.One issue with the game I've had is purchasing it and having it show up in my my library as a game I own. But still redirecting me to the store page as if I dont own the game. (Hopefully it gets fixed soon) but overall the game is a solid buy, if you have a lot of time to burn or just want a great narrative to sit through and enjoy, or if just love walking around a gorgeous looking open world. this is a must own title.

author: dragon
review: Overall I can't recommend this game. It's not a bad game, it looks and sounds stunning, the world is astonishing and the story it tells is fascinating. However the open world loses a lot of its purpose as soon as you realize how restrictive the game really is. You would expect that such a massive world created in a modern game engine would let you do whatever you want and see what happens, but unfortunately that's not the case. Instead this game is stuck in this "worst of both worlds"-state where it's frustratingly realistic about aspects one couldn't care less about, while not being realistic enough in actual fun or productive ways. Note: Some things might only apply to red dead online, as I've spent far more time there.Examples:1. Nearly everything you do needs to go through some detailed but lengthy animations. Sounds okay at first, but when you're stealing some supplies and an angry mob of workers is after you you're still going through the same long animation when stowing the supplies on your horse as if you were just out in the wilderness with all the time in the world, as if your character wanted to be beat up by them. At least give us hastier animations for heated situations.2. You can lasso stuff ranging from enemies to animals and you can even drag corpses behind you while riding, however you'll soon come to realize that you can't do that with anything you want, but rather only the stuff Rockstar Games wants you to lasso. You can drag a deer carcass behind you, but not a coyote one. You can drag a dead bounty target behind you, but not a hogtied one. The physics engine is clearly able to let me do whatever I want, yet I'm not allowed. And please game let me be stupid and lasso a tree branch while riding at full speed to dismount myself! You don't need to hold my hand all the time, the massive aim assist on the lasso is already enough to make me feel like I'm barely responsible for a good throw.3. Many animals spawn in pre-determined locations and it doesn't take long for the player to notice. One could argue an eagle has a favorite spot on this very bridge it often sits on, however I can kill the eagle and there will be another one in the exact same spot, reacting the exact same way the next time I approach. Plants and lootable items are the same. Everything is pre-determined and a more dynamic spawn system could really add a lot more atmosphere here. I'd love to find some mushrooms in unexpected places because the spawn mechanism instead of having pre-determined locations would use semi-simulated temperature, humidity, sun/weather conditions and so on to determine where they appear. I wouldn't mind if a bird sits in an awkward spot every once in a while if that meant they could in theory sit everywhere, regardless of where Rockstar thinks they look good.4. During missions or encounters it's a coin flip whether or not you can still do any side activity. You might still be able to buy ammo, but anything else you really just have to pray for.5. Horse physics and AI are really hit or miss. A lot your horse can do makes absolutely no sense, yet sometimes the tiniest rock on the ground gets your horse in the mood to come to a full stop. Usually the AI will try to avoid collisions, except when the horse feels like needlessly running into things and sometimes the AI will make it feel like you have very little actual control over the horse, which can often even be the cause for crashes.6. The honor and wanted systems aren't really smart, impactful or interesting. I can murder people regularly and easily make up in the honor system just by taking proper care of my horse and being resourceful with the animals I hunt. When you commit a crime with witnesses around they will usually report it and get you wanted. Unfortunately this witness system is kind of a mess. I can be in the middle of nowhere and kill someone who happened to just ride by. The game will now try really hard to spawn another person nearby just so they can be a witness and get me in trouble. This has happened way too often to be just a coincidence. Furthermore apparently witnesses are just impossibly sharp, because somehow they can look at a dead body and tell whether they were innocents that I murdered or criminals who tried to kill me. Speaking of honor, how do murders that no one knows of affect my honor? And why is it not murder if I kill what the game considers enemies during a mission or activity? Why is it okay to kill the people who ambushed me, but if I sit on one of their horses for one second it's horse theft? None of this makes sense, but fear not, the honor system is pretty pointless anyways and the wanted system doesn't even try to make it subtle when it spawns another set of law enforcers right in front of you when you were just about to lose them.7. Your inventory makes no sense. You are only allowed to hold a certain amount of each item, so if you kill 10 wolves you won't be able to hold more of their meat, yet if you kill just basically any other type of animal you can carry their meat just fine, because it's a different type. Or you can have 10 cooked meat seasoned with oregano, 10 seasoned with thyme and 10 seasoned with mint but you can't carry 11 uncooked pieces. No biggie, but still odd.8. No consistency. There are campfires you can use to cook and ones that somehow don't inherit the super power of heating up food. Want to see what happens when you put your horse on a train? Well too bad, it's just not possible. You want to put up your camp here? Well we can't do 'here' but we can do nearby, on the next spot we deem 'valid'. Want to sit on this bench? Sorry this one isn't suitable for sitting, try one in a saloon. You want to approach this mission in a slightly different way than we intended for you? Sorry, can't have that. You want to stow animal carcasses on a wagon not specifically meant for the player to do this? Well you can try, but our animations and physics will make it as hard and glitchy for you as they possibly can. You're hunting multiple animals from a herd? Better make sure not to run too far, because otherwise we'll despawn the animals you already killed! Sorry you can only pull out your fishing rod while standing directly next to water and when you do you lose the ability to run until you put it back in your pocket, too bad.And then on top of all this there are still plenty bugs and small annoyances. I'll go ahead and say that I don't like the gunplay in Rockstar Games since GTA IV. The aiming feels sluggish and delayed and in a lot of cases it just seems like it's truly balanced around controller+auto aim. PvP isn't very fun either in my opinion and just the slow nature of the game in general, where realistic character movement and behavior is way more important than player control doesn't really suit me. Instead of me having control of a character it most of the times feels like the character and game has control over me, where certain actions and animations need to play before I get my control back. Selecting weapons or fending off charging enemies in melee range, none of that really feels like I'm the one doing it. I'm just waiting/hoping for the prompts to show up and hit the buttons, often times not entirely sure how I even got a certain action from my character to occur. I just wish we could go back a little more to how things used to be in for instance GTA: San Andreas, where I select a weapon with the scroll wheel and it's simply selected. I can select it basically at any time, I don't have to wait for certain animations to finish before I can select it. If I get hit in melee I don't have to select it again. And when I move it feels like my character is responding immediately to my inputs. I don't mean we need to scrap everything we got since then, because in a lot of ways the newer games are also a lot better, but just dial back that realism slider a little more back toward direct player control.

review: It ran perfectly at ultra and it's just one of the most incredible singleplayer games ever made. It's very slow but it's the type of game that just sticks in your mind for months after you finish.

author: Rocky
review: The story is awesome. The online play is a bit of a grind but there is plenty to be doing; trading, bounty hunting, collecting, moonshining. Combat is engaging and fast paced, PvP can be brutal and frustrating if you've got some asshat hacker thinking hes edge. Anyway, along with all that the scenery in this game is stunning and you might just be prone to wandering about for an hour or two soaking up the place. I've put in over 150 hours in this game and I am still discovering parts of the map that I've not seen. Its been a treat for the eyes.

author: Liza
review: The best game I have ever played, the story is incredible, the characters are brought to life by very good writing and acting. Arthur Morgan is easily Rockstar best protagonist in a video game and for me is the best protagonist in any game ever. His character arc is compelling and emotional, and the actor did an amazing job voicing him. The open world is the most believable and alive open world I've ever seen and I have played a lot of them. The amazing attention to details that Rockstar put into the map as well as the AI that is head and shoulders above other open world games is present and better than ever in RDR2. Hunting and fishing in this game can be as fun as hunting and fishing in full fledged sims. There is an absurd amount of mini games and customisation that keeps you immersed into the game.in conclusion, this game is a masterpiece unlike anything we have ever seen before and definitely something I would highly recommend

author: NTylerWeTrust
review: I love this game, if I were able to complete it I'm sure it could very well crack my favorite games of all time list. If I could complete it...At this point I've had it with the game constantly crashing and having to do the same missions or sequences over and over and over. And now that I'm nearing the end of the game, its happening more and more frequently that I'm sorry, I can't waste my time dealing with this. I have very little time to actually play games nowadays, and less time to play games that I know are going to take a large chunk of time to finish. So it pains me to give up for the time being and just say f**k this game.I would love to return to the game and complete Arthur's story, he's left a great impression on me and this is a game I would recommend to everyone, but in this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ state were I can't reliably finish it and at any moment my game (and a lot of the time my computer) will crash setting me back 30, 20, 15 hell even 5 minutes just sucks. I'm done.I cannot recommend this version of the game that I waited over a year for and its flat out broken. In the past 72 hours my computer has crashed 20+ times, anywhere from starting a missions, from coming out of a cutscene, during a cutscene, hell even pausing the game for 30 seconds to come back and its frozen. Wait for the game to be fixed someday.

author: Zanteogo
review: To be clear, I only recommend Red Dead 2 if you are into the Rock Star "GTA" style of games. It's a good game, but has the same qualities and issues as the Grand Thief Auto games.Pros:-Graphics are crazy good, I have a high end computer and all I can say is "wow".-Voice acting is done well, and there is more spoken dialog in this game than the whole Lord Of The Rings trilogy.-Social "AI" done well. The way other character interact with you seems natural. Really notice this at the camp.-World is large. Well setup for a period piece game.Cons:-Missions seem to be too much alike. Due to the restrictions of being a period piece, they can only do so much. Also honestly, this is a flaw of the "GTA" formula. -Illusions of choice, the game has an "honor" system. Do good things it goes up, bad things it goes down. Doesn't seem to make much difference however, other than shop prices. Plus, when you do the story missions you are locked in, and pretty much act like a murderous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. However your honor is unaffected by these missions. So you rob a bank and kill swarms of police? No worries. Loot a dead body in cave with no one seeing you? Honor goes down.Overall, a good game but held back by the limits of the "GTA" formula. I also think they had planned to make this game have more depth but never got to that point. Prime example is the camp. It's implied you need to collect money for it and can use this cash for various upgrades to the camp. For the most part it's a total waste of time. In fact, the whole camp maintenance system is made to appear to be important, but really does very little. The game also suffers a horrible enjoyment curve. The first half is crazy good, then once you realize it's not really going anywhere and your on a rinse and repeat cycle for here on in, it goes from crazy good, to just ok.

review: There is so much to do in this game.  Its also beautiful and you can play many, many different ways.  Hunting, crafting, stealing, or just doing mostly story missions if you want.  The only bad thing about the game is it has consolitis.  In other words some of the mechanics and controls are a bit wonky, but don't let that stop you.  The amount of time you could sink into this game is mind blowing.  I think it feels a bit like skyrim in the old west in that way.

I think the   left a little more to be desired but overall, RDR2 is #1 on my list. On a second playthrough, I spent the most time in chapter 2... I would recommend doing the same.
