author: Tora
review: yehaw

author: Mr Fisk
review: I was hesitant at first since I absolutely hate the uncivilized "Wild West" where we saw humanity at it's most disgusting stage of evolution where greed controlled everything. However... This game is so well made and beautiful, and instead of glorifying this time, it depicts humanity for what we are, disgusting bandits, greedy sleezebags, or just poor folk trying to survive in a world that feeds on weakness. One can skip the online part completely since it's a Rockstar game. I didn't even bother starting it. I get the theory behind it (wild west with your friends yeeehaaaw), but after stepping into a Rockstar online universe once, never ever again will I make that mistake. Rockstar can create amazing games, but I have never seen a company fail so hard at online gaming as they. Even Fallout 76 is a better online game, and that says a lot.

author: Humble
review: It goes without saying this is one of the best games ever made. Countless GOTY awards and 10/10 ratings across the board. Personally I've been a fan of Red Dead for many years going back to the release of Red Dead Revolver in 2004, I can honestly say this game will go down as one of the best I will ever play. It's one of my favorites and I'm currently working on a 2nd 100% Play through as I've done with the First RDR. Rockstar spent 8 years developing this masterpiece and is shows. I do wish the Online would get more attention because it has so much potential. I highly recommend this game to anyone, Regardless if you are a fan of western gunslingers or not. This is a 10/10 in my book.

author: Redsleepless
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just the best game of all time, but quite possibly the greatest achievement in the history of human civilisation.Every pixel in Red Dead Redemption 2 is handcrafted by the gods themselves, imbued with a sense of life and energy that is simply unparalleled in any other game. The level of detail is mind-boggling, from the way the light filters through the trees to the way the dirt clings to your boots. It's as if you're really there, living and breathing in this incredible world that Rockstar has created.And what a world it is. The open-world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game, but a living, breathing world that exists independently of you. From the bustling streets of Saint Denis to the desolate plains of New Hanover, every inch of the map is meticulously crafted to create a sense of place that is simply unmatched in any other game. The world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game, but a work of art.But it's not just the world that's so incredible. The story of Red Dead Redemption 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece. It's a sweeping epic that takes you on an emotional journey that will leave you breathless. You play as Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van der Linde gang, and as you travel with him on his journey of redemption, you can't help but become emotionally invested in his story. The characters are so well-drawn and fully realised that they feel like real people, and their struggles become your own.The mechanics of Red Dead Redemption 2 are so satisfying, so perfectly crafted, that you'll never want to put the mouse down. Whether you're hunting game in the wilderness, robbing trains with your gang, or just exploring the world, the game is always rewarding and never dull. And let's not forget the horse riding mechanics, which are so immersive that you'll feel like you're really galloping across the plains of the American West.And if all that wasn't enough, Red Dead Redemption 2 also has an amazing, slightly controversial, multiplayer mode. But once you start teaming up with your friends to take down bandits, competing in horse races, or just exploring the world together, the multiplayer mode is endlessly entertaining and offers countless hours of fun.In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game, but a work of art that transcends the medium. It's a masterpiece of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay that will leave you in awe of what a video game can be. If you haven't played Red Dead Redemption 2, you owe it to yourself to experience this incredible achievement in human history.

author: Kirutastic
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is an open world story driven western game set in the year 1899 and follows the story of Arthur Morganand the Dutch Van Der'Linde gang as they try to hold on to whats left of the ever-dying lifestyle of being outlaws. as the law and the modern world catches up to them the game tackles a story that i have never seen told in a game before, it is not just GTA V set in a spaghetti western theme, the rich and gut wrenching story will have you pulled in and immersed.some complaints about this game is the immersion, at what point does it go from a cool gimmick to "oh god why don't i just go outside" but personally this is a game that you can get in to and really just get lost in the visually game breaking graphics and the gameplay which personally i am a big fan of, sure first person isnt the most practical but if you plug in a controller its actually not bad. every game will have problems but that goes for all medias, for an almost 4 year old game this is such a mind blowing game and experience. play the game, and i promise you will have an amazing time.9/10

author: ALDI
review: I originally played RDR2 on ps4 back in 2018 and couldn't put it down, and was then gifted it for Christmas on pc in 2019 - and I still can't put it down. At the moment I'm aiming for a 100% completion both in game and on steam achievements and I genuinely feel that I will be dead inside when I eventually achieve this. I've also started to play the online, (originally for the achievements) while not too polished - is fun. I can see myself playing it a fair bit before tiring of it. The game runs really well on most PC rigs, but make sure to take some time figuring out what settings work best for YOUR pc to truly get the best out of the visuals. But the story is really where the love lies in this game for me, I came from red dead redemption thinking no protag could best John Marston, but Rockstar really hit the nail in the head with Arthur Morgan's character and the supporting characters, story and environment. There's a lot to this game, you can speed through the story if you want to but you can only first experience this game once and so, I'd recommend that you take your time with the story and exploration. Do all the side missions, talk to all and everyone - go and look for strange things in the environment or even take the time to just sit on the edge of a cliff and watch the scenery. Maybe I could blame the pandemic for my absolute love for this game and for allowing me to be "outside" while most of us couldn't be, but truly this is Rockstar's 'hidden' gem of a game and I will continue to recommend it to anyone that considers playing.

author: BloodRush
review: MASTERPIECE! And I don't use that word lightly.This game was perfect and has set a new level for open world games to achieve. I would have happily paid a full price for this game if I knew this is so good. Also Rockstar, if you keep releasing such an amazing game once every decade, you're forgiven for milking GTA Online and for the trash GTA Trilogy Remastered.So, about the game, I don't know how do I praise this game more so I am just going to state some facts.- This game is probably one of the best looking games out there so I don't think anything more needs to be said about how beautiful the graphics are.- It has the best open world you will ever find. You can interact with anyone you like (even animals). You can rob any train, any person, any carriage, anything. Your behaviour decides what kind of world you create around yourself. You help people? It will be rewarded in the future in some way or other. You harm people? You will have trouble in the future in some way or other. The world feels immersive, alive and is full of interactions everywhere you go.- There are 4 endings, out of which 3 are easy to come by according to your choices (I have finished one, as of writing this review). Halfway through, it picks up the pace, it will keep you on your toes and you will always want to go for that "just one more task" feel. The story is so good that I haven't even watched movies this good. It will take time but it delivers. All your questions will be answered so please don't google anything about why something is happening (I did, and I regret it).- Your gameplay and choices actually matter. The world that I am playing in might be totally different from yours. There are tiny elements in the game which decide a lot of conversations around you and how the world reacts to what you do. A lot of small things which you do will have an impact on the world in ways you couldn't even think were possible. It almost feels real.- Optional missions are something I tried to do as many as possible. I am one of those who hates optional content. I usually skip all of that and speedrun the story because I am here for the story. This was the first game that I have played which gave good optional missions with their own little story going on. The stories were polished, fun, emotional and sometimes even sad.- IT IS HUGE. The content in this game is so much that I don't know if I will ever be able to 100% it. Hundreds of flora and fauna to discover, so many items to look for and craft, so many places to discover (I discovered a whole new place in the last 15 min of my story). There is so much to do that I guarantee, just exploring will provide you tens of hours of fun.Rockstar, if you are going to do something like this once a decade, I don't care what you do with GTA. You're forgiven for blatant scamming.

author: AlphaOfZFL
review: I feel like the difference between the Witcher 3 and RDR2 is that the former focuses more on complex story choices but characters and their relationship are portrayed more or less one-dimensionally, or to put simply, too "perfect". Ciri was always the lovable daughter, Regis, Dandelion and Zoltan were always the loyal friends, and Vesemir was always the graceful mentor. RDR2 on the other hand is all about challenging that. As Arthur, you witness the making and the breakdown of relationships in a way you never believed was possible; you're forced to cope with death and farewells, struggle with identity, question human nature, and of course, find redemption. Rockstar has managed to push the boundaries of RPG story telling once again with its unique style.

author: Viporex
review: I've played this game for at least over 150+ hours on PS4, just got it on PC. Best game I've ever played, would recommend to any casual gamer, great 60 hour story, easy to learn hard to master combat, and near endless gameplay with many in depth and well designed mechanics. The world is immersive and expansive with so many wonderfully voiced dialogue lines, countless random encounters, and personality filled characters that even after your 5th playthrough you will still be finding new things.❤ Audience ❤☐ Beginner☑ Casual Gamer☑ Normal Gamer☑ Expertstory mode is enjoyable and doesn't require much skill☼ Graphics ☼☐ Bad☐ Alright☐ Good☑ Beautiful☐ Fantasticneed a beefy computer♬ Music ♬☐ Bad☐ Alright☑ Good☐ Beautiful☐  FantasticPretty decent, don't like country music myself that much. Still good composition though.☠ Difficulty ☠☐ Easy☐ Average☑ Easy to learn / Hard to master☐ Hard☐ Unfairpretty casual story mode, hard and sweaty online mode though§ Bugs §☐ Bugs destroy the game☐ Lots of bugs☐ Few Bugs☑ You can use them for speedrun☐ Nothing encounteredrelatively polished☯ Story ☯☐ There is none☐ Bad☐ Alright☑ Good☑ FantasticDon't rush it or look at any content on youtube, I made that mistake. leaves you wanting to play the game again for the first time.⚔ Gameplay ⚔☐ Frustrating☐ Sleepy☐ Boring☑ Fun☐ ChallengingIts like a deep puddle, it gives you your items and you can use them however you want, finding new ways to fight.۞ Game time / Length ۞☐ Really short (0 - 3 hours)☐ Short (4 - 8 hours)☐ Few hours (10 - 20 hours) [if you focus on the main story]☐ Long (40-60 hours) [if you complete everything]☐ Very Long (61-100 hours)☑ Extremely Long (101+ hours)could play this game for thousands of hours, especially with mods$ Price / Quality $☑ Full price☑ Wait for Sale☐ Don't buy☐ Refund it if you canworth it, but waiting for a sale is acceptable.Online mode needs some working on to be fair. Rockstar was never great at that sort of thing.EDIT: Changed some stuff, i feel like i exaggerated a bit and was biased.

author: Coachjr7241.
review: This is easily one of the best games I have ever played. Rockstar did such an amazing job on this game. The amount of content alongside the visuals, soundtrack and story is absolutely incredible, a masterpiece. Everything compliments itself very well to create a wonderful immersive experience. The open world itself is massive and there is much you are able to do that it is quite impressive. The games presentation of a pre 19th century world is quite accurate and tells a story in itself. Towns are packed with things to do in them along a plethora of dialogue between the people in it. The sheer amount of character development within the story, side missions as well as just open world things makes you connect with the main and side characters on a different level then most other games. The beginning of the game starts off slow, but once it picks up, it becomes a roller coaster of pivotal moments in the story that keep you on the edge of your seat.Wish I was able to play this game for the first time again and experience it all. It truly was a wonderful experience. I would recommend this game to anyone, full price. Thanks for reading.

author: Crim0408
review: For starters, the campaign is simply awesome. The open world is really fun to explore, and has a lot of things going on, throughout my time playing, both on PS4 and PC, I've never gotten bored of it. The story is interesting and has believable characters, totally worth going in with minimal spoilers, a hard feat nowadays, but worth a shot.The multiplayer is a grind, but one that I found a lot more fun than GTAO. The gunplay feels a lot more weighty and impactful than GTA's, as well, the world has more going on. The open world has been nerfed some from singleplayer, but that's mainly small things, that would be nice to see, but aren't defining factors in the enjoyment of the open world.Overall, both the full game and buying just the online are fine options, and honestly, totally worth it to experience the game, I'd recommend it to anyone wanting an alternative to GTA, or for a fun online experience with friends.

author: orthon
review: The game has a good story with lots of action and also lots of side missions and random encounters. There is a lot to explore in the big map. The game has good graphics and a lot of attention to detail. Definitely worth the price. 10/10

author: Prince Striker
review: I'm not a fan of typical first person shooter games. I'm actually more of a nintendo and indie game type of person. But I won't deny I liked the game's story when I got introduced to it. But my word, when I actually got a chance to play someone else's copy for a bit... I was hooked. I got it for myself and I haven't been able to put it down very long.I love that the game lets me go at my slow detailed pace. I love the bits of humanity and cruelty that are on display throughout it. <3There are so many reminders of cruelty and beauty in the world. And as someone who shares the same personality type as Dutch... oi does it serve as a warning for me. Also dang it Arthur, I love how complex yet simple you are. Again, normally I'm more of your Artsy, Indie, Creative games sorts. So the fact that this game gripped me eventually is a huge statement to the quality of such a thing. Oh yes, and it's also been really nice to actually find a healthy way to deal with my gun phobia I got from child-hood trauma. I've never actually felt happy with a gun, but when I got to customize one and it actually felt like my personality... it was such an odd mental switch. Now my friend who loves (but is a stickler for safety with) guns can actually chat with me about it and I understand him. I actually am open to working on my phobia with him now that I have a basic interest, but again, he and I are gonna take it carefully and step by step. Glad this game opened a healthy way for me to finally be willing to tackle my childhood fear there.

author: Nightcaller
review: This is the 3rd time I've purchased Red Dead Redemption 2 and every time, I get the more pricey Ultimate Edition even though the bonuses it comes with become obsolete very quickly. Me paying way more than I should for this game each time should tell you how much I love and value it.  RDR2 is one of the most immersive games I've ever played and has one of the best written stories I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. Along with the main questline are a crazy amount of Stranger Missions(Side Quests) scattered all over the game world which all are very unique with stories that are on par and sometimes even better than the main storyline. The many characters of RDR2 are very well written and you are guaranteed to fall in love with Arthur Morgan and all the other people he journeys and meets with along the way.  The amount of details in this game are also nuts! RDR2 may be an open world story game but it also passes as an actual Wild West simulator with real world simulation. Your clothes get dirty if you don't bathe, not eating has negative affects to Arthur and can cause him to lose visible weight, NPC's will react to almost everything you do and remember you for it, leave an animal carcass you've killed and watch it slowly decay over a few days, and so much more. Hell when your horse goes into the cold, their balls shrink! There is so much little details in this game that has no purpose other than making you feel immersed and actually in a real world Wild West simulation. That alone is worth the price.  Now for Red Dead Online. This is coming from someone who pretty much no lifed Red Dead Online at one point in time. HARD SKIP! Online is fun for the first few hours with friends but after finishing the few co-op story missions, all the other activities become very grindy and repetitive. If you buy Red Dead, you're mainly buying it for it's singleplayer story and not really the online component.  I recommend Red Dead Redemption 2 to anyone who is looking for a very immersive escape into the Wild West or who wants a really well written story to experience. Go have fun being an outlaw! 11/10

author: Yilly
review: Bought at discount.Only played Singleplayer. (Tried multiplayer only briefly but wasn't for me and it kept crashing).The game is a roller coaster. It got me hooked from the first few minutes and I just came back for more.It also had some downright infuriating moments that had me just quitting the game. (Like horses deciding to give up on life so they casually walk into a campfire and burn to death, thus making them permanently die and leaves you stranded with your saddle.)Its riddled with bugs and archaic design and the game feels more rushed the last third of the game.Characters and enviroments appear and dissapear in just a few missions and the mission design feels like it gets more and more strict. Also your allies does not know what cover is so if you leave them for 5 seconds to loot something real quick they will die and fail the mission.I also had some issues playing through this game that hadnt been solved since atleast 2018. Things like having the wrong gun or ammo type into a "Duel Event" which forced you to restart events. Character also got stuck at crucial moments so had to just sit there and watch them fail over and over again until i finally got permission to skip it.Game also resets your loadout so if you prepare with certain weapons you suddenly have some other ones and since you can't call your horse on some missions you are stuck with weapons you didn't pick.The sound is top notch, the environments and attention to detail is some of the best i've ever seen. I loved most characters and how they interacted with eachother. It's enjoyable riding around to explore and I quite enjoyed doing some hunting.The world feels alive and lived in and the people you meet feel authentic.It's definitely a game I recommend despite its many flaws.

author: mohiteshk
review: This is the best action/adventure, open-world game ever. The amount of stuff to discover in game is huge. The attention to detail is higher than Rockstar levels. The music is beautiful. The graphics look like they're from a painting. The gameplay is satisfying. The world design is mesmerizing .And even better than all of the above stuff is the story. It will make you cry. The character development is so good, you'll remember most of the npc's. And you'll learn to love your gang. You'll understand why each character does what they do. The story combined with the music is surreal. You will come to love Arthur Morgan and his gang. This is a legendary game. It is worth full price. PS: Once I finished this, it took me 3-4 months to get back into another game.

author: Matty-t
review: This is a great game, but not for the reasons many point to. RDR2 is the world champion in the field of shallow game mechanics. All the 'survival' aspects are as simple as refilling your health/stamina/dead-eye. Keep clean to maintain stamina, sleep to refresh stamina, eat to maintain health, its all a slight twist on mechanics we've seen a million times over. The game also controls like ♥♥♥♥. Rockstar's commitment to animation is awesome for storytelling within cutscenses and a hinderence to your ability to control Arthur. The shooting mechanics are ancient. The game's main and side missions are ridiculously restrictive (I once failed for going back 10 feet to my horse for a different gun). The actual video game stuff is ripped straight out of PS3 era games.Luckily the game is first class in sound, visuals, the open world itself, and story/characters. The soundtrack provides so many perfect tracks for key moments. The game is beautiful. The world is a blast to explore at you leisure. The real selling point here is the story and characters. Each character is dynamic and distinct. The story seamlessly integrates the game's wide array of thematic material while keeping the characters and their development as the central focus. This is a good as story-telling has ever been in a video game. So, in short, I do not think this is the most immersive video game ever made. But, it offers something at least as good. A wonderful story that you won't forget full of great characters set in a perfectly realized world bolstered by world-class sound and visuals.

author: 𝓢𝓪𝓷𝓸𝓶𝓪𝓻𝓾
review: Almost 10 years on Steam and there are plenty of games that really made me WOW but RDR2 is seriously on a different level. I barely wrote any review on Steam, this might be one of my first one, but I feel the need to do it, especially after over 100 hours spent playing this masterpiece.Well, the first thing about this game that really made my jaw dropped is its OPEN WORLD. Hands down this game has the best open world graphic ever. Weather effects are on point, wild animals reaction is above and beyond also. I once left my game idle for few minutes and even saw a black bear trying to catch fishes near the river. Birds got scared and flew away when you're passing by on your horse.....everything is so real in this game. And not just the graphic and its open world, the story is awesome, it feels like you're watching a movie. Game soundtracks are TOP NOTCH.But that's pretty much all the positive reviews of this game is about. I'm not saying the gameplay is bad, but for me, it aint great either. The gun fight is not intense or challenging at all. the character control, house control is just.......meh. I couldn't keep track of how many times I got myself stuck in places that Arthur or his horse couldnt even move or perform any action. Horse control is straight up horrible also, riding it in Saint Dennis is a nightmare cuz bumping into one person can lead to whole lot of troubles. To sum it up, the control in this game doesn't match its beauty.In conclusion, this game is still a true masterpiece if you don't seek any extreme gaming experience and just wanna lay back on your couch and enjoy the story line with easy, relaxing gameplay. P/s; I hope this helps. And sorry my English is horrible.

author: retoid
review: Very awesome game packed with things to do!The design and graphics are really well done and thought out, even down to the specific lightning and colors of the environment. Has a great western feel to it.The AI is one of the best I've experienced in an RPG with hardly any glitches. Almost none.There are tons of side missions and things to explore and find throughout the really large map.One of the best aspects of the game is the hunting. This game blows The Hunter: Call of the Wild out of the water.There are seemingly hundreds of different animals to hunt and it's really rewarding. It's easy to load up the game and just go hunting without doing any missions what so ever and feel satisfied. Proper hunting techniques for different animals is rewarded as well and unlocks lots of unique attire and accessories. The weapon options are fantastic! And weapon modification is good as well as customization.The game starts out a bit slow but it's really good and gets you up to speed and helps you understand the game better.Once you finish up the main story, there is a rather awesome surprise that is revealed. And the game is virtually endless and playable for hundreds of hours with the hunting aspect etc.There are a few ways of travel throughout the area but horseback is by far the best. It is very satisfying and also allows you to find and experience new things all the time. Oftentimes finding unique events along the way.Definitely a very well made and thought out game, highly recommended to any RPG fan and western fan.

author: ☭Comrade Soviet☭
review: "The Stains of Time" is the boss theme and character song for Monsoon in Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance.The lyrics depict a gentle rain that washes away pain and suffering to bring them to a peaceful life, attempting to wash away the pain and suffering of one man in particular, but having no effect as the man has seemingly given up all hope. Upon realizing it has no effect, it transitions from a peaceful rain into a violent storm in a desperate attempt to erase the man's suffering, only dispersing on realizing the man is completely dead inside and is beyond hope. These lyrics seem to reflect on Monsoon's own life from his early childhood as a survivor of the Cambodian genocide, leaving him the nihilistic and hopeless man when encountered in the game.

author: Longbraz
review: Just finished the game... It leaves you touched, sadened and uplifted - all in the same time. Whatever it can be said about it, won't be enough. Rarely a game can leave me aching to play more - a new mission, a side activity, a stranger with an odd request. It grasps you and throws you deep in its world of late 19 century. The world of Read Dead Redemption 2 is so lively, believable, vibrant, beautiful and grotesque at the same time. As much as the real one. The characters are amazing, as made of flesh and bone. Slowly, you get sucked into it, attaching you to Arthur and van der Linde gang, craving to see more of their backstories, what life has for them just around the corner of the next day. Arthur Morgan is probably one of the best protagonists, and not only in a video game. And that speaks much of the quality of the story telling and character building.This is a game which will leave you both in love and heartbroken, and you will want more. Just a tiny bit more. RDR3 cannot come soon enough...

author: Venom
review: Graphics is still in my opinion one of the most beautiful a most realistic to this day.Music perfectly suits the game atmosphere and all sounds are very high quality, dubbing is the best out of any game.Gameplay is really simple and easy to learn, movement is good, shooting is good.It is really easy, you maybe dies a few times, but you will not be stuck on a mission.Completion is very hard, not hard on difficulty, but hard on time, took me 400 hours, but I was afk a lot and had another save, so it was probably about 200-250 hours.Story is perfect, you can see every character evolving as you go.Can be really different based on what your plans are, if you only want to complete the story, it will take you about 80 hours, there is also online that you can play forever.For my first 200 hours I had no bugs and the last 200 hours I had some visual glitches, about 4-5, but nothing game breaking.Easily 10/10

author: Kylenki
review: This is a *very* good game.If you liked Witcher, GTA, Oblivion/Skyrim, etc., you will like this.One particular thing this game does well is environmental factors; weather, terrain features, flora, fauna, and the like, are woven into an ecosystem that connects the player to the world. I've lived off of the land for six years in the past, and the way things fit together is nothing short of masterful. Another seemingly small factor is the attention paid to clutter; most games have stock clutter piles that just get re-arranged over and over to combine into less obvious repetition, but it is usually quite evident what they are; not so with this game--every room feels hand crafted. That kind of attention to detail is emblematic of everything in this game, which approaches perfection in RDR2.

No probs! You can live like ordinary 1899 man.I can probably spent infinite time describing how this game amazed me, but i'm just gonna give it a 9 \ 10 and i don't think we gonna see the game this good in about 3-5 years from now.

author: SpyTurtle49
review: Red dead redemption 2 is a catalyst, a push to establish videogames as serious pieces of media that are capable of telling thought provoking and dramatic stories. Red dead 2 is, and always will be my favorite game. The cinematic tension rockstar provides to this story of a gang of outlaws on the run from the law is astounding. Every mission is thoughtfully planned and executed with perfection, every stride and adventure the player takes aren't distinguished from main story content. The richness and saturation of the open world proves to deter boredom from long horse rides, and these side missions prove to strengthen the dynamic of Arthur becoming further disillusioned from dutch, and the way things are paced proves to convey Arthur as a changed man. But no game is perfect, and red dead redemption 2 is far from it. The gameplay becomes increasingly thinned out after chapter five. What makes missions full of combat and shooting is the context behind them, there is always a reason or rhyme behind every mission. And this plays beautifully into the immersion of the characters and gameplay. But after chapter 5 this context is dropped, senseless bloodshed and death every mission becomes extremely tiring. But, I think this was a conscious choice by Rockstar. As Arthur becomes disillusioned with dutch and the gang, dutch becomes less a man of mind and more a man of insanity. And the senseless bloodshed is a part of the story, like Arthur, we too feel as if there is no reason behind all of the killing. And that dutch is leading his gang into a pit of doom. This is no way excusing the lack of pushing cinematic shootout missions within the later chapters, but it at least gives context. Regardless of its faults, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an exceptional piece of media and it is the greatest story ever told within a videogame. Every part is masterfully executed and perfectly incorporated into the plot, the music, the voice acting, the story, it is amazing. I HIGHLY recommend you buy this game, and enjoy it to its fullest.By the way if you can please play this on the PS4, all actions feel more weighty and the aim-assist helps establish Arthur as an experienced and hardened gunslinger "Be Loyal To What Matters."5/5

author: BootySweat
review: The best game I have ever played, the story is incredible, the characters are brought to life by very good writing and acting. Arthur Morgan is easily Rockstar best protagonist in a video game and for me is the best protagonist in any game ever. His character arc is compelling and emotional, and the actor did an amazing job voicing him. The open world is the most believable and alive open world I've ever seen and I have played a lot of them. The amazing attention to details that Rockstar put into the map as well as the AI that is head and shoulders above other open world games is present and better than ever in RDR2. Hunting and fishing in this game can be as fun as hunting and fishing in full fledged sims. There is an absurd amount of mini games and customisation that keeps you immersed into the game.However, there are still some negative. Despite having the most amazing open world to date, Rockstar continue to use the same mission design that they have been using since GTA 4. Story mission are very linear and involve a lot of just walking and shooting and generally feel very restrictive on player's freedom. Rockstar put a lot of emphasis on realism in this game, but did not fully commit to it making the game feel awkward at times, such as hunting and skinning an animal in an realistic manner but instead of setting up a campfire yourself to cook it the game automatically set up a camp for you. While the weather such as heavy rain and snowfall are some of the best looking I have ever seen, they dont really affect the player such as making them sick if they dont seek shelter. However, I understand that this is a AAA title that need to be accessible to a wide playerbase, hence Rockstar's decision.In conclusion, this game is a masterpiece unlike anything we have ever seen before and definitely something I would recommend

author: Deku
review: This game is a work of art. The story is amazing and will make you have shivers every minute. Everything it's orchestrated with a beautiful soundtrack and shown with the best graphics i have never seen.The game it's pretty lengthy and will give you many hours of fun: Im only at 80% and have already 150 hours.It became my favourite game soon after the first chapter.Online:The online is fun if played with friends but it becomes boring soon if you don't shop gold.Gold can also be obtained doing missions but you have to farm a lot and is used to buy "roles" which give you the ability to play as a character. The roles are:-Bounty hunter -> bounty hunting. costs 15 of gold for lvl1 and another 15 for lvl2. lvl2 suggested for full experience.-Trader -> sell goods like gta online. To build up your stock you have to hunt for animals. Cost: 15 gold bars-Moonshiner -> like the trader but more passive. Price: 25 gold bars-Collector -> find precious treasures while exploring the map. price: 15 gold bars.-Naturalist -> hunt legendary animals. price: 25 gold bars.Total: 110 gold bars (or 50 euros, if you dont want to farm)Online it's not as good as the singleplayer mode. Maybe it will improve like gta5 did back in 2013.

author: Chucklenuts
review: What do I say about this masterpiece? I love Red Dead Redemption 2. It reminds you of those old Spaghetti Western film from the 1930's. The set pieces are fantastic and beautiful, you have a variety of environments ranging from cold, snow capped mountains, to wide open, dusty plains and everything in between. There are so many random events and encounters that it fully immerses you in the game. The attention to detail is also fantastic. Ok this may sound weird, but I love looting in this game. It may seem like a chore to others, but how you pick up and inspect items is really detailed. The story. A truly expertly crafted masterpiece. The characters and plot is fantastic. The way you dash from town to town, each with its own aesthetic is so cool. The map is huge and expansive as well. The heists, missions, side mission, activities are so fun, I keep replaying them. Fishing, hunting, DOMINOES, poker, and five finger fillet, are all so fun. Overall, a masterpeice of a game.

author: Bonzi Resurrectikkake
review: 9.5/10Probably one of the best games I've come across in my time on steam.  The story is top tier and the most immersive experience you'll ever play.Characters: Very rich in personality, even the random strangers you encounter in the world.  They look and act like real people instead of NPCs.  Each have their own set of troubles, tasks, dangers that they encounter.Camp: Heading back to camp after a day of hunting or fishing feels so relaxing and comfy.  The characters in the gang all have their own unique dialogues you can encounter, and if you stay in camp for a little while you might find something new.  There's favors you can do for them if they ask you, and there's some chores to take part in.  You also have to keep track of the camp's Food, medical, and Ammunition supplies.  If you keep all those three stocked up and upgraded, everyone in camp will not only be happier, but you'll get more donations in the box to resupply. Honestly very relaxing to be in.Gunfights, Exploration, and Gameplay:  Some people may get a bit tired of how the gunplay mechanics work, but honestly in my experience, it's very satisfying and rewarding.  The blood and gore is super realistic and since you don't have any full automatic weapons in there, besides the maxim gun which can rarely be found and used, each shot counts.  Rockstar games on PC eliminate the auto-aim mechanic, so free aiming is what counts.  It's a really beneficial way to improve your aiming in video games, especially playing this in first person.  The movement that you have to take note of, the tactics your enemies use, all that make each gunfight really unique.  Hell, going to a random town and starting a shootout can be a fun little hobby to pass the timeThe exploration is a big point to where this game shines.  It's a very calming journey traveling on horseback, especially with the ambient music behind it.  As there is so much to explore and take part in.  There's challenges you can complete for some upgraded gear, there's animals you can hunt to skin their pelts for upgrades and cool clothing, and the stranger missions you can encounter are 10x more fun and realistic then the Stranger missions in GTA V, and each one is more unique then the next.  There's over 200 animal species to study, hunt, and witness as you explore, as well as an abundant of plants you can harvest for tonics, and spices to improve your cooking at campfires.The game play is very fluid.  Although in the story there's a lot of """trailing""" missions, sometimes the game will skip the boring sections for you, and if not the dialogue during those moments makes up for it, as it feels really nice hearing the characters all have a conversation about different topics and the events that are about to take place.  I personally never got too irritated with the moments, because I'm pretty patient when it comes to dialogue.TL;DR, a very enjoyable and timeworthy single player experience and probably one of the most immersive experiences you will ever see in any video game. Once again, 9.5/10. Worth every penny!

author: gadshanks
review: Ok, it was tough for me to choose whether or not I recommend this game. Aesthetically, it is beautiful. I'm really enjoying the story line. The characters are well fleshed-out and the attention paid to realism is truly amazing. HOWEVER. This is the worst PC port I've ever experienced. There is a different. button. for. everything. A button to open your bag. A button to mount your horse. A button to skin a deer. A button to pick up your hat. A button to blow your nose. A button to untangle your necklace. A button to fold laundry. A button to go rollerblading. It truly never ends. It is really hard to stay focused on the game when I am constantly looking down to figure out which button I need to be pressing. The weapon/item wheel is also very counter-intuitive and just overall clunky. Each time I boot up the game, I have to go into my volume mixer settings to adjust, or else the game plays at 8% volume. It constantly slows down my mouse settings on its own, so I also have to adjust for that. I've updated all my drivers/system and do not experience these issues with other similar style games. I know that some of these problems would be solved by using a controller, but I feel like if the game was released on PC with keyboard/mouse control capabilities, it's valid for me have certain expectations of said port. As it stands, YES I would recommend this to anyone playing with a controller or on console, but NO I would not recommend it to keyboard/mouse gamers.

author: Kneecap Bandit
review: The world of Red Dead Redemption II is absolutely breathtaking, from the extremely rich and heartfelt storyline to the sheer abundance of things to do in its vast, densely-packed open world. The campaign is beautifully written, with engaging characters that make it nearly impossible not to get deeply, deeply attached to. The cast of characters are passionate, beautifully voice-acted, and are either extremely lovable or hateable (and that’s a great thing on both accounts) thanks to the superb writing.As for the world itself, it is absolutely riddled with levels of detail I’ve never seen before in an open-world game. The world truly feels alive thanks to all of the activity that occurs in every corner of the map. The large variety of NPC’s for example live out their day-to-day lives in a realistic manner, engaging among themselves and the player in a way that is unique and entertaining. There is also an incredible variety of animals that realistically roam the map and behave just like their real-world selves, from where they’re located to their hunting/feeding habits. There are many side activities found throughout the world that allow you to live out the rugged old-west lifestyle you hear about in spaghetti westerns, all without the consequences of the government breathing down your neck because you single-handedly drove an entire species of carp to extinction thanks to you relentlessly throwing dynamite into the town’s only source of food.The online component is no slouch either, being available to players as a standalone for much cheaper. While I recommend the full game to experience the incredible campaign experience, the online component is a very, very fun experience. The same vast world is available to you with many of the side activities found in the campaign, but now you’re able to experience the world with friends and rivals alike. When not actively engaging with other players, you can still find the same feature-rich activities found in the single-player campaign, such as hunting, fishing, stranger missions, and more. There are also features that are specific to specific “roles” that grants even more gameplay features to those that purchase it with the game’s premium “gold” currency that can either be earned in-game or bought outright through microtransactions. These roles offer more money-making opportunities while offering fun gameplay mechanics such as bounty hunting, fur trading, moonshining, and more. The only caveat to the online being that the sheer amount of work needed to get to these roles can be absolutely daunting. From what I understand, the earlier versions of this game were far, far worse. Today, there are plenty of money-making opportunities given to the player sure, but earning the game’s premium currency to buy into the much-needed roles can be taxing. The best advice I can offer if playing online is to enable 2FA to get the much need 10 gold bar head start, and to link Prime gaming to get the $1,000 that may or may be available as of right now. All in all, an absolutely fantastic game as a complete package.

author: myopigonic
review: Note: Light spoilers aheadI've recently completed RDR2 and felt obliged to review it by merit of the ongoing award season as well as the effort put in by the developers. It's certainly a game with much finesse and appetite, though, to mixed outcomes. For the sake of thoroughly assessing it's qualities, I will be continuing this review in a homage with a segmented paragraph format.The Good: The story is quite likely the best produced by Rockstar to date. The plot progresses fluidly and with unrelenting disregard for emotion over substance. Rockstar excellently smothers the player in the atmosphere of the world around them.  When you make a choice in the story, it isn't forgotten. When times are joyful, you're showered with lighthearted praise and friendly banter. When times are rough, you're subjected to irrational outbursts and pitiful pleas. Every character reacts dynamically to how you behave and operate. The gameplay co-opts this with intervals of squad mechanics, unique actions and self-aware combat for immersion in the brutality. Said brutality is also portrayed quite well for the medium, with a realistic depiction of the faults and merits of the Wild West. The game draws on the Western Revisionist tendency pioneered by films including the likes of Soldier Blue and El Topo. This is particularly prevalent with the implications of domestic abuse perpetrated not only by the uncouth barbarians roaming in rival gangs and on the frontiers but also by the "protagonists", including John Marston and Dutch; whom the devs took strides in showing the development of.  Perhaps more sensitive and contemporary is the depiction of the plight of indigenous peoples, which becomes especially prevalent in the later chapters of the game. You're made to writhe and squirm as they do, with an allegorical take on the abuse of their goodwill by demagogues and manipulation by would-be saviours. During this subplot, you're urged to aid their cause in varying forms but with virtually no tangible outcomes; quite aptly resembling how many feel about the present abuse of natives. Further moral dilemmas are explored in the Stranger sidequests, brilliantly expanding upon the themes of "I Know You" from the original Redemption. These all tie back into the honour dynamics of the main plotline, with some permanently affecting the manner of comeuppance for the doomed gang and it's legacy. Rockstar has truly come bounds from the humble beginnings of humoured killings and media outrage that defined it to craft an enduring narrative. The Bad: I'd like to dissect what I feel is the foremost issue in this game and what kept it from reaching total acclamation from myself and many others: the player is given a false sense of choice in execution. Upon indulging in commentary from NakeyJakey, Ahoy and Destructoid, I found my sense of relegation to a lofty conduit vindicated. To clarify, the player is often made to carry out tasks in a predetermined, superficial way during nigh on every mission; I recall about 7 out of the 109 mainline missions where the player is given the initiative to determine how they are carried out. This is a tragic departure from the nonlinear execution Rockstar practically invented with GTA III and improved on to practically having perfected in San Andreas, IV/The Episodes and Red Dead Redemption I. All of the aforementioned titles thrived on utilising gang combat and alternative routes to the utmost extent, so it's sad to have seen Rockstar contracted in this way. I also take issue with the karma/"Honour" system the story is built upon. Just to polish some blemishes before delving into the matter, I finished both stories with full High Honour and siding with John, subsequently researched alternative outcomes and appreciate that it is an improvement upon the system in the first game. The most glaring flaw is that simple actions in the world do not matter. As a proven hypothesis, if you were to massacre all the NPCs of a town but then performed several charitable actions, your previous infraction would not matter at all and you could finish the game with maximum honour without it bearing any impact on your character.  In terms of the story, I feel the devs backed themselves into a corner by opting for a standalone prequel. As the conflict escalates and Arthur, the primary playable character, starts to think for himself, you are given a series of choices that determine your final leanings and subsequent ending variants. This would be brilliant if it wasn't so selective. Case in point, you are at one time allowed to choose whether you indirectly challenge Dutch's impulsive mentality via aiding the tribe and stealing medicine. At another opportunity when Arthur is questioning Dutch's plan to confront a mortal enemy and stoke conflict, the player is given no autonomy in determining whether or not they follow him despite Dutch quite literally asking for a decision to be made by Arthur. Intersecting with the aforementioned approach restrictions, there are several points in the game where you will be forced to lower your honour via robbing to progress in missions and one particularly frustrating instance of linear game design in a sandbox that forces the killing of a subdued enemy in a raided homestead barn against all rational thought for the sake of moving the story along in a particular way. For the record, it is not supposed to be a meta commentary on integration of violence in games as forced killings in Spec Ops: The Line, SUPERHOT and MGS3 are. Amongst other sporadic gimmicks with untapped potential, (i.e. dynamite setups, hostage-taking) the variations in endings stand out. There are two premises to the endings, the paths determined by a last-minute choice. The ultimate conclusion of each differs slightly based on the honour of Arthur but are essentially the same and mostly inconsequential, save for a few dialogue changes. While satisfying in their own way, they lack a fundamental divergence in action and remembrance that makes them feel somewhat meaningless in the scope of the strife endured. To the credit of the developers, it's a difficult navigation in a time where standardised karma systems prevail in "non-linear" games over the more fluid choices in titles ranging from Silent Hill 2 to Chrono Trigger.The Ugly: As you've all likely heard, the latest iteration of Online is an unmitigated disaster. What will be frustrating to the many playing the game for the peak quality of the story, however, will probably be some quirky bugs that break immersion. I often found that whenever I'd pause for urgent matters, especially during missions, I'd unpause and find that the galloping of my horse with my weapon drawn would abruptly cease and turn into my horse involuntary pulling 180s for the next minute as the camera jittered erratically, this would sometimes occur even without the pause trigger. Another persistent issue was the player characters pausing in their treads whilst running during open combat as I'd turn the camera. For the many who bought this game to enjoy the graphical fidelity it offers, be warned that your framerate and texture quality will sometimes drop rapidly despite the game's own assessment claiming all is running smoothly in the menu. I don't yet know if this was a fault of my PC or the game but it seems to be the latter given my high-end specs that I spent a couple years worth of savings on and similar reports.Overall, I'd say the game is a worthwhile experience. Despite exacerbated attempts at being "cinematic", it provides a truly compelling story that's broken ground in the medium and deserves to be remembered in spite of particular flaws that are outdone by merits. Thank you to anyone who bothered reading through this review and please vote for this as the Outstanding Story-Rich Game of 2020 because I busted my ass off on this and the devs slaved on this game ayup.

author: ✞ 𝒂𝒍𝒑𝒉𝒂 ✞
review: is a sprawling Western tale of loyalty, conviction, and the price of infamy, chronicling the inevitable collapse of a motley crew of Wild West holdouts kicking against the slow march of civilisation and industrialisation. Set in Rockstar’s most authentic and lived-in open world ever, there are so many things to do, so many people to meet, and so many places to explore it’s giddily overwhelming. Red Dead Redemption 2 isn’t just Rockstar’s greatest achievement to date; it’s a game so lacking in compromise it’s tough to know where best to start discussing it.So let’s start at the beginning: It’s 1899 and American outlaws are an endangered species. Dutch van der Linde and his gang are on the run after a botched heist in the growing town of Blackwater and they’ve retreated high into the mountains where an atrocious blizzard is covering their escape. We slip into the spurs of Arthur Morgan, an exceedingly cool and capable outlaw who was found by Dutch as a boy and raised on the wrong side of the law, and settle in for a roughly 60-hour story. It’s a self-contained and linear introduction but it’s a clever one. The slick cinematics make a hell of first impression, embedding you in the gang and bringing you right up close to the characters who are doing their best to bellow over the howling wind. It also placed me in a distraction-free bubble while I learned some of Red Dead Redemption 2’s early controls and systems, which heightened the impact of having the full map open up to me a few hours later. The conditions on the mountain are almost claustrophobic, with visibility at a premium and thick snow trapping Arthur’s feet. Being set loose in the true open world after toughing it out in this intentionally oppressive environment really underscores the incredible feeling of freedom the full map offers.And what a world it is; broader, more beautiful, and more varied than the one we explored in 2010’s Red Dead Redemption by a massive margin (though parts of that game’s map are also included). There are snowy peaks and dank, alligator-infested swamps. Thick forests and open plateaus. Quaint homesteads and grand plantations. Narrow streams and great lakes. Dusty gulches and dim caves. There’s the muddy livestock town of Valentine, with its wooden buildings and rustic charm, and then there’s the imposing city of Saint Denis, a grimy and growing metropolis full of modern extravagances like electric trams, paved roads, and Chinese restaurants. The vast assortment of ecosystems and environments seamlessly stitched together here is nothing short of remarkable. does an exceptional job at slowly rationing out reasons to visit every corner of its huge world, too. I was still led to areas of the map I hadn’t yet visited even in the closing stages of its 60-hour main storyline. Because so many cards are kept up its sleeve, the joy of discovering new parts of the world is maintained throughout.The ability of this game to keep itself fresh after so many hours is extraordinary, and not entirely due to just the size and diversity of the world; it’s how alive all of those places feel. While the largely rural world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is far less dense than the likes of Grand Theft Auto V, it’s absolutely brimming with wildlife to discover, people to interact with (and potentially help), and places to scrutinise. The best kind of open worlds are those that seem almost indifferent to your presence in them; like life goes on whether you stick your nose into proceedings or not. I’ve sat and watched lumberjacks felling trees at a bustling logging camp and curiously tailed a perturbed Englishman wandering around town looking for his mate “Gav.” None of this is crucial to the progression of Arthur’s story; it just helps build a world around him that made me feel like a visitor rather than the centre of the universe. Red Dead Redemption 2 nails this in a way that few – if any – games have before.The slower pace of  compared to something like the slightly more breakneck GTA V is also a big part of how it encouraged me to drink in all the world has to offer. Bodies have to be manually looted, and Arthur needs to physically manhandle a body to do so. Single-action pistols need to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ before firing. Guns Arthur isn’t currently carrying need to retrieved from his saddle. Coffee needs to be brewed before drinking it.I suspect some folk may regard this sort of stuff as chore-like, but I really dig it. There’s something methodical about it that really helps ground Arthur in the world, rather than have him feel like he’s gliding through it. For instance, I love the deliberate and mechanical process of cycling a new cartridge with a lever-action rifle via a second pull of the fire button – you can even pause for dramatic effect halfway through. Rockstar’s designers didn’t need to factor that in but I think they understand that tiny, almost trivial instances of subtle control like this subconsciously seat me into the world as Arthur even more.The unhurried pace of checking vanquished enemies for goodies is an interesting design decision but I quite like the risk versus reward loot loop, to be honest. Do I dart around and pickpocket a dozen dead guys or do I just get the hell out of Dodge? They’re consequences you have to be prepared to accept either because your attention is needed elsewhere or because lingering around the scene of a crime naturally puts you at further risk of being discovered. Bounties don’t always come cheap. Did one of those fellas have a gold nugget in his trousers? Perhaps you’ll never know.About my only major logistical gripe is that the weapons I was previously carrying are regularly swapped out for others. Oftentimes it’s clearly mission-related to ensure you go into a task with a scoped rifle or bow when required, which is fine. More irksome are the times I end up with mismatching pistols for dual wielding, with the game trading out my preference. The admittedly brief bit of time it takes to swap back did elicit the occasional grumble from me.At any rate, it’s seriously worth settling into the pace Rockstar is trying to set here because there’s just so much to see and hear. You’ll hear unique, one-time conversations that occur in camp after certain missions, as well as other bespoke bits of dialogue that reference recent events. Strolling through camp, I’ve been privy to everything from a heated bust-up between John Marston and his partner, Abigail, to the good-natured con man Hosea Matthews regaling the young Jack Marston with stories of his latest fishing adventure. This is all happening around Arthur whether you pause to eavesdrop or not. It makes the camp feel like a concentrated version of the world at large, a place with people going about their business and interacting with one another completely independently of you. I can’t understate the genuine feeling of life this injects into the overall experience for me.Elsewhere in the world there’s still plenty for those who care to stop and smell the roses. Newspapers sold on street corners touch on the aftermath of Arthur’s exploits, as well as other things going on around the world. Much like in GTA V, you can visit theatres and take in some old timey entertainment. Dogs can be patted. I spent a good deal of time off-mission simply moseying around, bingeing on the world like a virtual museum. There’s simply too much to list.

author: mossfan1
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is a wild western tale of loyalty, fear, drought, and infamy.This is Rockstar's most lovable and sprawling world ever, with an endless amount of things to do, hundreds of activities, countless of people to meet, thousands places to adventure to. Red Dead Redemption 2 isn't just Rockstar's greatest game to date, it's a wacky game with so many things to say about it that it becomes a surprisingly big hurdle to decide what part to decide discussing it first.With the game's start taking place in 1899, at the end of the cowboy-era for gunslinging maniacs -- you and your cowboy gang are on the run from the law after a goofed heist.With a retreat to the snowy blizzard mountains, it causes a surprising start to a cowboy game. And I think that's one of the things Red Dead Redemption 2 does best: its surprises. You'd expect to start in the middle of the desert, in the vast field of cacti and the coarse, rough, and irritating sand. NOPE! It's that shocking kick-start that almost thrives you to keep going, to see what else kind of a twist the game will send at you, what wackiness is ahead.I truly think this is a self-contained albeit linear introduction which I feel is done awfully well considering my description. It's a clever introduction, with a heftier push into staying alongside your cowboy friends causing a thicker bond than otherwise obtainable if you could just hop away from the instant you gained control. It also heightens the impact of finally getting the full map just a few hours later. It manages to make the world just feel that much bigger & grander, by its prime introduction.And what a world it is, even wider & varied than the one from Red Dead Redemption 1 by an omega margin. As said there are elegant snowy summits, dank crocodile infested swamps, humid forests, barren plateaus, comfortable homesteads, and grand plantations, even narrow streams and huge lakes, dusty mesas and dimly lit caves, the scary jungle of Guarma, to the muddy yet charming livestocks of towns, alongside the imposing grimy metropolis of Saint Denis... The vast assortment of ecosystems & environments seamlessly stitch together and form this remarkable & impressive world of Red Dead Redemption 2. All-together it forms this cataclysmic world and its many unforgettable adventures.So much of the world just feels so alive to just walk around in, it feels like if you never even opened up the game the people of America 1899 would still continue their lives without you, like you're nothing more than just another gunslinging cowboy in its masses from an outside perspective.It captures this by the undeniable constantly active & sprawling world of not only the game's people, but also its wildlife & nature. There are endless amount of content to interact with or even scrutinize & seemingly infinite characters to talk with and potentially help or sabotage.With the slightly laid-back & slow pace of Red Dead Redemption 2 causes this almost relaxing & comfortable experience to be held, it encouraged me to slow down physically & mentally to once-in-awhile grab a drink or setup a tent. It made it all feel less like an expedition and more like an adventure; like I didn't need to run all the time, like I could just sit down and relax sometimes. This is further supported by how you have to manually slowly loot bodies after kills, and slowly pick up items, and slowly reload your gun, or slowly cook your steak, or slowly feed your horse, or slowly clean your gun... I wasn't bothered by any of this, I almost never felt like I was in a rush or had to hurry up and do something real quick. It became very relaxing... until...GUARMA.Guarma is unironically one of my favourite parts of this game, this is due to just how intentionally stupidly paced it is compared to the rest of the game. In the fifth chapter of this game you accidentally visit Guarma -- it's singlehandedly the most annoying, tedious, and fast paced part of this game. With such a sudden jump it once again comes at such a surprising shock that almost completely catches you off-guard with your jaw hanging. Guarma is such a restricted and dangerous part of the game, with no side-missions and only non-stop constant shooting & action, with horrible people all-around & depressing circumstances it's at a complete opposite compared to the rest of the game. You get pushed into this almost unbearable section where you feel so restricted and tired of main-mission that it all turns into this sorta constant drought. You'll be craving something to do, something that doesn't kill you instantly... but it's just not there.Sounds bad, ey? yeah, it is. After finally getting through the short act of Guarma I was nearing my limit, I was so tired of main-missions & action that when I finally returned to America that I began to respect both insanely much! Guarma felt like a big "NO!" to push me into playing side-mission, to do other stuff, to just relax. Its trigger-throttling pace ALMOST broke me, just enough that I was hurt, but not pushed away. I began to respect the game as a whole lot more just due to Guarma, even like ~80 hours later I still am affected by the effect of Guarma. Never before have I played a video-game that intentionally went out of its way to annoy me into loving every other part of the game even further. wow. bravo!With an epicly composed soundtrack made from the talented Woody Jackson behind Red Dead Redemption 1 too, alongside tens of other skilled people brought in to help. It perfectly captures that same sorta wild west experience audibly once again.From the charming sounds of the ambient music, to the triumphant upbeat marching drum-heavy action sounds of gun-smoking blastings; they all sizzle in almost unnoticed due to how seamless they flow into the game-play itself by reproducing the same feelings using extremely smart music-theory -- and yet when removed it becomes easily noticed. The best sorta sound-design & music is the kind that you almost don't notice is playing. They all essentially become one with the game itself & yourself.THEN out of nowhere they pull out fricking D'Angelo from the grave! WHAT THE?! He just comes in suddenly like 🎵Did I... Hear a thunder? Be, bah... I hea-bah, bu🎵As usual, totally unexpected, totally bad-ass.Woody Jackson became so invested in his own soundtrack that he even begun checking whether his music was effective by listening to the music while shooting at targets using a gun from the game. He even purchased multiple of Wrecking Crew's instruments to perfectly recreate this beautiful western feel from the classic movies, and his resorts were not in vein as I believe the Red Dead Redemption 2 soundtrack is one of the bests from 2018, up there alongside Celeste's.Red Dead Redemption 2 has been my unforgettable masterpiece, and while I must admit I do not care about hunting & fishing as much as I'd've loved to, it still managed to capture me throughout its hundreds of epic twists & turns, with its flaws only striving me into a further love towards the game.It's an impressive title, and an even more impressive experience.For anyone who's capable of getting captured in a fascinating & wild story with constant hoops through an amazingly refined world with many hours worth of content, I beg you to check this game out. It's not a game for everybody, but it's a game that most will either love or hate with barely any middleground; and I believe the chance is worth the roll.Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of my favourites in its genres, and has supplied me with endless amounts of hours worth of enjoyable content.Also please just make a Red Dead Redemption 1 port for PC already :(

author: Jenji
review: So far, I wasn't a big fan of Red Dead Redemption, but as soon as the second part came out, I had to buy it immediately. This game amazed me not only with its beautiful realistic graphics, but also with its enchanting story, which you will get into right after the first missions. Robbing shops, trains or chases on horses must not be missing. The game contains a lot of opportunities to spend time playing. You can complete the main storyline or do some side quests and meet random events on the map. Online is also very good, I just miss some heists, just like in GTA. It's one of the best games I've ever played and also one of my favorites.10/10

review: Great story so far and so many side quests to do in this vast world. MP kinda sucks though

author: LaScene
review: I came to this game with the expectation of being a cowboy game where i shoot things and have fun, but instead i was pulled into something entirely unexpecting. I was pulled into a rich enviroment and story game with interesting charactares who you will love or hate. You can hunt animals for their skin to make unique clothes or talismans, you can modify a weapon to fit your character or you can simply walk into a bar, have a drink and have a "friendly chat" with one of the drunk people who annoy you. The main character,Arthur Morgan, is one of the most beloved characters i've ever played and i will say that his story is interesting to play and watch, see how he feels and how he acts. Of course being a rockstar game you have a choice of being dishonourable or honourable which leads to different lines your character will say for different moments.All i have to say is this- Get this game. You will understand what i mean. This game cannot be described, it can be only played to have fun with it

A true masterpiece.(This review is based on my personal opinions, and should not affect yours.)---{Graphics}---☑️ You forget what reality is☐ Beautiful☐ Stylistic☐ Good☐ Decent☐ Bad☐ Don‘t look too long at it---{Gameplay}---☑️ Very good☐ Good☐ It‘s just gameplay☐ Mehh☐ Watch paint dry instead☐ Just don't---{Audio}---☑️ Eargasm☐ Very good☐ Good☐ Not too bad☐ Bad☐ I'm now deaf---{Audience}---☐ Kids☑️ Teens☑️ Adults---{Requirements}---☐ Check if you can run paint☐ Low☑️ Medium☑️ High end☐ NASA computer---{Difficulity}---☐ Just press 'W'☐ Easy☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master☑️ Average ☐ Difficult☐ Dark Souls---{Grind}---☐ Nothing to grind☐ Only if u care about leaderboards/ranks☐ Isn't necessary to progress☑️ Average grind level☐ Too much grind☐ You‘ll need a second life for grinding---{Story}---☐ No Story☐ Like Playing "Candy Crush" For The Story☐ It's Alright☐ Well Written☑️ Epic Story☐ It‘ll replace your life---{Lenght}---☐ Very short (0 - 5 h)☐ Short (5 - 15 h)☐ Average (15 - 25 h)☑️Long (25 - 60 h)☑️ Very long (60+ h)☐ To infinity and beyond---{Price}---☐ It’s free!☐ Underpriced☑️ Worth the price☐ If it's on sale☐ Could Be Cheaper☐ Overpriced☐ You could also just burn your money---{Bugs}---☐ Never heard of☑️ Minor bugs☐ Can get annoying☐ ARK: Survival Evolved☐ The game itself is a big terrarium for bugs---{10/10}---☐1☐2☐3☐4☐5☐6☐78☐9☑️10

author: Storm
review: While i am mostly writing this for the "steam awards" badge thing, this game is currently, and will always be one of my favourites. with an extremely immersive environment and story written so well that it could have been made into a film with almost no problems. the characters are well thought out and the voice acting for each character is done perfectly. each new random encounter and each mission is thought out and planned, and while i was playing the game i hardly ran into a single bug or glitch. this game will go down in history for one of the best games to ever exist.

author: Gladutz
review: I have no idea how to describe this game... except awesome! I've waited for this game to come on PC for a time, I actually didn't expect to be this GOOD!-STORY and Character Development: Arthur Morgan is one of the best characters that I have ever played! Why? It's simple! Because of the development that he gets trough the story: In the beginning he was just an outlaw (maybe with some good deep inside his heart) and he started to notice how the world changes how the most precious thing to him it's starting to disappear.. the life he had.. with the gang.. with the so called family but after he is been put trough some tests and like all heroes he passes them, and in the end he pays for the bad things that he done in his life (because that's all he knew) with GOOD things! In my book in the end he comes like a clean man, and you know why? Because he stood for what he believed and because he got smarter! Like all humans, he learned from his mistakes and he gave his life to remediate them! Arthur Morgan will live in the hearts of the people who helped (or not because you have choices to make Honorable/Dishonorable but most likely he's HONORABLE at the base so if you choose differently you are getting the bad ending which does not counts)-GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS/FREEROAM [For this I will put it in two paragraphs Multi/Singleplayer]1.Singleplayer: It's such a vast map with so much details that literally will make me spend so much time to explain what you can do, I actually think at this moment there's only one game comparable with this or maybe two( Witcher 3 and TESV:Skyrim ).Obviously there has been put a lot of work into this and it makes it feel so big and open.. it makes you feel FREE!2.Multiplayer: I like the idea but I think is not been made for this.. for me the online gameplay is boring.. why?.. because it doesn't reward you for the IDEA of being an outlaw, what I mean about this, you need to progress so slow that doesn't feel like you are committing crimes for a good living only after you spend a lot of time.. and even then you still get payed real bad, you better work as rancher for ♥♥♥♥ sake.. It feels like is consumptive you on deliberately.. which is true because they get a lot of money for this so you can get that GOLD, you either pay with a lot of time making the gameplay boring as hell or you pay.. so yeah! IT IS PAY TO WIN

author: Vaibhav
review: So after 90 hours on this game and completing all the 6 Chapters+2 Epilogue(74 % overall) in single player mode its a *Masterpiece Beyond Comprehension*. Perhaps the greatest video game I have played. A game everyone should play. Masterful storytelling this game has one of the best stories ever made, Oscar worthy voice acting, a soundtrack you could listen to over and over, an open world that feels alive but wants you dead, characters you wish you could confide in and cuddle, graphics that have truly set the bar for open world games and an experience you will never forget like never. Once again Rockstar games manage to out do themselves. You can easily sink 100's of hours in this huge experience exploring the vast beautiful world of the west in early 1900's. There's so much to do & that's just the single player experience, when you've finished that, there's 'Red Dead Online'! A huge open world with friends and foes alike! A true gem! I truly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys real cinematic games and without hesitation, just buy it. Its worth every penny.I give this game 10/10. Go for It.

author: *ness
review: Review - Red Dead Redemption 2 (No Spoiler)Review Score - (A+)📌 Rockstar Games...Тиймээ бидний сайн мэдэх Grand Theft Auto цувралын хөгжүүлэгч тэртээ 2004онд Red Dead гэх шинэхэн цуврал тоглоомоо Red Dead Revolver нэртэйгээр гаргаж байснаас 14 жилийн дараа буюу 2018 онд гарсан цувралын 3дахь анги Red Dead Redemption 2 тоглоомыг та бүхэнд танилцуулья  Review-г эхэлхээс өмнө Red Dead цувралын талаар бяцхан мэдээлэл өгье гэж бодлоо:  Red Dead цуврал нь Rockstar Games-н Сан Диего дахь салбар студийн бүтээл бөгөөд бидний мэдэх 19-20дугаар зууны зэрлэг өрнөдийн талаар харуулсан Open-World тоглоом юм. Энгийн үгээр бол хуучин баруун Америкийн Cowboy-той тоглоом гэж хэлж болно. 📌 Red Dead Redemption 2 тоглоомын хувьд өмнөх 2010онд гарч байсан Red Dead Redemption тоглоомын Pre-Sequel буюу зохиолын хувьд хоорондоо уялдаатай байх юм.  Бидний гол дүрийг Arthur Morgan гэх бөгөөд тэрээр Van der Linde-ээр овоглосон гэмт хэргийн бүлэглэлийн үнэнч гишүүн. Надад Arthur-н зан чанар, хэрхэн бусдыгаа асуудлаас гаргахаар хичээж байгаа болон тоглогч гол дүртэйгээ зохиолын турш бий болгох холбоог маш хүчтэй болгоход хөгжүүлэгчид үнэхээр анхаарсан нь маш их таалагдсан. Мөн түүнчлэн дараа дараагийн үйл явдлуудтай яг цав уялдаж байсан нь зохиолч, найруулагч нар хэр сэтгэл гаргасныг харуулж байлаа.   Red Dead Redemption 2 тоглоомоос өмнө Rockstar Games нь GTA5 тоглоомоо гаргаад аль хэдийн 5 жил болж байсан ч тоглогчдын хувьд GTA5 тоглоомын график үнэхээр сайн дүрслэлтэй хэвээр байсан. Гэвч RDR2-н график үзүүлэлт өөр ямар ч тоглоомтой жишихийн аргагүй GTA5-с ч илүү гайхалтай болсон гэдгийг амлаж байна. Мөн тоглоомын зохиол өрнөж байгаа он цаг, газар байршил зэргийн атмосфер үнэхээр төгс зохицсон байсныг дурдахгүй байж болохгүй бизээ. Дуу оруулалт болон хөгжмийн хувьд мэдээж маш сайн зохицолтой болсон ба тэр дундаа дуу оруулалт тоглоомын зохиол, орчинг илүү бодит, сэтгэлд хүрэхүйц болгосон. Түүнчлэн тоглоомын арын чимэг болсон ая, хөгжим, дуунууд нь яг л Clint Eastwood-н гайхалтай кинонд орсон мэт мэдрэмж төрүүлэхээс гадна тухайн нөхцөл байдалдаа нягт зохицжээ.  Тоглоомд удаан хугацааг өнгөрөөх явцад зарим нэг жижиг алдаа(bug) гарах боловч энэ нь тоглоход саад болохооргүй.(Намайг тоглоход ямар ч алдаа гараагүй)  Зөвхөн зохиол хөөж, гайхалтай дүрслэлд нүдээ унагахаас гадна маш олон side-activity таныг хүлээж байгаа.(Жишээ нь: ан хийх, загас барих, танихгүй хүмүүст туслах гэх мэт) Бас Red Dead Online гэх онлайнаар холбогдох боломжтой хувилбар ч бий.📌 Дүгнэлт: Эцэст нь хэлэхэд GTA5 тоглоомын томоохон амжилтын дараа ч Rockstar Games дахин нэг удаа гайхалтай нэгэн бүтээлийг хийж чаджээ..👉 Та бидний үнэлгээтэй санал нэг байна уу? Доор коммент хэсэгт өөрийн юу гэж бодож байгаагаа бичээрэй!(No Spoiler) .👉 Бас бидний хийж байгаа зүйлсийг дэмжиж Like, Follow, Award дараарай!

review: This game is truly a roller coaster of emotions. Stunning graphics aside, it has an equally amazing soundtrack which together beautifully complement the very perfectly written story. Yes the story is long and is a slow burn but I loved every minute of it. The game really knows how to create its moments- moments of peace, tension, hatred, I could go on and on. Hell, the game even made me feel like there's an actual bond between me and my horse, something completely unimaginable in a video game! I seriously cannot recommend this game enough to anybody. Can't say anything about Red Dead Online cause I haven't really played it but the story mode alone is worth it! Even after beating the campaign there's a TON of stuff to do. 10/10
