author: Mythicalus
review: A masterpiece, seriously.Just the single player campaign more than makes up for the price of the game. The story is beautifully crafted, the writing is really good and the voice actors are amazing as well. The map is huge and really detailed, there are lots of activities to do, items to collect, and many sites to discover. The side quests are meaningful as well, and aren't your usual cookie cutter fetch quests.I've encountered very little bugs and overall the game runs pretty well at med-high settings.I haven't played Online so I don't have any thoughts on it yet.

author: padris
review: Red Dead Redepmtion 2 was one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a while.Its astonishing graphics, outstanding and consistent storytelling, great game mechanics (Dead Eye, honor, crafting, lasso - just to name a few), as well as the vivid world, make it a truly enjoyable experience. The storyline is entertaining and there are only several weak spots during the mid-game, which may seem a bit slow-paced. If you don't feel like rushing with the main quests, you can just roam the wilderness, rob, hunt, complete side missions, bet your money in a game of poker and much more. The world is big and full of life. You will encounter travellers on roads, remote homesteads in forests and deserts, wild beasts in mountain passes etc. If you like to individualize your character (as for its stats), this game won't offer you many possibilites to do so. The only way to influence the physical strenghts/weaknesses of the character in the late game seems to be underweight/overweight, which influence the rate at which your stamina and health replenish. However, this aspect of the game was fine for me since there are other ways to improve the "performance" of your character - food, tonics, synergy with the horse (a fast and agile horse, or a strong and resilient stallion - the choice is up to you), a favourite weapon which slightly improves its accuracy, range or damage, etc. The only real downside of the game was the lack of possibility to set a different difficulty level. The game just seems far too easy when it comes to dealing with several enemies at the same time (you will more likely die by being kicked by a horse) or obtaining money. (Singleplayer)

review: Except for the terrible controls, some questionable and dated game design choices as well as unfixed bugs (dialogue errors, randomly getting penalized over things you have no control over, important items/weapons tied to the '100% achievement' disappearing) this game is a masterpiece.The first Redemption game had superior shooting mechanics, but this game has the better story, pacing and it spends a much better time building up all the important characters. author: Scaviferro
review: When they say it is slow, they are right. Best graphics I've ever seen and one of the most immersive games ever. Story-wise, it's got high and low points. This is not a GTA and you shouldn't expect flashy missions and you probably won't finish it in a couple of sittings. I've learnt to take my time with it and it has paid off. I enjoyed it, especially the final parts of it. Do I recommend it? Yes, but be aware of what I've mentioned. Maybe watch a walkthrough of a mission to get that slow-paced feel.Great!

author: Gator
review: IntroRed Dead Redemption 2 is almost an immersive masterpiece. Everything in the game could be mistaken for a movie. The characters are all thought out completely and given a background even if it isn’t explored. Only problems you will have with the game are minor nitpicks and some story beats.Characters / Story	 Red Dead Redemption 2 is a prequel to the first Red Dead Redemption taking place 12 years before the original following a new character named Arthur Morgan. The story is all about the gang John Marston was part of and its eventual demise. It does a great job of fleshing out the enemies along with the allies. 	Throughout the story the group moves base locations multiple times, every new location bringing new story beats. Sometimes these plots are left unfinished, but the overall story thrives because of it. They help develop the characters and string them all together in a messed-up cobweb until it can’t hold anymore and all falls down in a climatic end. 	GameplayThere are multiple ending to this game all focusing around one of the gameplay mechanics, your reputation. Reputation is a new addition to this game that adds consequences to how you act in the game. If you rob the innocent or go on a murder spree it rightfully punishes you for it. 	This leads to one of the pros and cons of the gameplay itself. The story wants you to be the good guy, but sometimes you just want to be the bad guy. If you want to be immersed by this game and play it by its rules then you will have an extremely fun time; if you like to stray off the path and just mess around you might not have as much fun with this title.	All of the content besides the main missions are optional, but it is all thoughtfully created. There are many missions that you can do with other gang members to flesh out the characters more and give you great missions to enjoy. 	The gunplay feels absolutely amazing and keeps giving you new weapons or upgrades to spice it up ever so slightly. Every fight seemed great even if it just lasted for a few seconds. Overall, the gameplay is absolutely amazing and I am sure anyone could have fun with it if they just give it a try.	ConclusionIn conclusion, this game is fantastic and it is almost a masterpiece. Every character is thought-out extremely well and given character development throughout the entire game. The plot is amazing besides a few story beats that drag it down. The gameplay is well thought out and feels amazing if you immerse yourself in the game and play it by its own rules. Everyone should give this game a try if you have the ability to play it.	If I had to give Red Dead Redemption 2 a rating I would give it a 9 .5/10!

author: Dr.Squatch
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 achieves its aim to create an immersive and realistic world in which to play out its Western drama. The game is intentionally slow-paced, which some may find off-putting, but this pacing is designed to make you explore, take in the natural world, and discover the various secrets and encounters that are out in that wilderness.This is not a game full of high-energy action every few minutes, but a slow, and often lonely, an experience which captures the pathos of the decline of the frontier and the old west. Personally, I have spent hours simply cantering around the world, greeting strangers, interacting with random events, and observing the wildlife, nothing more than me, my horse (named roach in reference to the Witcher 3), and the wild. It is visually stunning and weather effects and lighting can give even familiar areas a different atmosphere.In the critical reviews, there’s a lot of negative remarks about "spending most of the time riding" or "no fast travel"; I just don’t understand this criticism – Why would you not want to ride through remarkable scenery, encountering random things on the way, while heading to your mission? The hours spent riding through the world were probably the most immersive, most enjoyable experiences I’ve had in an open-world game for many years. Without that riding, I would never have been ambushed by the O’Driscolls on my way back to valentine, never met a crazy old man who tried to steal my horse, never camped in the wilderness and been threatened by a couple of crazy rednecks, never found out about the secret history of a certainly abandoned saloon.If games are only about action for you, then avoid this; If they are about the experience then this game will provide you hundreds of hours of entertainment.

author: Homeless Dishrag
review: So far, this game has met and pretty much surpassed my expectations, since I'd heard how good this game was when it came out. The level of detail is frankly astonishing (I'm sure you've heard plenty of jokes about how realistic the horses' testicles are). The realistic, dynamic surroundings of this open world game is what truly makes this game feel alive. One can literally go on a horseback ride and not see the next town for a while. Just you and your horse. There's plenty to do as well I'm sure, though I haven't played story mode to completion or done much besides a couple jobs online yet. All I'm saying is that if you're looking for an open world experience that takes you back in time yet does all of what GTA Online does right, then please, please, please, buy this game. It is pricey, but then again it is November. Just wait 'till Cyber Monday!

It is fun with friends!Definitely buy for the single player adventure! :D

author: Skylxr
review: Good lord this is not what I was expecting.So 2 years ago this game came out and I saw all this hype around it. Everyone was playing it. I was never a fan of shooters or anything, and from what little I saw of it I thought "meh, looks like just another shooter". I was also too into Minecraft to really care about any other games. Fast forward to July 2020 and I buy it just for the sake of buying it. Thinking "welp, I'm unemployed, can't really go outside because of this deadly virus thing, mine as well stock up on games to pass the time". Then I don't touch it for like a month. My girlfriend casually mentions that she didn't know I had this game after seeing it in my library. So that night I install it. 13 hours later it's installed, I play it, 3 hours later I drop it after barely making it through half of Chapter 1. Then a couple weeks later I beat GTA V for the first time and I think "isn't RDR2 just GTA V with horses" so I play it again. I haven't dropped it since. 227 Hours and 95% Completion on my first save, and I've barely touched Online yet. I honestly think I annoy my girlfriend with how often I mention this game.This game is a masterpiece, plain and simple. I am thoroughly surprised I did not pick it up for so long. The story is magnificent, really tugged at my heartstrings at multiple points. The characters are amazing. The attention to detail for not just the main group, but every notable side character and NPC is just beyond what I ever thought I'd see in a video game. There is so much to do aside from the story, so much to explore, so much to find. Each area in the game is unique, has it's own little challenges, the people are unique to each region. All the animals you can find and hunt act so real and it just adds so much. I used to love fishing as a kid, and I got the exact same excitement in this game when a fish was on the line that I did in real life (although there could be more fish species tbh). You feel like you can just live in this world and it's just so much fun. Now, it does have its shortcomings. Fish species could be more varied, I feel like there could be more customization with outfits (only one bandanna for example), more melee weapons, etc. But these don't exactly detract from the game, and as far as glitches go I have yet to run into many at all, and the ones I have are small things that kinda come with the territory of being a video game.Before Minecraft, I thought all these mega popular games weren't as great as people made them out to be. I was perfectly content sitting with my Sonic and Mario games and being happy. But then I tried it, and I told myself "maybe I should jump on the gaming bandwagon more often". After that came Undertale, which I loved. Then Rocket League, which I loved. Then Fall Guys. This game though, this has cemented that mindset. I will never look past a game that hits the mainstream like this one did again.Get this game. It's worth every penny. 10/10 would accidentally hit my White Arabian horse with a train again (RIP Lilliana, you did good).

author: pawtastic
review: I finished my first Gameplay this Monday (technically, it was my second one, but we'll get back to this later.) and the story surely left an impact on me. I absolutely adored the way the story had been written, although it admittedly had some not-so-well-written part, the overall narrative was amazing, although , which was expected. It awakened lots of emotions inside me, which doesn't happen that often anymore when it comes to games. The game made me feel as if I was living in the world of red dead 2. The fantastic graphics surely made the game even more enjoyable, and I had lots of moments when I stopped to admire the scenery as well as the smallest details that kept amazing me. The fact that some parts of the world remind me of Lapland, Finland, made the experience even more great for me personally. I'm a Finn and used to visit the northernmost part of the Lapland every summer when I was younger, as my family owns a small gold mine there, So riding around areas that reminded me of the golden days of my childhood and teenager years made me feel incredibly nostalgic, in a good way. I actually finally decided to build myself a brand new gaming PC just to play the game in the best settings possible, after playing for 3 chapters on my older computer. I, unfortunately, lost my old safe files as I got my new computer due to an error in cloud syncing. I didn't mind it too much, though, because playing the game from the start on the ultra settings was definitely worth it. I also ended up seeing many more interactions the second time I started the story. I also should praise the voice actors, because they really did a fantastic job. They all fit the characters perfectly, and they clearly knew what they were doing. They made me fall in love with my favorite characters even more. Those characters being Arthur, John, Charles, Sean, Lenny, Hosea, and Sadie. I would absolutely die for Sadie. Same with Arthur. Spoiler alert,  I ended up missing playing as him enough to start my technically third Gameplay right after finishing the epilogue. Now intending to get the game to 100%.The game mechanics were quite good, though there were some minor things I think could have been done a bit differently. I don't have that many complaints about them, though. I definitely recommend this game for everyone to play. It certainly will leave an impact on you. the game is 10/10 storymode wise.Now, to the online side of the game. I have spent maybe 60 hours on RDO, and so far it has been entertaining enough for me, as I have a friend to play with and am not yet done with the story as I have been focusing on the Trader as well as Collector roles for the most part. But I can see how the online version can get bland and boring after a while of playing. There are also lots of things we are missing, and Rockstar doesn't seem to be too interested in adding some of the stuff the community has been asking for quite a while now. It's such a shame. There seem to be lots of missed opportunities. Well, maybe eventually the online part of the game will be improved, at least so I hope. The game really deserves it, and we as a community deserve it. Also if you do play online I don't recommend using your money on it, as in don't waste your money on them gold bars. It's not worth it.

author: QVINQVAGINTA
review: buy the game review is over don't wait for sale or any thing just get some free time and seclude yourself from the world and immerse yourself in the beauty that is the virgin lands of the frontier. you're still reading?! what are you waiting for go buy the damn game though in all seriousness the game is a masterpiece of story telling sound and graphical design _unfortunately it leaves some performance on the table in terms of graphics because of bad optimization- nonetheless it is still the best rock-star game in my opinion and it comes packed with interesting and unique missions and i mean unique! and it is a Completionist's dream with challenges, collectables that come with their own missions and rewards and the illusive "best in the west" achievement -which requires you to get 100% game completion- riding around the map on your trusty steed with a peacemaker in your holster will never feel like a chore free-roam is the name of the game, the servival aspect comes through in this game unlike any other open-world game the hunting ,random interactions, easter-eggs and bandits all make a living breathing believable world, I'm sure you've heard about the horse's n*ts shrinking in the cold; that alone is how i will describe the attention to detail in this game -and BTW with an astonishing level of historical authenticity and realism- however there is no perfect masterpiece I have some gripes with this game, here are some from most to least "annoying" notice the quotes because it's just annoying: 1_broken wanted system 2_stiff shooting mechanics3_your character is stupid and can't climb sh*t and always turns in to a ragdoll if he just so slightly climbs something that is steeper than 180 degrees flat and good f**king luck trying to make him stand back up he will roll down the f**king hill in the speed of a snail and will take damage like he is being stabbed in the face f**k this ♥♥♥♥ this is not annoying its f**king infuriating i f**king hate i hate it, it happens way more often than it should.horses seemingly trip over nothing and fall for no reason.4_horses seemingly trip over nothing and fall for no reason.5_I wish there was a prologue because the first chapter is a bit confusing and a bit weaker than other chapters in my opinion, how about a DLC for pre black-water massacer events Rockstar?   6_weird controls,confusing menus. 7_the muliplayer; don't even bother with that money grabbing sh*t its an infinite grind with very spars content and infrequent updates.disclaimers and conclusion:  these are my opinions, buy this game don't wait  if you'll wait it should only be for a rig that can handle this game, and BTW playing the original  doesn't make a difference for RDR2 but in my opinion ruins the original..

author: ReMiX | Haeder Bazooka
review: It has been a long time since i have found a really likeable protagonist in a game where i really liked! A very charismatic and strong one. Arthur claimed him self up the ladder of my favourite characters in games rapidly!This game is amazing. Hi quality story content with good humor and great story telling just like always expected from Rockstar games. There is so much to do in this game you will lose your self mounting your (highly annoying) horse in the beautiful atmosphere.  Playing this with a 21:9 monitor was a blast and i am very happy for doing that, tho by having a higher 1440p resolution my PC was really sweating.  I have always had 30+ FPS so it didn't bother me much, tho i am used to play 144+ FPS... but oh well. a sacrifice to play on ultra settings ^^I did have a few bugs here and there nothing major. But the horse...... oh boy don't get me started...... it is the only reason i was glad i finished my 100% run not having to ride him/her again xDI did not touch the online mode, nor have any interest in doing so. I do hear that it is not that good. Full of hackers etc. It is nothing new. Same as GTA5 i guess ^^. If you get this get it for the story, for the HUGE and beautiful open world with plenty of activities, for a protagonist that you will really like (no spoilers) and If you have a lot of time to spend going from A to B with a some what slowish horse which  won't bother you than this game is for you.I highly enjoyed and recommend this game.10/10

author: parzival
review: PROS:1. Incredible story, rich characters and good writing.2. Sexy af graphics, the first proper showcase of what next-gen graphics might look like.3. Rockstar's classic third-person open world gameplay loop, insanely fun and very simple inventory and tool management system.4. Detailed, interesting, vast open world which is very fun to explore.CONS:1. Unlike GTA Online, Rockstar has completely neglected Red Dead Online and it is pretty much dead, not at all worth the crazy level of grinding you need to do to get to the fun parts.2. Optimization still isn't 100% sorted from Rockstar's end, performance dips are commonplace.3. No Story DLC or any post-release support. The game doesn't have a good Online multiplayer experience, so at least Rockstar can consider explanding the single player campaign.4. Not exactly a con, but I have heard people complain about how slow and tedious the game is, you're mileage may vary though. It is very realistic compared to other Rockstar games.Overall, if you can wait for a steep sale which brings the game's price down quite a bit, you will love the single player campaign on this one.

author: astra
review: Its just another Rockstar classic...If you've played any of the Rockstar games before, especially on their release you'd know- Rockstar Devs love to innovate with currently possible technologies and delivering the best experience in games . This game is no exception, once you start playing the game you can tell it's a world that functions regardless whether you're observing it or not. The use of professional actors does pay off, thousands of unique voice lines and even a casual conversation can be overheard by simply observing basic pedestrians.... The game offers a beautiful story line, but don't rush to beat it just yet. With side quests that feel like a harmonious expansion to the main story- there are no side quests. Every side mission is really just an opportunity to immerse yourself more into the story and learn more about characters, whom you will not be able to remain indifferent about. I've greatly enjoyed this game, even after fully completing it. It's the best sandbox the industry of gaming is able to currently offer.Now that were over with the good lets get to the bad and the ugly.The Multiplayer state is just like any other Rockstar multiplayer:A nice 'pay to win' incentive is a Rockstar trademark for Multiplayer games, allowing you to skip the grind and just straight up buy anything you want with real money. While its very ambitious the kind of activities in place, the multiplayer is designed for a Utopian society where-People will never want to bully/flame/impede on others' progress and would always love to cooperate. Turning most of your player encounters into just basic KOS (kill on sight) PVP. (this is written before any mp dlc, not sure how much of that DLC could really change)In addition the devs have removed the ability to install any kind of mods that the community has developed over the years, and now modding your game for SP can be tricky and can also trigger a ban in MP (for cheating), which is sad to see because the mods are a very nice addition to the vanilla experience.With multiplayer experience being questionable be warned that you might be buying the game only for its SP experience(Especially if you decide to MOD the game in any way). I would recommend buying the game with a discount.Overall its an amazing game and you will probably not regret getting it.

author: ogfundamentals2
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is another big leap towards the evolution of gaming. The story will keep you bound to it but the pace at which it progresses might not be everyone's cup of tea. The characters are very well written especially Arthur Morgan, the protagonist himself and the world feels truly alive with the ability to interact with every single NPC as you can engage them in a conversation, both friendly and non-friendly and even rob them if you want to. The gameplay is pretty immersive with the introduction of more RPG-like elements, to name one, Arthur will need to be kept well-fed in order to maintain his weight which will have stat boosts accordingly making it more realistic than ever which could also feel like a burden at times. The soundtrack is just a true masterpiece which will certainly enhance your gameplay experience.Overall, Rockstar Games have managed to outperform themselves yet again by giving us another great AAA title which does have its flaws but is nearly worthy of being called a masterpiece.Update: Truly one of the best gaming experiences in all of the industry. Still find myself going back into the wild west just to take a breather from real life.

author: Me no Totoro
review: A little background info and put you in perspective, I was never into cowboys, old western weapons, horses, rugged life or Dutch's damn plans. I really just tried this game because it has a R* logo and I thought my money will at least be worth it with the singleplayer experience. But, just a little over 30 hours of gameplay, it already had me hooked into the genre, I began looking up and learn about horse breeds and repeaters online. THIS GAME delivers you an experience that cannot be replicated. The world(map) is very spot in the sense that it's empty enough for you to feel grateful of how far humanity have come today, and it's also alive enough for you to admire wildlife and its beauty. It also has a huge and rapidly expanding city of San Denis for you to compare and contrast the different lifestyle people live. The jungle and dessert are vast with wild predators lurking in the dark, and despite armed to the teeth, gators in the swarm or cougars in the woods could sometimes take on you by surprise.The weapons are very very well made that you can see the jump from a single action revolver to a semi automatic pistol could mean day and night in a gun fight. You can feel the single action in your controls as you need additional action to pull the hammer back. Same with the repeaters. It is also, in my opinion, a very good change of pace compare to modern shooters or GTA, your aim means a lot more when you are loading bullets in one by one and doesn't have fully automatic weapons that could simply spray and pray. The singleplayer, without spoilers, put you in a lot of choice makings and they do matter in the end. The story itself is not Oscar worthy (unless you compare it to that modern Hollywood trash, then it might as well be), but it does it's job perfectly to hook and capture your interest. Some of you folks might only want the game for Online (I did), but I still recommend the Singleplayer as I believe it will change your perspective to see life in a much different light. The multiplayer is as tragic as Darth Plagueis the Wise; with GTA Online(GTAO) being the billion dollar success, it is only logical for R* to put most of their attentions into GTAO instead of Red Dead Online(RDO). After all, the old American west is more or less a niche market, as I mentioned above, I wouldn't discover it if I didn't buying it for the sake of R* Games. With that being said, it is still being updated with contents, but it's more or less just repetitive grinding that takes advantage of it's solid base gameplay. The are WAY, WAAAAAAAAAAYYYYY less griefers in this game as R* took a huge step to hide blips off the global map and with defensive mode enabled, if people engage you they will receive a debuff while you receive a buff to fight those people off. The majority of the player base of Online are friendly and PvE focused. Do keep in mind that modders will be a thing and they are capable of doing things to you similar to GTAO fashion, but their numbers are much fewer than GTAO as you are gaurantee to spawn in with one in GTAO. The premium currency, gold bar could be purchased with real money or simply by playing the game. All in all, Just grab it, for whatever amount you pay for this game, the amount of content you get is a great deal.

author: Def
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 changed my life.Pros:- Excellent story, with an amazing climax and epilogue. Made me reflect about my actions in real life.- Epic soundtrack during missions, along with great songs made for this game.- Extremely fun gameplay mechanics. You can spend your day fishing/hunting/robbing and it'll still feel like another day in the game. It feels like a world that you're in, and not one that you're controlling. Doesn't matter what actions or crimes you commit, life still continues on even without you.- Cool set pieces like the ,  and .Cons:- Controlling the horse can be a little wacky at times. But when it works, it works beautifully.- The police are as aggressive as GTAV's cops. Maybe even more aggressive.- You can't sell your weapons. Quite baffling to me how this isn't a feature.Story: 9/10Soundtrack: 10/10Gameplay: 9/10Overall: 9.5/10, what a beautiful masterpiece.Worth it at $70? Sure. Worth it at $60? Definitely.Get this game in your life. Now.

author: Moorep
review: I would 100% recommend Red Dead Redemption II especially for those those who have not played the first Red Dead Redemption. It is a game that is rich in strongly defined side missions, characters are principled and effected by the world. I am not a fan of the Grand Theft Auto series. The way the shooting plays out in that game seems kind of silly for modern weapons but seems to fit beautifully in this era of United States rough and tumble Romanticized Westerns.If you are here for a game with a solid shooter system, that his rich characters that change over time, and emotional investments that consistently shatter. Red Dead Redemption has for me personally been the most redeeming game for my belief in Rock Star Studios. Now for people asking if it is worth $60? Yes if you can get it on sale it was borderline theft. You might as well have a bounty upon installing the game. I personally thought the game ended in multiple chapters at multiple times but the content just kept going. It was beautiful!As far as Red Dead Online, its been a while so it is pretty not alive, but even the online has a mini story you can do which is extremely cool bonus feature for the solo player. Anyway this is going to end the review for me and ill see you out there Black Lung. *Tips hat with Revolver, Whistling Johnny Cash as I walk into the saloon to shoot that no good card cheating curr.*

I now have an all new ryzen-based system that runs this game like a dream.The main single player story was gritty, moving, and incredibly enjoyable. I couldn't help but binge the entire thing in 3-4 sittings. It was so good. 10/10Online is also pretty fun and enjoyable, but I am feeling the wear on the community from the lack of updates over the past year. Lots of griefing and hacking going on when it comes to online play. It's still an enjoyable experience, however. I love just hopping into game and doing some hunting after a long day at work.Seriously though, the single player story alone is what sells this game for me. Get it for that alone if you must.

author: SerinVeya
review: Many years ago, I tried to play the original Red Dead Redemption. While I could understand the appeal, and even found the multiplayer suite to be a lot of fun, I just couldn't bring myself to stop and enjoy the game in the same way I had, at the time, played through Grand Theft Auto IV. The game felt overly confused with its attempt at pacing, trying to feel as fast as a GTA game in its gameplay, but its storytelling being as slow as molasses.With Red Dead Redemption 2, I kind of expected the same experience. Significant burnout of interest in the single player experience, given my overall enjoyment of Grand Theft Auto V, but some mild entertainment with Red Dead Online to convince me not to request a refund. I'm extremely glad to say that not only is this not the case, but Red Dead Redemption 2 has become my new favourite Rockstar game to boot.Red Dead Redemption 2's greatest success, in my eyes, is discovering its own approach to pacing. Compared to the first game, RDR2 is much slower by comparison. Which is normally a death sentence for me, given how little I tend to jive when it comes to slower narrative and gameplay experiences. But what RDR2 gives up in speed, it makes up for in fluidity. Horses in RDR1 felt like sports cars with tank controls, but horses in RDR2 feel real and do an exceptional job of reacting to every part of their environment. RDR1's shooting controls felt like a shoddy Gears of War clone in terms of the bizarrely fast character walk speed and weaker weapons more reliant on volume of fire instead of accuracy. RDR2 makes up for this with each movement in combat feeling appropriately weighted, with the player needing to consider their options before making movements. On top of that, the weapons feel absolutely spot-on this time around, with everything having an appropriate amount of punch and feedback. While the game feels physically slower, it feels more natural to move, ride, and shoot because of how much detail there is in the player's movements.The continuing trend of the fluidity of its pacing continues into its narrative. The game's story is relatively slow, as it took me nearly 60 hours to finish the story mode through to the end. But instead of constantly rolling my eyes and wondering,"Oh god, can we just get to the next story beat, please,"I found myself instead enjoying every small activity along the way. It didn't matter that I wasn't riding off to the next big bank robbery or standoff with the rival gang. The best part of this game is the time you spend with your caravan crew. The big moments felt great when they happened, don't mistake me. But unlike Grand Theft Auto V, when I was required to slow down to enjoy the company of my companions, I absolutely enjoyed every minute of it, even if the activity was minor. This is also in no small part to the cast of fantastic characters and the amazing performances of the actors bringing each of them to life. Arthur Morgan is an excellent player avatar character, and his relationships with Dutch, Micah, John, Bill, Charles, Javier, and everyone else in the caravan allows the player to experience and enjoy each of their stories as well.The only real problem with Red Dead Redemption 2 is, ironically, its predecessor. Namely, how much you actually played through Red Dead Redemption 1. This is a very large double-edged blade, since RDR2 is a prequel to the first game. Despite being set several years before the first game and being largely disconnected to what happens in RDR1, echoes of what happens in RDR1 can potentially have an effect on the level of engagement you're having in some of RDR2's highest moments of tension and drama. I, thankfully, never really had any time with RDR1, and that ended up being the best-case scenario for me since knowledge of who's alive, active, and appears in RDR1 didn't get in the way of what's happening in RDR2. But that, inevitably, won't be the same story for everyone else. And I find that kind of a shame, since the writing is very much on point in favour of those who didn't experience RDR1.The final touch point is Red Dead Online. As someone who really enjoyed RDR1 multiplayer and spent a ton of time loving GTA Online in GTA5, I was pretty thrilled with the idea of GTA Online levels of fun, variety, and customization in the same infrastructure of RDR1 multiplayer. And Red Dead Online absolutely delivers. While I made the mistake of logging a few hours in RDO before starting the story mode, as the story mode has a much better introduction and tutorial compared to RDO, I found myself falling quickly in love with it. You make your own outlaw, much like your own character in GTA Online and as opposed to the preset characters from RDR1, and the amount of things available to create your own character identity and look are even more expansive than the options present in the story mode. While it can be difficult to fill lobbies for early story missions, as most regular players have long since played through these story missions, they're still structured quite well and are very enjoyable.The only real point of note is RDO's approach to microtransactions. GTAO is largely notorious for its invasive approach to microtransactions by having its best gear and cars locked behind immense price tags that are most practically remedied by expensive microtransactions. This, understandably, creates the frequent opportunity for a significant gap in power between players who work to unlock new items, and those who shell out the real money for their advantage. Rank restrictions are in place, but the price tags are the real measure of who crosses the finish line first. RDO somewhat attempts to remedy this by creating a separate currency type, gold bars, to separate it from the game's regular money. Gold bars have the immediate, distinct advantage over GTA$ in player friendliness by being restricted to cosmetic purchases. Gold bars can be used to purchase cosmetics without the rank restriction for an inflated cost, and cosmetics restricted to gold bars only for purchase are in agreeable price ranges for those who are exclusively earning their gold bars through gameplay. The system isn't perfect, as gold bar purchase prices are expensive and gold bar payouts for in-game activities are low. But compared to GTAO, this is a far more agreeable system that can easily help with retention.Red Dead Redemption 2 was a game I really, truly wish I played when I first had the chance. It easily would've fallen under the umbrella of my favourite games for 2019 overall, and absolutely has become one of my favourite games of the past decade. It stands in defiance of my usual preferences and wins my heart in spite of fighting uphill to earn it. Despite not connecting with the first game at all and skipping it in favour of more Grand Theft Auto, Red Dead Redemption 2 subverted every expectation I had of it and more. It's an amazing game with a fantastic story and some truly engaging gameplay, and I enjoyed every single second of it.

The story it's perfect .Arthur's path  really hits hard , all his regrets , guiding him towards redemption , I'm sure all the other players feel the same . both gameplay and story , 10/10 . However the online it's a different story with many bugs and glitches , hackers , lack of content and all the rest . Playing the online with it's mechanics of making money gets boring but you still have a beautiful ground to explore with your friends . If you have a posse full of players and you're all just chilling , even talking in camp by the campfire , it's worth playing it .

author: Princeツ
review: A damn good f*cking game if I may say so.This game has a special place in my heart. It's been there during my darkest hours.It's been a tough couple of years trying to get my life back together. I remember purchasing Red Dead Redemption 2 the moment it was released on Steam; and since then, it has played a huge part in my recovery.Been a huge gamer of 20+ years of my life, and no video game or media piece has moved me like RDR2 has. Here I am, watching the sun slowly set as I ride west.Thank you, Rockstar. I've been given the opportunity to play my childhood fantasies and I couldn't have been more happier. It has been one hell of a therapeutic ride.

author: LimesharkWeekly
review: This game is fantastic to play....when it works.When it works, and the game treats you fairly, then it is fantastic.But when there are:Constant disconnection issues that Rockstar doesn't seem to care aboutTerminator enemies with perfect aim and seemingly infinite healthYour horses not understanding what directions areNo payments from jobs being completed as a posseEnemies shooting through hard cover and getting a headshotOther players hacking you across the map and killing youOther players being griefers and ruining your experienceNo dedicated passive mode to prevent being griefedLow payouts for jobs and being paywalled under the guise of "updates"Overly priced itemsAnd LOUSY SERVRSthen this game is absolutely dreadful.Unless you have people to play this game with, then it sucks, the single player portion is great, it is a lot of fun, but the online portion of the game is absolutely dreadful and a plain aweful experience that can only be made better by playing with friends. Do not play red dead online solo, you will come to realize just how littler Rockstar actually seems to care about pleasing their playerbase.Go to EA, Rockstar, your Molyneux is showing

author: The Box Ghost
review: 300+ hours in campaign0 Hours in onlineThe campaign for this game is incredible.  The main character, the amount of lore that is added to the first game, the attention to detail and how NPCs react to different situations.  All of these things make this game a masterpiece.  Add this on top of incredible amounts of customization for Arthur, his weapons, and his horses and R* has created something that would be incredibly hard to top.  Rare moments in this game which change to how you approach a situation, dialogue that was put in the game that you may never hear if you don't play a certain way, this is what makes this game special.Example: I was doing a bounty for a man who was a criminal.  He was with his wife and kid.  This was my second play-through.  The man asks if he can speak to his son for a final time and then he will come with me quietly.  In my first play-through, I had allowed this and remembered that if you allow him to speak to his son then he will escape off the horse and you will be ambushed on the ride back.  In this play-through, I decided that I would shoot his wife in the face before he asked to speak to his son. This opened up a whole new dialogue.  He screamed at me the entire ride back, calling me a woman murderer, a coward, etc.  The ambush never came on the way back to town.  When I put him in the cell, he told the sheriff that I had killed his wife and that I should be behind bars.  Arthur replies, "You know this business, Sheriff, things happen."  Small differences in gameplay that aren't obvious but have been accounted for by R* is what makes this game special.

author: Kraven_ak
review: A visual masterpiece, and a strong storyline to add to that. The general detailing and level of detail to the most minute of things are astounding. When you watch the snow thaw, or the clouds gather and it starts raining incessantly, or the moonlight create the perfect shadows while you are riding in the wild west - it's a proper visual treat. The storyline is addictively immersive, the gameplay physics are absolutely flawless, the combat engine is probably the best I have ever played in a PC RPG - this is definitely one of the best RPGs that has ever been made.

author: Hi Players
review: I'm not one for single-player games but the more I played Red Dead the more it made me want to keep playing. There is so much to it with very little negatives in my personal opinion; * The story is amazing, the characters introduced all feel like they give their all so you as the player gain a full understanding of them and their story. * You're alright boah.* The world looks amazing, even on lower graphics, the map size is incredible too!* Interactions take place everywhere, each one is creative and makes the world feel more alive and immersive. * The easter eggs are pretty good, I would ask for more interactions with them but other aspects of the game make up for this, such as the amount of easter eggs. * The gameplay was never jittery and never stuttered for me apart from once or twice in Saint Denis, but I feel this is to be expected (especially when I was playing on near high graphics). The only downside I'm aware of is the multiplayer, now I haven't played much multiplayer but when I did play I experienced some lag, constant player harassment (no-one wanting to play friendly, such as GTA 5), lack of stuff to do. It is more suited towards those roleplay servers in my opinion rather than to play for fun, especially since you have to grind to do missions etc.

author: [ME] charming clown
review: 10/10: A Beautiful game, with a rich story to tell.This game asks you to take it slow, to enjoy the scenery and to take the world in. If you are averse to slow animations, immersive interactions and a general slow pace this isn't for you. If you are willing to give it a real shot, to take the time the game asks of you. You'll find something special.Red Dead Redemption 2, is by far Rockstars strongest narrative game.Missions should be viewed as interactive movie scenes as it's less about finding unique solutions to the problem presented and more going through the motion. This might not be to everyone's liking but it's how the story missions are structured. The Open World, is where player freedom comes in.The level of immersion you get from the writing, to the world and how you interact with that world, leaves other Open World games lacking in so many ways. Just the simple act of being able to "Greet" or "Antagonize" every NPC, seems like such a minor thing but it adds so much to the experience.The amount of talent Rockstar can find for the voice cast and then make use of with their incredible script and direction, is awe inspiring.I beat it on the PS4 after 140 hours of play with 89% completion.Am currently going through it again on PC, sitting at 121 hours of play with 64% completion.This time I intend to leave the game once I see that 100% after about 500 hours of play.If you're truly not willing to buy the game full price but do have an interest, then I encourage you to grab it during any sale event. You will not be disappointed.Performance is smooth though the amount of frames I get isn't in the hundreds. I get frames ranging from the low 40 to the high 60. Settings are a mix of mids & ultra.Even then, the game world and characters look beautiful.So if you're willing to swallow your pride and lower some setting here and there to get that stable frame rate, you'll have a grand time playing this.RIG:GTX 1080ti,I7-7700K 4.20GHz,32GB Ram,2560 x 1440p, 144hz monitor

author: U.R.S.S.O
review: If i could give a "mixed" review for this game, i would. Since i can't, i'll just go with a positive one since i feel it wasn't wasted money. To the review:The goodThe best of this game you probably heard already. The story is excellent, the graphics are beautiful, music is incredible, acting is top-notch, there's loads of good content, shrinking horse b... so lets proceedThe badThe "cream" of this game is of the best quality, but unfortunately the same can't be said for the pie, AKA its game design. The gameplay mechanics feels like a mess of ideas, as if the developers couldn't decide where they wanted to go with it. There's a constant inconsistency that often left me confused as for what was expected of me, and what i could or not do. To give some examples: -I completed a side-quest where at the end i was allowed choose between capturing some escaped criminals for the bounty or leave them be. Right after, i left to do a bounty mission that gave me a scene where i just felt like leaving the guy be, except this time i wasn't allowed to (i even tried walking away, but only got a "mission failed" screen and was forced to restart).-When doing crimes you'll often get recognized unless you wear full face mask and use clothes nobody in the region saw you in (sometimes even that isn't enough). Then there's a mission where you use a "disguise" that's just a pipe and a different hat (in a town where you were constantly frequenting) and apparently that does the job of hiding your identity just fine.And thats not even going into the clunky controls that made me choke an innocent bystander woman when all i wanted to do was hop on my horse, that stopped me from aiming my gun when i was being rained with bullets, or the terrible key mapping and dozens of different menus that could have very well been simplified, and why is it fine for random guys to beat me up in front of an officer but when i reciprocate its police gunfight time? There's plenty of other annoying moments born from the game's poor design choices, but lets proceed...The uglyFor starters, the Rockstar Launcher DRM. It requires you to connect to the servers every time you play the game after turning on the pc, needless to say how inconvenient that can be. Then there is to confusing graphical settings. Although its possible to run the game above the console quality with a GTX 1070, it takes a LOT of tweaking and research, with some settings needing to be on ultra (since any lower will look ugly af) while others having to be medium/low (on the risk of eating your fps for basically no visual gain).And then there were the crashes. Towards the end of the game, the game kept crashing randomly in the middle of missions for no apparent reason. All i could do was meddle around with some stuff, pray it doesn't crash on critical moments, then meddle around some stuff again when it finally did.The loading screens, oh god the loading screens, and why i can't pick the save that i want when i start the game?Veredict: There's definitely things to enjoy in this game that you'll be hard pressed to find in other games, but be prepared to deal with a set of annoyances.

author: Ty
review: *This a review about the campaign only* - Okay firstly, i have played this game previously on PS4 (hence my low steam hours), and i have played through the campaign twice but am now on my PC hoping to get to that 100% completion. I know i'm late to the review party, but the COVID isolation is getting to me and i wanted to make this my first ever steam review. So to my unsolicited review of possibly my favourite game of all time. (potential bias ahead) I have to say to anyone unsure of whether to play this game or not, this is easily one of the best pieces of [shall we say] "visual media" that i have ever experienced. Yes the game is immaculately made with some of the best graphics we have seen in gaming, i'm not really sure that is up for the debate, perhaps it is but i'm here to mostly talk about the story as I honestly believe it to be the games best quality. Those that have played the game through to its conclusion will probably understand what i am about to say, but there are some people I know who traded the game in before even finishing the middle chapters! I know, the nerve of these people... I have heard personally from both friends and people online that they found the game slow and boring, at least to start. I reject this completely as i'm sure many others do. Is the beginning of the game slow? Sure, i can see how it is viewed this way. But boring? um, no, i think you are boring lol. If you have been looking to play this game and have heard about the "hike" it takes to complete, i implore you to ignore this viewpoint. This game has some incredible storytelling and the rewards for sticking out the world and character building from the early sequences of the game (and of course throughout) are unrivalled in my opinion. Not only is this a beautifully made game, it is so well written and incredibly deep and heartfelt in many instances. This is a game full of exploration, not only of the beautiful world on display, but the characters too. There are several character studies on display and its so well done that you don't even realise the exploration of the human condition from the start of the game and through to the end. Themes such as family, trust, brotherhood, love, loss and everything in-between are all explored in GREAT detail. Anything from the main characters, to the NPC's are all so well thought out and planned that the simulated world you play in feels real. You will find yourself lost in this world and in the narrative served to you on a plate of gold if you just give it the time it deserves. Play this game, Boah! You will not regret it. Love,T x

author: JIT
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of Rockstar’s best games ever.It vastly improves upon the first game,and has the quality you expect from a Rockstar game and AAA games in general.Red Dead 2’s greatest strengths is it's story and voice acting,along with the very strong world that always feels alive,bustling and immersive.This is complemented by it's deep and solid gameplay,along with a vast amount of customization in the game that you can use to make your playthrough unique.This game is absolutely beautiful,with some of the best graphics I’ve seen yet in any video game.The tradeoff is that RDR2 can be pretty taxing on your system.On my system,I ran the game at 1080p with a mix of Medium-High settings,I got 55-60 FPS in general and 40-45 FPS in densed area(mostly in towns).Seeing as I played through the game on my PS4 Slim at 30 FPS,I was happy about this with my four year old rig.Despite early setbacks for PC version of this game,it is worth every penny.Rockstar created such a vast,deep,and beautiful game that is dripping with love and passion.It's been worth the 90+ hours I spent in the world so far.I don’t know where Rockstar is going to take Red Dead now,but I’m excited to see!My Specs: i5 4670,16GB RAM(DDR3),GTX 1070(Driver Ver. 442.59),Win 10 Pro 64 Bit(Ver. 1909)I insist...I INSIST that you must try it...atleast for singleplayer.

author: كлaうсиもн  Гえнaてpk
review: This review is going to be my personal take on the game and in this review .I am going to write about Graphics ,Open-World ,Gameplay ,Story and last of all Online.GRAPHICSThe visual fidelity of the game is breathtaking and also there are quite nice subtle effects as some body parts glowing red when sunlight falls on it .I don’t really want to write something long to graphics part because you can easily Google the game’s name and figure it out.STORYThe story of this game is well and truly one of the most emotional game i have ever seen, the voice acting is impeccable but i think they overrate it in forums and Reddit .Other than loving Arthur and hating Micah i didn’t feel any connection with characters, maybe through 6th chapter a little.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is fairly simple and fun .It is essentially a shooter as you gun down a large number of enemies in majority of the missions. There is a deadeye system which basically slows time (in story mod in online there are ability cards you can combine with deadeye) and you can unlock advanced forms of it in later game .Also there is a cover system which works exactly like GTA V’s but in Red Dead Redemption 2 some of the places you can cover are penetrable so you should choose your cover wisely .The horse AI in this game is awful, if you’re new to the game you can’t use jungle or mountain i literally mean you can’t you will end up falling constantly that you will immediately close the game .And one of the most important gameplay feature is camps ,sometimes you can just stay in the camp talk to all the gang members, listen their conversations, their thoughts and the stories they had to share. There'll be times when the gang will be celebrating on some occasions and sometimes there will be campfire songs that will feel cosy.OPEN WORLDRed Dead’s open world is far best open world i have ever been part of. It is a dynamic world teeming with life in every nook and cranny. From livestock towns to marshy swamps to hustling and bustling metropolis to snow-clad mountains to barren desolate deserts the game presents you with amazing and varied environments and vistas to explore. The seamless blending of all these diverse locations as you traverse through the sprawling open world is truly impressive. There are no annoying loading screens which makes it all the more immersive.ONLINEAs the old saying goes everything good has a bad side and in Red Dead Redemption 2 that bad side is online .In online servers there will be lots of server related bugs even most of the time you will get kicked .And about hackers there aren’t that much Modder like there was in GTA V but Rockstar never bans the real cheaters they only care about their premium currency which is gold .If there was a cheater in your lobby with god mode and teleporting you to wherever he/she wants Rockstar probably won’t do anything but if a cheater spawns treasure chest in front of you and if you take them you will probably get banned ,and Modder will roam free because they don’t detect cheats they just look to your gold history and if it seems suspicious they ban you like they did to me .But there is also good sides of online like community ,it makes easier you to make friends and if you like grinding you can still have fun just a little advise if you see a Modder just leave the lobby immediately.

author: Jhon_Dafish
review: If someone held a gun to my head and told me to pick a single game to play for the rest of my life, my choice is clear. I hate Rockstar as a company, mostly from their constant gouging of online components, namely milking GTAV and it's player base for every penny, and just completely forgetting about RDO's existence. But RDR2's story is an absolute masterpiece. I was originally reluctant to purchase it at launch in 2018, after seeing how broken portions of it were. However not too long after it went on sale for a slight discount on the Playstation Store for Black Friday I decided it was time to give it a try. I had no idea what I was getting into. Do yourself a favor and play this as blind as possible. If I had the chance to wipe the memory to play it blind again, I would.It's easily one of the best looking games on PC so far. I don't even know how to begin describing it. Clouds randomly generate in the sky, if you're on a mountaintop looking over the map you can see the shadows cast by them. All the weather effects are dynamic, it'll begin to fog after a heavy rain, roads become muddy, your clothes soak water, you can chase storm clouds across the map, snow has a haze, light shimmers and creates god rays through trees and fog, it just looks so damn incredible. The music is okay. The ambient overworld tracks could have definitely used some work because they just play randomly and some are quite repetitive. The mission specific songs are great, but the vocalized OST is where it really shines. All of them are pretty good on their own, like "That's the Way It Is" by Daniel Lanois. Listening to it without playing the game you think it's just a sad song, but after playing the game up to the point where the song is played you realize the true meaning of it. To me, that's the kind of music that makes a game so great. The kind that can make you feel genuine emotions while listening to it. If you spoil it for yourself by looking it up you're missing out. Seriously, don't look at the comments section of that song if you intend to play this game and enjoy it.Without going into specifics about the story, it's a prequel to Red Dead Redemption, and not a sequel as the name would suggest. You play as Arthur Morgan, right hand man to Dutch Van Der Linde in the Van Der Linde gang. It's up to you to help other members of the gang through thick and thin as you run from the Pinkerton detective agency after a botched robbery in the town of Blackwater. After chapter 1 the game world opens up almost completely, save for the entire area from the first game, minus Mexico, and the entire map is MASSIVE. How big is it? If you go from Strawberry to Van Horn, a distance of about half the map, it takes up to 10-15 real time minutes at full speed on your horse. The missing area you can't get to for the first portion of the game is only about a third of the total map size. Every inch of the map is beautifully detailed, from flora-rich forests and hillsides, to plains, industrious cities, and even snowy mountains. Yet for as big as it is, it's never empty. There's always something to hunt,a fish to catch, herbs to gather, strangers to meet, goons to kill, things to steal, it's almost endless. Everything is finely detailed, and you can even fully customize your weapons this time around, from changing the wood type and color to the color of individual metal parts and even engravings and even still the color of the engravings.Even at full price, you'll get your money's worth. I only just completed the entire game for the second time since PS4 and look how many hours I have. You wont find another game this good in longevity and writing for quite some.

author: Kenpachi
review: So after 110 hours on this game and completing all the 6 Chapters+2 Epilogue(74 % overall) in single player mode its a *Masterpiece Beyond Comprehension*. Perhaps the greatest video game I have played. A game everyone should play. Masterful storytelling this game has one of the best stories ever made, Oscar worthy voice acting, a soundtrack you could listen to over and over, an open world that feels alive but wants you dead, characters you wish you could confide in and cuddle, graphics that have truly set the bar for open world games and an experience you will never forget like never. Once again Rockstar games manage to out do themselves. You can easily sink 100's of hours in this huge experience exploring the vast beautiful world of the west in early 1900's. There's so much to do & that's just the single player experience, when you've finished that, there's 'Red Dead Online'! A huge open world with friends and foes alike! A true gem! I truly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys real cinematic games and without hesitation, just buy it. Its worth every penny.I give this game 10/10.

author: JSun
review: (I got this as a gift)I really enjoy this game. So far, I am done with the story and there is still more content and stuff to do. I always feel occupied, and when I'm not, I just take in the serene views of the world. It feels like real life, and most everything in the game I like. there are a few problems, and I will try to detail them.Most of the combat in this game is the same. Shoot, dead-eye and then the combat is over. It gets very repetitive, and sometimes you with the story explored more of the physics and possibilities of the combat. however, every combat mission (and there are a lot) mostly focus on the cool gun bang bang action and maybe some of the hand to hand combat. There have been some complaints about the mission layout, and how it is the same every mission, and basically the same as GTA. I have never played a GTA game, so I can't comment on that, but later on in the story, the missions do start to blend together and feel the same. However, that complaint is very minor, and only in the last chapters do you start to feel that sense, and it really isn't a large presence in your mind. Maybe if I played more rockstar games I might have felt it more, but I really didn't feel it. while we are on the subject of the missions and story, it is insane how good it is. Every gang member in the gang feels real and has real feelings, at least that is what I thought. Along with that, the mini-games and hunting, as well as the side quests feel really smooth and well thought out. I spent a lot of my hour time just looking for hunt and playing poker and five-finger fillet. Also, there are plenty of treasure maps and puzzles to solve for more money. And, if you feel like more action, you can go Rambo on all the plebs and go on a killing spree. Back to the story. The story is amazing, as I would sink hours just playing missions and making predictions in my head. The plot twists always felt fresh, and the story never draws any punches. I have heard some complaints that the story is to long, and that is should have ended at one of the chapters. I think this is a complete false. the story could have gone on for at least ten more hours, and I would still love it and play it more, awaiting my next move. But, like I said, this is my first rockstar game, and if I played more games by them then I might have thought differently. Lets talk about the graphics for a moment. I have a pretty low end GPU, and I still would waste days of in-game time just taking in a horses nose and the landscape. There are veins on the horse, and they behave like I would think a real horse would. I have also heard complaints that there are so many unnecessary details, but I think that it really helps build the world. There are a few bugs in the graphics and the cutscenes, like people not saying their lines, and people bugging out. These moments aren't very frequent, and they in no way break the game. I have also experienced crashes and some weird connection issues and error messages. This, for me, is the most annoying part of the game. I just want to play, and I do with they fixed more of these. The map in Red Dead is HUGE. It is filled with minute stranger details, and little details that you would miss on first glance that make the world seem so much more alive. I do feel like there is a little too much of this, however, and it is more manageable in the south. I feel like the cowboy era would be more lonely, not filled with people in the streets. you go into a discreet part of the world, just to envelope the sounds and graphics (which are amazing) only to find that some waiter is there, and wants you to help him find his girlfriend, or free him from a bear trap, or give him medicine, is it too much to ask for some alone time? This is definitely nit-picking, but I do with I could just trot with my horse with no one around. The cities (Saint Denis in particular) are stunning. There are little quirks, like a salesman trying to sell an article about white supremacy, that you would never find in a modern era setting, but also barbers, and street trolleys. There is something so familiar about stepping into a city, but there are also minute details that someone would miss. I would give this a 9.5/10. The story is something to remember, but I do wish there were less bugs.

author: Dr. 8 Ball
review: Best game I have ever played. Seriously, no game I have ever played has come remotely close to this. RDR2 is in a league of its own. The amount of detail and heart that went into this development of this game must've been unfathomable. If you get this game, do all the white missions first so that you get to experience those are they are a big part of this games experience, as those as temporary missions/side quests that can disappear if you do not initiate the event within a certain time frame. The yellow missions are the main story and stay on the map till completed. Don't rush through the game, there's so much to do that you'd end up enjoying it more if you take your time and do the activities the world has to offer.I love everything about this game. Trying to pinpoint bad things is this game is genuinely hard. The voice acting is next level, and the animations are really refined as well. I will never get bored of putting a sawed off double barrel shotgun underneath the chin of a rowdy civilian or O'Driscoll and blowing their head clean off their shoulders. It never gets old.Performance wise I'm not having any issues. Some aspects of the controls and menus definitely show that this game is a console port.  I've had 1 crash the whole time I've played this game. Pushing 60fps at medium settings on a Gtx 980, i7 6700 @4.0Ghz, 16gb ddr4. Also using an xbox controller, game was kinda designed for consoles initially.10/10. Perfection is impossible to reach but RDR2 flirts with that fine line and comes closer to it than any other title ever released imo.

author: loudipierro
review: UPDATED REVIEW: I initially did not recommend this game (see my original review below).  However, in the last two weeks I have not had any additional problems logging in to the R* servers and I have been able to play the game for about an additional 18 hours.  I have to admit - this game is spectacularly good.  I am completely and totally addicted to this thing.  Be warned, however, that it requires a tremendous amount of PC power to run this game.  I would imagine it is one of the most demanding games currently on the market in terms of hardware.  I am running an i7-9700k overclocked to 4.9 GHz and an RTX-2080 on a 1440p ultrawide and even at medium graphics settings I am only averaging about 60-80 fps!  I've been able to max every other game I've played so far on my system, and most run at 100+ fps.  But my god this game looks incredible even at medium settings!ORIGINAL REVIEW:I've only played this game for about 8 hours so far and it seems like a great game, the attention to detail is quite extraordinary.Unfortunately I cannot recommend that anyone spend $60 on this game.  Particularly if you are like me....a man in his 30s who has kids and has VERY LIMITED TIME TO PLAY.  When I have some free time to play, I NEED TO BE ABLE TO.  Otherwise its a complete waste of money for me.  Hence is the case here.  I have not been able to log onto Rockstar's ridiculous server or social club or whatever the ♥♥♥♥ it is they call it.  Frankly I don't care.  I paid $60 so I could play a SINGLE PLAYER game in the very limited free time that I have.  I'm moving onto another game.  I should be getting my money back for this, and if I had the time I would probably start making phone calls until somebody gave me my money back.  But I don't have the time to bother.

author: KRAKEN
review: So far, so fun. Story is captivating and gameplay can be engrossing, in a good way. Online mode is a blast and I am having more fun in this than even in GTA Online.My only gripe is that the graphics options are a mess; I have 2GB VRAM but the game defaulted to using slightly more than 2GB. Rockstar (for some reason) enabled a lock on changing graphics settings if the resulting VRAM usage is over capacity -- even if the change was to LOWER the settings after it started out too high!PROTIP, if you have this issue and desperately need to get your settings down to play (make sure you understand what you're doing before you attempt): Go to your save folder (in my case, Documents/Rockstar Games/Read Dead Redemption 2/Settings) and edit "system.xml" in Notepad. Change the settings here by changing values from "High" to "Low", etc. Some settings do not have "Low" options, such as the one relating to fur.

author: [FU]jepperkake
review: Utterly surprised by how good this game is. I played a good guy, the story was great. It's slow as ♥♥♥♥, so that takes some getting used to, but this is a proper RPG. Teeps:Read your journal from time to time, it gives light to a lot of backstory.Blow the ♥♥♥♥ out of legendary animals, they can't get ruined pelts.Grab an Arabian horse right after the intro (end of snowscape.)Use your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bandanna when committing crimes.Change your outfit to not be recognized after doing said crimes.Crime doesn't pay, treasure hunting does.Embrace the slowness of the game. I assume about 2 hours of my in game time has been animations from picking up flowers. Learn to love that ♥♥♥♥.Press B to eat cooked food, which makes out your cores a lot faster than the trashy biscuits you have at your disposal in the inventory wheel.And remember to have fun with the game! Lasso the last bad guy in an area and set him free on the other side of the map. It's great! Drag a guy behind your horse and feed him to the wolves! Tie people up and throw them in pig pens, horrible sounds to endure. You can do whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you please with most "bad guys", so play an evil kind person for the most out of the game :DAnd remember to turn off the in-game sound and blast thrash metal when committing heinous acts :D

author: MrGreen
review: I thought I'd never say this but RDR2 is a outstanding game with really good characters and good storylines, the villain was the first one I ever wanted to punch in the face at the end.I think RDR2 did a outstanding job with the Story telling, Graphic design, Combat details, Characters and their personalities. Music, and many many other things I don't want to spoil.I feel like this game deserves a lot of attention, if anyone out there who doesn't like the Western genre but wants to try this game you should. It has a good story to it and You'd get tied to it very easily. You'd most likely like other stuff besides western to being a western freak like me. But then again I already liked western to begin with.This was such a amazing game from PS4 to PC.I feel like Online deserves more attention to anti-cheat though, cheaters mainly ruin almost everything you plan to do for your game. But then again ROCKSTAR just cares about people buying the in game purchases for the online. So if you want this game for the online I won't recommend it. But the story mode is wayy better.

author: Dont Panic My Frags R Organic
review: First of all, before reading what is below, I would like to say that this game if fantastically fun. That being said there are some serious concerns as far as the online play goes. The reason why I would not recommend this is explained below.The multiplayer was extremely fun at first, but within the past week it has gone very downhill. Almost every server that I have been on has had someone cheating. Whether it was just blatant trolling like for instance, we had someone spawning the geysers under us sending us sky high, or the classic pulling everyone to the railroad tracks where we can't move and then having a train run us over. The thing that really gets me though, are the people who are invincible, and just spawn themselves in front of you while you're doing a trader run or moonshine run, and there is nothing you can do about it. You cannot kill these people, and they're often with a group of people they're likely boosting. The multiplayer is almost unplayable right now as far as money making goes outside of the missions. The concept is great, but their player management and response times for reports have to be unbelievably slow. To top things off, for whatever reason, they keep reports confidential and you will never know if the person you reported was caught or not. This leaves the players with no real idea of what happens after a report. There is no way to track how long it took, whether or not action was taken, etc etc. TLDR the multiplayer is abysmal with the amount of cheaters there are at the moment. Do not recommend playing online.

review: This game is fantastic if u like a relaxing open world game! Iv'e mainly played Online with both alone and with friends ofc. The game is demanding as hell considering i play at 4K but ofc the grapichs are thereafter 2. Just chillin around the plains studying the view and grapichs with ur rifle hunting for the perfect animal is relaxing. No stress in this game as i actually can take a break from reality and live in the moment.  And vs GTAV where griefers have Opressor/Hydra ++ harassing u 24/7 this is not a problem in RDR2O. Here u have an enormous world AND horses + u cant rly see eachother on the map unless u are close to eachother.Would i recommend it?  Ofcourse, if u are into this type of western open world game. Relaxing envirement, no stress and just hunting, collecting and surviving. + multiplayer. There is 1 thing that holds this game back and that is the bugs/Crashes. Since its a new release on PC i can understand there is still fixes in progress and i kinda forgive em for that BUT they have to do something asap about it.

author: SnarinAaron
review: I bought the game about 6 days ago at the time of this review, so my play time should mostly vouch for the quality of this game and the potential I see in it. HOWEVER, if you're buying this for a polished online experience, don't waste your money.R* has proven since the online's release over a year ago (on console) that they clearly don't care about the online experience in this game as much as they care about whatever other "projects" they are working on (GTA VII). For instance, I bought this game along with two other friends, and we enjoy it a lot when it works. With that said, we all consistently receive an error message saying that an issue on R* servers has caused us to disconnect from online. This wouldn't be a big deal if it didn't happen almost every 30 minutes (not exaggerating).You can basically ignore all of the reviews saying that the game won't run or it's got terrible optimization; if you have a decent PC and you think you can run it, you probably can. I've had NO issues with crashes overall (maybe 1-2 instances); The REAL ISSUES lie in R* online servers.The moments when you're able to stay in game long enough to experience the content that RDO offers (or lack thereof), you'll enjoy it and want more. Unfortunately, there's also a rather severe lack of content on the online side of the game, but I'm hoping that that may soon change.Overall, singleplayer is fantastic, don't worry about it. You'll enjoy it.Multiplayer is great when it works, but those times seem to be few and far between. There's a lack of content, and even the content that's there seems almost inaccessible because of R* dismissive nature in regards to the Red Dead Online servers and bugs that are present.I really hope this game gets tuned up and polished to the potential that it could be, because I obviously enjoy it and it's a fantastic game, as well as an excellent successor to the original Red Dead Redemption. All we need to make that happen is Rockstar's support and a little bit of time.

The graphics and world building are incredible. Not completely sold on the controls though. It feels as if functionality is sometimes sacrificed for realism.Edit 2: Once the game starts to open up, be prepared to lose many hours to it. I no longer cautiously recommend this game. It's a must buy if you enjoy open world games.

author: Blackburn
review: "More and More Civilization" Arthur Morgan- What is a real game? - After 23h play the game just to run to explore the unspoiled land, overwhelmed by the beautiful scenery of the snowy mountains when starting as a game, this is not a game this is real life.- The story is set in 1899 in a fictionalized representation of the Western, Midwestern and Southern United States and follows outlaw Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van der Linde gang. Arthur must deal with the decline of the Wild West whilst attempting to survive against government forces, rival gangs, and other adversaries. The story also follows fellow gang member John Marston, the protagonist of Red Dead Redemption.- The graphics in the game are beautiful, the details are meticulously recreated.  Extremely impressive weather effects you will be impressed when there is a storm coming.- The game system is very good, the tempo can be pushed up very suddenly when you are exploring the beautiful scenery of the game and chased mercilessly by a group of bounty hunters.  You will be able to make a true western gun to do what you want, creating a world without law.- Heist Mission...........(GTA5).- One of the best open world games I've ever played.  After more than a year of waiting, we hope to have a pc version from PS4 and Xbox.  Waiting for a graphical upgrade version. - This game is heavy on graphics, if you do not have a powerful enough PC then do not buy it.  You need 1 VGA strong enough to experience the charm and wild beauty of the Western, Midwestern and Southern United State.- Score 10/10 Masterpiece!
